Police Force receives an additional Exchequer grant.
The Royal Ulster Constabulary (RUC) operates under the direction of a
chief constable who is responsible, through a police authority, to Northern
Ireland’s Minister of Home Affairs.
The RUC, which has a strength of some 4,000, undertakes the policing
of the whole of Northern Ireland, its cost being borne by the Northern
Ireland Exchequer. The police authority, which consists of a chairman, a
vice-chairman and between 14 and 20 other members appointed by the Gover¬
nor of Northern Ireland, has the same powers and duties as the police author¬
ities in Great Britain.
The chief constable has under his command a deputy chief constable and
assistant chief constables. The area is divided into divisions under chief
superintendents and superintendents who have under their command in¬
spectors, sergeants and constables. Conditions of service and pay follow closely
on the lines of the police service in Great Britain, and the general duties
pertaining to the various ranks are much the same.
The RUC is assisted in its normal police duties by a reserve of special
constables who are paid a small ‘bounty’ for their services. While on duty,
members of the reserve have the same powers, privileges and duties as (by
the law for the time being in force) may be exercised by, or are conferred
upon, a member of the RUC.
4 DEFENCE
Europe
Far East
Dependencies
The United
Nations
POLICY
Britain’s basic security depends on the strength of the North Atlantic Alliance,
and it is to the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) that by far the
greater part of Britain’s military forces is committed. Britain makes a major
contribution to the full range of deterrent capabilities, both conventional and
nuclear, required by the present NATO strategy of flexible response. At the
same time the British Government supports the Alliance’s efforts to engage the
Soviet Union and its allies in discussions which could lead to a real and lasting
relaxation of tensions between East and West, and hopes that progress in
negotiations on such questions as Berlin could make improvements possible
over a wider field in Europe.
Within NATO Britain has played a leading part in the efforts of the European
members of the Alliance to take a fuller and more effective share of the common
defence burden: in a European Defence Improvement Programme Britain
and nine other of the European NATO countries have adopted measures to
improve the Alliance’s conventional capabilities. Currently engaged in a num¬
ber of co-operative equipment projects with European allies (see p. 119),
Britain is ready to explore those possibilities of defence collaboration which
would contribute to the cohesion and effectiveness of the European defence
effort.
At the same time it is recognised that British interests and responsibilities
are not confined to the NATO area, and that Britain has a shared interest in
the stability of such areas as the Far East and Gulf. Britain is therefore willing
to play, on a scale appropriate to national resources, a part in countering threats
to stability outside Europe. Britain is a member of the Central Treaty Organisa¬
tion (CENTO) and the South-East Asia Treaty Organisation (SEATO). In
South-east Asia, Britain contributes, with Australia, New Zealand, Malaysia
and Singapore, to the Five-Power defence arrangements in Malaysia and
Singapore; this involves the continuing deployment of British forces in this
area. In the Gulf, Britain is willing to help to maintain stability in the area
by the loan of British personnel to serve with local forces, and by training and
liaison visits from units of all three services.
Britain is also responsible for the defence and internal security of its re¬
maining dependencies. Recently British troops have operated within the United
Kingdom in aid of civil authorities, to halt communal disturbances. In general,
Britain’s armed forces assist civil communities at home and abroad, particularly
in emergency and development tasks.
Britain supports the peacekeeping and other efforts of the United Nations
and other international authorities working to eliminate the sources of tension
and conflict between nations and to promote arms control and disarmament.
Having played a leading part in the negotiations for the 1963 Partial Nuclear
Test Ban Treaty, the 1968 Non-Proliferation Treaty, and a constructive
no
Service
Organisations
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
role in the negotiation of the 1971 Sea-Bed Treaty, Britain has proposed a
draft convention for the prohibition of biological methods of warfare.
Information about defence policy and the armed forces is provided by the
Government in an annual Statement on the Defence Estimates (Cmnd. 4592
in 1971) usually published in February. ^
The Government is concerned to keep defence costs within the country’s
resources, and since 1965 there have been substantial reductions in the annual
defence estimates as calculated at constant prices. The defence budget for
!97:1-72 totalled £2,545 million, which represents about 5-5 per cent of the
gross national product. Projections of expected defence expenditure for the
next five years are published each December (Cmnd. 4518 in i97°): a rise by
an average of O'l per cent between I970-71 an<^ I974—75 planned.
PLANNING AND CONTROL
Supreme responsibility for national defence rests with the Prime Minister and
the Cabinet, who are responsible to Parliament. Defence problems and their
implications for foreign and economic policy are dealt with on the Cabinet s
behalf by the Committee on Defence and Oversea Policy, under the chair¬
manship of the Prime Minister.
The formulation of defence policy is the responsibility of the Secretary of
State for Defence. In recent years the emphasis in defence organisation has
been on a greater degree of Service co-ordination, and on overall functional
planning of the defence effort as a whole. Since the unified Ministry of Defence
was created in 1964, the central organisation of defence has been regularly
reviewed and a series of changes made to increase efficiency and economy.
The former two Ministers of Defence (for administration and equipment
respectively) were replaced during 197° a s^n§^e Minister of State for
Defence who is responsible for the Armed Forces and in 1971 a Minister of
Defence Procurement (see p. 5°) was appointed. The two ministers together
with the three Parliamentary Under-Secretaries of State for the Navy, Army
and Air Force respectively, the Chief of the Defence Staff, the three Service
Chiefs of Staff, the Chief Scientific Adviser, and the Permanent Under¬
secretary of State for Defence, sit on the Defence Council, which deals with
major defence policy under the chairmanship of the Secretary of State. The
Chiefs of Staff Committee, comprising the Chief of the Defence Staff as chair¬
man and the Chiefs of Staff of the three Services, is responsible for giving pro¬
fessional advice on strategy and operations, and on the military implications
of defence policy. The day-to-day management of the three Services is the
responsibility of the Admiralty, Army and Air Force Boards of the Defence
Council.
The Royal Navy has four main arms. These are: the Naval General Service,
which mans and maintains the surface fleet; the Fleet Air Arm; the Sub¬
marine Service; and the Royal Marines, who provide a seaborne and airborne
land striking-force. # . .
The Army is organised into some 3° arins and services which include
the Household Cavalry, the Royal Armoured Corps, the Royal Regiment of
Artillery, the Corps of Royal Engineers, the Royal Corps of Signals, the five
regiments of Foot Guards, the Infantry of the Line (grouped into divisions),
the Army Air Corps, the Royal Corps of Transport, the Royal Army Medical
Corps, the Royal Army Ordnance Corps and the Royal Electrical and Mechan¬
ical Engineers.

The Royal Air Force is organised in commands, on a functional basis at
home and on a geographical basis overseas.
The three women’s services, the Women’s Royal Naval Service (WRNS), the
Women’s Royal Army Corps (WRAC) and the Women’s Royal Air Force
(WRAF), are integral parts of the Navy, Army and Air Force respectively.
Servicewomen serve alongside servicemen in Britain and overseas. Nursing
services are provided by Queen Alexandra s Royal Naval Nursing Service,
Queen Alexandra’s Royal Army Nursing Corps and Princess Mary’s Royal
Air Force Nursing Service.
The home and overseas commands of the Services are set out below.
Under a phased programme shore commands have been reorganised under a
single Commander-in-Chief, Naval Home Command, Portsmouth, with sub¬
ordinate Area Flag Officers at Plymouth, Chatham and Rosyth. Sea command
has been reorganised to bring under a single major operational commander, the
Commander-in-Chief Western Fleet, an area comprising the North Sea, the
North and South Atlantic Oceans, the Mediterranean and part of the Pacific
Ocean. British naval forces in the North Atlantic and Mediterranean are ear¬
marked for assignment to the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO).
Naval forces in the Far East come under the Commander, Far East Fleet (see
P- II5)-
Army Strategic Command, Northern Command, Southern Command,
Western Command and two Independent Districts (HQ Northern Ireland
and HQ Scotland). During 1972 the four major commands will be replaced by
a single command, United Kingdom Land Forces. The overseas commands
are: British Army of the Rhine (BAOR); Far East Land Forces; Near East
Land Forces; Land Forces Hong Kong; and British Troops Malta and
Gibraltar.
Strike Command, which has a number of subordinate Groups taking the
place of the former Bomber, Fighter and Coastal Commands; Air Support
Command, Training and Maintenance Commands. Overseas commands are
Royal Air Force Germany; Near East Air Force; and Far East Air Force.
After 1971 British forces in the Far East will, along with the forces of Australia
and New Zealand, be under the operational control of an integrated command
in Singapore.
Britain’s armed forces consist of regular Service personnel. Entrants to the
non-commissioned ranks of the three Services are given basic training, and
further training is given during the course of their careers. Young service¬
men have the opportunity to read for the General Certificate of Education
‘O’ level (see p. 154). Trade and technical training, though primarily designed
for Service purposes, leads in many cases to nationally recognised qualifica¬
tions; completion of many Service trade or technical courses followed by
experience is recognised by trade unions as a qualification for membership
by men who have left the Services.
Commissions may be granted for short, medium or long terms. Promotion
from the non-commissioned ranks is possible in all three Services. In the
Royal Navy, the largest entry is through cadetships in the Britannia Royal
112
Higher Defence
Training
RESERVE AND

FORCES
Royal Navy
Army
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Naval College, Dartmouth; in the Army through cadetships in the Royal
Military Academy Sandhurst. This is followed by specialist training which
may include degree courses. In the RAF entry is through cadetships in the
RAF College, Cranwell, or civilian universities. There is also a scheme in all
three Services for the award of University Cadetships, which enable young
men to take a degree before commencing their Service training. There are
also schemes for the entry of graduates and other qualified specialists.
All three Services provide training facilities for the armed forces of Common¬
wealth and foreign nations.
Selected officers of all three Services who have had previous staff training or
have been to the Royal Naval Staff College, Greenwich (London), the Army
Staff College at Camberley (Surrey), or the Royal Air Force Staff College
at Bracknell (Berkshire) go to the National Defence College (formerly the
Joint Services Staff College) at Chesham (Buckinghamshire). Here, in an
intensive and broad-based programme of courses, particular attention is paid
to the inter-Service aspect of staff work. Specially selected and more senior
officers from the Services, the Civil Service, and from the Commonwealth, the
United States, and allied European countries attend the Royal College of
Defence Studies (formerly the Imperial Defence College) in London. Con¬
siderable training is done through joint-Service and inter-allied exercises, on
which increasing emphasis is placed.
In the defence estimates for 1971-72 £34 million is allocated to reserve and
auxiliary forces. Apart from their essential military role, these are considered
to form an important link between the Services and the civil community.
The Regular Reserve consists of various categories of former full-time officers
and ratings liable to recall in emergency. The Volunteer Reserves comprise
the Royal Naval Reserve (with its associated women’s reserve) and the Royal
Marines Reserve; they carry out regular part-time training and man a number
of operational minesweepers.
The Royal Naval Auxiliary Service, a civilian organisation composed of
men and women volunteers, is responsible in time of war for minewatching
duties around the coast and the waterways, and other duties.
Men who have completed the Colour portion of their service with the Regular
Army are retained on the Regular Army Reserve to complete a total engage¬
ment of seven or 12 years, according to their initial commitment; they are
liable to recall to the Colours. Thereafter they are transferred to the Long
Term Reserve (LTR) where they remain until the age of 45 and are liable to
recall in an emergency. The Army General Reserve consists of certain former
National Service specialists.
The Territorial and Army Volunteer Reserve (T & AVR) consists of
independent and sponsored units. Independent units are raised on a terri¬
torial basis and each is based on one or more training centres. Sponsored
units consist of specialists and have to be recruited on a nation-wide basis.
These units are divided, for administration purposes, into Group A, which
has a liability for call-out when warlike operations are in preparation or in
progress; and Group B, which consists of miscellaneous units (for example,
University Officer Training Corps) with various liabilities. The establishment
of the T & AVR has been increased to provide an uncommitted reserve of
10,000 infantrymen and an additional armoured car regiment.

CIVIL DEFENCE
In January 1970 recruiting began for the Ulster Defence Regiment, a
locally recruited, part-time force under the General Officer Commanding
Northern Ireland, whose role is to support the regular forces in the Command.
The annual cost will be some £1 million, and numbers will not exceed 6,000
officers and men.
The Regular Reserve consists of former full-time officers and airmen, of
whom a few are detailed for specific tasks in emergency and the remainder
have a statutory liability for recall. The Royal Auxiliary Air Force, consisting
of three maritime headquarter units which would, in an emergency, reinforce
Strike Command (see p. in), and the Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve,
which includes the 16 University Air Squadrons, are liable for part-time train¬
ing and for recall in an emergency.
In 1968 civil defence arrangements were put on a care and maintenance basis.
The physical assets of civil defence organisations are being preserved so far
as is practicable, and training and planning continues at the minimum level
required to maintain knowledge and techniques and to enable more active
preparations to be resumed if this should appear to be necessary. Total annual
public expenditure on civil defence is between £8 million and £9 million.
The arrangements being maintained include an emergency system for
decentralised governmental control and communications, and the United
Kingdom Warning and Monitoring Organisation, including the Royal
Observer Corps, which would provide public warning of an attack, of the
location and power of nuclear explosions, and of the distribution and level of
radioactive fall-out; also planning for the police and fire services. Central
training courses are provided at the Civil Defence Training Establishment,
near York.
NATO COMMITMENT
The basis of the present NATO strategy of flexible response, which retains
the principle of forward defence, is that credible deterrence of military actions
of all kinds is necessary, and that this can be secured only through a wide
range of forces equipped with a well-balanced mixture of conventional and
tactical and strategic nuclear weapons. While NATO must be ready to use
nuclear weapons if necessary, the capability of its conventional forces must be
maximised and their number maintained at a level which would give NATO an
alternative to a nuclear response against anything but a major attack: thus
permitting a flexible range of responses able to meet aggression with direct
defence at approximately the same level; to gain time for negotiations to end
a conflict; and to reassert deterrence through the possibility of escalation to a
higher level of conflict.
The strategy, with its emphasis on the need to be prepared for attacks of
varying scales in any region of the NATO area, requires a comprehensive
range of mobile and well-equipped conventional forces, and tactical and
strategic nuclear weapons. Britain makes a contribution to the North Atlantic
Alliance unmatched by any other European member of NATO. The British
Polaris force forms the contribution to the Western strategic deterrent.
Virtually the whole of the Royal Navy is earmarked for assignment; the
British Army of the Rhine (BAOR) and RAF Germany (a tactical air-force)
are assigned; and most of the air and ground combat units based in the United
Kingdom are also formally committed, to provide an important part of
114 BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
NATO’s mobile reinforcement capability. As part of its contribution to the
European Defence Improvement Programme, Britain has increased the
capabilities of air and naval forces committed to the Alliance.
DEPLOYMENT
In January 1971 forces (including locally-enlisted troops and the Royal Navy
at sea) were distributed as follows:
Britain, 258,800; European Continent, 62,500 (nearly all in Germany);
Mediterranean, Near East and Gulf, 24,700; Far East, 34,000 (including
Gurkhas); and elsewhere, 5,700.
The deployment of forces is summarised below.
Europe The Western Fleet operates in European sea areas; frigates, submarines and
coastal minesweepers carry out training, trials and fishery protection, and
Britain ships of all classes spend periods at home for refitting. All major ships have
NATO commitments in the Channel, Eastern Atlantic, and Mediterranean;
a frigate is assigned to the Standing Naval Force Atlantic. Submarines of the
British Polaris force are on continuous deterrent patrol.
The majority of the field force headquarters and units stationed in the
United Kingdom are in the Army Strategic Command. This includes the
land elements of the United Kingdom Mobile Force (of which No. 38 Group,
Royal Air Force, provides the air element), the British contribution to the
land element of Allied Command Europe Mobile Force (Land), and 22 Special
Air Service Regiment, all of which have roles in support of NATO. Other
field force units and training organisations are stationed in the United King¬
dom together with units engaged on logistic tasks.
The combat units of the Royal Air Force in Britain are provided by Strike
Command and Air Support Command. The former provides strike and
strategic reconnaissance squadrons, interceptor squadrons for the air defence
of Britain, and long-range maritime reconnaissance squadrons. It also pro¬
vides some forces for maritime air defence and strike attack. Plans to transfer
the remaining fixed-wing operational support to the Royal Air Force from the
Royal Navy have been deferred until the late 1970s. These forces are all com¬
mitted to NATO. Air Support Command is responsible for both strategic and
tactical transport forces, tactical reconnaissance, and for the force of Phantoms
and Harriers in No. 38 Group designed for the close support of the Army in
the field. The Phantoms and short-range transport aircraft in No. 38 Group
provide the RAF part of the UK Mobile Force which is committed to NATO,
while the Harriers provide the British contribution to NATO’s Allied Com¬
mand Europe Mobile Force (Air). There are also units of the Royal Air Force
Regiment, responsible for airfield defence.
Federal Ground forces in the Federal Republic of Germany consist of the British
Republic Army of the Rhine (BAOR) and an independent brigade in West Berlin.
of Germany BAOR is organised as a corps of three divisions each of two brigades, plus corps
troops including two artillery brigades and an armoured reconnaissance force.
The BAOR brigades have been reorganised to produce a better balance
between armoured units and mechanised infantry. Royal Air Force Germany
is a tactical air force including strike/attack, reconnaissance, close support, and
air defence aircraft, all assigned to Supreme Allied Commander, Europe
(SACEUR). Helicopters for army support are also committed to NATO.
Surface-to-air missiles and light anti-aircraft squadrons are deployed for the
defence of RAF Germany’s airfields.

In the Mediterranean Britain’s maritime presence includes two frigates and a
guided missile destroyer which are earmarked for assignment to SACEUR,
one of which participates in the NATO ‘on call’ force; these are reinforced by
the occasional deployment of an aircraft carrier, a commando ship, and
frigates and submarines earmarked for other NATO commands.
Royal Air Force units in the area consist of strike/attack, maritime recon¬
naissance, photographic reconnaissance, air defence and transport squadrons;
surface-to-air missiles; and RAF Regiment squadrons. These forces are based
in Cyprus and Malta. RAF support for NATO is provided from the forces in
Malta, while support for the Central Treaty Organisation comes from forces
in both locations. Britain also supplies at its own expense about 900 men for
the United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus (the largest national
contingent). There are small garrisons in Malta and Gibraltar.
Britain continues to declare forces to certain contingency plans of the South-
East Asia Treaty Organisation (SEATO).
During 1971 combat units were maintained in Malaysia, Singapore and
Brunei, and a garrison in Hong Kong (which will remain unchanged after
^V1)-
Naval forces in the Far East comprise an amphibious ship, destroyers,
submarines and frigates. These forces operate in the Indian and Pacific
Oceans and undertake patrol duties in the Mozambique channel. Ships of the
Royal Australian and Royal New Zealand Navies operate with the Far East
Fleet. The Far East Air Force is made up of units of the RAF and Royal
Australian and Royal New Zealand Air Forces. Although the strength of the
RAF contribution has continued to run down, it comprises air defence air¬
craft, long-range maritime reconnaissance aircraft, support helicopters and a
medium-range transport squadron.
From the end of 1971 the British contribution to the Five-Power defence
arrangements for Malaysia and Singapore, which is designed to complement
the forces of the other four countries, will consist of a battalion group, in¬
cluding an artillery battery and engineers, in Singapore; a detachment of long-
range maritime reconnaissance aircraft and support helicopters; and six
frigates or destroyers, a submarine and mine counter-measures vessels.
Two frigates, equipped with helicopters and carrying a detachment of Royal
Marines, operate in the Caribbean. A small Royal Marine force and a
Royal Navy hovercraft unit are maintained in the Falkland Islands, and the
Royal Navy’s ice-patrol ship, HMS Endurance, operates there seasonally.
A small Army garrison remains in British Honduras. Some Royal Engineers
are stationed in Anguilla.
COMBAT FORCES
Combat forces may be functionally divided into six major groups, as described
below.
Responsibility for the British contribution to the Western strategic deterrent
now rests with the Royal Navy Polaris submarine force whose four nuclear
submarines—Resolution, Repulse, Renown and Revenge—are now in service
and provide a continuous deterrent patrol. Each has indefinite underwater
cruising range and carries 16 Polaris A3 missiles (with a range of about 2,500
miles and thermonuclear warheads).

The Polaris and other submarines operate from the Clyde submarine base
completed in 1968. Britain also provides facilities for a depot ship for United
States Polaris submarines at Holy Loch on the Firth of Clyde.
Britain’s nuclear strategic force is assigned to NATO. Within the Alliance
Britain has played an active part in the discussions designed to associate the
non-nuclear members of NATO with the Alliance’s nuclear planning. Political
guidelines for the defensive use of tactical nuclear weapons have been approved,
and procedures for consultation on the possible use of nuclear weapons have
been refined.
The cost of nuclear strategic forces for 1971-72 is estimated at £34 million.
The European theatre ground forces consist of the BAOR and an independent
brigade in West Berlin. Their cost in 1971-72 is estimated at £263 million.
Armoured regiments have completed re-equipment with the Chieftain main
battle tank, which incorporates new features in protection and mobility and
mounts the fully stabilised 120 mm gun. Armoured regiments are also being
equipped with Swingfire anti-tank guided missiles on a version of the armoured
personnel carrier. The field artillery has been re-equipped; its weapons now
include the British Abbot self-propelled 105 mm gun, and the American self-
propelled 155 mm and 175 mm guns; the issue of the new Field Artillery
Computer Equipment (FACE) gives improved accuracy and response times, as
does the Cymbeline light-weight mortar-locating radar. Surface-to-surface
tactical nuclear support is provided by the Honest John free-flight missile and
the 8 in. (203 mm) howitzer. Infantry mobility has continued to improve;
infantry battalions have tracked armoured personnel carriers (FV 432), some
of which are modified to carry the 81 mm mortar or the Wombat 122 mm anti¬
tank gun. The Stalwart (high mobility cross-country load-carrying vehicle)
has come into service. Mechanised infantry battalions have been equipped
with a new 66 mm anti-tank rocket. Surveillance and target acquisition
capability has been improved by a new drone (unmanned reconnaissance air¬
craft) and by the issue of ground surveillance radar and additional night¬
fighting devices. For chemical defence an improved range of clothing is being
issued. Air defence is provided by Thunderbird and Rapier anti-aircraft guided
missiles; both systems are fully mobile. The field trunk communications
system, Bruin, has proved valuable and effective, and is being extended.
The naval general purpose combat forces comprise the following: amphibious
forces; aircraft carriers and squadrons; submarines (excluding the Polaris
force); cruisers, destroyers and frigates; mine countermeasure forces; and
support and other ships. Any of these ships can be sent to other theatres if
needed in an emergency, either as reinforcements or to carry out joint opera¬
tions with the Army and Royal Air Force. Their cost, including aircraft and
overseas bases, in 1971-72 is estimated at £301 million.
The aircraft carriers HMS Ark Royal (having been refitted to carry Phantom
aircraft) and HMS Eagle were in service during 1971. HMS Ark Royal will
be retained until the late 1970s, but HMS Eagle will not operate beyond 1972.
HMS Hermes has been phased out of the fixed-wing-flying role, and is under¬
going conversion to the commando ship role, to replace eventually HMS
Bidwark. The carrier-borne strike and air-defence aircraft consist of the
Buccaneer, Sea Vixen and Phantom. The Buccaneer Mk 2 is a long-range, low-
level strike aircraft, equipped with the Bullpup air-to-surface missile. The Sea
Vixen Mk 2 is an all-weather interceptor/ground attack aircraft, and carries
Firestreak and Red Top air-to-air missiles in its air defence role: the Phantom,

Amphibious forces are provided by the commando ships HMS Albion and

in the mid-seventies. These helicopters have an anti-submarine role and a
capability against surface vessels. The strike capability of surface ships will be
improved by the introduction of the French Exocet, a surface-to-surface
guided missile system.
Progress is being maintained on the three classes of surface ships to be
introduced during the seventies. Four of the new Amazon class frigates (Type
21), to be equipped eventually with the Sea Wolf surface-to-air missile system,
are under construction, and the first of the new destroyers (Type 42) to carry
the Sea Dart surface-to-air missile (with a surface-to-surface capability) is
under construction. HMS Bristol, the new Type 82 guided missile destroyer,
with Sea Dart and Ikara, an anti-submarine missile, is complete. Some of the
Leander class frigates are being equipped with Ikara. A new type of cruiser,
to carry helicopters, with a ‘through-deck’ design giving the option of operat¬
ing V/STOL aircraft, is being designed; it too will be armed with Sea Dart.
A new general purpose frigate is also being designed.
Six nuclear fleet submarines (hunter-killer) are now in service—Dread¬
nought, Valiant, War spite, Churchill, Conqueror and Courageous) three more
are under construction, and a tenth has been ordered. A force of 26 conven¬
tional patrol submarines is also in service. Studies are in hand for submarine-
launched anti-ship missile systems.
Maintenance and repair facilities are provided by fleet maintenance ships, a
submarine depot ship, a heavy repair and maintenance ship, and a mine
countermeasure support ship—all manned by naval personnel. Ships of the
Royal Fleet Auxiliary Service provide afloat logistic support such as fuel, food,
ammunition, stores and spare gear. These ships fly the Blue Ensign and are
manned by civilian personnel. The dockyards at Portsmouth, Devonport,
Chatham and Rosyth provide the Navy with major repair and supply facilities
in Britain.
Army general purpose combat forces consist of the ground forces deployed
outside Europe to meet Commonwealth and treaty commitments; the Army
Strategic Command; and other front line units in Britain. Their cost in 1971-

Army Strategic Command’s (see p. m) primary role is in support of

Equipment is in general similar to that of the European theatre ground

The Army’s force of helicopters is being increased and will be equipped

The Royal Air Force general purpose combat forces comprise all front line
formations and units except those designated Air Mobility Forces (transport
and tanker forces). They fall into five main categories: strike/attack, offensive
support, tactical reconnaissance, long-range maritime reconnaissance and air
defence. Their cost in 1971-72 is estimated at £379 million.
Interceptor squadrons are equipped with the Lightning, which is supersonic
and can carry Firestreak or Red Top air-to-air missiles. Bloodhound and
Tigercat surface-to-air missiles are also available for air defence. The air
defence system is fully co-ordinated, with ground radars. New military radars
and centralised data-handling equipment are being installed in Britain as part
of the integrated plans for air defence and national air traffic control (the
Linesman/Mediator system). The Ballistic Missile Early Warning Station at
Fylingdales would provide warning of a missile attack on Britain, it also
detects, tracks and identifies objects in orbit.
A number of Phantom and Harrier squadrons have been formed in Air
Support Command. The Harrier, with its unique vertical take-off and
landing capacity, will concentrate mainly on quick reaction close support, while
the Phantom will cover the longer range ground attack and reconnaissance
functions. The ground attack version of the Anglo-French Jaguar (see p. 119)
will release further Phantoms from this role to replace in turn the Lightning
interceptors, and it is planned to increase the Jaguar front-line by a further
four squadrons. The Buccaneer Mk 2, already in service in a maritime strike
role, has been deployed to RAF Germany to start replacing the Canberra in
the tactical strike and reconnaissance role. Vulcan aircraft also operate in the
strike/attack role, and Victor aircraft in the reconnaissance role. The Shackleton
has been largely replaced by the Nimrod, the only land-based jet maritime
reconnaissance aircraft in the world, in the maritime reconnaissance and anti¬
submarine role. Some Shackleton aircraft are being converted to provide air¬
borne early warning.
Phantom FG 1 squadrons are now operational in Strike Command, in the
maritime air defence role; Buccaneer Mk 2 squadrons are operational in the
maritime strike/attack role.
Air mobility forces are made up of the strategic and tactical transport forces,
tanker aircraft to refuel combat aircraft in flight, support helicopters and

The strategic transport force is equipped with Comet 4C, Britannia, Belfast and

other aircraft.
DEFENCE PROCUREMENT AND SUPPORT
Responsibility for the procurement of defence equipment, including aircraft,
ships, ordnance, guided weapons and electronics, lies with a Procurement
Executive within the Ministry of Defence. The executive, set up in 1971
following a reorganisation of the government departments responsible for
defence procurement and civil aerospace (see pp. 56-7), has taken over this
aspect of the work of the former Ministry of Aviation Supply, an interim
department which took over the defence and aerospace role of the former
Ministry of Technology in late 1970.
A substantial part of the equipment used by the Services is developed and
produced in Britain, some by private industry on a contract basis and some
by the Royal Ordnance Factories, the Royal Dockyards and other establish¬
ments operated by the Ministry of Defence.
Because it is too costly for Britain or any other European country to develop
all its own defence equipment, a balance, which reconciles economic, industrial,
and political objectives with defence requirements, is maintained between
national development, development in collaboration with allies, and foreign
purchase. In 1971-72 the total value of exports of British defence equipment
was estimated at some £270 million, the Ministry of Defence share being
estimated at about £58 million.
There has been continued progress towards increased European co-operation
in the development and procurement of defence equipment. The most
important collaborative venture at present is the multi-role combat aircraft
(MRCA) in which Britain is co-operating with the Federal Republic of
Germany and Italy. Successful collaboration with France on the Jaguar strike-
trainer, the Martel air-to-surface missile, and the Gazelle (SA 341), Puma (SA
330) and Lynx (WG 13) helicopters, is at an advanced stage. Britain is
collaborating with the Federal Republic of Germany and Italy on a 155 mm
towed gun, and with Australia for the Ikara anti-submarine missile. Belgium
has become a partner in the programme for armoured combat vehicles.
Regular consultation takes place between Britain and her European allies
to harmonise the tactical doctrines on which joint operational requirements
for weapons systems are based.
The bulk of research work is carried out in the 26 research establishments
under the control of the Ministry of Defence; these establishments also
evaluate the development work undertaken by private industry for the
Government. Consultation and collaboration between Government and

BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
industry is secured through the National Defence Industries Council and the
Defence Scientific Advisory Council. These establishments are being organ¬
ised increasingly on a functional rather than on a single service basis. Research
and development work is in six major fields—aircraft, guided weapons, satellite
communications, electronics, ship construction and naval weapons, ordnance
and military vehicles.
Since 1967 efforts have been made to reduce the resources directed to
defence research and development, to make increased resources available for
civil research and development (see p. 319). The 1971 estimate for defence
research is £264 million. Analysis of the implications of policy is made by the
Defence Operational Analysis Establishment. The Controller, Research and
Development, is responsible for the oversight of the whole equipment research
and development programme, and exercises control through the Defence
Research Committee, the Operational Requirements Committee, and the
Weapons Development Committee, which evaluate the options on the various
weapons systems required by current strategy and defence policy.
Over 30 major projects are at present in hand, including the MRCA, the
Sea Dart and Sea PEoZ/'ship-to-air guided weapons, Blowpipe, an infantry air-
defence missile, Clansman, a net radio system for field communications,
LinesmanjMediator, an integrated control and reporting system for air defence
and air traffic control, gas turbine development for ship propulsion, the
adaptation of hovercraft for naval purposes, a field artillery rocket system, and
two families of air-portable armoured combat reconnaissance vehicles. The
defence research establishments also undertake civil work, and publicise the
many industrial applications of their research.
In addition to research and development, there is support of a general nature
supplied in Britain to the Services as a whole. The major items include:
general training; the overhead costs of naval dockyards, ordnance factories
and repair, maintenance and storage units; Ministry of Defence and local
administrative services in Britain; and military pensions. Work continues to
rationalise and reorganise these support services. The total estimated cost for
1971-72 is £953 million.

civilian personnel; a strength of about 350,000 military personnel is envisaged
for the mid-1970s. Table 7 below shows the allocation of expenditure between

STATE AND VOLUNTARY SERVICES
In Britain the State is responsible, through either central or local government,
for a range of services covering family allowances, national insurance, help for
war victims, financial assistance to those in special need, health and welfare
services for mothers and young children, the sick, mentally disordered, elderly
and handicapped and for families in difficulties of various kinds, and the care
of children lacking a normal home life (all described in this chapter); and for
education (see Chapter 6) and housing (see Chapter 8). Public authorities in
Britain are spending £ 10,443 million a year on this range of services, that is,
over £187 a year per head of the population.
Voluntary organisations, especially the Churches, were the pioneers of
nearly all the social services. They provided schools, hospitals, clinics,
dispensaries, and social and recreational clubs before these were provided by
the State. They made themselves responsible for the welfare of the very young
and the very old, the homeless and the handicapped. Gradually the State
accepted the primary responsibility for the major services, supplementing the
voluntary services and developing a comprehensive structure that ensured a
minimum standard of living and well-being for all citizens.
State and voluntary social services are now complementary and co-operative.
The State may work through voluntary agencies specially adapted to serve
particular needs and ensures that necessary standards are maintained. The
officers of central and local government, in carrying out their duties, co-operate
with the workers of many voluntary social service societies, while the
residential provision made by the State and by local authorities for the care of
children, the chronic sick and the aged is supplemented by voluntary homes
of various types. Most of the sick and elderly receive State pensions or benefits.
The Charity Commission, a government department, gives free advice to
trustees of charities, making schemes to modify their purposes or facilitate
their administration when necessary; it maintains central and local registers
of charities which are open to public inspection; and it works to promote co¬
operation between charities and State services.
The number of voluntary organisations in Britain runs into thousands; they
range from national organisations to small individual local groups. Most
organisations, however, are members of larger associations or are represented
on local or national co-ordinating councils or committees. Some are chiefly
concerned with giving personal service, others in the formation of public
opinion and exchange of information. A number are concerned with giving
help to immigrants. In recent years there has been an increase in organised
service by young people.
Organisations concerned with personal and family problems include the
voluntary family casework agencies like the Family Welfare Association,
Family Service Units, and the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty
to Children; marriage guidance centres affiliated to the National Marriage
Guidance Council; the National Council for the Unmarried Mother and her
Child; and the Samaritans, who help people near to committing suicide.
124
Social Workers
BRITAIN I972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Voluntary service to the sick and disabled in general is given by—among
others—the British Red Cross Society, the St. John Ambulance Association
and Brigade, the Women’s Royal Voluntary Service and the Leagues of
Hospital Friends, but an increasing number of societies exist to help people
with particular disabilities and difficulties, such as the Royal National Institute
for the Blind, the Royal National Institute for the Deaf, the National Associa¬
tion for Mental Health, the National Society for Mentally Handicapped
Children, the Spastics Society, the constituent members of the Central
Council for the Disabled, Alcoholics Anonymous, Narcotics Anonymous and
their Scottish equivalents.
Bodies working on a national scale whose work is specifically religious in
inspiration include the Salvation Army, the Church Army, Toe H, the Com¬
mittee on Social Service of the Church of Scotland, the Church of England
Children’s Society, the Church of England Council for Social Work, the
Young Men’s Christian Association, the Young Women’s Christian Associa¬
tion, the Society of Friends, the Crusade of Rescue, the Society of St. Vincent
de Paul, the Catholic Marriage Advisory Council and the Jewish Welfare
A wide range of voluntary personal service is given by the Women s Royal
Voluntary Service, which gives help in every kind of practical difficulty, brings
‘meals on wheels’ to housebound invalids and old people, provides flatlets
and residential clubs for the elderly, helps with family problems and assists in
hospitals and clinics, as well as doing relief work in emergencies.
A central link between voluntary organisations and official bodies concerned
with social services is provided in England and Wales by the National Council
of Social Service, which brings together most of the principal voluntary
agencies for consultation and joint action, either as a whole or in groups of
those concerned with particular aspects, such as youth work or work among
the handicapped. There are also the Scottish Council of Social Service and the
Northern Ireland Council of Social Service, which perform similar functions.
The Citizens’ Advice Bureaux, of which there are now some 500 in Britain,
are steadily increasing in number. The primary role of the bureaux is to give
explanation and advice to the citizen who is in doubt about his rights or who
does not know about the State or voluntary services which could help him.
While the voluntary worker giving full-time or part-time service has done
pioneer work in many of Britain’s social services and continues to play an
essential part, social services of all kinds increasingly depend for their opera¬
tion chiefly on professional social workers, that is, full-time salaried workers
trained in the principles and methods of social work. Most professional social
workers are employed by local authorities (for the personal social services and
probation work), by hospitals (for medical and psychiatric social work), or by
voluntary organisations. Training for most types of social work consists of a
basic university degree, diploma or certificate course in social science followed
by a university course in applied social studies or specialised training for a
particular service. Training is also possible in colleges of further education.
The statutory central training council for the United Kingdom is the Central
Council for Education and Training in Social Work which,in WTL replaced
the two former national councils for social work training, the Council tor
Training in Social Work and the Central Training Council in Child Care and
which also undertakes the training functions carried out formerly by the
Advisory Council for Probation and After-Care. Advice on social work training
is given by the Social Work Advisory Service.

Urban A four-year urban programme providing for government-aided local authority
Programme expenditure of some £20 million-^25 million was launched at the end of 1968
to assist areas of special social need, in particular to relieve problems resulting
from overcrowding, inadequate housing and schools, and other forms of
deprivation. In 1970 the programme was extended to 1976 with total expendi¬
ture for the period 1968-76 of £60 million-^65 million. Projects being under¬
taken include help for play groups and the provision and improvement of
nursery schools and classes, day nurseries and playgrounds, language classes
for immigrants, in-service training courses for teachers, children’s homes,
family advice centres, housing aid services, family planning clinics, help for
community centres and summer holiday schemes for deprived children. A
particular aim of the programme is to support the work of voluntary bodies.
An experiment in community development has also been started by the
Government. This involves bringing together those services, both statutory
and voluntary, which are concerned with relieving various forms of social
handicap and encouraging the resources of self-help within the community.
SOCIAL SECURITY
National insurance, industrial injuries insurance, family allowances, family
income supplements and supplementary benefits together with (in a special
category) war pensions constitute a comprehensive system of social security in
the United Kingdom.
The Department of Health and Social Security administers these services
in Great Britain; within the Department the Supplementary Benefits Com¬
mission is responsible for the system of supplementary benefits. In Northern
Ireland the first five of these schemes are administered by the Ministry of
Health and Social Services which contains the Supplementary Benefits Com¬
mission for Northern Ireland. Pensions and welfare services for war pensioners
and their dependants are the responsibility of the Department of Health and
Social Security throughout the United Kingdom. Appeals relating to claims
for the various benefits and allowances are decided by independent authori¬
ties.
Although the development of public provision for social security in Britain
can be traced back for several centuries (the Poor Relief Act of 1601 may
be regarded as specially important in England and Wales), the modern system
of comprehensive provision is a creation of the twentieth century. Non¬
contributory old age pensions were introduced in 1908, and the first con¬
tributory pensions for old people, widows and orphans in 1926. A contributory
National Health Insurance Scheme was begun in 1912, and in the same year
a scheme of unemployment insurance was introduced which in 1920 was
extended to cover the great majority of employees. By the beginning of the
second world war social security provision in Britain was among the best in
the world, but lacked co-ordination because of its piecemeal development, and
not everyone came within its scope. In the immediate post-war years a series
of Acts introduced the present comprehensive system, which became fully
operative in July 1948. Statutory provision for the war disabled goes back to
the end of the sixteenth century, but the main lines of the present war pension
provisions were laid down during the first world war.
Family allowances and national insurance and industrial injuries benefits
or allowances, other than maternity, unemployment, sickness, injury or dis¬
ablement benefit, are included in the taxable income on which income tax is
assessed. On the other hand, various income tax reliefs and exemptions are
126
Reciprocity
FAMILY
ALLOWANCES
FAMILY INCOME
SUPPLEMENT
NATIONAL
INSURANCE
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
allowed on account of age or liability for the support of dependants. Family
income supplements and war disablement pensions are not taxable.
The national insurance, industrial injuries and family allowances schemes of
Great Britain and those of Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man operate as a
single system. Reciprocal agreements on industrial injuries, family allowances
and most national insurance benefits are in operation with Belgium, Denmark,
Finland, the Federal Republic of Germany, Jersey and Guernsey, Norway,
Sweden, Switzerland and Yugoslavia; a similar agreement with Austria is
expected to be ratified in 1972. Agreements with Cyprus, France, the
Republic of Ireland, Israel, Italy, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands and
Turkey cover industrial injuries and most national insurance benefits. With
Australia and New Zealand there are agreements on family allowances and
most national insurance benefits. There are limited agreements with Bermuda,
Canada and the United States. Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man are also
party to most of these agreements with other countries.
Family allowances are provided in Great Britain under the Family Allowances
Act 1965 (which consolidated the Acts of 1945^^4)> ^ Northern Ireland
under its own legislation. They are being paid in Great Britain to more than
4 million families with over 11 million children, and in Northern Ireland to
138,000 families. The allowances are payable to families with two or more
children below the age limits which are 15 years for children who leave school
at that age, 16 years for certain incapacitated children, and 19 for children
who remain at school or are apprentices with low earnings.
The rates of the allowances are £0-90 a week for families with two children
below the age limits and a further £1 a week for each additional child.
Family allowances are paid from the Exchequer and their object is to benefit
the family as a whole; they belong to the mother, but may be paid either to
the mother or to the father. There is no insurance qualification for title to the
allowances, but there are certain residence conditions.
Family Income Supplement is a new social security benefit introduced in
August 1971 to help families (and single people) with small incomes where the
wage-earner is in full-time work and there is at least one dependent child. It is
payable when the weekly sum of a family’s resources falls below a prescribed
amount, fixed at £18 a week where there is one child plus £2 for each additional
child. The weekly rate of the supplement is half the difference between the
family’s income and the prescribed amount up to a maximum of ^4' Some
190,000 households containing about 500,000 children are expected to benefit,
including about 54,000 single people with children.
The National Insurance Acts apply, in general, to everyone over minimum
school-leaving age living in Great Britain. There are similar schemes in
Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man. (The National Insurance Act 1965
consolidated the provisions of the National Insurance Acts i94^—^40
The national insurance scheme provides benefits in specified contingencies
where contribution conditions have been fulfilled. The benefits are paid for
partly by insured persons’ contributions, partly by contributions of employers
in respect of their employees, and partly by a contribution made by the
Exchequer out of general taxation.
The original system was based on flat-rate contributions and benefits.
Contributions varied only with the sex and insurance class of the insured
SOCIAL WELFARE
127
Contributors
person and benefits were at standard rates. (In both cases lower rates apply to
those under 18.) Two modifications were subsequently introduced to provide
additional earnings-related contributions and benefits. For retirement, grad¬
uated contributions and pensions were introduced in 1961; and for the first
six months of sickness, unemployment or widowhood the National Insurance
Act 1966 introduced a scheme for earnings-related supplements to the flat-
rate benefit and contributions.
In November 1970 pensions were introduced for elderly people who were
over pension age when the scheme started and had therefore been previously
excluded, and in April 1971 for widows aged between 40 and 50 when widowed
or when entitlement to widowed mother’s allowance ended. From September
1971 an old person’s pension became payable to all other non-pensioners aged
80 and over; at the same time an invalidity pension was introduced for anyone
who had received sickness benefit for six months, with an additional invalidity
allowance for people becoming chronically sick more than five years before
retirement age. An attendance allowance for severely disabled people needing
constant supervision will become payable in December 1971.
Contributors under the national insurance scheme are divided into three
classes:
Class 1. Employed people. Most of those who work for an employer under a
contract of service or are paid apprentices—over 23 million.
Class 2. Self-employed people. Those in business on their own account and
others who are working for gain but do not work under the control of an
employer—about million.
Class 3. Non-employed people. All those insured who are not in class 1 or
class 2—about a quarter of a million.
There is a general liability to pay flat-rate contributions according to this
classification but certain people are excepted. These include full-time students,
prisoners and most people in receipt of national insurance benefits. Self-
employed and non-employed persons whose income is below £468 a year can
apply for exception. Married women can choose to pay contributions and
receive benefit in their own right or not to pay flat-rate contributions (if they
are working they must pay graduated contributions) and rely upon their
husband’s insurance for maternity grant, retirement pension (at a lower rate),
widow’s benefit and death grant. If a married woman works for an employer
he must pay his full share of the flat-rate contributions even if she has chosen
not to pay flat-rate contributions.
Flat-rate contributions are credited to students up to the age of 18, and
to most people in receipt of national insurance benefits. People who are
excepted from liability to pay but are not entitled to credits may pay con¬
tributions at the non-employed rate if they wish to safeguard entitlement to
retirement pension and widow’s benefit.
An employed person ceases to be liable for national insurance contributions
at the age of 70 (for a man, 65 for a woman), or when he retires from regular
employment after reaching minimum pension age (65 for men, 60 for women),
whichever is the earlier. If he does any work as an employed person thereafter,
he must pay an industrial injuries contribution; the employer still has to pay
his full share of the flat-rate contribution.
Contributions
Flat-rate contributions are normally paid by means of national insurance

stamps bought from a post office and fixed, for each contributor, to a single

The stamps for class 1 contributors also include the employer’s redundancy

insurance contribution although the two services are separate). It is the
employer’s responsibility in the first place to see that the class 1 contributions
are paid, but he can deduct the employees’ share from their wages. The self-
employed and non-employed must stamp their own cards. Flat-rate contribu¬
tions are usually credited for weeks of unemployment, sickness or injury, or if
certain widow’s benefits are being paid.

In general graduated contributions are payable by employed people (in¬
cluding married women but not retirement pensioners) aged between 18 and
70 (65 for women) who earn more than ^9 a week. The range of graduated
contributions is given in Table 9. Employees whose job provides them with
an occupational pension of at least £3-48 a year for each year of service (£2-90

for women) may be ‘contracted out’ of part of the graduated pension scheme.
Contracted out employees pay graduated contributions at the rate of 0-5 per
cent of that part of their weekly pay lying between £9 and £18 and 4-35
per cent on earnings between £18 and ^42; their employers pay the same
amount. Employees who are not contracted out pay graduated contributions
at the rate of 475 per cent of the part of their weekly earnings between £9 and
£18 and 4-35 per cent of the part between £18 and £42. Their employers pay
the same amount.
Graduated contributions provide a graduated addition to retirement pension
and meet the cost of earnings-related supplements to sickness and unemploy¬
ment benefit and to widow’s allowance. The contributions are collected
through the same machinery as is used to collect pay-as-you-earn (deduction
at source) income tax.
The scheme provides payments to contributors in the event of unemployment
(if normally working for an employer), incapacity for work and invalidity (if
normally working for an employer or self-employed), and confinement and the
weeks immediately before and after (for women normally working for an
employer or self-employed and paying national insurance contributions at the
full rate). Retirement pensions are paid to people who have reached 65 (60 for
women) if they have retired from regular work and from the age of 70 (65 for
women) even if they continue to work; people aged 80 and over who have not
participated in the scheme are eligible for an old person’s pension; widows
normally receive benefit in the first 26 weeks after bereavement and sub¬
sequently while they have young children or if they have reached the age of
40 when widowed or when their children have grown up; and there are two
kinds of allowance in respect of orphan children where a widow’s pension is
not payable. The scheme also provides lump-sum cash grants for two expen¬
sive contingencies—the birth of a child and a death.
For most of the benefits there are two contribution conditions. First, before
benefit can be paid at all, a minimum number of contributions must actually
have been paid since entry into insurance; secondly, the full rate of benefit
cannot be paid unless a specified number of contributions have been paid or
credited over a specified period. There are special rules to help a widow who
does not become entitled to a widow’s pension at widowhood or when her
children have grown up, to qualify for sickness or unemployment benefit in
the period before she can have established or re-established herself in insur¬
ance through her own contributions; there are also provisions to help a
divorced woman who was not paying contributions during her marriage.
The basic amount of the majority of flat-rate benefits is ^6 a week which
may be reduced if insufficient contributions have been paid, but is not affected
by other unearned income or the previous level of earnings. Earnings received
while the benefit is in payment, however, may cause its reduction or with¬
drawal : unemployment benefit cannot be paid to a person earning more than
a specified amount from a subsidiary occupation; retirement pensioners under
the age of 70 (65 for women) have their pensions reduced in step with earnings
over certain specified amounts; sickness benefit, though not affected by con¬
tinued payment of wages during illness, is not normally payable to a person
doing any actual work. Widows’ benefits, however, are not affected by earn¬
ings. Exceptions to the basic flat rate are the higher rate of £8-40 a week
payable to widows during the first 26 weeks after bereavement, the increased
retirement pension earned by someone who has continued at work and paid
130 BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
contributions beyond minimum pension age and the invalidity allowance paid
to people becoming chronically sick more than five years before pension age;
and the lower rate of jC4,20 a week unemployment or sickness benefit payable
to married women who pay contributions and the rates for widows between 40
and 50 which reduce on a scale to ^1-80 a week for a woman aged 40 at the
date of entitlement. The standard rate of retirement pension for a woman on
her husband’s insurance is £370 a week and the old person’s pension is ^3-60
for a single person and £5-8° for a married couple. An age addition of ^0-25
a week is paid to pensioners aged 80 and over. Invalidity allowance is £0-30,
£o-6o or £1, depending upon the age at which incapacity begins. Attendance
allowance will be ^4'80 a week.
Standard increases of flat-rate benefit are payable for dependants at the rate
°f £370 for an adult (generally a wife), £1-85 for the first or only child under
the family allowances age limits; £0-95 for the second child and ^0-85 for each
other child over and above any family allowances payable (see p. 126). The
sum payable for the children of widows, invalidity and retirement pensioners
is £2-95 for each child inclusive of family allowances.
A guardian’s allowance of £2-95 a week is payable to a person who has in
his or her family a child who has lost both parents, one of whom was insured
under the National Insurance Acts. The allowance can sometimes be paid
on the death of one parent. For certain fatherless children there is a child’s
special allowance also of £2-95 a week inclusive of family allowances; this is
payable to a woman whose marriage has been dissolved or annulled and who
has not remarried, if her former husband dies and she has a child to whose
support he was contributing before he died.
The graduated addition to retirement pension is at the rate of £0-02% a
week for each £7-50 of all graduated contributions paid by a man and for each
£9 of such graduated contributions paid by a woman (with in each case, the
matching amount of graduated contribution coming from the employer). The
earnings-related supplements to flat-rate unemployment and sickness benefits
are one-third of that part of a person’s average weekly earnings between £()
and £30,1 but the supplements cannot raise the total benefit, including in¬
creases for dependants, beyond 85 per cent of earnings. The supplement is
also paid to widow beneficiaries who have the appropriate record of earnings,
if they become unemployed or sick.
An earnings-related supplement is paid in addition to the widow s allowance
to widows whose husbands were under 7° and had not retired from regular
employment; this supplement is one-third of that part of the husband s
average weekly earnings between £<) and £30.1
The rates of grants are varied: £25 maternity grant is payable for a con¬
finement and a further £2$ for each additional child born at the same con¬
finement living 12 hours after birth; and £^0 death grant on the death of an
adult (less for a child, or for an adult who was within ten years of minimum
pension age when the scheme started).
Duration In general, national insurance payments are paid as long as the situation
requiring them lasts. However, invalidity pension cannot be paid if fewer than
156 contributions have been made (possible in three years for a contributor
continuously at work) and unemployment benefit is payable for a maximum of
one year. The supplement to unemployment and sickness benefit is paid for a
maximum of six months starting from the thirteenth day of unemployment or

incapacity for work. Maternity allowance begins 11 weeks before the expected
week of confinement and ends after the sixth week following the expected week
or the actual confinement if this is later.
Similarly, a widowed mother’s allowance at the full rate ceases when her
children are no longer dependent on her, though a mother can continue to
receive £6 a week for herself while she has living with her a son or daughter
under 19. The widow’s pension payable to the childless widow, provided she
is 40 or over at the time of being widowed, or the similar pension payable to
the widowed mother who has reached 40 when her widowed mother’s allow¬
ance ends, normally continues until she has reached minimum pension age and
retired, or at most till the age of 65. On retirement she receives a pension at a
rate not lower than her widow’s pension.
NATIONAL
INSURANCE
(INDUSTRIAL
INJURIES)
The industrial injuries insurance scheme, which, in 1948, replaced the work¬
men’s compensation scheme (first introduced by the Workmen’s Compensa¬
tion Act of 1897), provides benefits for personal injuries caused by accidents
arising out of, and in the course of, employment, and for prescribed diseases
due to the nature of employment. It covers practically everyone in class 1 of
the national insurance scheme and certain others. Like the national insurance
scheme, the industrial injuries scheme is financed partly from contributions
(see Table 9) and partly from taxation. The legal basis of the scheme is the
National Insurance (Industrial Injuries) Act 1965 which consolidated the 1946
Act and subsequent legislation. Similar cover against industrial injuries and
diseases is provided by Northern Ireland’s legislation.
Benefits
Injury Benefit
Disablement
Benefit
Injury benefit for an adult is £8-75 a week plus £2>'l0 f°r an adult dependant,
^1-85 for the first or only child under the family allowances age limits, £0-95
for the second child and £o’8$ for each other child in addition to any family
allowance payable. It is paid when the insured person is incapable of work as
a result of an industrial accident or prescribed disease, and payment can
continue for a maximum of 26 weeks beginning on the date of the accident or
development of the disease. A person entitled to sickness benefit who draws
injury benefit instead, also receives any earnings-related supplement (see p.
130) to which he is entitled.
Disablement benefit may be paid (but not at the same time as injury benefit)
when, as the result of industrial accident or prescribed disease, there is a loss
of physical or mental faculty. The amount depends on the extent of the
disablement as assessed by a medical board; it varies from £10 for 100 per
cent disablement to £2 a week for 20 per cent disablement, but for disable¬
ment of less than 20 per cent a gratuity of up to £660 is normally paid.
In certain circumstances disablement benefit may be supplemented as
follows: unemployability supplement, at the weekly rate of £6; constant
attendance allowance of up to £\ weekly normally, or a special rate of £6 or £8
a week in exceptionally severe cases; an allowance of £4 a week for exceptionally
severe disablement; a special hardship allowance of up to £4 for a person who
is unfit to return to his regular job or to do work of an equivalent standard;
and hospital treatment allowance which raises the benefit to that for a 100 per
cent assessment during hospital treatment for the industrial disability. In¬
creases of benefit for dependants are payable with unemployability supplement
and hospital treatment allowance. People receiving unemployability supple¬
ment may also receive an additional allowance similar to invalidity allowance
(see p. 130).
132
Death Benefit
SUPPLEMENTARY
BENEFITS
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
If the accident or disease results in the insured person’s death, death benefit
may be paid to the dependants.
For a widow a pension of ^8-40 a week is payable for the first 26 weeks of
widowhood. In addition she receives any earnings-related supplement (see p.
130) that would have been paid had she claimed widow’s allowance under the
main national insurance scheme. Thereafter, the widow can receive a pension
of £6-55 a week if she was aged 50 at the date of her husband’s death, or has
dependent children or other special needs; otherwise she receives j£i-8o a
week. If she had been living apart from her husband, the pension is limited to
the weekly rate of maintenance he was paying, if less than the rate otherwise
appropriate.
In addition, allowances are paid for children under the family allowances
age limits. For widows, these allowances together with any family allowance
payable amount to £2-95 a week for each child. For other beneficiaries, the
rate is j£i‘85 each.
Certain other dependants, such as parents and other relatives, may be
entitled to pensions, allowances or gratuities.
The Ministry of Social Security Act 1966 provided for a scheme of supple¬
mentary benefits to replace the system which had been administered by the
former National Assistance Board since 1948. The Act established within the
then Ministry of Social Security a Supplementary Benefits Commission re¬
sponsible for guiding the scheme and for determining awards of benefit.
Parallel legislation in Northern Ireland made similar provision.
Every person in Great Britain aged 16 or over who is not in full-time work,
attending school or involved in a trade dispute and whose resources are in¬
sufficient to meet his requirements is entitled to a supplementary benefit. The
benefit takes the form of a supplementary allowance for people under the
statutory retirement age, and a supplementary pension for those over. The
benefit is the amount by which a person’s requirements exceed his available
resources, both being defined by rules laid down by the Act. The calculation
of requirements is based on different amounts for single people and family
groups (for blind people there are special higher amounts) with, in each case,
an addition for rent. For the old and most other long-term cases a special
addition is made. Available resources include certain income and capital; the
main national insurance and industrial injury benefits, family allowances and
maintenance payments from a husband or the father of the claimant s children
are taken into account in full but some part of all other resources is disregarded.
The payment of a supplementary allowance in the case of an able-bodied
person of working age may be conditional on registering at an employment
exchange of the Department of Employment and in the case of fit people under
the age of 45 may be limited to four weeks in areas where there is plenty of
work available. The allowance is then paid at the exchange; otherwise it is paid
weekly through a post office.
The Supplementary Benefits Commission also has a duty to influence people
without a settled way of living to lead a more normal life. The Commission
provides temporary accommodation for them in 17 reception centres, four of
which are administered by local authorities on behalf of the Commission. For
men who have been unemployed for long periods and who are receiving
supplementary allowances or are using reception centres, it runs 13 re¬
establishment centres, three of which have residential accommodation where
they are given help to fit them again for work.
