Responsibility for clean air in towns and cities rests with local authorities,
who may declare ‘smoke control areas’ within which the emission of smoke
from chimneys constitutes an offence: nearly 3,500 smoke control orders
have been confirmed and 4-9 million dwellings and commercial premises are
subject to smoke control. Central government is responsible through the alkali
inspectorate for enforcing control of emissions to the air of noxious and offen¬
sive substances including smoke, grit and dust from certain industrial pro¬
cesses. The emission of smoke from motor vehicles is also controlled. The Clean
Air Council (set up in 1956) and a similar council for Scotland review the pro¬
gress made in abating air pollution in Great Britain. Partly as a result of air
pollution control, London no longer experiences dense (‘pea-souper’) fogs or
serious smogs and in central London winter sunshine has increased by 50 per
cent since 1956. Sheffield claims to be the cleanest industrial city in Europe.
Local authorities are also responsible for the enforcement of the Noise
Abatement Act i960 which requires them to inspect their areas for noise
nuisances and to take action (which can be enforced by the courts) to secure
abatement. More than 8,000 complaints about noise were received by local
authorities in 1969, and in over half of these cases the authorities considered
that nuisance existed and took appropriate action. The Advisory Council on
Noise is studying the working of the Act.
Other special measures have been introduced to help to combat water
pollution (see p. 233), to reduce the level of fumes from motor vehicles and to
ensure that the use of agricultural chemicals is properly supervised (see p. 278).
The Royal Commission on Environmental Pollution (see p. 321) gives
advice on matters concerning the pollution of the environment.
Under the Countryside Acts 1967 (for Scotland) and 1968 (for England and
Wales) Countryside Commissions (with an advisory committee for Wales)
encourage the provision and development of facilities for open-air recreation
in the countryside. These include the creation by local authorities (sometimes
in association with other bodies) of country parks within easy reach of towns;
the establishment of camping sites and picnic areas; and the increased use of
reservoirs, canals and other waterways for bathing, sailing and other activities.
By August 1971, 40 country parks and 50 picnic sites had been approved in
England and Wales by the Government. In Scotland a large number of local
authority schemes for the provision of a variety of countryside facilities have
been approved for grant aid. By January 1971, the Countryside Commission
for Scotland had approved four country parks. The Commissions are also
responsible for encouraging and promoting measures to conserve and enhance
the natural beauty and amenity of the countryside and may undertake research
projects and experimental schemes, working in consultation with local authori¬
ties and such bodies as the Nature Conservancy and the Sports Council (see
p. 446). Grants to local authorities are available from the Government for
certain approved schemes and the Commissions have powers to make grants
or loans to people carrying out similar projects.
The Countryside Commission (for England and Wales) replaced and assumed
the functions of the National Parks Commission set up under the National
Parks and Access to the Countryside Act 1949 to select national parks and
‘areas of outstanding natural beauty’ and to make proposals for the creation of
long-distance footpaths and bridleways. Ten national parks have been estab¬
lished: Northumberland, the Lake District, the Yorkshire Dales, the North
York Moors and the Peak District in northern England; Snowdonia, the
Forest Parks
Local
Footpaths and
Open Country
BRITAIN I972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Pembrokeshire Coast and the Brecon Beacons in Wales; Exmoor and Dart¬
moor in south-west England. They cover a total area of 5,258 square miles
(13,618 sq. km.), or 9 per cent of the area of England and Wales. They have
various forms of administration, based on representation of the local planning
authorities of the areas concerned, as well as members appointed by the
Government. By August 1971, 27 areas of outstanding natural beauty had been
designated, covering some 4,464 square miles (11,562 sq. km.).
The land in the national parks and designated areas generally remains
privately owned, but agreements or orders to secure additional public access
may be made by local authorities. Steps are taken to preserve and enhance
the landscape’s natural beauty by high standards of development control, and
by positive measures, for which government grants are available, such as tree
planting and preservation, and the removal of eyesores. In the national
parks, other measures for the benefit of the public include the provision of
car parks, camping and caravan areas, and information centres. All national
parks and some other designated areas have warden services. More than 1,414
miles (2,276 km.) of long-distance footpaths and bridleways had been
approved by August 1971. Large stretches of these paths are already public
rights of way; the 250 miles (402 km.) of the Pennine Way form Britain’s first
long-distance footpath and the South Downs Way, stretching for some 80
miles (129 km.) is the first long-distance bridleway. Further routes are being
established.
Under the Amenity Lands Act (Northern Ireland) 1965 the Ulster Country¬
side Committee advises on the establishment of national parks and the
designation of areas of outstanding natural beauty. Seven areas have been
designated. Four amenity areas, acquired by the Ministry of Development, are
being managed as country parks. Although there are no national parks as such
in Scotland, five large areas are subject to special planning control under
ministerial supervision. The areas are: Loch Lomond-Trossachs; Glen
Affric-Glen Cannich-Strath Farrar; Ben Nevis-Glen Coe-Black Mount; the
Cairngorms; and Loch Torridon—Loch Maree—Little Loch Broom. Over 98
per cent of the land in Scotland has been designated as countryside within the
jurisdiction of the Countryside Commission for Scotland.
The Forestry Commission (see p. 285) has formed, and opened to the public,
seven forest parks in some of the finest country in Great Britain: Argyll, Glen
Trool, Glen More and the Queen Elizabeth Forest Park in Scotland; the
Forest of Dean and the Wye valley woods on the borders of England and
Wales; Snowdonia in Wales; and the Border Forest Park on the borders of
England and Scotland. The total area of the parks approaches half a million
acres (202,340 hectares). Camping and other recreational facilities provided in
all the parks are used by several million holidaymakers each year. The historic
New Forest, in Hampshire, although not a forest park, is also open to the
public. In Northern Ireland, the Forestry Division of the Ministry of Agricul¬
ture has established five forest parks—Tollymore Park, Castlewellan, Gortin
Glen, Drum Manor and Gosford Castle—and there are also five forest scenic
drives; in some 40 forests recreational facilities have been provided.
Under the National Parks and Access to the Countryside Act 1949 county
councils in most areas of England and Wales have prepared maps showing all
public rights of way, which must be kept free of vehicles and obstructions and
must not be permanently disturbed. If a path is not shown on the map, a
private citizen can show that it is a public right of way if it has been used and
TOWN AND COUNTRY PLANNING
179
Nature
Conservation
regarded as such without interruption for at least 20 years. Public footpaths are
maintained by local highway authorities who must also provide signposts and
supervise the duty of landowners to repair stiles and gates. Local authorities in
Great Britain can create paths and ways, close existing paths which are no
longer in public use, and divert paths to secure a more efficient use of the land
or simply a shorter route. Local planning authorities can convert minor roads
into footpaths or bridleways and provide recreational facilities.
The 1949 Act is also concerned with access to open country, which now
includes mountains, moors, heaths, downs, cliffs and foreshores, woodlands,
rivers and canals and their banks, but not farmland unless it is simply used for
grazing. There is no automatic right of public access to open country, but
local planning authorities can secure access by means of agreements with land-
owners; if agreements cannot be obtained, authorities may acquire land or
make orders for public access. These powers were extended in 1967 to cover
Scotland.
Common land totals an estimated 1^ million acres (607,030 hectares) in
England and Wales. (There is no common land in Scotland or Northern
Ireland.) This is usually privately owned land which must not be enclosed and
on or over which certain people have legal rights, for example, of access or of
pasture for their farm animals. Commons are protected by law and it is un¬
lawful to erect buildings or fences on them without the consent of the Depart¬
ment of the Environment or the Welsh Office. The Commons Registration Act
1965 provided for the registration of all commons and village greens, and by
the close of the registration period in 1970 over 16,000 areas had been regis¬
tered. Under the Countryside Act 1968 local authorities can provide facilities
for enjoyment on any common land to which the public has access.
The Nature Conservancy (on behalf of the Natural Environment Research
Council—see p. 332) is responsible for nature conservation in Great Britain.
The Conservancy has established 130 national nature reserves, covering
268,642 acres (108,718 hectares); in Northern Ireland 12 nature reserves have
been established by the Ministry of Development on the advice of the Nature
Reserves Committee. Local nature reserves in 26 areas, established by local
authorities in consultation with the Conservancy, are safeguarded against
development and play an important part in scientific education. In woodland
areas there are some 13 forest nature reserves, created by informal agreements
between the Nature Conservancy and landowners (including the Forestry
Commission) and managed by the owners for research and conservation.
There are also some 2,600 sites of special scientific interest in Great Britain,
designated because of their flora, fauna or geological or physiological features:
local planning authorities are informed of the importance of these areas by the
Conservancy, which they must consult about any development proposals
affecting them. In Northern Ireland 29 sites have been scheduled by the
Ministry of Development and are subject to special planning control.
Throughout Britain voluntary organisations co-operate in the conservation
of nature (and in many cases establish their own reserves or other specially
protected areas); these include: the National Trust, the Royal Society for
the Protection of Birds, the Society for the Promotion of Nature Reserves, the
County Naturalists Trusts and the Council for Nature (which consists of some
450 natural history and conservation societies).
8 HOUSING
Administration
There are some 19-2 million dwellings in Britain: over 16-9 million in England
and Wales, i*8 million in Scotland and 445,000 in Northern Ireland. Nation¬
ally the numbers of households and dwellings are about equal, but they are
unevenly distributed and local housing shortages persist in the more prosper¬
ous commercial and industrial centres, such as London and Birmingham.
The large majority of people in Great Britain—85 per cent in the 1966
sample census—live in houses or bungalows, mostly with gardens; the remain¬
der live in flats or maisonettes, normally in blocks of from two to 20 storeys.
High blocks of flats are built mainly in the central areas of large towns where
they replace old, congested housing and the land is expensive.
About a half of all dwellings in Britain are owned by their occupiers, some
30 per cent are rented from public housing authorities, and most of the
remainder are rented from private landlords (see diagram below). There are
variations, however, in the distribution of tenure between the different
countries of the United Kingdom—in Scotland more than half the dwellings
are rented from public authorities—and in different regions and areas of those
countries. Private rented accommodation is generally more common in the
central districts of large towns, while owner-occupation is more frequent in
their outer suburbs and in country areas.
New house construction in Britain is undertaken by both public and private
sectors. Of the 362,000 dwellings completed in i97°> rather more than half
were provided by public housing authorities, and the remainder by private
interests including voluntary housing associations and societies. Public housing
authorities provide dwellings mainly for renting, while private interests build
mainly for sale to owner-occupiers. The construction of private dwellings to
rent has dwindled to a very low level.
Over 7’5 million new dwellings have been built in Britain since 1945* anc^
more than one family in three now lives in a post-war dwelling (see diagram
below). There remain a large number of older dwellings, some of which have
been kept in good repair and modernised, while many others—particularly in
the centres of cities—are unsatisfactory by modern standards. A survey
carried out in 1967 established that out of a total stock of 15 ’7 million dwellings
in England and Wales, some i-8 million (12 per cent) were unfit, while a
further 4-5 million (29 per cent) lacked basic amenities or were in need of
repair. The demolition of slum dwellings and more advanced standards for
new house-building (particularly in the public sector) have, however, led to
significant improvements in the general quality of British housing. The average
size of houses has risen appreciably in the last 30 years and comparative Euro¬
pean statistics show that the degree of overcrowding in Britain (defined as more
than one and a half persons to a room) is lower than in most other countries.
Responsibility for formulating housing policy and supervising the housing
programme is borne by the Secretary of State for the Environment in England,
by the Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales, and by the Minister of
Development in Northern Ireland.

BY DATE OF CONSTRUCTION-GREAT
BRITAIN
In Great Britain most of the public housing is provided by the 1,600 local
housing authorities, which are responsible for ensuring that the supply of
housing in their areas is adequate. These are: in England and Wales, the
councils of county boroughs, boroughs, urban and rural districts; in London,
the Greater London Council, the London borough councils and the Common
Council of the City of London; and in Scotland, the town and county councils.
Other public housing authorities in Great Britain are the new town authorities
(see p.172) and the Scottish Special Housing Association (SSHA), which was
established in 1937 to supplement building by local authorities in Scotland
and builds mainly to support economic expansion in the development areas.
The central government departments specify certain standards for the
construction and equipment of new dwellings; these are enforced by the local
authorities. In the public sector, the government departments control the
numbers and costs of new dwellings through the exercise of loan approval for
local authority building schemes. Subsidies are made available to the authori¬
ties to assist them with housing costs, and guidance is given on design and
layout. The local housing authorities decide the details of expenditure
within the framework of controls, inducements, help and guidance provided by
the Government.
Besides providing public housing, local authorities are involved in many
other aspects of housing policy, including paying house improvement grants to
the private sector, and granting mortgages (see p. 183) to owner-occupiers.
Some carry out slum-clearance and redevelopment programmes. A growing
number are establishing housing advisory centres to provide the public with
information on local housing opportunities in both public and private sectors.
In Northern Ireland the housing responsibilities of local authorities are
being transferred to a new public body established in 1971—the Northern
Ireland Housing Executive (NIHE). The executive, which operates through
area boards and is assisted by an advisory council, will eventually have direct
responsibility for all public housing in Northern Ireland, including that owned
by the new town authorities and the Northern Ireland Housing Trust (a
public body responsible for about a quarter of the dwellings built annually).
During the period of transition, local authorities are continuing to provide
public housing as agents of the executive.

Policy
Research and
Development
Public Sector
Housing
Finance
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The main objectives of government housing policy are to secure a decent home
for every family at a price within its means, to offer families a fairer choice
between owning a home and renting one, and to ensure fairness between one
citizen and another in giving and receiving help towards housing costs. An
important part of this policy is to encourage, by subsidies, the provision of
adequate public sector housing at fair rents, in order to meet the needs of those
who, because of income or family circumstances, are unable to buy their own
homes.
Another major policy objective is to enable more people with moderate
means to become owner-occupiers, and this is encouraged by measures to
facilitate borrowing for house purchase (see p.183).
The Government is specially concerned to ensure that best use is made of
the existing housing stock. It offers financial assistance to local authorities and
(through them) to private owners to improve their houses (see p. 186).
In order to assist poorer tenants in paying rents, the Government is to
introduce a national scheme of rent rebates and allowances which will cover
tenants of all unfurnished accommodation in both public and private sectors.
Most local authorities already operate rebate schemes for their own tenants.
People without full-time work and with inadequate resources are assisted in
meeting housing costs by the Supplementary Benefits Commission of the
Department of Health and Social Security (see p. 132).
Research into building techniques and into new methods of house construc¬
tion, as well as into the needs of families, is carried out by the Research and
Development Groups of the Department of the Environment and the Scottish
Development Department, the Building Research Station, the architects
departments of major local authorities and the research groups in big con¬
structional firms. All government building research and development is co¬
ordinated by the Directorate-General of Research and Development within the
Department of the Environment. Advice on ways of increasing productivity in
housebuilding is given by the National Building Agency.
Public housing authorities in Britain own nearly 6 million houses and flats
and in 1970 completed about 188,000 new dwellings—rather more than half
the total house construction in the country. The number of houses owned
by each authority varies; some have less than 100, while, for example, the
Birmingham City Council has nearly 150,000. Authorities plan their own
building programmes within the framework of government policy.
Local authorities in Great Britain meet the capital costs of new house con¬
struction by raising loans on the open market or by borrowing from the Public
Works Loan Board (see p. 173). Current expenditure, including maintenance
costs and loan interest and repayments, is met from rents, supplemented by
subsidies from the Exchequer and sometimes (particularly in Scotland) from the
rates. Exchequer subsidies are designed to reduce to 4 per cent the interest
paid by all local authorities on loans raised to meet the approved capital cost
of dwellings. Plans to re-allocate subsidies in order to benefit those authorities
and tenants in greatest need have been outlined by the Government. #
Supplementary subsidies are paid for high building; to councils with in¬
sufficient resources to provide urgently needed houses; for houses required in
connection with a major transfer of industry; for expensive sites; for pre¬
cautions against subsidence; for building in certain materials; and for overspill.
Subsidies for the construction of public housing totalled some £120 million in
England and Wales in 1969-70, and over £30 in Scotland.

183
In Northern Ireland, the NIHE receives grants towards its current expendi¬
ture through the Ministry of Development. Capital expenditure is financed by
loans raised on the open market or borrowed from the Government Loans
Fund.
A high proportion of local authority tenants have incomes below the national
average and they include many elderly people living on pensions.
In selecting tenants for new or vacant dwellings, local authorities are
required to give preference to large families and to those living in overcrowded
or unsatisfactory conditions. Otherwise they are free to allocate houses accord¬
ing to their own schemes. Authorities normally establish waiting lists and treat
applicants (outside priority categories) in order of application; some require
applicants to fulfil residence requirements within the area before they are
accepted on waiting lists.
Local authorities are responsible for deciding the rents of the houses which
they own. In many areas, particularly in Scotland, rents are low in relation to
the economic cost of providing the housing. The average weekly rent in a local
authority dwelling in 1970 was ^2-23 in England and Wales and ^1*42 in
Scotland. In order to free resources to assist those in greatest need, the
Government is proposing to require local authorities to base their rents on the
fair-rent principle (see p. 185) and to introduce a system of rent rebates to
assist poorer tenants. In 1970, 83 per cent of tenants in England and Wales
were covered by rebate schemes and some 92 per cent in Scotland.
Although a number of authorities employ direct labour to build houses, most
building is undertaken by private firms under contract. Some authorities work
in consortia to make the best use of industrialised systems in their house
building programmes.
Dwellings are constructed to meet the needs of different sizes of household.
More than a quarter are of the single bedroom type suitable for smaller house¬
holds including the elderly, but the majority are designed for families of from
four to six people and have three bedrooms, two living rooms and a kitchen,
bathroom and lavatory. The standard of new local authority housing has
improved considerably in recent years, particularly in the floor space provided
and heating systems installed. In England and Wales in 1970 almost 90 per
cent of new dwellings had central heating, and houses built for families of
four or five people had a superficial area of 960 square feet (89 square metres)
and cost an average of £3,384 to build.
In 1970 more than 174,000 private sector dwellings were completed, almost all
of which were intended for owner-occupation. The number of people owning
their own houses has more than doubled in the last 20 years, and the 9^- million
owner-occupied dwellings in Britain now account for almost half of the total
housing stock. Although most owner-occupied houses were built for that
purpose, in recent years many private rented dwellings have been sold for
owner-occupation. Local and new town authorities are encouraged by the
Government to offer houses for sale to sitting tenants (at up to 20 per cent
discount on market prices) in order to increase the resources available for
housing those in need. The Government also encourages voluntary housing
societies which provide co-ownership housing (a form of tenure similar to
owner-occupation).
Loans to enable people to buy their houses by a system of instalment purchase
are available from various sources, including building societies, insurance
184
Financial
Assistance
Building
Standards
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
companies, industrial and provident societies and local authorities.
Building societies (see also p. 358) are the most important of these agencies.
They do not build houses themselves but provide long-term loans on the
security of property bought for owner-occupation. They usually advance 80
to 90 per cent of the value of the houses. Loans are repayable over periods of
up to 30 or even 35 years by equal monthly instalments to cover capital and
interest. The average price of houses mortgaged to building societies in 1970
was £4,975; houses in London and the south-east of England cost a third more
on average than those in the north-east, where property is cheapest in Britain.
The societies usually work on the principle that a person’s monthly payments
on housing (including rates) should not exceed one week’s income. In 1970
they advanced nearly £2,000 million.
Local authorities are expected to concentrate their mortgage resources on
helping people with special housing needs who are unable to obtain loans
elsewhere. Their mortgage lending in 1970 amounted to £154 million.
Owner-occupiers are entitled to tax relief on their mortgage interest payments,
and in 1970-71 this amounted to £302 million. Tax relief benefits most those
with larger taxable incomes, and in 1968 the Government introduced an
alternative form of assistance—the option mortgage scheme—designed to help
those with smaller incomes. Under the scheme, borrowers receive, through the
lending agency, a subsidy which reduces the rate of mortgage interest which
they pay by up to 3 per cent. Subsidy payments under the option mortgage
scheme amounted in 197^71 to £13 million. Associated with the scheme is the
option mortgage guarantee scheme, whereby mortgage loans of up to 100 per
cent of the valuation of a house (not exceeding £7,5°°) maY be made t0 those
participating.
In Northern Ireland, the Government pays lump sum subsidies to private
people who build dwellings for letting or owner-occupation.
For building in the private sector the National House Builders’ Registration
Council (NHBRC) sets standards and enforces them by inspection and
certification. Over 95 per cent of all new private houses carry a ten-year
guarantee against any major structural defect. A two-year guarantee is also
given against faulty workmanship. Most building societies do not grant
mortgages on a new house unless it is covered by a NHBRC certificate.
Privately During the last 20 years there has been a steady decline in the number of
Rented rented dwellings available from private landlords—from nearly 60 per cent in
Housing 1947 to about 15 per cent in 1970. Major factors in this decline have been the
increased demand for owner-occupation, the greater availability of public
rented housing, and the operation of rent restriction. Most privately rented
dwellings are let unfurnished, but an increasing proportion—about a sixth in
England and Wales—are now let furnished. While most landlords in Britain
are private individuals with limited holdings, a considerable proportion of all
privately rented housing is provided by the small number of larger property
owners, including property companies. .
Privately rented dwellings form a high proportion of Britain s older housing
and many have been demolished under slum clearance programmes. Of the
3 million dwellings remaining, three-quarters are 50 years old or more.
Rent Restrictions Most privately rented dwellings are subject to rent restriction under legislation
which provides separate machinery for dealing with furnished and unfurnished
accommodation. Tenants have a wide degree of security of tenure and eviction
Housing
Associations
and Societies
HOUSING 185
from any dwelling (without a court order) and harassment of occupiers are
criminal offences with severe penalties.
Rent restriction was originally introduced in 1915 as a temporary wartime
measure and successive Acts have varied its scope. In 1957, the Government
removed restrictions in Great Britain on all dwellings with a 1956 rateable
value of more than £30 (£40 in London and Scotland). Below these levels,
rent control continued to operate, and in England and Wales there remain
some 1 -3 million unfurnished dwellings whose rents are still controlled by
reference to 1956 rateable values, and in Scotland about 100,000 whose rents
are tied to historic rent levels. Controlled rents are very low by comparison
with other rents.
The Rent Act 1965 brought back into protection all unfurnished dwellings
with 1965 rateable values of less than ^200 (£400 in London). Tenancies pro¬
tected under the 1965 Act, which are not still ‘controlled’ under the earlier
legislation, are termed ‘regulated tenancies’. Under the Act a ‘fair rent’ may be
fixed for a regulated tenancy by independent rent officers at the request of the
landlord, the tenant, or both. Factors taken into account by rent officers in
determining rents include the age, character and locality of the house. To
eliminate any artificial value derived from scarcity, the assumption is made that
for similar dwellings to let in the area demand does not exceed supply. If the
landlord or tenant objects to the decision of the rent officer, the case is referred
to a rent assessment committee. Since 1965 some 200,000 applications to fix
fair rents have been made in Great Britain. Once determined, the rent is not
normally reviewed for at least three years.
Landlords of ‘controlled’ dwellings whose houses are of a satisfactory
standard, or who improve them to such a standard, are now able to convert
controlled tenancies into regulated ones, and the Government intends to
hasten transfer of the remaining tenancies into the rent regulation system.
For furnished dwellings under the 1965 rateable value limits, tenants or
landlords may refer tenancy agreements to a local rent tribunal for determina¬
tion of a reasonable rent. Tribunals may grant tenants security of tenure for up
to six months with a possibility of further periods if they so decide.
Most rent legislation for England and Wales has been consolidated in the
Rent Act 1968 and for Scotland in the Rent (Scotland) Act 1971.
Measures of control and de-control also apply in Northern Ireland. In 1951
and 1956 legislation was passed which permitted prescribed increases in the
rents of certain controlled houses. The 1956 Act also released from control
houses with a net annual value of over £50 (with certain safeguards) and houses
with a net annual value of over ^26 of which the landlord was in actual
possession when the Act came into force, or of which he subsequently obtained
possession.
Since the early 1960s the Government has done much to encourage the growth
of non-profit-making housing associations and societies.
Housing associations have long existed as voluntary bodies set up for the
purpose of providing low-rent housing for people in need. The Housing Act
1957 made money available to local authorities for the granting of up to 100
per cent loans to such associations. Further encouragement to housing associa¬
tions to purchase and convert old houses into new dwellings was offered by the
Housing Act 1969 which provided for a 20-year subsidy equivalent to three-
eighths of all charges (capital and interest) on loans raised for this purpose.
Housing societies build dwellings either for co-ownership by a group of
occupants or to let at unsubsidised rents. Following a pilot scheme introduced
i86
Improvement
of Houses
Slum Clearance
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
by the Housing Act 1961, the Housing Corporation was set up under the
Housing Act 1964 to stimulate the formation of such societies. Half of the
money needed for approved housing society schemes is advanced by building
societies, with the Housing Corporation providing the remainder. In 1969-70
housing societies completed over 6,300 dwellings a record number.
Private owners in Great Britain can obtain grants from local authorities to
improve their houses by providing amenities such as baths and for carrying
out other works to modernise their properties. Grants are also available for
converting large houses or other buildings into flats. The grant normally
amounts to half the approved cost of the works up to a grant limit of £1,000
(£1,200 in Scotland). If a house of three or more storeys is converted into
flats the upper limit of grant is £1,200 for each flat provided. A Government
contribution amounting to three-quarters of each grant is paid to the local
authority. Aid on a similar basis is given by the Government to local authorities
and housing associations, but this includes the cost of buying properties for
conversion and improvement as well as that of carrying out works. Under the
Housing Act 1971 increased grants have been made available for a tvo-year
period to private owners and local authorities within the development and
intermediate areas. _ u 1
Since improvement grants were first introduced in i949> more than i4
million dwellings in England and Wales and some 120,000 in Scotland have
been improved with their aid. In 1970 grants were approved for some 180,000
dwellings—a 50 per cent increase over the previous year. Grants for house
improvement are also provided in Northern Ireland.
In order to tackle systematically the improvement of whole areas of older
housing, local authorities in Great Britain have been given powers to declare
‘general improvement areas’. The aim in these areas is to encourage house¬
holders to improve their dwellings with the aid of grants, while the local
authority uses its comprehensive powers to improve the environment. A
government contribution is available of half the local authority s expenditure
on environmental improvements on costs of up to £100 a house.
Over 2^ million people have been rehoused since the mid-1950s as a result of
slum clearance programmes. Some housing authorities have eliminated all their
slums and others expect to achieve this within a very few years, but in certain
of the older industrial towns, including Birmingham, Glasgow, Liverpool and
Manchester, clearance may take longer. Local authorities with major slum and
overcrowding problems are being given priority by the Government which
intends to provide special assistance towards the cost of slum clearance. Their
house-building programmes have increased sharply in recent years and in
many cases the designation of new towns (see p. 172) nearby has further eased
their housing problems.
Housing authorities are obliged to see that other accommodation exists,, or
can be provided by them, for people displaced by slum clearance. The Housing
Act 1969 changed the basis of compensation paid to the displaced owner-
occupiers of unfit houses. Those subject to compulsory purchase orders now
in effect receive compensation to the full market value, while those subject to
clearance orders, who retain their land, receive a payment amounting to the
difference (if any) between the site value and the market value.
9 THE CHURCHES
The Church of
England
Every person living in Britain has the right of religious freedom and may mani¬
fest his faith in teaching, worship and observance without interference from
the community or the State. Churches and religious societies of all kinds may
own property, conduct schools, and propagate their beliefs in speech and in
writing. There is no religious or denominational bar to the holding of public
office, except in the case of the Lord Chancellor, where there is some doubt
whether existing statutory provisions would permit this office to be held by a
Roman Catholic.
In the services administered by the State, such as the armed forces, the
national hospitals and the prisons, the clergy of the established Church of
England or the Church of Scotland provide the principal ministrations and
are paid a salary by the State for this part of their work. Clergy of other de¬
nominations may also be appointed as required. Voluntary schools (see p. 150)
provided by churches of any religious denomination may be wholly or partly
maintained from public funds.
There is no precisely accurate or uniform method of assessing the number
of adherents to the various churches in Britain, since no enquiries are made
about religious beliefs in population censuses or other official returns, and each
church adopts its own criteria in counting its members. The membership
figures given in this chapter are therefore approximate.
The Church of England’s status as the established church of the land derives
from the Reformation in the sixteenth century; its form of worship is embodied
in the Book of Common Prayer, first compiled in 1549. The Church’s rela¬
tionship with the State1 is one of mutual obligation—privileges accorded to the
Church balanced by certain duties which it must fulfil. The Sovereign must
always be a member of the Church, and promises on his or her accession to up¬
hold it; Church of England archbishops, bishops and deans are appointed by
the Sovereign on the advice of the Prime Minister; all clergy take an oath of
allegiance to the Crown; the Church must obtain Parliament’s consent to
change its forms of worship (although it has temporary powers until 1980 to
use alternative forms without the need for parliamentary approval); and the
two archbishops (of Canterbury and York), the bishops of London, Durham
and Winchester, and 21 other bishops (according to their seniority as diocesan
bishops) have permanent seats in the House of Lords (see p. 32). Clergy of the
Church of England (together with those of the Church of Scotland, the Church
of Ireland and the Roman Catholic Church) are legally disqualified from sitting
in the House of Commons (see p. 34).
1 A church commission set up to consider the relationship between the Church of
England and the State has recommended in a report, Church and State (see Biblio¬
graphy p. 474), that, while the establishment of the Church should be maintained, the
Church should be given final authority over its forms of worship and doctrine; altera¬
tions should be made in the present procedure for the appointment of bishops; ministers
of all churches should be permitted to stand for election to the House of Commons and,
if elected, to take their seats; and leading members of other churches should be invited
to sit alongside Church of England bishops in the House of Lords.

Church
Organisation
and Government
Church Finance
The Anglican
Communion
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Church is organised into 43 dioceses, grouped into two provinces:
Canterbury, comprising 29 dioceses, and York, 14 dioceses. The dioceses are
subdivided into ecclesiastical parishes, of which there are some 14,300. The
Archbishop of Canterbury is styled ‘Primate of All England’, and the Arch¬
bishop of York is ‘Primate of England’. Of the population born and resident in
the two provinces, about three-fifths (27-6 million) are baptised into the Church
and almost one-fifth (9-9 million) are confirmed members.
The central governing body of the Church, the General Synod, is invested
with both spiritual authority and legislative and administrative powers; and
bishops, clergy and lay members are equally involved in decisions affecting the
whole range of the Church’s concern. Deanery and diocesan synods give
advice on church affairs and involve the parishes in church life. Certain impor¬
tant issues must be referred for the approval of the dioceses before they are
finally decided by the General Synod. Lay members of the Church are
associated with church government in the parishes through parochial church
councils whose members are appointed by baptised members of the Church
over the age of 16 who are on the church electoral roll of their local parish:
the estimated number on the rolls is some 2-5 million.
The General Synod is the centre of an administrative system dealing with
various aspects of the Church’s work—such as education, recruitment and
training for the ministry, and church work at home and overseas. It is re¬
sponsible for the Church of England schools (more than one in nine of the 8
million pupils in the maintained schools of England and Wales in 1970 at¬
tended the Church’s maintained schools); about 40 direct grant and 45 inde¬
pendent Church of England schools; some 25 church colleges of education in
England and two in Wales, providing places for more than 18,500 students;
theological colleges; and establishments for the training of women in pastoral
work.
The Church has its own courts whose jurisdiction today extends only to
matters of purely ecclesiastical concern.
Church finance is administered locally by the parishes and the dioceses, with
contributions to a central General Synod Fund which the Central Board of
Finance administers for the maintenance of central services, including capital
expenditure on training and theological colleges and grants for training can¬
didates for ordination. (Although the State pays for or contributes towards
services provided by the Church—see p. 187—it makes no direct financial contri¬
bution to church expenses as such.) The Church’s endowment income (from
its assets amounting to over £416 million in land and investments) is mainly
administered by the Church Commissioners, the body largely responsible for
the payment of clergy stipends and the provision of finance for pensions. The
total net income (^24-5 million in 1969-70) has greatly increased in recent
years—in broad terms this has meant a rise in the stipends of the poorer
clergy and the introduction of schemes for better parsonage houses, for church
buildings in new areas of population, and for better pensions for clergymen and
their widows.
The Anglican Communion comprises 21 autonomous provinces in Britain and
overseas and two regional councils overseas with a total membership of over
47 million. In the British Isles, in addition to the established Church of
England, there are other, unestablished, Anglican churches: the Church in
Wales, the Episcopal Church in Scotland, and the Church of Ireland.
Every ten years (most recently in 1968) the Lambeth Conference meets for
THE CHURCHES
The Church of
Scotland
The Free
Churches
189
unofficial consultation between all Anglican bishops; presided over by the
Archbishop of Canterbury, it has no executive authority, but enjoys great
moral prestige, and its findings on doctrine, discipline, relations with other
communions, and attitudes to political and social questions are widely studied.
The Anglican Consultative Council—an assembly of laymen and clergy as well
as bishops which meets every two years—is designed to provide consultations
within the Anglican Communion and to serve as an instrument of common
action.
The Church of Scotland, established by law, has a presbyterian form of
government. It has been described as ‘the supreme example of a church which
is established and yet is free’. It derives its status from the Treaty of Union
1707 and the Church of Scotland Act 1921 which confirmed its complete
freedom in all spiritual matters. The Church appoints its own officers and its
decisions on questions of doctrine and discipline are not subject to parliamen¬
tary discussion or modification.
All ministers of the Church of Scotland are of equal status, each of some
2,000 churches being governed locally by the Kirk Session, consisting of the
minister and the elected elders of the church; above the Kirk Session is the
Court of the Presbytery, then the Court of the Synod, and finally the General
Assembly, consisting of elected ministers and elders, which meets annually
under the presidency of an elected moderator who serves for one year. The
Sovereign is represented at the General Assembly by the Lord High Com¬
missioner.
The training for the ministry (to which women may be admitted) has given
the Church a high reputation for scholarship and has in turn influenced the
standard of education in Scotland. The membership of the Church of Scot¬
land is estimated at about 1 -2 million.
The phrase ‘Free Churches’ is commonly used to describe the ‘nonconformist’
churches of England (which dissent from certain practices of the established
church and, generally speaking, have distinctive convictions regarding organisa¬
tion and worship) and protestant churches in other parts of Britain (apart from
the established Church of Scotland). Certain other churches and religious
associations have links with the main Free Churches.
The Methodist Church, the largest of the Free Churches with some 651,000
adult full members, originated in the eighteenth century following the evan¬
gelical revival by John Wesley, and is nowadays based on a 1932 union of most
of the separate Methodist Churches. The Methodist Churches which did not
join the union include the Independent Methodists (over 6,500 members) and
the Wesleyan Reform Union (with some 4,800 members).
The Congregationalists with an adult membership of about 170,000 are the
oldest community of dissenters in Britain; their churches were formed into the
Congregational Union in 1831 (reconstituted in 1966 as the Congregational
Church in England and Wales).
The Baptists are nearly all grouped in associations of churches, most of
which belong to the Baptist Union (formed in 1813), within which some 2,200
churches have a total membership of about 207,000; in addition there are about
62,300 members of churches in the separate Baptist Unions of Scotland and
Ireland and other Baptist churches.
Among the other Free Churches are the unestablished Presbyterian Churches
which include the Presbyterian Church in Ireland (with some 143,000 regular
communicants in Northern Ireland); the Presbyterian (or Calvinistic Method-
[QO BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
ist) Church of Wales, which arose from the revivalist movement led in 1735
by Howell Harris and now numbers some 110,000; the Presbyterian Church of
England which has about 61,000 members; the Free Church of Scotland; the
United Free Church of Scotland; the Free Presbyterian Church of Scotland;
the Reformed Presbyterian Church of Scotland; the Reformed Presbyterian
Church of Ireland; and the Non-Subscribing Presbyterian Church of Ireland.
Other protestant denominations in Britain include: the Unitarian and Free
Christian Churches; the Churches of Christ (known also in the United States
of America as Disciples of Christ), which have been an organised community
in Britain since early in the nineteenth century; the British Province of the
Moravian Church, which is an international missionary church; and the Free
Church of England (or Reformed Episcopal Church), which was formed in
1844 as a direct result of the Oxford Movement. The Society of Friends
(Quakers)—with nearly 21,000 members in Britain—came into being in the
middle of the seventeenth century under the leadership of George Fox and
works for peace and the relief of suffering in many parts of the world. The
Salvation Army, founded in Britain in 1865, has since spread to 74 other
countries. Within Britain it has some 100,000 active members operating from
more than 1,000 centres of worship and a total community strength of about
350,000. Believing in a very practical expression of Christian concern, the
Salvation Army also has 191 centres providing daily help for some 10,000
people in need.
Also there are a number of other religious organisations with churches or
assemblies in Britain, including the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day
Saints (the Mormon Church) with about 85,000 members, and the Christian
Scientists with some 320 branch churches and societies.
The Roman The Roman Catholic hierarchy in England and Wales, which became tem-
Catholic Church porarily extinct during the sixteenth century, was restored in 1850; the Scottish
hierarchy became extinct in the early seventeenth century and was restored in
1878. There are now seven Roman Catholic provinces in Great Britain, each
under an archbishop, 20 episcopal dioceses, and nearly 2,400 parishes. In
Northern Ireland, there are six dioceses, some of which have territory partly in
the Irish Republic. It is estimated that there are some six million adherents
(including children) to the Roman Catholic faith in the whole of Britain.
The Roman Catholic Church attaches great importance to the education of
its children in their own faith, and requires that the children of marriages
between its own members and members of any other denomination should be
brought up as Roman Catholics. Many schools for Roman Catholic children
in Britain are staffed by members of the religious orders for men and women,
who also undertake other social work such as nursing, child care, and the con¬
duct of homes for old people.
Jewry Jews first settled in England at the time of the Norman conquest, but were
expelled at the end of the thirteenth century by an edict of Edward I. The
Anglo-Jewish community in Britain dates from 1656; consisting of some 410,000
people, including both Sephardi (originally from Spain and Portugal) and
Ashkenazi (from Germany and Eastern Europe), it has become one of the lar¬
gest groups of Jews in Europe. The community is divided into two schools of
thought—the Orthodox, to which about 90 per cent of practising Jews belong;
and the Reform, which originated in 1840 and was followed in 1901 by the
Liberal Jewish movement. The Chief Rabbi is the head of the largest group
(Ashkenazi) within Orthodox Jewry; the Haham is the head of the Sephardi
Other Religious
Communities
Co-operation
among the

THE CHURCHES IQ1
group. Synagogues in Britain number about 300. There has been an increase
in the number of Jewish denominational schools, which are now attended by
about one in five Jewish children.
Immigrants to Britain from overseas Commonwealth and foreign countries
have established centres for worship, especially in London, for their own com¬
munities. Among the Christian communities represented are Orthodox,
Lutheran and Reformed Churches of various European countries and the
Armenian Church.
The principal non-Christian communities in Britain, apart from the Jews,
are the Muslims and the Buddhists. The Muslims are the more widely repre¬
sented, their number in Britain being estimated at several hundred thousand.
There are mosques or Islamic centres in London, Manchester, Liverpool,
Bradford, Cardiff and in many of the other larger cities in Britain.
Buddhism has several thousand adherents in Britain. The Buddhist Society
has its headquarters in London, with a Shrine Room and a Buddhist library
claimed to be one of the finest in Europe; there are also Shrine Rooms in the
three Viharas in London, one of which is run by Thai monks and supported
by the Thai Government. In Scotland there is a Shrine Room at the Tibetan
Centre.
The British Council of Churches, composed of representatives or consultant
observers from all the main Christian churches in the British Isles, facilitates
common action among the churches and seeks to further Christian unity.
The Free Church Federal Council (which has a concordat with the British
Council of Churches) comprises most of the Free Churches in England and
Wales and aims to promote unity and joint action among the Free Churches
and to provide a channel for communication with central and local govern¬
ment authorities.
The Anglican-Roman Catholic Permanent Joint Commission explores points
of possible unity between the two Churches. Proposals for union between the
Anglican and Methodist Churches, which have gained a large measure of
support, have not yet been finally accepted. A union between the Congrega¬
tional Church in England and Wales and the Presbyterian Church of England
has also been proposed.
The Anglican and the main Free Churches in the British Isles also partici¬
pate in the World Council of Churches, which links together nearly 240
churches in over 70 countries for co-operation and the study of common prob¬
lems. The Council of Christians and Jews works for better understanding
among members of the two religions and deals with problems in the social field.
The New English Bible, a translation into modern English completed in
1970, is the result of co-operation among many of the Christian churches in
Britain.
The Sharing of Church Buildings Act 1969 enables agreements to be made by
two or more churches for the sharing of church buildings.
lO THE NATIONAL
ECONOMY
Earlier
Development
of the Economy
BACKGROUND
Britain ranks about 75th in size among the countries of the world, with
about 0-18 per cent of the world’s land area. In population, approaching
2 per cent of the world’s inhabitants, it ranks tenth. In density of population
it is fourth: of the major countries, only Japan, Belgium and the Netherlands
are more crowded; and there are nine times as many people to the square
mile in the United Kingdom as in the United States. In terms of national
income per head it ranks appreciably below the United States and also below
Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Sweden and Switzerland, and slightly
below France and the Federal Republic of Germany. In world trade, it
ranks third, accounting for over 11 per cent of the total. It takes over 20 per
cent of the world’s exports of primary products, and provides over 12 per
cent of the world’s exports of manufactured goods.
Britain, from its own soil, provides only about half of the food it needs,
an(l—apart from coal, low-grade iron ore and natural gas—it has been able to
exploit few natural resources; thus it is one of the world’s largest importers of
such products as wheat, meat, butter, fodder grains, fruit, tea, tobacco, wool,
and timber. In return, it is one of the world s largest exporters of aircraft,
motor vehicles, electrical equipment, chemicals, textiles and most types of
machinery. No other major country has such a small proportion of the working
population engaged in agriculture (about 3 per cent).
Britain is also a major financial centre and British banks, insurance under¬
writers and brokers and other financial institutions provide financial services
throughout the world. The City of London provides perhaps the most
comprehensive and advanced service for a capital market in the world.
The total external assets owned by the British Government and British
residents are estimated at about £20,000 million.
During the nineteenth century Britain secured a leading position as world
manufacturer, merchant, carrier, banker, and investor and supported a
rapidly increasing population at a rising standard of living. In the period from
1870 to 1890 British industry had a clear lead over that of other countries.
Between 1890 and 1914, industrial competition from Europe and North
America grew, but its effects on Britain’s export industries, particularly cotton
textiles and coal, were offset by the rise in world trade, by the demand for
British textiles from India and other eastern countries and by the earnings of
British shipping and financial services and the returns on Britain s large over¬
seas investments.
After the first world war Britain’s older industries met increasing competi¬
tion, for example, coal and iron and steel from other European countries and
textiles from some eastern countries where labour was cheaper. At the same
time Britain failed at first to gain a compensating share of world trade in the
newer types of engineering products. Some countries sought deliberately to
protect young and even established industries by tariffs and (later) quotas and
exchange restrictions. The result was heavy unemployment in Britain’s older
THE NATIONAL ECONOMY
193
Effects of
the Second
World War
The Post-war
Period
industries, the national rate averaging 14 per cent in the years 1921-29, and
rising above this in the years following the collapse of the American stock
market in 1929, reaching a peak of 22 per cent in 1932, when the associated
slump in world trade was at its worst. In some districts relying mainly on the
most heavily affected industries the rate was much higher. Income from
invisible earnings (for example on overseas investments, shipping and
insurance) and relatively cheap imports, particularly food, however, cushioned
the effects of the fall in the volume of exports.
After 1932 levels of production and employment improved, stimulated by
an increase in home investment which was aided by the policy of cheap
money, by some revival in world trade and, after 1935, by the armament
programme. The decade saw a strong expansion in the vehicles, electrical,
chemicals and aircraft industries, while the construction of 3 million houses
brought about a large growth in the building and ancillary industries. By
1937 average real income per head was about 14 per cent higher than in
1929.
In spite of generous aid from the United States and Canada, the second
world war ran down British domestic capital by about £3,000 million,
through shipping losses, bomb damage, and arrears of industrial maintenance
and replacements. Some £1,000 million worth of overseas investments were
sold, nearly half in North America, and new external debts of £3,000 million
were accumulated. By 1944 exports had fallen to less than one-third of their
1938 volume.
After the second world war rationing and other war-time controls were
relaxed gradually as civil production expanded and trade recovered. The
abolition of quantitative restrictions on imports, other than from the dollar
area, was largely completed by 1955. Exchange controls on transactions
between the sterling area and the rest of the world were also progressively
lifted, and in 1958 convertibility of sterling on current account for all non¬
residents was introduced.
The period since 1945 has been one of rising production and living
standards and a relatively low level of unemployment. Economic growth, how¬
ever, has been rather slower and more intermittent than in most other western
Europe countries and there have been certain persistent economic problems,
especially repeated crises in the balance of payments particularly during
periods of relatively rapid economic growth. In spite of the contribution from
invisibles, there were in a number of years substantial deficits on current
account transactions with the rest of the world and a low level of reserves
meant there was little room for manoeuvre.
Successive governments sought to deal with these difficulties in three main
ways: by monetary and fiscal measures aimed at restraining the growth of
home demand; by advice and exhortation—and for a time the use of certain
limited powers—to try to restrain rises in incomes and prices; and by measures
having a direct effect on the balance of payments (see, for example, p. 197).
In the years leading up to 1967 a gradual and serious deterioration in the
balance of payments led to a loss of overseas confidence in sterling. To meet
the situation, the Government devalued sterling in November 1967 from
$2.80 to $2.40=£1. It then proceeded to take a number of fiscal, monetary
and administrative measures to restrain increases in expenditure, prices and
incomes. A major reorientation of the economy was in fact achieved. In the
three years following devaluation there was a massive switch of resources into
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
the balance of payments. The volume of exports of goods and services
increased about four times as fast as the gross domestic product. In con¬
sequence the balance of payments improved rapidly during 1969 and in 1970
the surplus on current transactions was more than £600 million.
Economic growth, after a brief spurt in 1968, declined and the level of
unemployment rose. Wages and prices continued to increase in spite of
government exhortations and some statutory control, a high bank rate,
restraints on lending and a higher level of total taxation. Towards the end of
1969 the rise in incomes and in 1970 the rise in prices began to accelerate.
Current The combination of sluggish economic growth and under-employment of
Problems resources with a rapid rise in prices and incomes and a highly favourable
and Policies balance of payments was a new situation; and the Conservative government
which took office in June 1970 was pledged to tackle it with new policies aimed
at stimulating economic growth by a reduction both in taxation and in the
share of resources taken up by public expenditure. Since the autumn of 1970
tax reductions amounting to some £1,100 million in 1971-72 and £1,400
million in 1972-73 have been introduced.
At the same time new policies towards industry and agriculture have been
introduced. The changes include a move towards a different system of agri¬
cultural support through levies on imports rather than subsidies to farmers
(see p. 272); new priorities for regional assistance (see p. 213); the use of tax
allowances rather than outright grants as investment incentives (see p. 343);
and the abolition of some of the bodies through which government advice,
assistance and intervention have been channelled.
Following a major reorganisation the number of public bodies with broad
economic responsibilities on a national scale is now relatively small. The
government departments concerned are primarily five: the Treasury with its
responsibility for public and national finance; the Department of Trade and
Industry which is responsible for government policy on all aspects of industry
and trade; the Department of Employment; the Ministry of Agriculture,
Fisheries and Food; and the Department of the Environment with its specific
responsibilities for transport and building and its general responsibility for all
the relevant factors of environment and amenity.
An important advisory body on general economic policy is the National
Economic Development Council, which brings together representatives of
government, management and trade unions under the chairmanship of the
Prime Minister. It has an independent but publicly financed secretariat and
has established a number of economic development committees dealing with
different industries and services and different aspects of industry. Other
bodies responsible for advice on specific aspects of policy include the National
Joint Advisory Council (on labour matters, see p. 406), the Monopolies Com¬
mission (on action to prevent the abuse of monopoly power, see p. 202) and
the Office of Manpower Economics (provides the secretariat for bodies advising
on certain wages and salaries in the public sector and undertakes research on
pay questions generally). .
Final responsibility for the broad lines of economic policy rests with the
Cabinet (see p. 45) which alone can take into account all the political, social
and economic considerations. There has for some time been a system of inter¬
departmental committees designed to help in co-ordinating departmental
policies in each of the main areas of government concern and to ensure that
final decisions command the agreement of the Cabinet as a whole. In 1970 a
Central Policy Review Staff, a small multi-disciplinary body, was established
Incomes and
Prices
OUTPUT AND
EMPLOYMENT
THE NATIONAL ECONOMY 195
within the Cabinet Office itself to work under the supervision of the Prime
Minister on the formulation and review of overall government strategy.
The main factor pushing up prices in 1970 was the excessive rate of increase
in pay settlements, which had begun in the autumn of 1969. By the early
months of 1971 there were signs that the rate of increase had been checked.
During 1970 export prices of manufactures rose faster than those of Britain’s
main competitors, but the devaluation advantage was broadly maintained to
the end of the year.
The present Government declared itself opposed to the statutory control of
prices and incomes tried under the previous Government. It believed that, in
the longer term, reliance must be placed on the firmness of employers (in¬
cluding public authorities) in resisting unreasonable wage claims and in the
good sense of trade union leaders as they came to realise that such wage claims
were pushing up prices and contributing to unemployment among their
members. It expected that these factors together with its new industrial
relations legislation (see p. 407), would in time lead to a much greater price
stability. In the meantime monetary and fiscal policies were designed to
secure a rate of growth of output in line with production potential, so avoiding
the addition of demand pressures to the existing cost inflations.
THE FRAMEWORK OF THE ECONOMY
The following sections sketch briefly the salient features of Britain’s national
economy in recent years.
In 1970 Britain’s gross national product at factor cost (the measure of the
value of total goods and services produced at home and net income from
abroad) is estimated to have totalled £42,819 million. In real terms, that is,
after allowing for price changes, the increase over the 10 years since i960 was
about 29 per cent.
About a third of this output can be attributed to manufacturing industry
and this proportion has remained more or less constant for the past 12 years.
The relatively rapidly expanding sectors are gas, electricity and water (from
2-7 per cent in 1959 to 3-1 per cent in 1970) and services (financial, health and
educational, professional and personal) from 17-5 per cent to 22-6 per cent.
Agriculture, forestry and fishing account for a small and very slowly declining
share (about 3 per cent), and mining for a small and rapidly declining share
(under 2 per cent compared with over 3 per cent in 1959). The relative con¬
tributions of the distribution sector and the transport and communications
sector have changed little in the past 12 years and are now about 11 per cent
and 8-3 per cent respectively.
Within the large manufacturing sector, some industries—especially those
producing new, technically advanced and rapidly developing products—have
been expanding (for example, office machinery, computers, instrumentation,
aircraft and aircraft engines, and glass), while others, including traditional
industries such as cotton textiles, have been in decline. In general the speeding
up of technical progress in industry has in Britain as in other industrially
advanced countries brought with it a number of human problems. There are
problems of labour supply and unemployment. In London, the south-east
and the midlands, where expansion and change have been most rapid, there
have been shortages of certain types of professional, technical and craft skills
and the general unemployment rate (the ratio of those unemployed and seeking
BRITAIN 19721 AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
employment to those in or seeking employment) has stayed at a very low
level compared with the rest of the country. These low unemployment rates
in the greatest concentrations of population helped to keep the average un¬
employment rate for Britain under 2 per cent in most years from 1948 to 1967.
Since 1967 the rate has been over 2 per cent and was over 3 per cent in the
early months of 1971. On the other hand, in areas which were formerly
largely dependent on a single traditional industry, such as coalmining or
cotton textiles, or on certain types of heavy engineering now less in demand,
there have been serious pockets of long-term unemployment, some of which
have tended to persist in spite of special measures to encourage additional
employment in the area. The general unemployment rates in Northern
Ireland, Scotland, Wales and the northern and certain other parts of England
have thus been considerably above the national average and it is in these less
fortunate areas that the recent increases in unemployment have been most
marked.

As a proportion of gross national product at factor cost fixed capital formation is
now over 20 per cent as compared with 15 per cent in 1951. The total value of
fixed assets in Britain, valued at constant replacement cost, is estimated to have
more than doubled between 1948 and 1970 when their current replacement
value, net of depreciation, was estimated at £117$00 million, of which approxi¬
mately two-thirds was accounted for by buildings and one-third by vehicles,
plant, and machinery. , r , ,
Of total investment in 1970, 9° Per cent was accounted for by domestic
fixed capital formation, 4-6 per cent by physical increase of stocks and work in
progress and 5-8 per cent by investment overseas. Of net domestic fixed capital
formation, 33 per cent was in plant and machinery, 42-5 per cent in buildings
(including land and existing buildings but excluding dwellings) and works,
19*5 per cent in dwellings and 5 per cent in vehicles. By sector, about 52 per
cent was in the private sector and about 48 per cent in the public sector,

Public

including central Government, local government and nationalised industries.
By industry group, about 21*4 per cent was in manufacturing industry, and
about 13-4 per cent in the public services. Within the manufacturing sector, the
largest investments were in the chemical and allied industries, the engineering
industries and the food, drink and tobacco. The most marked trends in
recent years have been the increases in investment in the chemicals and textile
industries (reflecting respectively the expansion of petrochemicals and the
growth of synthetics), the gas supply industry (mainly provisions for natural
gas).
The rising levels of investment have been financed by saving in all the
main sectors of the economy, though, despite increases in local rates and in
grants from the central Government, the current surpluses of local authorities
have been sufficient to provide for only a quarter of their capital needs so
that the rest has had to be met by short- and long-term borrowing from the
Government or elsewhere. The central Government has increased its current
surplus sufficiently to finance a considerable proportion of its own capital
expenditure, make capital grants to industry, lend large sums (mainly to public
corporations) and, since 1969, repay a substantial amount of debt. It has in¬
creased its current surplus (before providing for depreciation) from £496
million in 1964 to £3,738 million in 1970. The public corporations, largely
because of their big investment programmes, have, despite payment of
subsidies (particularly to the transport corporations), been heavily dependent
on borrowing from the central Government. The companies’ sector, though a
large gross saver, is also a large investor and though in most years it has
covered its investment from its savings, this was not so in 1969 or 1970. In the
latter year over a quarter of its investment within Britain was financed by
borrowing or the sale of financial assets. The personal sector has shown a large
if fluctuating excess of saving over acquisition of fixed assets (mainly dwellings).
Increasingly the main forms of financial assets acquired by the personal sector
are insurance policies, interests in pension funds, building society shares and
bank deposits, while the most important and rapidly increasing financial
liabilities of this sector are loans on house mortgages from building societies.
Current expenditure on goods and services by the central Government
(including the national insurance funds) and the local authorities rose by
50 per cent at current prices over the period 1965 to 1970 in spite of numerous
measures taken to restrain its growth and in the latter year amounted to about
21 per cent of the gross national product. The main cause of this increase was
the continuing growth of the social services, especially education. Defence has
recently accounted for a declining share of public expenditure on goods and
services—27 per cent in 1970 compared with 34 per cent in 1965 and a post¬
war peak of over 50 per cent in 1953*
In addition to their expenditure on goods and services, public authorities
transfer large sums to other sectors, mainly the personal sectors, by way of
national insurance and other social security benefits, grants, and interest and
subsidies. The Government also makes grants to local authorities to finance
about 50 per cent of their current expenditure, but this is a transfer between
public authorities and does not affect the position of the public authorities as
a whole in relation to the rest of the country.
In the period following the 1967 devaluation the Government initiated a
programme of substantial increases in taxation and reductions in public
expenditure in order to curtail home demand and permit a switch of resources
into exports. By 1970 the total of Government taxes on income and expendi-

1970 it had a net borrowing requirement of only fn million. Changes in
the 1971 budget were expected to reduce the public sector’s current surplus
from £5,101 million to £4,568 million in the 1971-72 financial year, increasing
the expected borrowing requirement from £666 million to £1,209 million.
Personal incomes before tax at current prices rose rapidly and fairly steadily
for 22 years from £9,955 million in 1948 to £42,833 million in 1970—a
compound rate of nearly 7 per cent a year. The increase in consumer expen¬
diture per head of population at constant prices has, however, been very much
lower—about 2 per cent per annum. The difference is accounted for mainly
by rising prices and to a lesser extent by the growth of population, a higher
incidence of direct taxation and increased personal savings.
Income from employment in 1970 totalled £30,487 million and accounted
for 71 per cent of total personal income (against 60 per cent in 1938). The
three other main sources of personal income were self employment (8 per
cent), income from property (11 per cent), and grants from public authorities
(10 per cent). The general pattern of income distribution is thus dominated
by the pattern for income from employment. The effects of property income,
which tends to add to the income of the already affluent, are relatively slight
and to some extent counterbalanced by the effect of grants from public
authorities to those in need.
British direct taxation falls heavily on the rich and the combined effect of
taxation and transfer payments and benefits in kind is a redistribution of
income on more egalitarian lines. According to studies by the Central Statis¬
tical Office, the effect in 1969 was to raise the average income of the poorest
fifth of families from 35 to 53 per cent of the average for all families. There are
a number of theoretical and practical limitations to these studies, but the
broad result is too marked to be in dispute.
PERSONAL INCOME AND EXPENDITURE, 1970
(In £ million at current prices)
National insurance benefits
The rise in the volume of consumer expenditure per head has been accom¬
panied, in Britain as in other advanced industrial countries, by changes in
the pattern of that expenditure. The proportion devoted to food has been
falling slightly each year and in 1970 accounted for about 20-5 per cent of
consumer expenditure at current prices compared with 26 per cent in 1958.
On the other hand the proportions spent on housing and fuel and light
together rose from 14 per cent to 17-5 per cent.
11 INDUSTRY
The Structure
of Industry
Manufacturing
ORGANISATION AND PRODUCTION
The United Kingdom was the first country in the world to become highly
industrialised, and today thirteen people work in mining, manufacturing and
building for every one engaged in agriculture. It is the world s third largest
exporter of manufactured goods, and the range of its industrial manufactures
reflects its position as one of the most important workshops of the world.
The pattern of ownership and organisation in industry is varied. Personal,
corporate, co-operative and public enterprise all assume a number of different
forms, and all are important in the economy. Industrial enterprises vary from
the many small workshops to vast organisations such as the National Coal
Board, a public corporation with about 530,000 employees ; Imperial Chemical
Industries Ltd., a limited liability company which, with its subsidiaries,
employs 197,000 persons in the United Kingdom; and the Co-operative
Wholesale Society Ltd., with about 35,000 employees.
Most manufacturing is in the hands of private enterprise. Exceptions include
fissile materials and radioactive isotopes made by two statutory companies,
iron, steel and a small range of chemicals from the plants of the British Steel
Corporation, locomotives and rolling-stock built in the workshops of British
Railways, and military equipment and supplies made in establishments of the
defence services. Staff of the Stationery Office do some printing and book¬
binding. Certain factories giving employment to the severely disabled are
operated by Remploy Ltd., a non-profit-making public company financed on
the Vote of the Department of Employment, which appoints the directors
(see p. 394). The Government holds about 49 per cent of the equity of a major
oil company, British Petroleum Limited, and has a controlling interest in a
few other companies. _
The most recent analysis of the size distribution of establishments and
enterprises in manufacturing industry, and of the degree of concentration, is
contained in the Report of the Census of Production 1963. This shows that some
cy per cent (52,000) of the 90,000 or so establishments which submitted returns
had fewer than 25 employees each, and accounted for only 6 per cent of total
employment; some 30,000 establishments, one-third of the total, had between
25-500 employees, and accounted for over two-fifths of the total labour force;
2 400 establishments, each with between 500 and 2,000 employees, were
responsible for 28 per cent of employment; while 19 per cent was m the hands
of the 430 leading groups each with over 2,000 employees. A high proportion
of the biggest establishments were in the heavy industries; the average size
of establishments in industries making consumer goods was smaller than in
manufacturing industries as a whole. Comparisons with results obtained in
earlier years suggested a slow but significant trend towards increased average
size of establishments. ... r 1 • c
The size of establishments is not in itself an indication of the size of manu¬
facturing enterprises, as a single enterprise may own several establishments,
not all of them necessarily engaged in the same or similar activities.

201

Mining and
