Monopolies and
Restrictive
Practices
An enterprise, as defined in the 1963 census, normally consists of either a
single firm or a parent company together with its subsidiaries. Just over 60 per
cent of all employment in British manufacturing industries in 1963 was
accounted for by about 975 large private enterprises employing 1,000 or more
people, the largest too or so accounting roughly for a third. A further indica¬
tion of company size is the value of capital employed (net assets). For a few of
the very largest, including the Imperial Chemical Industries group, British
Petroleum and Shell Transport and Trading, the figure exceeds ^1,500
million; about 65 companies registered in Britain have over £100 million net
assets.
With intensified competition in the economy and in many branches of
industry the growing dependence of profitable operation on concentration and
an increasing scale of production, the trend towards mergers and regroupings
gathered momentum throughout the 1960s. Larger units of control have been
established in almost all the leading industries and in some a small number of
big companies and their subsidiaries are responsible for most of total produc¬
tion. Examples are, oil refining, non-ferrous metal smelting, motor vehicles
and aircraft, electrical engineering, electronics, machine tools, brewing,
textiles, basic chemicals, tobacco and magazine publishing. Shares in these
companies are usually distributed among a great number of holders and it is
rare for a few large holders to have a controlling interest. For example, five of
the largest public companies each have more than 100,000 shareholders.
An account of some of the principal manufacturing industries is given on
pp. 235-60.
In building and civil engineering, large-scale work is usually carried out by
private contractors, although the Department of the Environment (see p. 51)
is the largest single employer of building labour while some 45 per cent of the
industry’s output is for public authorities. Building firms may be divided into
those undertaking general building and civil engineering work and those con¬
cerned with highly specialised work, many of which operate outside as well as
inside the building industry. Building is an industry of small firms; almost
three-quarters of the firms employ fewer than 20 employees. For a fuller
account of the building and civil engineering industries, see p. 233.
Much the most important of the British extractive industries is coalmining.
The coalmining industry of Great Britain (see p. 216) is operated as a single
co-ordinated enterprise under National Coal Board direction (see p. 217).
Nearly all other mining and quarrying (sand, gravel, chalk, limestone, salt,
tin, slate, oil shale and china clay) is undertaken by private enterprises, usually
owned and operated by limited liability companies; about 59,000 workers are
employed, excluding coalmining.
Legislation exists for scrutinising and, if desirable, for the investigation by an
independent administrative body of monopoly situations and for the judicial
examination of restrictive trading agreements.
The Restrictive Trade Practices Acts 1956 and 1968 govern the registration
and judicial examination of restrictive agreements. They require the entry in
a public register of the particulars of a wide range of restrictive agreements
(including those relating to common prices, approved lists of dealers and the
limitation of production) which affect the supply or processing of goods for
the United Kingdom market. Proposed agreements of national importance
which promote efficiency or provide for new productive capacity, can be
exempted from this requirement for a specified period by the Secretary of
202
Role of Public
Enterprise
BRITAIN AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
State for Trade and Industry (see p. 209). The Registrar of Restrictive Trading
Agreements is responsible for keeping the register and for bringing the agree¬
ments before the Restrictive Practices Court set up under the 1956 Act. The
Court, which includes laymen but is presided over by one of Her Majesty’s
judges, is, in effect, responsible for deciding whether an agreement is in the
public interest. If the parties to an agreement fail to satisfy the Court that
special circumstances set out in the legislation exist, and that the restriction is
not unreasonable, having regard to the balance between the benefit it confers
and any public detriment likely to result from its operation, that restriction
must be found contrary to the public interest. Agreements are void in respect
of restrictions so found. The Court can make orders preventing the parties
from operating their agreement, or from making new arrangements having the
same effect. Agreements relating exclusively to exports are not subject to this
procedure but have to be notified to the Secretary of State for Trade and
Industry.
Under the 1956 Act collective enforcement of resale price maintenance was
prohibited, but individual suppliers remained free to enforce minimum resale
prices in the courts. The Resale Prices Act 1964 made minimum resale price
maintenance unlawful, except in respect of classes of registered goods for
which temporary exemption has been sought under the provisions of the Act.
Where resale price maintenance is prohibited, it is also unlawful to notify to
dealers prices stated or calculated to be understood as the minimum price
which may be charged on the resale of goods in the United Kingdom, or to
seek to maintain such prices by withholding supplies. Suppliers may continue
to practise resale price maintenance on registered goods, pending a decision
by the Restrictive Practices Court as to whether a case for exemption has
been made out against the criteria in the Act. Periodically, the Registrar of
Restrictive Trading Agreements issues lists of classes of goods in respect of
which the Court has refused to make an Order exempting them from the
terms of the Act. Only two classes of goods (books and maps and medicaments)
have so far gained exemption under an order from the court; nearly 500 classes
have been refused exemption. .
Monopolies and kindred arrangements (other than those within the scope
of the Restrictive Practices Court) may, in circumstances indicated m the
Monopolies and Mergers Act 1948 and 1965, be referred by the Secretary ol
State for Trade and Industry for investigation and report. The Department of
Trade and Industry (DTI) in co-operation with any production department
(see p. 209) concerned, take appropriate action on reports but no Order can be
made without parliamentary approval. The 1965 Act strengthened and
extended the legislation on monopolies. It reorganised and enlarged the
Monopolies Commission; provided for the investigation, at the reference o
the DTI, of services as well as goods and of proposed or recently completed
mergers; made special provision for newspaper mergers; and improved and
extended the Government’s powers—subject to parliamentary control—for
taking action on the basis of the Monopolies Commission reports including
new powers to prohibit mergers and break up undesirable monopolies and
mergers.
Direct State participation in productive and commercial activities is effected
mainly through special statutory bodies set up to deal with a particular
activity. Such bodies, though not part of a government department, are under
a considerable but varying degree of public control (see below). The most
important of these statutory bodies are the public corporations which operate
INDUSTRY
203
major industries and services in the public interest. Altogether about 12 per
cent of the labour force works for these bodies. Their managing boards and
staffs are chosen for their experience and competence in a particular field; they
are not civil servants, and, although accountable to Parliament for their actions
in a variety of ways, it is they and not the ministers of the sponsoring depart¬
ments who are responsible for the management of the corporations. Certain of
the corporations are self-supporting; others receive Exchequer grants to help
them carry out duties with which they have been charged.
These corporations are described in their relevant sections.
The extent to which the responsible minister has power over the working
of the boards which have been set up to run the nationalised industries varies
from industry to industry, but two features are common to almost all of them.
First, the minister appoints (and may dismiss) the chairman and members of
each board, and, secondly, he has power to give general directions as to how
the industry should be run, but does not interfere in day-to-day management.
It is usually also laid down that the board shall give to the minister any in¬
formation, statistics and financial accounts which he may require. In practice,
as the responsible minister is kept fully informed and major policy decisions
are reached in consultation with him, there is very seldom occasion for him to
issue a formal directive.
The minister also has financial powers and responsibilities. The usual
statutory requirement is that the board is required to conduct its business so
that receipts at least balance outgoings taking one year with another. The
responsible minister is usually empowered (subject to Treasury approval) to
say what shall be done with any surplus revenues which may accrue. As
regards finance of capital expenditure, the present system is that such finance
as cannot be met from internal sources is mainly provided, in the form of
interest-earning loans, by the minister from the Exchequer, bank advances
being used only for normal requirements of short-term capital.
It is usual for the minister responsible for each nationalised industry to be
required by statute to take steps to see that the interests of the industry’s
customers are protected. This is generally done by the establishment of
representative consumers’ councils to consider complaints and suggestions
made to them, and to advise the board or the minister on the changes they
think desirable.
Financial targets have been agreed by the Government with the different
industries (or are under discussion) ranging from 12*4 per cent gross return
on capital employed to ‘breaking even’ after interest and depreciation have
been allowed for. In addition the industries are expected to apply a test
discount rate for new investment of 10 per cent.
Government policy towards the nationalised industries is subject to the
approval of Parliament. Opportunities for parliamentary discussion are
afforded by debates, including debates on their annual reports and accounts,
and by answers to parliamentary questions, which, in principle, are admissible
only if concerned with policy rather than details of administration. A House of
Commons Select Committee on the Nationalised Industries, which examines
the reports and accounts of the nationalised industries and reports to Parlia¬
ment, has been in operation since 1957.
From the middle of the nineteenth century, private industrial undertakings
have increasingly entered into voluntary association for a number of different
purposes. Some of the more important of these are classified as: (1) the pro¬
vision of common services, the exchange of information, liaison with the
204
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Government, and representation of their members’ point of view; (2) the
regulation of trading practices, sometimes including the regulation of prices
(see p. 202); (3) negotiation with trade unions on wages and conditions of
work. Associations for the first and third of these purposes cover, with varying
completeness, most of British industry, but there are wide sectors of industry
where there are no collective agreements to regulate trading practices. Em¬
ployers’ organisations which deal with labour matters usually consist of firms
engaged in the same type of operation or manufacturing process. Trade
associations mainly concerned with representations to the Government, pro¬
vision of common services or the regulation of trading practices are built up
round a product or an allied group of products. In an industrial sector con¬
cerned wholly with an allied group of products, a single association may
undertake all the required functions.
There are about 75 national federations and probably altogether about
1,500 employers’ organisations (mostly regional or local, and members or
branches of the national federations) all concerned with negotiation of wages
and conditions of work. The number of manufacturers associations concerned
with providing common services is not known precisely but is thought to total
some 1,300, varying greatly in importance, structure and activities.
The central body representing British industry nationally is the Confedera¬
tion of British Industry (CBI). It is recognised by the Government as a
channel for consultation between government departments and representatives
of private employers as a whole. For its members it acts as an advisory and
consultative body providing them with information and statistics, ascertaining
their collective views and representing them nationally to the Government
and the public and also internationally, for example in the Council of European
Industrial Federations. CBI representatives sit on a number of government
advisory committees, on other statutory bodies and on voluntary bodies con¬
cerned with matters affecting industry.
The CBI membership consists of some 13,000 companies and about 220
trade associations and employers’ federations. Nationalised industries have
joined as industrial associates. The CBI has a regional organisation in t e
United Kingdom and is widely represented abroad.
In matters of common concern the CBI often acts jointly with the chambers
of commerce. These are open to all kinds of producers and traders and exist
to promote the interests of local industry and commerce. The Association of
British Chambers of Commerce, founded in i860, is the central organisation
to which 91 local chambers of commerce (together with 17 British Chambers of
Commerce operating abroad) are affiliated. In Scotland there is an additiona
central organisation, the Scottish Chamber of Commerce, and in Northern
Ireland, the Northern Ireland Chamber of Commerce and Industry to which
local chambers are affiliated.

Greater London
and the South-east
Region
The following is a summary of the geographical distribution of British industry
today, grouped by the areas covered by the regional economic planning
machinery.
London, lying at the head of ocean navigation on the Thames estuary is
Britain’s capital and main communication centre, probably still the world s
most important financial centre, and one of the world’s four largest cities
(with Tokyo, New York and Mexico City) and three largest ports (with New
York and Rotterdam). It is the main centre in Britain of printing, cinema film
production and the manufacture of clothing, food and drink, furniture, materia s
INDUSTRY
South-west
England
East Anglia
West Midlands
205
for the arts, precision instruments and many other specialised products. Small
firms predominate in many of these industries and the average size of manu¬
facturing firms (particularly in the central area) is well below the national
average. London is also important, especially in its outer ring, for light
engineering, chemicals and consumer goods and has some heavy engineering
plants and a number of leading research establishments.
Towards the periphery of Greater London (population 7,379,014) and in
the new urban development outside it, industry, particularly the electronics
and a variety of consumer goods industries, has expanded greatly; some of the
largest aircraft plants are in these areas, for example at Weybridge and Hatfield,
as well as factories, at Dagenham, Luton and Dunstable, of two of the four
main motor vehicle manufacturers. There are other major motor vehicle
manufacturing plants at Cowley, Oxford (109,000), some 50 miles north-west
of London. Along the lower Thames and Medway estuaries there are large oil
refineries as well as some smaller shipyards, engineering works and major
concentrations of the paper and pulp and cement industries.
A great part of the Channel coast eastwards from Poole (population 107,000)
and Bournemouth (153,000) consists of built-up areas, which from Brighton
(166,000) eastwards are partly dormitories for people working in London.
Holiday resorts fringe the coast. Portsmouth (197,000) is a naval port with
some shipbuilding and general manufactures. Southampton (215,000) is
Britain’s largest port for ocean-going liners; its industries include ship repair¬
ing, oil refining, cable-making, electronics and synthetic rubber. Dover,
Folkestone and Newhaven are packet ports.
Devon and Cornwall have a considerable tourist trade. Bristol (425,000) is a
leading port and commercial centre with aircraft, aero-engines, tobacco, food
processing, paper, printing and other industries and important non-ferrous
metals and basic chemicals plants at Avonmouth. Gloucester (90,000), origin¬
ally an inland port and commercial town, Cheltenham (70,000), originally a
resort town, and the area between and adjacent to them produce a variety of
manufactures, including machinery, instruments and accessories, and cloth.
Swindon (91,000), besides railway workshops, has important engineering
works. Bath (85,000), originally a resort town and centre of an agricultural
district, has become noted for engineering and other manufacturing.
Besides being one of the most productive agricultural regions, the eastern
counties possess some sizeable towns. Cambridge (99,000) is a leading centre
of research-based industry; Ipswich (123,000) and Peterborough (70,000) are
noted for diesel engines, agricultural machinery and engineering generally;
and Norwich (122,000) for footwear and food manufacture. Food canning and
freezing, based mainly on locally grown produce, have developed rapidly.
The fishing ports of Great Yarmouth (50,000) and Lowestoft (52,000) have
fish processing plants, and have also become important bases for companies
engaged in natural gas exploitation in the North Sea.
The West Midlands conurbation, which stretches from Birmingham (1,013,000)
to Wolverhampton (269,000) and includes parts of Staffordshire, Worcester¬
shire and Warwickshire, has an unusually wide variety of industry, including
the manufacture of metals, electrical and engineering products of all kinds and
also jewellery, rubber products, chemicals and domestic metalware. The
largest concentrations of motor vehicle manufacture (including components
and accessories) in Britain are in Birmingham and Coventry (335,000).
The smaller conurbation of North Staffordshire, centred on Stoke-on-Trent
206
East Midlands
North-west
England
Yorkshire and
Elumberside
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
(265,000), is devoted chiefly to the manufacture of pottery and china and to
coalmining, although other industries are growing in importance, while
Stafford (55,000) has heavy electrical and other engineering works.
Other industrial centres are Rugby (59,000), electrical engineering,
Worcester (73,000), machinery; Burton upon Trent (50,000), brewing and
rubber; and Kidderminster (47,000), carpets.
The industrial cities and towns of the East Midlands include Leicester
(284,000), noted for hosiery and knitwear, boots and shoes and machinery for
making these products; Derby (219,000) for general engineering, aero-engines
and man-made fibres; Nottingham (303,000) for hosiery, cycles and a variety
of other engineering products, lace, pharmaceutical products and tobacco;
Northampton (127,000), footwear and engineering; Chesterfield (69,000),
engineering. Corby (48,000), a new town in Northamptonshire, has a large
integrated steel works. Part of Britain’s richest and most highly mechanised
coalfield lies under the north-east of the area. Some of the towns on the coal¬
field, such as Mansfield (58,000), have important manufacturing industries,
particularly textiles.
Manchester (541,000) is the commercial hub of the cotton and man-made
fibre textiles industries, a very important financial and commercial centre and
a major port. It is also one of the chief centres for electrical and heavy engineer¬
ing and the production of machine tools, petro-chemicals, dyestuffs, and
pharmaceutical goods, while it has a wide range of other manufactures. In
the traditional cotton-manufacturing towns man-made fibres are also pro¬
cessed alone or blended with cotton; the largest of these are Bolton (154,000),
Oldham (106,000), Rochdale (91,000), Stockport (140,000), Burnley (76,000),
Blackburn (102,000), Preston (97,000) and Bury (68,000). In the majority of
these towns engineering industries, notably the manufacture of printing, paper
making, textile and electrical machinery and heavy commercial vehicles
(especially in the Chorley-Leyland area), have been expanding while the
cotton industry has been declining. The Lancashire coalfield also lies in the
Manchester-Wigan area.
The Manchester Ship Canal, which carries a substantial volume of overseas
trade, links Manchester and Merseyside. It passes through Warrington
(68 000) with its metal industries (such as wire-drawing), Widnes (57,000) and
Runcorn (36,000) with their chemicals, and Ellesmere Port (62,000) with its
oil refinery installations, before reaching the Mersey estuary. St. Helens
(104,000), to the north of the canal, is famous for glass manufacture. Liverpool
(607*000) is the second port of Britain, a great commercial and insurance
centre and, after London, the greatest centre for processing imported food¬
stuffs and raw materials, noted especially for flour milling, soap manufacture,
sugar refining and rubber products. Among its older industries is ship repair¬
ing; shipbuilding is a major industry across the river at Birkenhead (138,000).
Many new industries, including electrical engineering, manufacture of heavy
industrial equipment and, more recently, of motor vehicles, have been
established around Liverpool. Salt, extracted in Cheshire, is used mainly by
chemical works on Merseyside.
Barrow (64,000) in the north-west of Lancashire, is well known for ship¬
building and marine engineering. Blackpool (151,000) on the coast is Britain s
most popular holiday resort.
About three-quarters of the United Kingdom’s worsted and woollen industries
are found in the West Riding of Yorkshire. Bradford (294,000) is the com-
INDUSTRY
207
Northern England
Wales
mercial centre of the wool trade and important for worsted; Wakefield
(60,000) produces both worsted and woollens; Morley (44,000) and Leeds
(495,000) have specialised in cheaper cloths, and Batley (42,000), Dewsbury
(51,000) and Spenborough (41,000) in heavy cloth, but their production is
becoming more diversified. Huddersfield (131,000) has a reputation for fine
woollens and worsteds and Halifax (91,000) for carpets. In most of the larger
centres of the wool industry a variety of engineering products are manu¬
factured. Leeds, the commercial capital of the area, has a large ready-made
clothing industry and important engineering plants. Farther south is the heavy
engineering centre of Sheffield (520,000), famous for its high quality steels,
cutlery and tools. The area’s extensive coalfields provide nearly a quarter of
Britain’s coal; Doncaster (83,000), also with tractor and nylon manufacturing,
and Barnsley (75,000) are the largest towns on the coalfield.
York (104,000) is noted for chocolates and confectionery manufacture and
has important railway workshops, and Hull (285,000), one of the world’s
largest fishing ports and with many manufacturing industries, including
engineering, vegetable oil processing, paints and sawmilling, is the most
important industrial town in the East Riding of Yorkshire.
On the south (Lincolnshire) side of the Humber lie Scunthorpe (71,000),
an important and expanding steel-making centre, and the major fishing port of
Grimsby (96,000) which has a food processing industry and also growing
chemicals and textiles industries close by at Immingham.
The greater part of this region (Northumberland, Cumberland, Westmorland,
Durham and the North Riding of Yorkshire) is an area of mountains, lakes and
moors and is relatively thinly populated. Most of its population is concentrated
in the coastal strip from the coalfields north of the Tyne to the Tees. Within
this area the main centres are Tyneside, including Newcastle upon Tyne
(222,000), Gateshead (94,000), Tynemouth (69,000), South Shields (101,000),
Wallsend (46,000) and Jarrow (29,000); and Teesside (395,000) and Hartlepool
(97,000). Other large towns are Sunderland (217,000), Darlington (86,000) and
in the west, Carlisle (71,000).
The whole region is more dependent than other parts of England on
traditional heavy industries, notably coalmining, iron and steel manufacture,
shipbuilding and repairing and chemicals (the complex of chemical plants on
both banks of the Tees is probably the most extensive in Europe), which
together employ nearly a third of the male workers. This proportion has been
falling steadily as the result of the region’s efforts, with government help, to
attract new types of enterprise. It is one of the most important areas for the
manufacture of electrical plant, and the many other industries include mining
machinery, rolling mill plant, earth-moving equipment, machine tools, ropes,
paint, glass, clothing and scientific instruments. An aluminium smelter is
under construction on the Northumberland coast. Atomic energy is important
in Cumberland, with two nuclear power stations and other installations.
Nearly two-thirds of the population of Wales and Monmouthshire live in the
two counties of Glamorgan and Monmouthshire. In this area are the coal
mines which, though long worked and operating at increasing depths, still
produce nearly all Britain’s anthracite and much of its steam and other
specialised coals, and employ more workers than any branch of manufacturing
industry. Rhondda (89,000) and Merthyr Tydfil (55,000) are the largest
centres in the coalmining area. The steel industry, with some of the most
modern plants in Europe, supplies almost all Britain’s output of tin plate and
much of its sheet steel. In the past 35 years many new industries have been

established, often on government industrial estates; they include plastics,
synthetic fibres, clothing, electronics, motor vehicle components and light

The main urban centres are also the three major ports—Cardiff (278,000),
Newport (112,000) and Swansea (173,000). Milford Haven (14,000), a magni¬
ficent deep-water harbour recently developed, has two major oil refineries.
In North Wales a number of light industries, notably man-made fibres, are
located in the seaside resorts and some other towns, particularly Wrexham
(39,000), and there is a large steelworks in Flintshire.
About three-quarters of Scotland’s population (5-2 million) is concentrated in
the central Lowlands between the Firth of Clyde and the Firth of Forth. The
principal cities in this area are Glasgow (897,000) and Edinburgh (453,000).
Clydeside, which includes Glasgow, is a major shipbuilding and marine
engineering centre; it also has a great variety of general engineering enter¬
prises and other industries. The steel industry, sited mainly in north Lanark¬
shire, produces a wide range of products. The widely dispersed electronics
equipment industry is represented by a growing number of firms in such
centres as Glasgow, north Lanarkshire, Dundee and central Fife, as well as in
Edinburgh, where this and other modern industries are expanding alongside
the long-established engineering, printing and brewing industries. Motor car
manufacture has been established in Renfrewshire and in West Lothian there
has been a major expansion of commercial vehicle building.
Outside the central Lowland belt there is considerable industrial concentra¬
tion in and around Dundee (182,000) and Aberdeen (182,000) and a number
of towns outside these areas have attracted light industries in recent years.
Dundee’s traditional manufacture, jute, has been supplemented by office
machinery, clocks and watches, refrigerators and electronic products. In
north-east Scotland is the largest concentration of whisky distilleries, while
the paper and metal industries are also important.
Most of northern Scotland is mountainous and much of southern Scotland
is hilly and rugged. These regions are sparsely populated, but the Scottish
Highlands possess significant resources of hydro-electric power (see p. 225).
There are high-quality tweed and knitwear industries both in the valley
towns of the Borders and in the Highlands and Islands. Small engineering and
electronics industries have recently been established in towns in the Borders
and the south-west. Small-scale manufacturing has also been introduced in the
Highlands, and larger enterprises include the experimental atomic reactor
establishment at Dounreay and the aluminium smelter recently commissioned
at Invergordon. (see p. 238).
Although the area of Northern Ireland is relatively small and lacking in
minerals, there is substantial and growing industrialisation, particularly in and
around Belfast, the capital city (359>000)- Britain’s largest single shipyard
incorporating the world’s biggest shipbuilding berth is m Be fast; other long-
established activities include the manufacture of textile machinery and other
engineering products; ropes, twine, tobacco and clothing. Northern Lelan
has also long been an important centre for textiles—it is particularly well
known for linen. The textile industry is now extensively diversified; Northern
Ireland is one of the most important areas in Europe for man-made fibre pro¬
duction and provides about one-fifth of Britain’s output. There has also been
extensive development in vehicle components, oil-well equipment, electronic
instruments, telephone switchgear, toys, shoes, carpets and synthetic rubber.

Relations
between the
Government
and Industry
Statistical

Production and

Production Trends
209
The Government can influence industrial activity in a number of ways—
through fiscal and monetary policy, through the level of public expenditure,
through the placing of government contracts, through the policies of publicly
owned enterprises, by physical controls, by inducements, by exhortation and
by the provision of services, information and advice. Apart from labour
legislation (see Chapter 17) and certain export and import controls over a
small range of products (see Chapter 16), there are few physical controls over
industry—the main ones are the use of the legislation concerning monopolies
and restrictive practices already described (see p. 201) and the operation of
powers to control new industrial and office building and changes in land use.
There is close association between industry and the Government through
such channels as the National Economic Development Council, the main forum
for consultation between the Government, management and the trade unions,
and Economic Development Committees (EDCs) which cover particular sectors
of industry.
A major reorganisation of the machinery of central government was
announced in October 1970, involving important changes in relation to
industrial and commercial policy. A new Department of Trade and Industry
(DTI) was set up, combining the functions of the Board of Trade and the
Ministry of Technology (other than aerospace). The DTI is thus the first
single body with responsibility for all policies affecting production and trade
(both internal and export), and for the government’s relations with individual
industries. Following a review of the machinery for aerospace policy and defence
procurement, it was announced in May 1971 that the former, together with
civil aerospace research, would be transferred to the DTI, while the latter
would be handled by a new procurement executive at the Ministry of Defence.
The new organisation will be fully operational by April 1972.
Policies on labour matters, including industrial relations, industrial training
and manpower in general are the concern of the Department of Employment.
Other departments involved with industrial issues are the Treasury (fiscal and
monetary policy and medium- and long-term economic questions); and the
Department of Education and Science, which is responsible for the promotion
of education and for civil science, operating primarily through the research
councils; and the Department of the Environment (relations with the con¬
struction industry and some regional matters).
There are separate departments of the Northern Ireland Government for
matters within the competence of the Northern Ireland Parliament. The
Ministry of Commerce deals with industry and industrial development.
The Central Statistical Office (CSO), which is attached to the Cabinet Office,
is the central body for government statistics. Although departments them¬
selves compile statistics relating to their responsibilities and may publish them
in their own standard publications, the comprehensive statistical publications
are prepared by the CSO, which acts as co-ordinator. The Business Statistical
Office, which is responsible to the CSO for policy but is administratively part
of the DTI, will eventually take over the responsibility for compiling a wide
range of statistics relating to industry and commerce.
Industrial production (mining and quarrying, manufacturing, construction,
and gas, electricity and water) was in the first half of 1971 fractionally less
than a year previously, about one-third higher than in i960 and about double
the pre-war level. The course of production and employment from 1963 to
1970 is shown in Table 12.

The size of the labour force has fallen slowly in the last five years and the
increases in production have been due mainly to a variety of factors influencing
productivity, including advances in products, machinery, processes an
methods of work; the rate of fixed capital formation; more intensive competi¬
tion and sales promotion; and improved management.
Although gross fixed capital formation at home has, as a whole, been well
maintained since 1966, the proportion devoted to manufacturing has tende
to fall. The total in 1970 amounted to 20 per cent of the gross domestic product
and was estimated (at current prices) to be more than double the 1959 level.
Part of this rising investment is associated with the introduction of new
techniques and equipment and in particular of machines and instruments
which lessen the demand for human skill and supervision though they may
require more skill from fewer people. This process of automation is giving rise
to far-reaching changes in the pattern of industry and m the internal organisa¬
tion and labour requirements of business enterprises and has already been
responsible for consequential increases in production and efficiency which, m
the long run, are likely to be very large. Much investment, however, sti 1 con¬
sists of replacements, additions and improvements of a more traditional kind.

Both the long-term and the short-term growth of productivity thus depend
most directly on the decisions of individual undertakings. But though the
promotion of productivity is regarded as primarily a matter for industry,
government departments and educational and research establishments also
have an important contribution to make. Government budgeting and financial
policies also have a strong influence on the extent and direction of demand,
and government purchasing policies take account of national industrial
objectives.
Within industry employers’ organisations often provide technical assistance,
conduct market surveys, and support schemes of vocational education and
training, and many trade unions organise special training schemes and courses
to promote understanding of modern management techniques. Changes in
working methods to facilitate higher output feature in a number of produc¬
tivity agreements negotiated between management and workers. Private con¬
sultants specialising in management and work study are available to advise
firms on measures to increase their productive efficiency; there are also many
specialist institutions, both public and private, concerned with various aspects
of productivity. The local organisations arrange meetings, inter-factory visits,
courses, conferences, film shows and exhibitions.
The British Standards Institution (BSI) is a voluntary non-profit-making
body incorporated by Royal Charter. It prepares and promulgates standards
in respect of, inter alia, quality, performance, dimensions, testing methods and
codes of practice. Voluntary acceptance of such standards by manufacturers,
buyers and sellers reduces unnecessary variety and simplifies the specification
of requirements. The BSI is governed by a council consisting of representa¬
tives of the main organisations of employers and workers, professional institu¬
tions and the larger government departments.
The Council of Industrial Design (CoID), set up in 1944 by the Government
to promote higher standards of design in British industry, is concerned with
all aspects of industrial design from durable consumer goods to capital goods.
The CoID, with its Scottish Committee, is a grant-aided body sponsored by
the Department of Trade and Industry; its members include industrialists,
engineers, retailers, architects, designers and educationists. At The Design
Centre in the Haymarket, London, a selective but changing display of modern
British consumer goods is maintained; exhibits are chosen from Design Index,
the CoID’s illustrated record of more than 10,000 well-designed products.
Special exhibitions on particular themes are also arranged regularly. An
annual awards scheme, Council of Industrial Design Awards, covering capital
goods and engineering equipment as well as consumer products, was intro¬
duced in 1967. The Duke of Edinburgh also presents his annual Design Prize.
The Scottish Committee runs the Scottish Design Centre in Glasgow, and
there are two independent regional design centres, each maintaining a duplicate
of the Index, at Liverpool and Manchester. The CoID organises temporary
exhibitions in regional centres and overseas; arranges regular conferences and
training courses; undertakes industrial study tours in Britain; and operates a
designer selection service which can make recommendations to any individual
or organisation from a list of over 3,000 British graphic and industrial
designers. It publishes a monthly magazine, Design, and maintains reference
and photographic libraries.
Other bodies concerned with industrial design include the Royal Society of
Arts (see p. 323), the Society of Industrial Artists and Designers, which is the
representative professional body in Great Britain of designers engaged in
212
Co-ordination
Management
BRITAIN 1972*. AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
industry and commerce, and the Design and Industries Association (DIA), a
voluntary association of industrial companies, designers, and others interested
in the promotion of good design in industry. The Crafts Council of Great
Britain the Crafts Centre of Great Britain and the Scottish Craft Centre are
all grant-aided by the Department of Trade and Industry. Their aims are to
improve craft design and to promote closer relations between craftsmen and
industry.
The Department of Trade and Industry is responsible for the co-ordination of
activities related to the improvement of industrial productivity. It is represented
on the EDCs (see p. 209)—which are concerned primarily with the removal o
obstacles to efficiency—by seconded industrial advisers. The DTI is also
charged with extending the introduction of automatic control systems and
advanced techniques into industry, sponsors the BSI, the British Calibration
Service1 and the National Computing Centre, supports the National Data
Processing Service, and provides technical advisory services. It is concerned
directly with research into such factors as productivity measurement techniques,
group technology, production engineering and fatigue among operators, ihe
Manpower and Productivity Service of the Department of Employment
advises firms on aspects of productivity connected with manpower utilisation
and industrial relations. A number of other departments have responsibilities
which bear on productivity.
In Britain, as elsewhere, management is recognised as a subject requiring
special skills and knowledge. This is reflected both in a change in the general
educational qualifications of recruits and in the spread of systematic education
and training for management. . . ,
The British Institute of Management (BIM) is the central national ma g -
ment body, independent, non-political and non-profit-making. Its purpose is
to study and promote scientific management, including management education
and training, throughout industry, commerce and public administration. T e
BIM receives an annual government grant of about £100,000 to help it expand
services to industry. The Industrial Society works to promote better use ot
human resources; it advises members and conducts conferences and courses.
Management studies and education for management are expanding rapidly
in Britain and have become a recognised feature of higher education (see
n. 162'). There are graduate business schools in London and Manchester.
Training courses for higher management are held at several universities an
colleges” including the Administrative Staff College, Henley-on-Thames, and
Ashrfdge College of Management, Berkhamsted. The larger firms, especially
those with wide responsibilities, often provide general management courses
for senior executives, and systems of informal training within an organisation
are numerous. There are also bodies concerned with specialised branches o
management, for example, the Institute of Personnel Management, the
Institution of Works Managers, the Institute of Office Management and the
Institute of Marketing. .  .
The growing number of professional personnel working as manageme
consultants—now about 4,000-and the use of the semces of mdependen
management selection firms in the appointment of senior staff are furthe
indications of interest in the science of management in Britain.

Under the Finance Act 1971, cash grants to encourage capital expenditure on
plant and machinery were replaced by a system of investment allowances. This
permits 60 per cent of such expenditure to be written off for tax purposes in
the year in which it is incurred, and provides a standard writing down allow¬
ance enabling 25 per cent of the reducing balance of the expenditure to be
written off successively in later years. The allowances administered by the
DTI also cover investment in computers, hovercraft and mining works. Ships
qualify for free depreciation. In order to maintain a greater incentive to invest¬
ment in development areas (see below) certain forms of expenditure—mainly
on plant and machinery used in the manufacturing, construction and extrac¬
tive industries—receive free depreciation. A separate system of grants and
loans to encourage hotel development operated until March 1971; limited
assistance is still available to tourism projects in the development areas.
Some parts of Britain have long been less prosperous than others. Their rate of
economic expansion has been below average and their level of unemployment
above average as a result of the decline of some traditional industries or the
lack of job opportunities. For many years unemployment has remained a
persistent problem in Scotland, Wales and the north-east and some other
parts of England. This regional imbalance has been aggravated by the tendency
for new industries to concentrate in the Midlands and the south-east where, as
a result, the demand for labour is high and there are increasing problems of
congestion. An important aim of the Government’s regional policy is to
achieve a better distribution of industrial development between the different
parts of the country. The Government has in recent years taken important
measures aimed at securing balanced economic development.
Government aid to areas of high unemployment began in the 1930s and has
been developed in various ways since the end of the second world war. Since
August 1966 large parts of Britain have been designated as ‘development areas’
where industrial development is to be encouraged. They cover northern
England, Merseyside and nearly the whole of Scotland, Wales, Cornwall and
north Devon and contain approximately a fifth of Britain’s working popula¬
tion. The Department of Trade and Industry provides businessmen with
detailed information on industrial location within the development areas and
offers a wide variety of inducements to new or expanding businesses in these
areas, the first priority being given to smaller ‘special development areas’.
Besides the free depreciation allowances on capital investment there is a
wide range of financial and other inducements available under the Local
Employment Acts 1960-70 to encourage industry to expand in the assisted
areas. The Department of Trade and Industry may build factories for leasing,
in some cases with an initial rent-free period, or sale on deferred terms; make
building grants of 35 per cent (and 45 per cent in special cases) of the cost of
building an industrialist’s own factory; make grants towards the removal costs
of firms moving into a development area; and make loans for the general
purposes of an undertaking (for example, working capital, plant and machinery,
etc.). In the special development areas, operational grants of 30 per cent of
eligible wage and salary costs may be paid to help new firms during the first
three years of their establishment.
Factory building and estate management are undertaken on the Department
of Trade and Industry’s behalf by the English, Scottish and Welsh Industrial
Estates Corporations; premises administered by the three Corporations total
over 60 million square feet and give employment to over 250,000 people.
Assistance from other government departments includes 85 per cent capital
214
Northern Ireland
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
grants to local authorities for clearing derelict or neglected sites and for im¬
proving basic services; and help from the Department of Employment with
the cost of training additional labour in development areas and of transferring
workers in connection with establishing new enterprises.
Employers in the manufacturing industry in development areas are entitled
not only to refund of selective employment tax (see p. 345) but also receive
regional employment premiums of ^1*50 a week for every full-time ma e
employee with lower rates for women, part-timers, boys and girls.
A committee set up in 1967 to investigate the needs of ‘Intermediate
Areas’—those areas with special economic problems but situated outside the
development areas-published its report in 1969. Under the Local Employ¬
ment Act 1970 a number of such areas have been designated as Intermediate
Areas and given special assistance, similar to but more limited than that
available in the development areas under earlier Local Employment Acts,
including factory building grants, additional provisions for industrial training
and help in a clearance programme of derelict land.
Since 1948 control of new industrial building has been exercised throug
the use of a system of Industrial Development Certificates. Any application
under the normal town and country planning machinery for planning per¬
mission for industrial development involving more than 10,000 square feet
of floor space (or 5,000 square feet in the Midlands and south-east) must e
accompanied by a certificate from the Department of Trade and Industry
certifying that the development in question can be carried out consistently
with the proper distribution of industry. In considering applications the
Secretary of State pays particular regard to the need for providing appropriate
employment in the assisted areas. In practice this obligation has led to the
refusal of certificates for most projects outside the assisted areas unless it can
be shown that the project could not reasonably be undertaken in such an area
or in Northern Ireland. Subject to this priority, the control is also used to
encourage dispersal of industry to new or expanded towns taking population
from .hi more congested areas. Under the Control of Office and Industnal
Development Act 1965 the Board of Trade was given power-transferred to
the Department of the Environment in October 1970-to control office
development in certain areas. Office development permits are needed only for
developments of over 10,000 square feet in the south-east of England.
Under its own legislation Northern Ireland provides for the payment of capital
grants at 20 per cent of the cost of new machinery and equipment and 35 per
cent of the cost of new buildings for the manufacturing, construction and
extractive industries in Northern Ireland. There is also provision for assisting
firms by means of loans to carry out major schemes of re-equipment to move
to another area in particular need of industrial development or to undertake a
rehousing of their business in association with a major scheme of modernisa¬
tion and reorganisation. Help under the investment grants legislation is made
without regard to how much employment is created as a resu t.
As an alternative means of assistance the Northern Ireland Governm
continues to use its comprehensive and flexible powers authorised ™der the
Industries Development Acts for projects which offer a reasonable amount o
employment. In such cases individual development grants of up to 40 per cent
of expenditure on new machinery and equipment and 55 per cent of the cost
of new buildings. For those projects which offer exceptionally attractive
returns in employment or location within Northern Ireland, the assistance
offered could include tenancy of a government-built factory at a very low ren ,

grants towards operating costs in the initial stages, and grants towards costs of
removing existing machinery and installing it in a factory in Northern Ireland.
The regional employment premium also applies to Northern Ireland.
Since 1945 almost 300 new firms have been established in Northern Ireland
with government assistance, giving employment to some 85,000 people. The
Ministry of Commerce is the Northern Ireland government department con¬
cerned with the administration of industrial development policies. The
Northern Ireland Economic Council was set up in 1965 to assist in furthering
economic growth. The chairman is the Minister of Commerce, and the
membership includes representatives of industry, commerce and the trade
unions.
Certain regions and areas in England have industrial development associations
concerned with promoting local industry. These are sponsored mainly by local
authorities, trade associations and individual firms.
Several voluntary associations are concerned with Welsh industry. The
Development Corporation for Wales, founded in 1959, is the most prominent.
In Scotland, the Highlands and Islands Development Board, set up by
statute in 1965, works to stimulate the economic and social development of
the seven ‘crofting’ counties (see p. 275). It provides grants and loans to
industrial, commercial and other enterprises; it may also acquire land, provide
management and other advisory services and set up and carry on businesses.
The Scottish Council (Development and Industry), a voluntary association,
promotes the general economic development of Scotland.
Encouragement is given to the development of rural industries. Much of this
work is done under the aegis of the Development Commission1 with finance
from the Development Fund, notably advice and guidance to small businesses
in rural areas and country towns and loans for assistance to tourism in the
rural parts of development areas. In England and Wales this service is pro¬
vided by the Council for Small Industries in Rural Areas acting in consulta¬
tion with the Rural Community Councils through their Small Industries
Committees in the counties; by the Small Industries Council for Rural Areas
of Scotland; and in Northern Ireland by the newly formed Local Enterprise
Development Unit of the Ministry of Commerce, and the Rural Industries
Development Committee of the Northern Ireland Council of Social Services.
Another service provided by the Commission is the financing of small factories
to stimulate rural industries and to combat rural depopulation.
Under the Finance Act 1968 hotels in certain rural parts of the develop¬
ment areas qualify for a refund of selective employment tax (see p. 345).
FUEL AND POWER
The main primary sources of energy currently used in Britain are coal,
petroleum and, to a lesser extent, nuclear energy, natural gas and water power;
secondary sources produced from these are electricity, town gas and coke.
Coal, mined within the country, still represents nearly half primary energy
consumption, although the amount of coal used and its share of the total energy

fisheries.

The fuel and power industries, with the exception of petroleum, are under
public ownership. General responsibility for the effective and co-ordinated
development of fuel and power resources lies with the Secretary of State tor
Trade and Industry. Research is undertaken by the fuel and fuel-using
industries. The Secretary of State also has an Advisory Council on Research
and Development. . _ . . . . . , .
The nationalised fuel and power industries in Britain employ in total about
780 000 people, or 3 per cent of the working population; their capital invest¬
ment in 1971-72 be in tbe region of j£8o° tbfir annual turnover is
about /3,00c million; and the value of their net output is about 5 per cent of
the national product. The nationalised industry boards’ investment is financed
through internal resources and borrowing from the Government (long term),
the clearing banks (short term), and from overseas (long term) sources.
The responsible ministers—the Secretary of State for Trade and Industry
in England and Wales and for Scottish electricity the Secretary of State for
Scotland—are required by statute to set up consultative councils for each of
the nationalised fuel industries to protect the interests of consumers. National
Industrial and Domestic Coal Consumers’ Councils were set up m 1947 and
Area Electricity and Gas Consultative Councils (supported by d 1stnct_ com¬
mittees) were set up in 1948 and 1949 respectively. Each consists of a chairman
and from 20 to 30 unpaid members appointed from nominations put forwar
by interested bodies, mainly local authorities.
Coal has been worked in Britain for over 700 years and an organised coal¬
mining industry has been in existence for over 300 years, some 200 years
longer than in any other country. British coal exports dominated the world
market until about 1910. By 1913—the peak production year—the industry

was producing 287 million tons of coal, exporting 94 million tons and employ¬
ing over a million workers.
In 1947 the coal mines passed into public ownership by means of the Coal
Industry Nationalisation Act 1946, which set up the National Coal Board as
a statutory corporation to manage the industry.
ENERGY TRENDS 1960-70 GAS
The National Coal Board (NCB) consists of a chairman and between eight
and eleven members appointed by the Secretary of State for Trade and
Industry. The NCB has, with minor exceptions, exclusive rights over the
extraction of coal in Great Britain, but is empowered to license private
operators to work small pits and open-cast sites. It has no monopoly in
distribution, and retail sales remain largely in private hands, but it has, how¬
ever, some retail depots and makes bulk sales to large industrial consumers.
The NCB is responsible for the day-to-day running and the commercial
2i$ BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
management of the industry, but is answerable to the Secretary of State (and
through him, to Parliament) for its efficiency. The Secretary of State has power
to issue general directives on matters affecting the national interest, and to
authorise borrowings to finance capital investment. Under the Coal Industry
Act 1971 he also has power to give directions relating to the Board’s non¬
colliery activities. .
At the end of March 1971 there were 292 collieries in operation. Of these,
289 were grouped into 17 areas, each controlled by a director who is respon¬
sible to the NCB. The remaining three collieries (in Kent) are controlled by a
general manager who is also responsible to the NCB.
A typical area produces nearly 8 million tons of coal a year, employs up to
17,000 men and has a turnover of about £55 million.
Pattern and Coal consumption in Britain increased by an average annual rate of nearly
Trends in 4 million tons between 1947 and 1956; sales fell sharply, however, between
Supply and 1956 and 1959 and large stocks of coal accumulated at pit heads Growing
Demand competition from oil, increasing efficiency in the use of coal and reduced
requirements of the gas, steel, railway transport, and other industries con¬
tributed to the fall in demand which is still continuing (see Table 14). Un¬
distributed stocks have recently been run down considerably and at the end
of March 1971 were 6 million tons.
About half of total consumption is by the electricity authorities and nearly
one-quarter by domestic and industrial users together. Coke ovens are other
large users while consumption by the gas industry is falling rapidly with the
switch to natural gas. Consumption by the electricity industry has increased
by 32 per cent since 1961 to 73 million tons in 1970 whereas the requirements
of all the other main classes of consumer have declined. For domestic users this
fall has been slightly offset by increased purchases of solid smokeless fuels.
Coal exports have declined for somewhat similar reasons and now average
about 3 million tons a year. The peak post-war figure was 19 million tons in
1949. The principal markets are in Western Europe and the Republic of
Ireland. Because of the low stock situation, restrictions on imports of coal,
coke and manufactured fuels were lifted in December 1970. In the first quarter
of 1971 imports amounted to 626,000 tons.
Production and
Manpower
The fact that the British industry was developed so early has meant that many
of the best seams of coal are now worked out. There are abundant reserves of
coal with which production can be maintained well into the next century,
there is also scope for opening new collieries should these be required.
The main coal-bearing areas are: (1) the Yorkshire, Derbyshire and
Nottinghamshire field, which produces about 51 per cent of the total output
(2) the Durham and Northumberland field, (3) the South Wales field, and
(4) the Scottish field. Other important coal-bearing areas are those of
Lancashire and the west Midlands (Staffordshire and Warwickshire).
Table 14 shows the main trends in the industry since 195°*
Coal consumption has fallen steadily over the past 20 years as shown in
Table 14, and fell by 11-5 million tons in 1970-71. The fall in demand has
been accompanied by increases in productivity and has resulted in a rundown
of the labour force from some 700,000 to about 290,000. There were 3,254
fewer workers in March 1971 than in March 1970. Overall productivity has
risen by half since 1961 to 2-2 tons per manshift in 1970-71. Coal face output
has doubled over the last 20 years to 7*2 tons per manshift in 1970-71. e
increases have been obtained largely by concentration on the more productive

The NCB raises capital, including working capital, by borrowing from the
Secretary of State for Trade and Industry. At present there is a statutory limit
of £900 million on such borrowing. Within certain limits the Board may also,
with the permission of the Secretary of State for Trade and Industry, borrow
temporarily (by way of overdraft or otherwise). The greater proportion of
investment, however, is financed from internal resources.
Capital expenditure by the industry totalled £462 million from 1947 to 1955
and about £790 million in the nine years 1956 to end-March 1964. At the end
of the 1964-65 financial year the total capital debt to the Exchequer amounted
to about ^960 million. In 1965 legislation was enacted to effect a capital re¬
construction involving the writing off of £415 million of the existing debt. As
a result, the total debt to the Secretary of State at the end of March 1971
amounted to £675 million.
Under the nationalisation statute, the NCB has been required to break even
on its current account (taking one year with another) after meeting all proper
charges including provision for reserves. It has made surpluses in some years
and deficits in others. In certain areas, such as Scotland, Lancashire and Wales,
deficits have been persistent, and profits from the areas of high productivity,
for instance, the Midlands, have been inadequate to cover the losses sustained.
By March 1966 the accumulated deficit on the current account had reached
^115-6 million; this was included in the £415 million written off. Interest
payments and depreciation provisions have been reduced as a result. In the
year ending March 1971 the NCB made an operating profit of ^34 million,
and after payment of interest there was a surplus of £500,000. The maximum

BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
permitted level of accumulated deficit was raised by the Coal Industry Act
1971 to £75 million.
To assist the redeployment of manpower and the elimination of uneconomic
colliery capacity, the Coal Industry Act 1971 authorised the Secretary of State
for Trade and Industry to make grants on a tapering basis up to a maximum
aggregate amount of £24 million over the three years to 1974.
The NCB has two research organisations: a Coal Research Establishment,
at Stoke Orchard, near Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, providing facilities for
fundamental research; and a Mining Research and Development Establish¬
ment, near Bretby, Derbyshire, for the investigation of underground problems,
developing new machines and testing equipment.
Research associations receiving grants from the NCB and the Department
of Trade and Industry include the British Coke Research Association and the
Coal Tar Research Association. Much of the work of other bodies, such as the
Safety in Mines Research Establishment (SMRE), is closely related to the
Board’s problems; the SMRE carries out research on explosions and fires,
pneumoconiosis, engineering and metallurgy.
The petroleum industry in Britain dates back to 1850, when Dr. James Young,
a Glasgow chemist, succeeded in obtaining lamp oil and lubricants from
natural mineral oil occurring in the Derbyshire coal measures. The Scottish
shale deposits, yielding similar products, were first worked in 1858 and ceased
production in 1962.
Sources of crude oil within Britain meet only 1 ton in every 1,200 of total
United Kingdom requirements, the remainder being imported from overseas.
Annual production of crude oil from indigenous oilfields now totals about
82,000 tons. Prospecting for crude petroleum has so far led to the establish¬
ment of several small oilfields, notably in Nottinghamshire (Egmanton and
Bothamsell), in Leicestershire (Plungar), in Lincolnshire (Gainsborough) and
in Dorset (Kimmeridge). Production of natural gas from an on-shore gas field
at Lockton, Yorkshire, began in May 1971.
Seismic prospecting in the North Sea has been going on since 1962 and full-
scale exploration activities since 1964) following the enactment of the Con¬
tinental Shelf Act 1964, and the subsequent award of a first round of licences.
Further licences were awarded in 1965 and 197° and applications for a fourth
round are under consideration. The total area now under licence is 25,000
square miles (64,700 square kilometres) out of a total area, over which Britain
has rights, of 168,000 square miles (435,000 square kilometres).
Drilling, which started in 1964, has proved the existence of five major fields
of natural gas in the British sector, and large quantities of gas are coming
ashore from three of these (West Sole, Hewett and Leman Bank). Develop¬
ment of the other two fields is in progress. Oil has also been found in encoura¬
ging quantities, but there is as yet no commercial production.
British and British-Dutch oil companies have been responsible for developing
the oil resources of many countries to mutual advantage, especially in the
Middle East, Far East, Africa and Caribbean areas.
Today production by these companies amounts to about 17 per cent of total
world production and they operate a tanker fleet (partly owned by them and
partly on charter) amounting to over a quarter of the world s tanker tonnage.
(British registered tanker tonnage is about 14 per cent of the world s total.)

Oil Pipelines
In 1970 the United Kingdom imported 102-5 million tons of crude oil
valued at £687 million, the largest single item among imported products.
Libya (23 per cent) regained from Kuwait its position as the largest supplier.
Other major suppliers were Saudi Arabia, Iran, Nigeria and Venezuela.
Deliveries of petroleum products for inland consumption in 1970 totalled
about 90 million tons, having doubled since i960. Fuel oil consumption in 1970
constituted 42-5 per cent of the total. Demand for gas and diesel oils (excluding
those used in road vehicles) rose by a further i-6 million tons to 12 million
tons in 1970. Sales of motor spirit have expanded by an annual average of 6-4
per cent since i960 and totalled some 14 million tons in 1970.
The most important uses of gas and diesel oils in 1970 were for non-
industrial central heating, agricultural tractors and the railways. Electricity
generation accounted for about 30-9 per cent of total fuel oil consumption,
excluding that used in oil refineries; the steel industry accounted for 13-2 per
cent; and non-industrial central heating for a further 10-9 per cent. Of the
remainder, the largest users were the cement, paper-making, general chemical,
glass, engineering, brickmaking and textile industries.
Before 1939 three-quarters of the United Kingdom’s supply of petroleum
products was refined overseas, as it was considered more economical to refine
at the source of production. Since the second world war the industry has
favoured the siting of refineries in the consuming areas.
At the end of 1970 rated refinery capacity in Britain amounted to 113 million
tons a year. Of the 23 refineries in operation, seven have a capacity of under
0-5 million tons. The eleven largest are situated at Fawley, near Southampton
(16-5 million tons); Stanlow, in Cheshire (10-75 million tons); Isle of Grain
and Shell Haven (both 10 million tons), and Coryton (7 million tons), all three
on the Thames Estuary; Teesport, Yorkshire (6 million tons); Grangemouth
(7 million tons); Milford Haven and Pembroke in Pembrokeshire (6-3 million
tons and 5-9 million tons); Llandarcy near Swansea (8 million tons); and
Killingholme near Grimsby (7 million tons). Other important refineries are
located at Belfast, Billingham, Heysham (Lancs.) and second refineries at
Killingholme and at Milford Haven. Stanlow is to be expanded by "j\ million
tons and Shell Haven by 9 million tons. Grangemouth is scheduled to expand
to 18 million tons by 1974.
Output of refined products (excluding refineries’ own consumption) has
risen steadily; from 4 million tons in 1948 to 25^ million tons in 1954, 40
million tons in i960 and the peak total of 93 million tons in 1970. There is a
substantial external trade in refined products which tends to follow trading
and seasonal requirements and the commercial arrangements of the major oil
companies. Exports from Britain, mainly in the form of heavier products
to European countries, were valued at £167 million in 1970. Imports of refined
products (including liquefied gases) amounted to ^213 million.
Three main crude oil pipelines are in operation in Britain between harbours
capable of berthing very large tankers and refineries: in west Scotland, from
Finnart to Grangemouth; in South Wales, from Angle Bay, Milford Haven,
to Llandarcy; and in north-west England, from Tranmere to Heysham.
Pipelines carry refined products from refineries to major marketing areas; for
example, from Stanlow to the Manchester area, from Fawley to Staines and
Heathrow Airport, and from the Isle of Grain to Walton-on-Thames and
Heathrow Airport. A 245-mile (394-kilometre) pipeline, opened in 1969, feeds

refined products to north London and the Midlands from refineries and
installations on the Thames and Mersey; a similar line is planned from Milford
Haven to the Midlands and Manchester. Pipelines carrying petrochemical
feedstocks run from Stanlow to Carrington, near Manchester, from Fawley to
Severnside, near Bristol, and from Teesside to Fleetwood and Runcorn. The
Pipelines Act 1962 is designed to secure the orderly development of privately
owned industrial pipelines.
Research into problems of petroleum technology is carried out mainly by the
leading oil companies, which have also endowed research at the universities
on a substantial scale. Research centres are situated at Sunbury-on-Thames
(the British Petroleum Company), Thornton, in Cheshire, and Woodstock,
in Kent (Shell), and Abingdon, in Berkshire (Esso). The first of these covers
the full range of petroleum research and development, from geology and
production to product utilisation and petroleum chemicals. In general, the
remainder are concerned with the evolution of new and improved fuels and
lubricants and the development of new uses for petroleum products and of
new products based on petroleum, especially chemicals.
A public supply of electricity was first provided in Britain in 1881, at
Godaiming, Surrey. From its earliest days a measure of public control has
been a feature of the industry. In 1919 the Electricity Commissioners were
created as a supervisory body and to promote reorganisation on a national
scale through voluntary agreement. In 1926 the Central Electricity Board
was set up to construct and operate a national grid inter-connecting individual
power stations, thus co-ordinating generation and transmission. In 1943 the
North of Scotland Hydro-Electric Board (NSHEB) was established as a public
corporation to develop the water-power resources of the Highlands. In 1948
all municipal and private undertakings (other than those in Northern Ireland)
were acquired under the Electricity Act 1947 and vested in the British
Electricity Authority and 14 regional boards, except in the north of Scotland
where they became the responsibility of the NSHEB. Two subsequent Acts
(1954 and 1957) effected a measure of decentralisation and gave the industry
its present structure. Electricity supply employs about 213,000 people, in¬
cluding 5,900 in Northern Ireland.
In England and Wales, electricity is generated and transmitted by the Central
Electricity Generating Board (CEGB) and distributed by 12 separate Area
Electricity Boards; co-ordination is effected by the Electricity Councd. In
Scotland, two boards—the NSHEB and the South of Scotland Electricity
Board (SSEB)—both generate and distribute electricity. In Northern Ireland,
the Belfast Corporation and the Electricity Board for Northern Ireland
generate and distribute electricity, and the Londonderry Development Com¬
mission distributes only.
The Electricity Council is the central body of the supply industry with a
general responsibility for promoting electricity supply and for advising the
Secretary of State for Trade and Industry; it is also responsible for a number ol
common services, principally capital financing, research and industrial rela¬
tions. The Council consists of a chairman and two deputy chairmen, the chair¬
man and two designated members of the CEGB, the chairmen of the 12 Area
Electricity Boards and not more than three other members. The CEGB con¬
trols the operation and maintenance of power stations and the mam trans-
INDUSTRY
223
Scotland
Northern Ireland
Generation
mission system (the national grid) and supplies electricity in bulk to the 12
Area Boards. The CEGB consists of a chairman, a deputy chairman and
between six and eight members. Each of the 12 Area Electricity Boards acquires
bulk supplies of electricity from the CEGB and is responsible for distribution
networks and sales of electricity to its area consumers.
Area Consultative Councils were set up under the Electricity Act 1947 in
the area of each Board to represent the interests of consumers; their chairmen
are ex officio members of their respective Area Boards. The Secretary of State
for Trade and Industry appoints the chairmen, deputy chairmen and members
of the Electricity Council, the CEGB, the Area Boards and the Consultative
Councils; approves each Board’s capital development programmes and the
industry’s research programme; and approves, in consultation with the
Treasury, the industry’s borrowing requirements.
The boundary separating the areas covered by the two Scottish Boards runs
roughly from Dumbarton on the Firth of Clyde to Newburgh on the Firth of
Tay. Members of both Boards and of the respective consumer consultative
councils are appointed by the Secretary of State for Scotland; each Board
comprises a chairman and between four and eight members, one of whom is the
chairman of the other Board. The Secretary of State’s responsibilities in rela¬
tion to the Boards are similar to those of the Secretary of State for Trade and
Industry.
In Northern Ireland electricity is generated at power stations in Belfast and
at Ballylumford and Coolkeeragh. Those in Belfast are operated by the city
corporation and the remainder by the Electricity Board for Northern Ireland.
Generation is co-ordinated by the Northern Ireland Joint Electricity Authority,
set up by statute in 1967. The output of the stations has, since 1948, been
purchased in bulk and re-sold to distributors—the Belfast Corporation for
Belfast and district, the Londonderry Development Commission for the City
of Londonderry, and the Electricity Board for the rest of Northern Ireland.
As Britain has abundant supplies of coal, together with good rail and water
transport for moving it, most of its electricity is produced by coal-fired steam
generating stations. In some areas oil or natural gas would provide cheaper
fuel but the rate of conversion from coal to these fuels is controlled to cushion
its effects both on the balance of payments and on employment of coalminers.
Hydro-electric development on any scale is comparatively recent, water-power
resources being relatively small and in remote areas. Since 1965, nuclear energy
has become increasingly important.
The output capacity of the generating stations of the electricity boards in
Great Britain at the end of 1970 totalled 56,033 megawatts (MW), an increase
of over 50 per cent since 1963.
In the years 1965 to 1970 an annual average of 2,500 MW of generating
capacity was installed, including 2,700 MW in 1969 and 4,300 MW in 1970.
About 10,500 MW of capacity will come into operation in England and Wales
in the period 1971-73. The SSEB’s plans provide for its total capacity of
5,214 MW at the end of 1970 to be increased to some 7,400 MW by 1973. The
NSHEB capacity of 1,830 MW will be increased to 2,140 MW by 1974.
Sales of electricity in Northern Ireland (where, of the total installed
generating capacity of 1,204 MW, 720 MW is in oil-fired and the remainder in
coal-fired thermal stations) amounted to 3,696 million kilowatt-hours in 1970.
Generation by the public supply in Great Britain exceeded 224,000 million
kilowatt-hours (kWh) in 1970; conventional steam power stations provided

maintained during the past five years, although the total of electricity

 20,000 million kWh in 1970. The major sources outside the fuel industries

An analysis of electricity generation in Great Britain is given in Table 15.
The electricity authorities take about half the British consumption of coal and
about 10 per cent of the consumption of oil. The authorities’ demand for
these fuels continues to expand. However, the growth of demand for these
fuels has been slower than was at one time expected, because of some tem¬
porary slowing down of the growth of demand for electricity and because of
the increasing thermal efficiency of the generating stations. This has led to
some rephasing of the capital programme.
An oil-fired station of 2,000 MW has been commissioned at Fawley, on
Southampton Water, and others are under construction at Pembroke, South
Wales, and at Inverkip, Renfrewshire. A dual-fired station of the same size to
burn either coal or oil is being built at Kingsnorth, Kent, the 336 MW Hams
Hall ‘C’ station near Birmingham has been converted to dual coal/natural gas
firing and the 1,300 1MW West Thurrock station in Essex is being converted.
By the end of 1972 nine further stations totalling 3,000 MW capacity will have
been converted from coal to oil-firing. An oil-fired station of 3>300 MW is to
be built at the Isle of Grain. Average thermal efficiency (that is, the ratio of the
electrical energy output to the heat energy input of the fuel consumed) of con¬
ventional steam stations in England and Wales rose from 2075 per cent in
1947 to 28-20 per cent in 1970 as new plant was brought into use. The 20 most
efficient stations, containing much of the newest plant, had an average thermal
efficiency of 33-41 per cent in 1969-70.

A cross-compound generating unit with an output capacity of 550 MW came
