operation at the Ferrybridge ‘C station, Yorks, in 1966. In 1968 Ferrybridge
‘C’ became the first of the 2,000 MW stations to supply electricity from all four
of its generating sets. By the end of 1970 34 sets had been installed, of which
27 had been commissioned at nine stations. Station capacities are also increas¬
ing. By 1972, ten stations, each with capacities of 2,000 MW, with four 500
MW single-shaft generating units, will be in service. Six larger generating
units, of 660 MW, will be installed at Drax (Yorks) and five at the Isle of
Grain. (For locations see map, inside back cover.) In Scotland, a 1,200 MW
station at Cockenzie was commissioned in 1968 and one of 2,400 MW (four
generating units of 600 MW) at Longannet in 1970. A 1,980 MW station at
Inverkip (three units of 660 MW) is expected to be commissioned in 1975.
Large gas turbine units of 55 MW and 70 MW, based on aero jet engines,
have been introduced since 1965 for peak load operation. The CEGB and
SSEB have installed 919 MW of such units and a further 900 MW are planned.
Smaller gas turbines have been introduced at new stations to safeguard the
auxiliary supplies to the large new steam units, and also to provide capacity for
peak operation. Auxiliary units of this kind in service at the end of 1970 totalled
985 MW, and by 1973 will exceed 1,300 MW.
Hydro-electric generation is at present confined to Scotland and Wales al¬
though a hydro-electric station is planned for Northern Ireland. Most of the
water-power so utilised is drawn from high-level reservoirs with their own
natural catchment areas. The setting up of the NSHEB in 1943 marked the
beginning of an era of intensive water-power development in the Highlands.
In 1970-71, 3,435 million units were sent out by the NSHEB from water¬
power, compared with 322 million in 1949. At the end of March 1971 there
were 54 main hydro-electric conventional stations in operation in the north
of Scotland with a total installed capacity of 1,052 MW and the largest—the
Loch Sloy station—has a capacity of 130 MW. The Cruachan pumped
storage section of the Awe scheme, with an installed capacity of 400 MW from
four reversible-pump-turbines, came into full operation at the end of 1967.
Construction of a 300 MW pumped-storage project at Foyers, Loch Ness,
began in November 1969. It will have two 150 MW reversible-pump-turbines
and is planned for completion in 1974. In addition, there are stations generat¬
ing electricity by water-power in the south of Scotland (122 MW) and in
Wales (469 MW). The latter includes the 360 MW pumped-storage station
at Ffestiniog, which was completed in 1963. (In pumped-storage schemes
electricity generated in off-peak periods is used to pump water to higher levels
from which it descends at peak periods to operate turbo-generators.)
Some 10 per cent of Britain’s public supply generation was in nuclear power
stations in 1970 and the proportion is expected to rise to about one-sixth by
the mid-1970s. Britain accounts for some 25 per cent of world nuclear
generation.
The AEA itself has three main stations which produce electricity for the
national grid: the Advanced Gas-Cooled Reactor (AGR) at Windscale,
Cumberland (14 MW electrical output); the experimental fast breeder station
at Dounreay, Caithness (14 MW); and the Steam Generating Heavy Water
Moderated Reactor (SGHWR) at Winfrith, Dorset (100 MW).
The former AEA stations Calder Hall, in Cumberland (198 MW) and
Chapelcross, Dumfriesshire (198 MW) are now owned and operated by British
Nuclear Fuels Ltd.
Others are owned and operated by the electricity authorities. Under the

first commercial programme, originally announced in 1955 since twice
modified, nine stations with a total design capacity of 4,500 MW were in
operation in 1971: Berkeley, in Gloucestershire (276 MW design capacity),
and Bradwell, in Essex (300 MW), were both commissioned in 1962; Hunter-
ston ‘A’, in Scotland (300 MW), in 1964; and in the following year Hinkley
Point ‘A’, in Somerset, Trawsfynydd, in Wales (both 500 MW), and Dungeness

1966; and Oldbury, in Gloucestershire (600 MW), in 1968. A ninth station,
Wylfa, in Anglesey (1,180 MW), was commissioned early in 1971. These
stations, like Calder Hall and Chapelcross, are all magnox stations—graphite¬
moderated, carbon-dioxide cooled, using natural uranium metal fuel elements
canned in magnesium.
Under a second programme announced in 1964 and extended in 1965, a
further 8,000 MW of nuclear capacity is planned by about 1976. The reactor
design chosen for the programme is based on the AGR at Windscale, which uses
slightly enriched uranium dioxide fuel canned in stainless steel, a logical
development of the magnox system. The first five AGR stations under con¬
struction are Dungeness ‘B’ (1,200 MW), Hinkley Point B , Hunterston B ,
Hartlepool and Heysham (each of 1,320 MW capacity). Further stations of
about 2,500 MW total capacity are to be built at Sizewell. They will produce
electricity more cheaply on base load than the best contemporary coal stations.
A large prototype fast reactor (PER) of 250 MW capacity is being built
at Dounreay where in October 1962 the experimental fast reactor became the
first of such type to produce electricity for public use and to operate at a high
power level. It is due for completion in 1972.
British Nuclear Fuels Ltd. was set up under the Atomic Energy Authority
Act 1970 to take over from the Atomic Energy Authority the manufacture and
reprocessing of nuclear fuels for nuclear reactors in Britain and overseas at
Springfield in Lancashire, Capenhurst in Cheshire and Windscale in Cumber¬
land. In 1969-70 completed export orders for new and reprocessed fuel
amounted to £4-4 million, outstanding orders to £20 million and new con¬
tracts to £7-1 million. Income from fuel services in Britain amounted to £23'9
million.
Main electricity transmission lines—the national grid supply most of the
country. By 31st March 1970 those of the CEGB totalled over 8,500 circuit
miles (13,680 kilometres), of which 6,115 miles (9,841 kilometres) were 400,000
volt, and 2,339 miles (3,764 kilometres) 275,000 volt. Primary distribution in
England and Wales is at 132,000 volts, comprising 11,000 circuit miles (17,700
kilometres) of lines, with secondary distribution at 33,000 volts, tertiary at
11,000 volts and general low voltage distribution at 415/240 volts. In Scotland
there were some 4,500 circuit miles (7,200 kilometres) of main transmission
lines at the end of March 1971, of which 1,500 circuit miles (2,400 kilometres)
operated at 275,000 volts and the remainder at 132,000 volts. Energy move¬
ments on the grid in England and Wales are controlled through the seven
operational areas, set up for that purpose and distinct from the regions in
which the generating side of the industry is organised; each area has a separate
control, and the operations are co-ordinated by a National Control in London.
The grid in Scotland is operated from the control centres at Pitlochry
(NSHEB) and at Kirkintilloch (SSEB). _
The development of the grid system has made the British system the largest
fully interconnected power network under unified control in the world.
Twin cross-Channel cables laid between Dungeness and Boulogne, capable of

transmitting up to 160 MW at 200,000 volts (direct current), have been in

between France and Britain in the timing of peak loads.
A direct current transmission link to reinforce supplies in the London area
is being installed; due for completion in 1971, the scheme—the first of its
kind in the world—will have a capacity of 640 MW.
In England and Wales the Area Electricity Boards distribute to consumers
electricity acquired mainly from the CEGB, supplemented from other sources,
such as industrial plants, and the nuclear power stations of the AEA. There
are 18-5 million consumers. Industrial concerns are the biggest users of
electricity. The principal domestic uses of electricity are for lighting, cooking
and for space and water heating, but the demand for numerous other domestic
purposes is rising steadily.
The NSHEB has about 474,000 consumers, many in remote areas. The
SSEB supplies more than 1 -5 million consumers.
About 5 per cent of the annual gross fixed capital formation of the United
Kingdom in 1970 was attributable to the electricity supply industry. The
industry’s plans for new capital investment are based on a growth in demand
estimated at an annual average rate of 5 -7 per cent up to 1976-77.
Capital expenditure of the electricity supply industry has been expanding
very rapidly: from ^249 million in 1956 it rose to £720 million in 1966 but has
since fallen to £461 million in 1970-71. In recent years about two-thirds of the
industry’s capital requirements have been financed from internal resources.
The statutory limit to borrowings by the industry in Great Britain is £5,200
million. The Gas and Electricity Act 1968 empowered the industry to borrow
(long term) from overseas sources.
The Electricity Council, in consultation with the Secretary of State for Trade
and Industry, is responsible for drawing up a general programme of research,
comprising: direct research carried out by the Electricity Boards themselves,
supported by co-operative research with selected industrial research associa¬
tions and by research contracts placed with universities and other organisations.
The Council itself is empowered to conduct research. It is advised by the
Electricity Supply Research Council. Collaboration on research between the
supply industry and the plant manufacturers is co-ordinated by the Power
Engineering Research Steering Committee set up in 1966.
The main research establishments of the industry are run by the CEGB and
comprise the Central Electricity Research Laboratories at Leatherhead,
Surrey, the Berkeley Laboratories in Gloucestershire, concerned with nuclear
problems, and the Engineering Laboratories at Marchwood, on Southampton
Water. Research on distribution technology and electricity utilisation is under¬
taken at the Electricity Council Research Centre at Capenhurst, Cheshire and
by the area boards.
Both Scottish electricity boards carry out research and experimental work
either on their own or in co-operation with other electricity authorities. The
SSEB undertakes a wide range of research and development work, both
independently and in conjunction with the universities and manufacturers
and, with the NSHEB, is associated with the activities of the Electricity
Council and CEGB.
Public supply of gas in Britain dates from 1807, when Pall Mall, London,
was first lighted with gas. In 1812 the London and Westminster Gas Light
228
Organisation

BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
and Coke Company received a Royal Charter to supply gaslight in London.
In the early years of the industry gas was used almost exclusively for lighting,
provided by a growing number of company and municipal undertakings.
The gas industry in its present form developed in the main during the
period between the two world wars when increasing competition from
electricity had to be met, and by 1939 the industry had become mainly a
supplier of heating rather than lighting.
The Gas Act of 1948 brought the industry in Great Britain, in which about
120,000 persons are at present employed, under public ownership and control
on 1 st May 1949. The assets of 991 undertakings, of which 269 belonged to
local authorities, were vested in 12 Area Gas Boards.1 The central body is
the Gas Council,1 appointed by the Secretary of State for Trade and Industry.
It is both a co-ordinating council and, since the enactment of the Gas Act 1965,
a trading body. It consists of a full-time chairman and deputy chairman, the 12
chairmen of the area boards and up to five other members. Its general duties are
to advise the Secretary of State on questions affecting the industry and pro¬
mote the efficient performance of their duties by the area boards. It also has
specific duties relating to finance, labour relations and research.
The Area Gas Boards, which have a large measure of financial and opera¬
tional responsibility and are similar in most respects to the central bodies of
the other publicly owned corporations, are responsible for the local manu¬
facture of gas and its distribution to consumers. Each of the Area Gas Boards,
appointed by the Secretary of State, consists of a full-time chairman and deputy
chairman, in some cases one or more full-time members, and usually five or six
part-time members, including the chairman of the Area Consultative Council.
There is no common pattern of organisation; each board is fully independent
and has devised its own subordinate structure. Each is required to pay its way,
taking one year with another. The operations of the area boards have resulted,
in the 22 years up to 31st March 1971, in an aggregate disposable surplus of
approximately £95 million before taxation.
In Northern Ireland the gas supply industry remains in the hands of a
number of municipal undertakings and statutory and non-statutory companies.
The main single source of gas in Britain in 1970 was natural gas which
accounted for some 62 per cent of all gas available, compared with 36 per cent
in 1969. Gas manufactured from oil accounted for 21 per cent of total gas
available in 1970 and gas from coal 5 per cent.
In 1970 the quantity of gas produced in Northern Ireland was about
35 million therms, most of it for household use.
Three-fifths of all gas sold by gas boards is for household use and the remainder
for industrial and commercial purposes. Total consumption has been rising
steadily since 1961, after a period when growth was almost negligible. For
the last three years consumption has risen by over 10 per cent each year.
Sales reached a level of nearly 5,773 million therms2 in 1970. There are about
13 million consumers, an increase of about half a million in the past seven
years.
About 40 per cent of the domestic load is used for central heating, with gas
fires and cookers each accounting for about 25 per cent.

Natural Gas
Gas has traditionally been used extensively in industries which require the
control of temperatures to a fine degree of accuracy, for example, in the pottery
industry and in certain processes in the manufacture of iron and steel products.
Natural gas is being used as a chemical feedstock and in bulk fuel markets.
In 1970 sales of gas to industry totalled 1,462 million therms.
Production of coke at gas works in 1970 was 2 million tons (8 million tons
in 1965) and at coke ovens 16-3 million tons, reflecting the use of oil and the
increasing use of natural gas.
Under the Gas Act 1948, borrowing by the Gas Council and the Area Gas
Boards was limited to £250 million. In 1954 the industry’s borrowing powers
were increased to ^45° million, in i960 to ^525 million, in 1963 t° £^5°
million, in 1965 to £1,200 million and in 1968 to an interim limit of £1,600
million with provision for a further increase to £2,400 million. The present
limit is £2,100 million. The Gas and Electricity Act 1968 empowered the
industry to borrow (long term) from overseas sources.
The industry had been spending about £50 million a year on capital
investment in the period 1955 since 1961—62 expenditure has
increased sharply; in 1970-71 it reached £197 million and £202 million is
planned for 1971-72. Between vesting day (1st May 1949) and the end of
March 1971 about £1,650 million had been invested in fixed assets.
Much of the gas industry’s current research and development effort is
concentrated on transforming the industry from one based on manufactured
gas to one based on indigenous natural gas. In 1970 the Gas Council estimated
that the switch over to natural gas in Great Britain would be completed in
seven to eight years.
A phased programme of converting the 30 million gas appliances is in
progress. Investigations are being made into projects involving various
methods of storage of natural gas to meet peak load conditions. Further
storage facilities for natural gas are under construction near Coatbridge,
Scotland, and other facilities are planned.
Since 1964 deliveries of natural gas from the Sahara have been made in liquid
form to Britain. A pipeline system distributed the gas from a terminal on
Canvey Island to 8 of the 12 Area Gas Boards. This pipeline has been
expanded to form a national high pressure pipeline system. By March
1971, some 1,600 miles (2,560 kilometres) of the required 2,500 miles (4,000
kilometres) had been constructed. The central distribution system is fed
from the two shore terminals by five feeder mains. A third terminal is under
construction.
The first productive well in the North Sea was discovered in 1965. Five
major gasfields have now been located as well as a number of smaller struc¬
tures. The former Minister of Technology estimated that production could
exceed 3,000 million cubic feet (85 million cubic metres) per day by 1975. In
1970 the abstraction rate was estimated at 1,100 million cubic feet (30 million
cubic metres) per day.
The first pipeline to pump natural gas to the shore, at Easington in York¬
shire, was put on flow early in 1967. The second pipeline, which comes
ashore at Bacton in Norfolk, came on flow in August 1968, and the third, also
to Bacton, in July 1969. Supplies of gas from an on-shore field at Lockton,
Yorkshire, are expected to rise to an average 75 million cubic feet (2*1 million
cubic metres) a day.

BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Gas Council expects gas consumption to increase by some 20 per
cent a year up to 1975 and therefore substantial expansion is required. The
need to provide additional storage capacity and the strengthening of the
distribution system will also give rise to substantial investment.
The Gas Council has a research committee which advises on research policy
at four research centres. The engineering research station at Killingworth,
Northumberland, has concentrated on large-scale distribution problems.
Research is also carried out on behalf of the Gas Council at a number of
universities and colleges.
Efficiency in the use of fuel, among both industrial and domestic users, has
been assisted by various bodies representing producers and consumers and
by the technical advisory services of the fuel and power industries.
The Coal Utilisation Council consists of representatives of the National
Coal Board, solid fuel distributors and appliance manufacturers and distri¬
butors. Originally formed in 1932, it informs and advises domestic users
on the best use of solid fuel, including the choice of installation and the
operation of solid fuel appliances.
A non-profit-making company, the National Industrial Fuel Efficiency
Service, was formed in 1954 and sponsored by the fuel and power industries
to promote fuel saving in industry. In addition to consultancy work, it provides
advice and services to all non-domestic fuel users in a variety of forms, from
‘spot’ inspection to full-scale surveys and regular visits on a contract basis.
Sponsoring by the fuel and power industries ceased on 1st April 1969 but the
Government is providing a measure of financial support until April 1972,
when it is hoped that the service will have become fully self-supporting.
WATER SUPPLY
Britain’s water resources are, with progressive development, sufficient for
domestic and industrial requirements. The sources of water are often distant
from the areas where supplies are needed, however, and water undertakings
are therefore mainly concerned with abstraction, storage, treatment and
distribution. Supplies are obtained partly from surface sources such as
mountain lakes, streams impounded in upland gathering grounds and river
intakes, and partly from underground sources by means of wells, adits and
boreholes. Unlike other public services in Great Britain, such as electricity and
gas, water supply remains in the hands of a large number of undertakings.
Ministerial responsibility in England and Wales is shared by the Secretary of
State for the Environment and the Secretary of State for Wales; in Scotland it
lies with the Secretary of State for Scotland; and in Northern Ireland with
the Minister of Development.
England and It was not until the nineteenth century that the provision of water supplies
Wales became a general public service, largely due to the efforts of Edwin Chadwick
and his colleagues who demonstrated the dangers arising from inadequate
Organisation water supply and sanitation. The Public Health Act 1848 laid the basis for
a long series of statutes dealing with public health. From the middle of the
nineteenth century onwards a number of water undertakings were set up
to provide water to the expanding urban population, and the water supply
system developed rapidly, although in piecemeal fashion and with some over¬
lapping and waste.

231
Present Supplies
Local authorities have a duty as sanitary authorities to ensure that water
supplies are adequate for the needs of their areas, and they may do this
either by operating water undertakings themselves or by ensuring that other
bodies are providing adequate supplies. Over one-fifth of the water consumed
is supplied by statutory water companies. The householder receives his
domestic water supply at a comparatively small charge, varying in different
areas, which he usually pays by way of a water rate levied, like other rates,
on the value of his house. Industrial users are charged in most cases according
to actual metered consumption.
The Secretary of State for the Environment and the Secretary of State for
Wales have a duty to promote the conservation and proper use of water supplies
in England and Wales and are advised by the Central Advisory Water
Committee on general questions relating to water and organisation of supplies.
Since the passing of the Water Act 1945, over 800 smaller water authorities
in England and Wales have been absorbed by larger authorities or by the
creation of joint boards in order to improve the efficiency of the water supply
industry. There are now some 190 statutory water undertakings of which
about a third are local authorities, a half joint boards of local authorities and the
remainder statutory companies.
The largest undertaking in Britain is the Metropolitan Water Board, which
supplies over 385 million gallons daily to 6 million people in the London
area. It consists of 39 part-time members who are the elected representatives
of the various local authorities within the Board’s area of operations, together
with one representative each from the Thames and Lee Conservancies.
Public water supplies in England and Wales—reaching over 99 per cent of
the total population—now total some 2,900 million gallons a day, out of a total
estimated abstraction of nearly 6,000 million gallons a day (excluding water
used for cooling in connection with electricity generation). Capital expenditure
by water undertakings, which averaged about ^58 million a year in the period
1961-65, has risen to over ^80 million a year. Interest and running costs are
largely met from annual income.
The provision of piped supplies for rural districts has been assisted by
grants under the Rural Water Supplies and Sewerage Acts 1944 to 1971. By
March 1971 schemes costing over ^114 million had been completed or were
in progress with the aid of grants under these Acts.
The Water Resources Acts 1963 (which came into full operation in April
1965) and 1968 created a new administrative structure consisting of 29 river
authorities and a central Water Resources Board to meet growing domestic,
industrial and farm irrigation needs. The river authorities, the Thames
Conservancy and the Lee Conservancy Catchment Board have a majority of
members appointed by the county and county borough councils in their areas.
The remainder are appointed by ministers mainly for their knowledge of land
drainage, fisheries, the public water supply and water in use in industry and in
agriculture. The authorities manage the water resources of river basins
and carry out other functions in respect of land drainage, flood control,
administration of fisheries and prevention of pollution. They are responsible
for assessing water resources and requirements, controlling and developing
resources and securing regulation by a system of licensing. Special arrange¬
ments exist for the Greater London area, where the full range of river authority
control is not necessary. The work of the river authorities is co-ordinated by
the Water Resources Board, an expert advisory body which reports to the
Department of the Environment and the Welsh Office. It reviews national
232
Scotland
Northern
Ireland
Measurement
of Resources
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
water resources and requirements, encourages the transfer of water between
areas according to need, and initiates research. Since April 1969 water con¬
servation has been financed from charges levied by river authorities on the
licensed abstractors and users of water.
The administrative arrangements for water supply and distribution in Scotland
were reorganised by the Water (Scotland) Act 1967 under which the functions
of 200 local water authorities were transferred to 13 regional water boards in
May 1968. The Act also established the Central Scotland Water Development
Board which supplies water in bulk to its seven constituent regional water
boards; it does not supply direct to individual consumers. All the members of
these boards are members of town or county councils.
The water problem in Scotland is broadly similar to that in England and
Wales except that there is not the same need to allocate water between
competing interests and less reliance needs to be placed on underground
sources. The Secretary of State for Scotland is responsible for general over¬
sight and co-ordination and has a general duty to promote the conservation of
water resources in Scotland; and to require regional water boards to provide
supplies of wholesome water everywhere in their districts, where this can be
done at reasonable cost; at present, they supply over 99 per cent of the total
population. The Scottish Water Advisory Committee advises the Secretary of
State on general questions relating to resources and supplies and the organisa¬
tion of the water service. The Rural Water Supplies and Sewerage Act 1944,
as amended, makes available to Scottish regional water boards and to local
authorities grant assistance up to a maximum of £60 million towards the cost
of water supplies and sewerage schemes in rural areas.
Northern Ireland has abundant supplies of water for both domestic and
industrial consumption. Distribution is the responsibility of local authorities,
some of which have combined to form joint boards. About 90 pet cent of the
population has a piped supply and over 100 million gallons are supplied daily.
Under the Water Supplies and Sewerage Act (Northern Ireland) 1945 the
Ministry of Development may pay grants towards the cost of water schemes.
Since 1945 over ^48 million have been invested, of which almost £25 million
were government grants. It is proposed that the Ministry of Development will
become responsible for water conservation, pollution control and the provision
of water supply and sewerage services.
Information on the yield, behaviour and quantity of the nation s surface
water resources is provided in the Surface Water Year Book of Great Britain,
published annually by Her Majesty’s Stationery Office. This publication
contains particulars of the run-off and related rainfall from a large number of
rivers, streams and reservoired areas. The Water Resources Board is respon¬
sible for the collation and publication of hydrological information: the field¬
work of surface water measurement is done by river authorities, water under¬
takings and other bodies. Detailed studies of the resources and use of water in
specified areas have been published in the series of hydrological surveys which
cover approximately half of England and Wales. General information on rain¬
fall, published annually in British Rainfall, is the responsibility of the Meteoro¬
logical Office, while advice on ground water is the responsibility of the Water
Resources Board. The Hydraulics Research Station of the Department of
the Environment at Wallingford and the Water Research Association s station
at Medmenham carry out research into problems of the design and calibration
INDUSTRY
233
Barrages
Pollution
Structure
of gauging weirs and flumes for the measurement of surface water, and into
other hydraulic problems.
Barrage projects involve dams across or within tidal estuaries to form a lake
of fresh water. Full-scale feasibility studies are being made of barrages across
Morecambe Bay and the Dee estuary. Preliminary ‘desk studies’ have been
carried out at Solway Firth, and for the Wash.
A full feasibility study of the use of pumped storage artificial reservoirs in
the Wash has been authorised. The largest desalination plant of its kind in the
world is to be built at Ipswich.
Each river authority is responsible for the control of pollution of rivers and
certain tidal waters in its area and its approval must be sought before polluting
effluents are discharged. Control of pollution in the tidal Thames is exercised
by the Port of London Authority. In Scotland nine river purification boards
have been set up. The Secretary of State for Scotland is advised by the
Scottish River Purification Advisory Committee on questions affecting the
cleanliness of Scottish rivers. In several ports the petroleum companies
co-operate in the prevention of oil pollution from tankers and refineries.
The Water Pollution Research Laboratory at Stevenage investigates
problems connected with the treatment of polluted water, the treatment and
disposal of sewage and industrial waste water, and the effects and prevention
of pollution of surface water and underground water.
CONSTRUCTION
The construction industry includes firms engaged on the construction, altera¬
tion, repair and maintenance of buildings, highways, airfields, drainage and
sewerage systems, waterworks, docks, harbours and canals, sea defence works,
electrical wiring, heating and other installation work, open-cast coal prospect¬
ing and mining, and structural work connected with thermal and hydro¬
electric power stations and telecommunications. About 1-5 million people are
engaged on construction in both the public and private sectors. They repre¬
sent nearly 6-5 per cent of the total civilian labour force and their net output
provides about 7 per cent of the gross national product.
The construction industry is due to complete the change to metric from
Imperial weights and measures in 1972. Design offices did so during 1971;
contractors started working in metric terms on some projects in January 1970.
Constructional work is carried out both by private contractors and by public
authorities which employ their own labour. Over five-sixths of the work is
done by private firms. Although there are over 75,000 firms in the industry,
about a quarter of them are one-man businesses. At the other end of the scale
are about 220 firms each with more than 600 employees.
Public authorities as a whole employ about 350,000 operatives but a very
large proportion of these are engaged on repair and maintenance work which
local authorities, for example, carry out with their own labour.
Over 40 per cent of operatives are occupied on building maintenance, valued
at over £1,100 million annually. The total labour force includes about 800,000
skilled craftsmen, who have been trained for four or five years under the
industry’s apprenticeship schemes. A further 100,000 are employed as
apprentices.
234
Output
Housing
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL|HANDBOOK
Some firms are vertically integrated, owning quarries and workshops,
mechanised plant and standard builders’ equipment; some undertake respon¬
sibility for projects from initial design to finished building. All but the
smallest projects are generally carried out under professional direction, either
by architects or, in the case of the more complicated civil engineering projects,
by consulting engineers. The functions of the latter, acting on behalf of a
client, embrace advice on the feasibility of projects, the drawing up of plans
and the supervision of the constructional work by the contractor.
The Department of the Environment (see p. 51) is responsible for the
construction programmes undertaken directly by the Government (except for
health and education projects), including work for the armed services, both at
home and overseas. It is also responsible for co-ordinating research and
development throughout the government service and seeks to influence
methods and techniques in the building industry as a whole.
The output of the industry has been rising steadily over many years. The
value of work done in 1970 amounted to ,£4,971 million, of which £783
million represented work carried out by the labour employed directly by
public authorities. Private contractors carried out the remaining £4,188
million (£3,325 million on new work and £863 million on repair work).
About 319,000 houses were started in 1970 and some 352,000 were completed,
of which 170,000 were for private owners. Of the £1,135 million of new
housing carried out by private contractors, £549 million, or less than half, was
for private owners and the remainder for public authorities. Industrialised
building methods employing prefabricated components are used in much of
the work.
The National Building Agency is an independent advisory body, managed
by a board of directors appointed by the Department of the Environment and
the Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales, and financed by a government
grant and the fees which it earns. Its main function is to encourage the adoption
of advanced methods of housebuilding, especially industrialised building
methods, as well as to provide technical advice and services, in particular to
local authorities.
Civil
Engineering
Projects
Britain was the first country to develop civil engineering as a large-scale
modern industry and the first to provide techniques, finance and equipment
to carry out major civil engineering projects throughout the world. Prominent
figures in the early development of civil engineering included John McAdam,
pioneer in road construction; Thomas Telford, builder of roads, bridges,
canals, docks and railways; George and Robert Stephenson and Isambard
Kingdom Brunei, pioneers of railway building.
Among important construction projects in hand in the United Kingdom in
1971 were several major conventional power stations and nuclear power
stations (see p. 225), dams and reservoirs, hospitals, large-scale housing
developments, such as the Thamesmead (London) project to house 60,000
people, the new town being built at Craigavon, Northern Ireland, and a £15
million scheme to extend the London underground railway system to London
Airport (Heathrow). Projects for road construction, bridges and tunnels
included about 260 miles (416 kilometres) of motorways under construction
(see p. 301), and the £28 million second Mersey Tunnel scheme. The £6
million Erskine Bridge over the Clyde was completed in 1971.
INDUSTRY
235
Overseas
Constructional
Work
Research
British constructional firms have been as active overseas as in the United
Kingdom. British consulting engineers, in particular, have built up a tradition
of knowledge and integrity which has caused their standards to become
international practice and their services to be in world-wide demand.
A British firm acts as consultant to the World Bank on the Indus Basin
irrigation scheme, the largest in the world, and several firms were involved in
the design of the Mangla Dam, Pakistan, which forms part of it. Other design
projects included a new port at Dammam, to cost between £10 million and
£12, million, for the Saudi Arabian Government, and a £75 million new town
in Abu Dhabi.
Among important construction projects by British contractors in hand in
overseas countries during 1971 were: a £24 million deep-water harbour to pro¬
vide 15 deep-water berths at Dubai in the Persian Gulf; an ^8’5 million road
bridge at Rio de Janeiro; a £4-1 million extension to a cement plant in Uganda;
and a ^9-6 million gas separation plant in Algeria. A British company is
helping to build the £12-5 million Bosphorus bridge.
It has been estimated that the total value of work carried out during the
year ending in March 1971 by some 91 British contractors, operating in 103
countries, was £274 million, compared with £220 million in the previous year,
and that the value of new contracts obtained was ^311 million, compared
with £341 million in the previous year. Members of the Association of
Consulting Engineers had projects worth about £2,032 million in hand on
1 st January 1971.
The Directorate-General of Research and Development in the Department of
the Environment (Construction Industries) is responsible for co-ordinating
research and information services to increase efficiency in the building
industry. The Building Research Station which forms part of the Department
was originally set up in 1921, thus making Britain the pioneer of organised
building research, and is concerned with research into all aspects of building.
It provides a technical advisory service for construction firms. An Agrement
Board, set up by the Government, tests and certifies new products and
methods.
The Construction Industry Research Association carries on research affect¬
ing all sections of the industry.
The Heating and Ventilating Research Association, an industrial research
organisation, deals with problems of heating and ventilation of large buildings.
The major construction firms have research departments working on plant,
materials and methods. Other bodies concerned with research include the
universities and colleges of technology. Most of the producers of primary
building materials have trade associations which maintain research institutions
chiefly devoted to seeking new and more efficient use for their materials.
MANUFACTURING INDUSTRIES
Britain’s manufacturing industries supply a wide range of products, many of
which are of major importance in world trade. Output has increased by over
one quarter since 1963, and in 1970 was 1 -2 per cent higher than the previous
year; output per head showed an advance of 1 -6 per cent in 1970 bringing the
rise since 1963 to 27 per cent. In 1970 this sector spent £1,583 million on
fixed capital equipment (at 1963 prices), 74 per cent of which was spent on
plant and machinery. The number of employees in manufacturing industry
(including the unemployed and those absent from work through sickness and

The employment and production figures listed in Table 16 give an indica¬

Expansion has been particularly marked in those industries utilising advanced

The metal manufacturing industries employ 591,800 persons. Of these, 281,000
are in the iron and steel industry, 112,500 in the manufacture of iron castings,
55,500 in the manufacture of aluminium and aluminium alloys, and 90,000 in
the copper, brass and other base metal industries. Exports of iron and steel
products and non-ferrous metals in 1970 had an aggregate value of £698
million.

Iron and Steel
Britain pioneered the application of coal to the smelting of iron ore from the
seventeenth century onwards and British inventors were responsible for the
discovery of the processes which led to the great expansion of steelmaking in
the second half of the nineteenth century. Today Britain is the world’s fifth
largest steel producing nation. Output of crude steel in 1970 totalled a record
27-9 million ingot tons, 3 -5 per cent more than in 1969 (adjusted for comparison
to a 52-week basis. Pig iron production in 1970 amounted to 17-4 million
tons.
Net deliveries of finished steel amounted to 21 million tons in 1970. The
4-3 million tons of iron and steel products which were exported were worth
£348 million; the United States (£50-5 million), Sweden (^22-0 million) and
Spain (j£i6-9 million) were the main overseas buyers.
The main producing districts are: Wales (30 per cent of total crude steel
output); Yorkshire and Humberside (26 per cent); Northern (17 per cent);
and Scotland (12 per cent). Wales concentrates mainly on the manufacture
of flat products, especially sheet steel and tinplate; the output of the north-east
coast and Scotland is predominantly of heavy steel products (plates, sections
and rails), but a wide strip mill for sheet production is also in operation in
Scotland. Production of special alloy and stainless steels is centred on Sheffield.
During the last decade, fixed capital expenditure totalled some ^1,250
million, reaching a peak in 1961 of ^230 million, due mainly to the strip mill
expansion programme. Expenditure in 1970 amounted to £153 million, of
which some £20 million was accounted for by a major new development by the
British Steel Corporation at Scunthorpe, which will cost £155 million by 1973.
Between i960 and 1970, steel production by the converter processes increased
from 8 per cent of output to over 33 per cent; by electric furnaces from 7 per
cent to 19 per cent; while the share from older open hearth processes fell from
84 per cent to 47 per cent. The emphasis in recent years has been on improving
efficiency rather than raising total capacity and Britain has some of the most
modern plant in Europe.
Output per blast furnace has risen markedly in recent years, due both to an
increase in average size and to improvements in efficiency, such as improved
preparation of raw materials, the injection of fuel and oxygen, and the use of
higher blast temperatures. Industry-wide research and development is carried
out by the Corporate Laboratories of the British Steel Corporation. Total
annual expenditure by the industry is about -£12 million.
Outstanding development projects completed in the last few years include
wide strip mills at new integrated works in Newport (Monmouthshire) and
at an existing works in Scotland; a new plant at Stoke-on-Trent, based entirely
on continuous casting for supplies of semi-finished steel; an advanced unit for
the mass production of alloy and special carbon steels at Sheffield; the world’s
largest electric melting shop and a steelworks in which a linked three-computer
system controls production planning throughout, both at Rotherham; and a
new large-scale steel-making plant at Port Talbot with two oxygen converters,
linked with a deep-water harbour.
The iron and steel industry has been subject to some form of public super¬
vision since 1932. The Iron and Steel Act 1967 brought into public ownership
13 major steel companies together producing well over 90 per cent of Britain’s
crude steel and employing some 70 per cent of the manpower in the industry.
Their shares and securities were vested in July 1967 in the British Steel
Corporation, whose specific duties include promoting the efficient and eco¬
nomic supply of iron and steel products, exports and research development; it is
also statutorily responsible for the finances of the nationalised industry. The
238
Iron Castings
Non-ferrous
Metals
MECHANICAL
ENGINEERING
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Corporation’s Third Report on Organisation, published in December 1969,
recommended the formation of six product divisions, four covering iron and
steelmaking and two covering constructional engineering and chemicals, and
this structure came into effect in March 1970. The remaining private sector
includes some 200 companies accounting for about one-third of the value of the
industry’s sales.
About 900 foundries are engaged in the production of iron castings. Output
of castings in 1970—3-78 million tons—was 1*3 per cent less than in 1969.
The main users of iron castings are the general engineering industry, account¬
ing for nearly one-third of the total tonnage sold and about one-half of the
industry’s turnover, the motor vehicle industry, the manufacturers of pressure
pipes and fittings, the building and associated industries and the steel industry.
Exports are included in the total for iron and steel in the previous section.
The non-ferrous metals industry is the largest in Europe and as a consumer
of aluminium, copper and lead Britain is second only to the United States
among western countries. Output in 1970 included: aluminium, 39,600 metric
tons of virgin metal and 201,600 metric tons of unwrought alloys; refined cop¬
per, 42,200 tons of virgin copper and 157,200 tons of secondary metal; lead,
146,600 tons of secondary metal refined from scrap and 153,600 tons of virgin
lead refined from imported lead bullion; zinc, 146,600 tons of slab metal; and
tin, 22,100 tons. Mining in Britain is confined to the small-scale working of tin,
although plans are in hand to re-open several mines, notably in Cornwall.
In 1970 exports of non-ferrous base metals were valued at ^351 million.
The main products exported, including semi-finished products, were copper
and copper alloys (£126-6 million), nickel and its alloys (£59-5 million),
aluminium and its alloys (£26-4 million) and tin and its alloys (£24-2 million).
The Federal Republic of Germany (£57-6 million), the United States (£31-1
million), and Italy (£25-2 million) were the largest purchasing countries.
Indirect exports are also substantial.
Nearly half of the industry is situated in the Midlands; other centres in¬
clude South Wales, London, Tyneside and Avonmouth, where one of the
world’s largest zinc smelters (capacity 120,000 tons a year) was formally opened
in May 1968. Firms are engaged in smelting, casting and fabrication by rolling,
extrusion and drawing and the techniques of powder metallurgy and pressure
diecasting are also employed.
Two of the three major aluminium smelters whose construction was
approved by the Government in 1968 are now operational. When the three
smelters are in full production they will provide over half of Britain’s require¬
ments for aluminium by 1974.
Britain is also a major producer of the newer specialised metals including
uranium, zirconium and beryllium for the nuclear energy industry; niobium
for aircraft production; and selenium, silicon, germanium and tantalum for
electronic apparatus. Scientific and technological research for the industry as a
whole is conducted by the British Non-Ferrous Metals Research Association.
Mechanical engineering, employing some i-2 million people, comprises a
family of industries including all types of machinery, machine tools, engineers’
small tools, mechanical handling equipment, construction equipment, in¬
dustrial plant, ordnance and small arms, watches and clocks, and scientific
instruments. Vehicle engines are included in the section on vehicles (p. 245).
The volume of production from these industries rose by almost 35 per cent
INDUSTRY
239
between 1963 and 1970. The aggregate value of the main products of all sec¬
tions other than small arms was about £3,500 million in 1970. Exports of
non-electric machinery were valued at £1,642 million in 1970, 12-5 per cent
up on the previous year.
Agricultural
Machinery
and Tractors
Tractors
Metal-working
Machine Tools
There are many hundreds of firms, employing 33,500 people, in the agricultural
machinery industry, including three large firms employing well over 1,000
workers. In 1970 deliveries, excluding tractors, were valued at £72 million
and exports were worth £41 million; the main overseas markets were the
Republic of Ireland, France, South Africa and the Netherlands.
The number of self-propelled combine harvesters, forage harvesters, pick¬
up balers and grain driers in use has increased in Britain in recent years.
Deliveries in 1970 included 2,132 combine harvesters, 3,761 milking machines,
14,260 pick-up balers and 999 grain and grass driers.
The bulk of British tractor output and exports consists of agricultural tractors.
Some 160,000 agricultural and industrial wheeled tractors were delivered in
1970,114,700 (72 per cent) for export. In addition, 21,700 small market garden
tractors were delivered. Exports of new agricultural and track-laying tractors
were valued at £119-8 million in 1970; South Africa (£11 million), the United
States (£7-1 million) and Denmark (£6-i million) were the main buyers.
Production is dominated by two large organisations. Britain has one of the
heaviest tractor densities in the world (see p. 270).
Britain was the birthplace of the modern machine tool industry. The industry’s
output today ranges from watchmakers’ lathes weighing a few pounds to
machines weighing hundreds of tons, and to electronically controlled machine
tools giving accuracies of one-ten-thousandth part of an inch. Almost 3,000
numerically controlled machine tools have been installed in Britain. The
Government, through the Department of Trade and Industry, is assisting the
industry in various ways, including pre-production purchase schemes, nu¬
merical control advisory services and the placing of research and development
contracts.
Deliveries of machine tools were valued at £199 million in 1970, compared
with £172 million in 1969. Recorded exports in 1970 had a value of £87-7
million, 19 per cent up on 1969, and of the orders on hand at the end of
December 1970 (£149 million), 50 per cent were for export; the Soviet Union
(£8-9 million), the Federal Republic of Germany (£8-9 million), the United
States (£8-8 million) and Australia (£6 million) were the main overseas
markets in 1970. N ine major groups account for over two-thirds of the industry’s
output although the high degree of specialisation makes it possible for smaller
firms to flourish. The industry, centred mainly in the Midlands, Yorkshire and
Lancashire, and to a lesser extent near London and Glasgow, employs about
70,000 people.
The Machine Tool Trades Association of Great Britain is the representative
body of most manufacturers and importers, and is responsible for the Inter¬
national Machine Tool Exhibitions held in Britain every four years, the next
being due in 1972. The industry is served by its own research body, the
Machine Tool Industry Research Association.
Industrial
Engines
Britain manufactures a wide range of industrial engines. Deliveries of engines
(including parts) had a value of £143 million in 1970 and exports (including
marine engines) were worth £64-1 million; in addition, parts exported were
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
valued at £21-8 million. The total brake horse-power of the 336,600 internal
combustion engines delivered was 15-9 million, ranging in size from under
3 b.h.p. to over 4,000 b.h.p. Production is concentrated among the large firms
in the industry, and a total of 31,500 people are employed.
Textile
Machinery and
Accessories
The textile machinery industry, one of the oldest of Britain’s mechanical
engineering trades, produces machines and accessories for the manufacture
and processing of yarns and fabrics from all types of natural and man-made
fibres. In 1970, the industry’s exports (£ 123-1 million) accounted for roughly
70 per cent of total deliveries. Principal markets were the United States (£12-4
million), the Federal Republic of Germany (£13-3 million) and Pakistan
(£8-2 million). Comprising about 400 predominantly small-scale firms, the
industry has some 46,000 employees and is situated mainly in Lancashire,
Yorkshire, Northern Ireland, Dundee, Leicester and Nottingham.
Mechanical
Handling
Equipment
Contractors’
Plant
Office
Machinery
Almost every industry makes use of mechanical handling equipment, which
extends from individual units and accessories to complete operating systems.
The value of deliveries in 1970 was £202-1 million, the main products being
cranes and bridge transporters, lifts, escalators, conveyors, elevators and hoists.
In addition, British firms produced 35,000 powered industrial trucks, includ¬
ing 26,900 fork-lift trucks. Exports of mechanical handling equipment (in¬
cluding industrial and works trucks) in 1970 were valued at £84-2 million,
23 per cent more than in 1969. There are many small firms in the industry; in
all, 69,000 people are employed.
Almost the whole range of plant required by the construction industry is
produced, including crawler tractors, motor graders, scrapers, trenchers, dozer
equipment, dumpers, excavators and loading shovels, and crushing, pulverising
and screening plant. The labour force numbers 43,000.
The value of deliveries from the industry was £256 million in 1970 of
which £138 million was for export; earth-moving machinery accounted for
82 per cent of total deliveries. France, the Federal Republic of Germany, the
Irish Republic and South Africa are important markets.
The office machinery industry has been expanding rapidly, with deliveries
(excluding computers and copiers) valued at £127 million in 197° an^ exports
at £66 million (52 per cent). Deliveries in 1970 included 132,700 standard and
273,600 portable typewriters. Deliveries of accounting and similar machinery
were valued at £67 million, of which £3I-6 million was for export, and other
office machinery at £28 million, including £14-6 million for export. Exports of
all office machinery (including electronic computers and data processing
equipment) were valued at £152 million. The most important overseas pur¬
chasers were the Federal Republic of Germany (£19'1 million), the United
States (£18-5 million), France (£18 million) and Australia (£8-i million).
British subsidiaries or associates of United States firms are prominent in the
industry. There are 56,000 persons employed.
Industrial Plant British industry manufactures almost every type of industrial plant and
and Steelwork steelwork, and 188,000 are employed in this branch. Of particular importance
are chemical and oil refining (process) plant, steam-raising boilers, sintering
plant, metallurgical furnaces and plant, lime and cement kilns, nuclear reactors,
water and sewage treatment plant, and fabricated steelwork for bridges, build¬
ings, etc. The industry, comprising both equipment manufacturers and plant

British companies delivered shell boilers and other boilerhouse plant to the
value of 37-5 million in 1970. Water tube boilers of advanced design and of large
steam-raising capacity are produced for power stations, whereas shell boilers
are used for steam-raising and heating in factories and buildings. Exports of
steam generating boilers in 1970 amounted to £7-4 million, and of boilerhouse
plant to ^6-9 million.
The steelworks plant industry provides, in association with firms producing
rolling mills, almost all Britain’s requirements as well as plant for export.
The value of deliveries in 1970 was £25-2 million; rolling mills and ancillary
equipment accounted for a further £20-4 million. This industry consists of a
small number of firms, most of which are business associates or members of a
consortium. India, Pakistan, Algeria and South Africa are a few of the coun¬
tries in which British firms have undertaken major plant projects.
The manufacture and erection of specialised equipment for the chemical and
oil-refining industries has expanded rapidly in recent years. In 1970, expendi¬
ture on plant in Britain by the process industries totalled an estimated £880
million. Exports by the process plant industry (including contractors’ overseas
business) were worth some £340 million. The range of chemical plant produced
includes distillation columns, heat exchangers, high-vacuum drying equip¬
ment, and plant for the manufacture of chemicals from all feedstocks including
petroleum.
Two major consortia, consisting of leading firms in the heavy electrical
engineering, civil engineering, boiler, instrument, and associated industries,
were formed in 1968 to build nuclear power stations for the United Kingdom
electricity authorities (see p. 225). These replaced the three groups formed
in 1959. The Atomic Energy Authority grants them non-exclusive manu¬
facturing licences and is working in close collaboration with them in research
and development.
In addition to the mechanical engineering firms described in preceding sec¬
tions, there are about 1,800 enterprises whose principal product is a type
of machinery not so far mentioned. The main products include: mining
machinery, printing and bookbinding machinery, refrigeration appliances,
space heating, ventilation and air-conditioning equipment, pumps and pump¬
ing machinery, industrial valves and cocks, compressors, scales and weighing
machinery, portable power tools, food processing machinery and many other
types of equipment. The total value of deliveries in 1970 was some .£1,100
million. There are 284,000 workers employed in these industries.
This industry makes a wide range of equipment and appliances, extending
from domestic and commercial refrigerators of varying sizes to industrial
refrigeration equipment for cold stores, manufacture of chemicals and other
products, ice-making plant and refrigeration plant for ships. Total deliveries
of refrigerating machinery were valued at £40-4 million and of space-heating,
air conditioning and ventilation equipment at £92-1 million.
Industrial valves controlling the movement of liquids and gases are a vital
component in many industrial processes, particularly in the chemicals, oil and
electric power industries. The value of deliveries of pumps and valves in 1970
was £186 million and that of air and gas compressors and exhausters £53-2

The value of deliveries of other major products in 1970 was: mining machinery,

The industry manufactures scientific, surgical and industrial instruments; it
has a labour force of 132,000 persons. Deliveries in 1970—some £210 million
—comprised: optical instruments, £12-3 million; electric, electronic, and
nucleonic instruments, ^29‘9 million; and nautical and aeronautical instru¬

Exports of scientific instruments have risen from £27-9 million in i960 to
£64-8 million in 1970. The Scientific Instrument Research Association con¬
ducts research on behalf of the industry.
Radioisotopes are processed and marketed by the Radiochemical Centre at
Amersham, now part of the Atomic Energy Authority (see p. 329)- year

Deliveries of photographic equipment in 1970 totalled £66 million, including
£53-3 million for export, while those of sensitized paper and cloth were worth
£100-8 million including ^38*7 million for export.
The present industry is largely a post-war development. It employs 15,000
people, the majority skilled craftsmen, and many of its factories are located on
new industrial estates in the older industrial areas, particularly in Scotland.
Output in 1970 included clocks (^7-3 million), watches (£4-4 million) and
time switches (^9'4 million) and time recorders and parking meters (^i’2
million); export sales were valued at ^5'^ million.
Behind the firms manufacturing the major products outlined in this section
are about 3,600 enterprises, employing 247,000 people, whose main functions
are to supply parts and components, to conduct research and development
work, and to undertake general sub-contracting, fabricating and repair work.
(Some enterprises are included because the mixed character of their work pre¬
cludes their classification under any single industry.) The sector includes
several large undertakings with more than 5,000 employees. Ball and roller
bearings, and chains, are important products; exports of the former were
valued at £22-i million in 1970 an<^ exports of chains at £^)'2 million.
The electrical engineering industry, with a labour force of 901,000, is engaged
in the manufacture and installation of a wide variety of electrical equipment,
including all types of generating, transmission and distribution equipment;
motors; telecommunications and broadcasting apparatus; and specialised

laboratory and electronic equipment and domestic appliances. The volume of
output rose by over 49 per cent between 1963 and 1970, and the total value of
production in 1970 was estimated at over £2,100 million.
Exports of electrical machinery, apparatus and appliances in 1970 were
valued at £579 million, 20 per cent more than in 1969. Products are exported
to all parts of the world; in 1970 the United States (£45’i million), South
Africa (£37 million), the Federal Republic of Germany (£35-3 million),
Australia (£30-4 million) and the Netherlands (29-5 million) were the main
markets.
The industry’s leading representative organisation is the British Electrical
and Allied Manufacturers’ Association; industry-wide scientific and techno¬
logical research is carried out by the Electrical Research Association.
British scientists and engineers have been responsible for many of the basic
advances in the generation and transmission of electric power. The experi¬
ments of Michael Faraday pointed the way to the production of electricity
as a source of cheap and abundant power. Sir Charles Parsons produced and
patented the first turbo-dynamo, the forerunner of the giant turbo-generating
sets of today.
In 1970 deliveries of electrical machinery were valued at £439 million,
comprising £83-5 million worth of generating equipment, £52-3 million worth
of transformers, £185-4 million worth of switchgear and control gear and
£117-8 million worth of other electrical machinery, including electric motors.
Exports of electric power machinery (generators, motors, converters, trans¬
formers and rectifiers) amounted to £74 million in 1970, the main purchasers
being the United States (£8 million), South Africa (£7-1 million) and Canada
(£6-9 million). Switchgear, starting and control gear exports were valued at
£55 •! million.
About 600 firms manufacture electrical machinery, but two important
mergers in 1967 and 1968 led to the creation of one of the leading electrical
engineering groups in Europe, while a number of smaller firms have been re¬
organised into larger units. The total labour force numbers 189,000. Manu¬
facture takes place in many areas, including Manchester, Rugby, Tyneside,
Stafford and Larne (Northern Ireland).
Production of electronic equipment is one of the most rapidly expanding of
British industries. United Kingdom scientists and inventors have made many
basic contributions to electronics—the thermionic valve, which made amplifica¬
tion possible, the development of radar, the first public transmission television
service, and the ‘printed circuit’, which has led to far-reaching changes in the
radio industry. Gross output in 1970, valued at £1,403 million, was 22 per cent
up on 1969; export deliveries totalled £384 million. The industry employs
355,ooo people.
Deliveries of electronic capital equipment in 1970 were valued at £617 million
(41 per cent of total output), including 249 million for export. (Indirect exports
incorporated in ships, aircraft and machinery are considerable.) Computers
are the most important item of capital equipment; Britain has the largest
indigenous computer industry outside the United States and has supplied
over one-half of domestic computer installations. The merger in 1968 of the
two major British computer concerns created a single group, responsible for
almost all home output. Total deliveries, which have more than doubled
in the last three years, were valued at £209 million in 1970 and exports at
£90-8 million.
244 BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Deliveries of radar and navigational aids were valuedat^i 137 million in 1970,
over six times the i960 level, and almost a half of total output was exported.
Three-quarters of the world’s radar-fitted merchant ships use British equip¬
ment, as do most of the world’s civil airports outside the American continent.
All-weather landing systems and inertial (automatic) navigation systems are
amongst recent developments. Other important items of capital equipment
include electronic control equipment (£79 million), radio communications
equipment (£67 million) and electronic measuring and testing equipment
(^44 million).
Components Deliveries of components (^337* 1 million in 1970) included active components
at ^140-6 million and passive components at ^196-5 million. A recent feature
of the industry has been the growing use of transistors instead of conventional
valves, and the increasing emphasis on miniaturisation. The evolution of micro-
circuit technology has been especially important.
Consumer Goods The consumer goods sector of the industry manufactures radio and television
sets and radiograms. The industry is dominated by several large firms. Output
of television sets in 1970 rose to 2-2 million (including 380,000 colour television
sets); the total sales value of ^136'4 million was almost all in the home market.
Production of radios and radiograms numbered 1-3 million in 1970 and total
sales were worth £20-1 million.
Telecommunications Only a part of the telecommunications industry is concerned with electronics
goods, but it is normally considered as a sector of the electronics industry.
Britain is one of the largest exporters of telegraph and telephone equipment.
Shipments overseas had a value of ^45'^ million in 197°* Research and
development work is done by firms in the industry in co-operation with the
Post Office. The industry employs 88,000 persons, and three firms are
responsible for almost all the output.
Insulated Wires The industry produces cables and wires for the distribution of electric power,
and Cables for telegraph and telephone networks and for many other purposes; its products
include submarine cables and cables insulated by a great variety of materials.
It is supplying the high voltage cable to carry the expanding output of electric
power in Britain (see p. 223). The value of deliveries in 1970 was ^3317 million.
Exports of electric cables, wires, etc., were worth £55 million; the main
purchasers were Hong Kong and the United States. Most of the industry s
labour force of 52,000 are employed in four major groups.

accumulators in 1970 were valued at £18-9 million. The industry has a labour

The industries which manufacture vehicles and aircraft are an important
source of overseas earnings; exports of transport equipment in 1970, valued

In both size and value the largest section of the vehicle industry comprises the
manufacture of cars and commercial vehicles.
At one time located mainly in the Midlands and the London area, the in¬
dustry, during the last decade, has built manufacturing and assembly plants on
Merseyside, in Wales and in Scotland.
Car and commercial vehicle output is dominated by the four largest firms—
British Leyland Motor Corporation, Ford, Chrysler United Kingdom and
Vauxhall—which account for over 95 per cent of complete vehicle production;
the balance is in the hands of smaller, specialist producers of heavy commercial
vehicles, omnibuses, coaches, limousines and sports cars. The principal trade
association is the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT),
which holds a motor show annually in London and a Commercial Motor
Exhibition every two years. The Motor Industry Research Association carries
out collective research on vehicles and components.
Output of passenger cars in 1970 totalled 1-64 million units, compared with
1-72 million units in 1969. Exports in 1970 amounted to 693,400 cars valued
at £330 million. The United States (£62-3 million) was again the largest single
purchaser, followed by South Africa (£i9-B million), Australia and Belgium.
About one-fifth (by value) of all exports went to EFTA member countries
and one-seventh to the EEC.
Production of commercial vehicles, including chassis (146,000 in 1946), totalled
458,000 in 1970, slightly less than in 1969. Exports in 1970 of new commercial
vehicles numbered 148,300 worth £152-4 million. South Africa (£21-7
million), Australia (£16-8 million) and EFTA countries (£24-2 million) were
the main markets. Since 1961 Britain has been one of the world’s largest
exporters of commercial vehicles. The prototype of a gas-turbine-powered
commercial vehicle was demonstrated in 1968.
Exports of parts and accessories for cars and commercial vehicles, including
bodies, chassis and engines, had a value of £290-4 million in 1970; caravan and
trailer exports totalled £22-5 million.
Deliveries of bicycles have declined in recent years, amounting in 1970 to 1-6
million. Most of British manufacturing capacity is in the hands of a single
group of companies concentrated in the Nottingham area. About 900,000
cycles worth £io-6 million were sent overseas in 1970; the United States
(£3-6 million) was the largest single market. A small-wheel bicycle, developed
in Britain, is the first major technical change in the bicycle for 60 years.
Deliveries of motor cycles and three-wheeled vehicles in 1970 amounted to
69,800 and 12,700 respectively. Manufacture is dominated by one large group.
Exports of motor cycles and parts totalled £19 million in 1970, with the United
States much the biggest market.
The British Railways Board has its own workshops which supply British
Railways and certain other users in Britain; private firms build locomotives,
246
Aircraft and
Aero-Engines
Aircraft

BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
carriages and wagons for British Railways, for industrial users and for export.
The total value of exports of railway vehicles and parts in 1970 was fiyz
million; South Africa, Ghana and Canada were the largest purchasers.
Almost all the aircraft produced by the British industry today are based on
civil and military applications of the gas-turbine aero-engine, first developed
by Sir Frank Whittle. The most notable turbo-prop aircraft in current pro¬
duction and operation is the Hawker Siddeley 748, of which over 250 have
been sold or are on order. A second generation of jet airliners, the medium-
haul Trident, the longer-haul Vickers VC10, and the BAG One-Eleven, the
world’s first jet transport designed to operate economically on short-haul
routes, have been in service for over seven years. Other civil aircraft in produc¬
tion include the HS125 executive jet, the Skyvan and the Islander, an
economical feeder-line aircraft. Flight trials of the Concorde, the world’s first
supersonic airliner, developed jointly by Britain and France, are in progress.
The industry produces a wide range of military aircraft, including the
Jaguar, in collaboration with France, and the Harrier vertical take-off strike
aircraft, the second major overseas order for which was placed by the United
States Government in 1970- Britain, the Federal Republic of Germany and
Italy are jointly developing a supersonic multi-rate combat aircraft (MRCA)
to meet the needs of their air forces during the late 1970s and 1980s. It is also
engaged on work on rockets, earth satellites and other aerospace requirements,
including the Blue Streak and Black Arrow satellite launchers.
Hovercraft, a new type of transport vehicle invented in Britain, are being
increasingly used throughout the world. Almost 350 have been built in Britain
up to 1970 and a number of types, including a 170-ton version, the SRN 4, are
in production or under development.
In 1970 exports of the aerospace industry totalled £260 million, 15 per cent
lower than in 1969. Exports of new aircraft and parts in 197° (excluding
electrical equipment) had a value of £133-2 million. Leading buyers included
the Federal Republic of Germany (£21 -2 million) and the United States (£16-4
million). In addition, exports of instruments were worth £6 million, and tyres
£1-3 million. .
The construction of aircraft is dominated by two large airframe manufac¬
turers and one helicopter concern; outside these groups are a few important
smaller companies. Besides extensive research work by the industry, research
on a substantial scale on problems of aircraft and their engines is carried out
by the Government, chiefly at the Royal Aircraft Establishment and the
National Gas Turbine Establishment, both at Farnborough, and the Royal
Aircraft Establishment at Bedford. The British aerospace industry has over
50 collaboration and licence agreements with overseas governments and
companies.
Exports of aero-engines and parts have provided well over £1,000 million in
overseas earnings since 1946, and in 1970 were valued at £114-2 million: major
customers were the United States (£32-9 million), France (£18-5 million) and
the Federal Republic of Germany (£10-9 million). Thirteen different types of
British jet engines power over 30 types of aircraft currently in production
overseas. Famous engines include the economical Dart turbo-prop, the Spey
turbo-jet, the revolutionary Pegasus lift-thrust engine for vertical take-off and
landing (VTOL) aircraft, and the Olympus, the power plant for the Concorde.
In February 1971, Rolls-Royce Limited, the company responsible for al¬
most all of Britain’s aero-engine production, was taken into public ownership,

engines to the United States Lockheed Lion airbus. Development and pro¬

The building of large ocean-going vessels is concentrated in four main areas:
the river Clyde in Scotland, the north-east and north-west coasts of England
and Belfast in Northern Ireland. Numerous yards around the coast build
smaller vessels such as fishing vessels, yachts and harbour craft.
Co-operative research into shipbuilding and marine engineering is under¬
taken by the British Ship Research Association with its headquarters and a
research station on the river Tyne.
A gradual fall in tonnage launched from the 1955 peak of 1 -5 million tons was
halted in 1964, and launchings in 1970 totalled 1 -24 million gross tons, 198,000
tons above the 1969 level. British launchings were the fourth largest in the
world in 1970 accounting for 57 per cent of the world total (5-4 per cent in
1969). Fifteen oil tankers, totalling 373,400 gross tons, were launched in 1970.
Launchings also included 22 bulk carriers totalling 482,300 gross tons and 25
cargo ships amounting to 301,800 gross tons. At the end of 1970 orders on
hand for merchant vessels of over 100 gross tons were 336 (285 in 1969)
totalling 4-9 million gross tons with a record value of £737 million, 25 per cent
up on 1969. Of these vessels, 80 (1 -2 million gross tons) were for export.
Since the publication in 1966 of the report of the Shipbuilding Enquiry
Committee, many British shipyards have embarked on programmes of
modernisation and reorganisation. In many cases this has been facilitated by
assistance from the Shipbuilding Industry Board, set up in 1967, whose life
was extended to the end of 1971. In recent years, modernisation in British
shipyards has been paralleled by major structural changes resulting from the
proposals of the Shipbuilding Industry Board. A series of mergers has led to
the creation of two major groups on Clydeside, one of which is to be reorganised
following its liquidation, one in north-east England, one in eastern Scotland and
one in southern England. Together with one group in Belfast—where the
world’s largest building dock is now operational—they accounted in 1970 for
almost nine-tenths of the industry’s new orders.
There are many specialist ship-repairing establishments and most of the larger
shipbuilding firms also carry out repair work; about one-quarter of ship¬
repairing activity is concentrated on the north-east coast of England. Repair
yards and dry docks are situated in all the large ports.
Many of the larger shipbuilding yards maintain or have closely associated
engine building works, constructing various types of marine slow-speed diesel
engines, usually under licence. One firm designs large low-speed diesel engines
and there are two independent builders of these engines. Steam turbines of the
highest powers are also built.
The group of industries manufacturing metal products not already described
consists of a large number of companies with a total labour force of 637,000
in 1970; the main groups were engineers’ small tools and gauges (72,000
persons), bolts, nuts and screws (45,000), wire and wire manufactures
(44,000), cans and metal boxes (35,000), jewellery, plate, and refining of
precious metals (22,000), tools and implements (22,000), cutlery (18,000), and
