The manufacture of engineers’ small tools and gauges is an expanding
industry, deliveries having doubled in value since i960. Totalling ^135-9
million in 1970, they included jigs and fixtures (£25-9 million), press tools,
moulds, etc. (£23*8 million), hard metal-tipped tools (£18 *6 million) and other
metal cutting tools (£13-3 million). Export deliveries in 1970 totalled £25-4
million. The industry has a labour force of some 74,000 persons.
The production of cutlery and flatware is centred mainly in the city of
Sheffield and the industry’s reputation has been built up on the skill of its
craftsmen. Mass-production methods are, however, extensively used except
in the case of some of the highest quality wares, although firms remain mainly
small. The value of sales of cutlery and flatware in 1970 was £16-3 million,
including export sales of ^4-6 million.
This industry, located mainly in the Midlands, Lancashire, Yorkshire, South
Wales and London, produces a wide range of domestic utensils, such as
saucepans, buckets and dustbins, mainly from aluminium and wrought steel.
The value of sales in 1970 was ^28-1 million, of which £9 million were sales for
export.
The manufacture of hand tools is one of the oldest British industries, covering
the manufacture of such tools as files, saws, hammers, axes and spades;
Sheffield, Birmingham and other Midland towns are the most important
centres. The value of sales of implements and tools, other than machine tools
and portable power tools, was £47-8 million in 1970, of which £15-2 million
worth were exported; the totals included sales of hand tools, at home and for
export, valued at £44 million and j£i4'8 million respectively.
The making of jewellery, gold and silver ware and the refining of precious
metals is an industry in which British craftsmen are heirs to a long tradition.
Most of the firms in the industry are small. The law requires that gold and
silver plate shall not be sold until it has been hall-marked at one of the Assay
Offices situated in London, Birmingham, Sheffield and Edinburgh. The
Birmingham office, located in the main centre of the jewellery industry, is by
far the most important. The total value of sales of jewellery, goldsmiths and
silversmiths’ wares and electro-plated nickel silver wares in 1970 was £29
million, of which ^6-3 million was for export.
The chemicals industry, with a labour force of 471,000, comprises the manu¬
facture of: general chemicals (140,000 employees), pharmaceutical chemicals
and preparations (74,000 employees), toilet preparations (26,000 employees),
paint (33,000 employees), soap and detergents (24,000 employees), synthetic
resins, plastics materials and synthetic rubber (59,000 employees), dyestuffs
and pigments (27,000 employees), fertilisers (14,000 employees) and other
chemical industries (74,000 employees). The industry is capital intensive, its
fixed capital expenditure, excluding mineral oil refining, amounting to over
/i,495 million during the seven years 1963-69, and totalling £376 million in
1970. In January 1970, a leading British company announced plans to double
its chemicals production over the next five years with a £225 million invest¬
ment programme—the largest ever undertaken in the British chemical

industry. The value of exports in 1970 was ^846 million, or 10-5 per cent of
total British exports. Production in the general chemicals industries rose by
58 per cent between 1963 and 1970.
Over half the output of the inorganic chemicals industry consists of a limited
number of relatively simple chemicals, such as sulphuric acid, caustic soda,
chlorine and ammonia, produced in very large quantities and serving as basic
materials for industry. Sulphuric acid has the largest production of any
chemical and 33 million tons were produced in 1970. The remaining output of
this sector consists of a very wide range of chemicals of varying complexity.
Substantial quantities of inorganic chemicals are used in the manufacture
of such products as fertilisers, detergents, paint, glass and metals. About one-
sixth of output is estimated to be exported directly.
Production of organic chemicals (which include coal-tar chemicals) rose
by 68 per cent between 1963 and 1970. To an increasing extent petroleum is
the raw material used and it is estimated that in 1970 petroleum-based
chemicals accounted for over four-fifths of the total output of organic chemicals;
deliveries of feedstock for the petroleum chemical plants totalled 6-2 million
tons in 1970 compared with 0-3 million tons in 1959. The most important
products (by weight) in 1970 were ethylene (982,000 tons) and propylene
(448,000 tons). The main outlets for organic chemicals are plastics materials,
solvents, synthetic rubber, man-made fibres and detergents. Consumption of
dyestuffs is geared primarily to demand by the textile industry; about 34,000
tons of synthetic dyestuffs were produced in 1970.
Exports of chemical elements and compounds amounted to ,£210-3 million in
1970, major purchasers in 1970 were: the Netherlands (£29-9 million), the
United States (£20-4 million), France (^ii'i million) and Australia (,£8-6
million).
The first plastic, Parkesine (later called Celluloid), was produced and patented
in Britain in 1865 by Alexander Parkes; other British discoveries include
polyethylene. Plastics manufacture is one of the fastest growing sections of the
economy. Output of synthetic resins has increased by 79 per cent since 1963
and total production in 1970 was 1-3 million tons (an increase of 18 per cent
over 1969), of which 1 million tons consisted of thermoplastic resins.
Expansion in recent years has mainly been in thermoplastic materials, of
which the most important are polyethylene (used in coverings and packaging—
notably for foodstuffs), polyvinyl chloride (known as PVC and used for a wide
range of industrial purposes and consumer goods) and polystyrene (a cheap
non-inflammable material used for toys, light mouldings and many consumer
goods). One of the newer thermoplastic materials is polypropylene, which can
be fabricated as mouldings, films and fibres. A new family of plastic materials
reinforced with carbon fibres is now in commercial production in Britain; they
are up to three times the strength but only half the weight of steel. Rapid
expansion of capacity for all the main types of plastics materials is planned.
Exports in 1970 amounted to about 549,000 tons, valued at £143-7 million.
The main purchasers were Australia (£14-9 million), South Africa (£12-3
million), Sweden (£10-7 million) and the United States (£8-2 million).
The first general purpose synthetic rubber to be manufactured on a com¬
mercial scale in the United Kingdom was marketed in 1958. High styrene
rubbers for shoe soles and flooring, and nitrile rubbers for use where oil
resistance is required, are in large-scale production, and neoprene rubber is

The development of artificial fertilisers owes much to the pioneer work of
the British scientists Sir John Lawes and Sir Joseph Gilbert. Production is
dominated by three firms and there are a number of firms marketing compound
fertilisers from the principal constituents—nitrogen, phosphorus and potas¬
sium. To encourage use, home sales are assisted by government subsidies to
farmers (see p. 273). Output of nitrogenous fertilisers (in terms of nitrogen
content) has been increasing and in 1969-70 totalled 700,000 tons, while
438,000 tons (in terms of phosphate content) of phosphatic fertilisers were
produced; production of compound fertilisers amounted to 27 million tons
in 1969-70. The use of ammonium nitrate (35 per cent nitrogen), ammonium
phosphate, and, to a limited extent, urea (mostly 45 per cent nitrogen) is
resulting in more concentrated fertilisers. The value of exports of manufactured
fertilisers, mainly nitrogenous, was ^4'8 million in 1970.
Manufacturers’ sales of paint and varnish during 1970 amounted to oyer 106
million gallons (including 22 million gallons of emulsion paint) valued at
/158 million. Britain is one of the largest exporters of paints in the world;
exports of pigments, paints, varnishes and related materials in 1970 amounted
to £44-4 million. Indirect exports in the form of surface coatings for finished
goods are considerable. , ,.
In recent years many improved techniques have been introduced, including
new ranges of synthetic resins and pigments, quick-drying paints and paints
needing only one application.
The whole range of drugs is produced in the United Kingdom, including
antibiotics, sulphonamides, anti-malarial drugs, anti-histamme products,
anaesthetics, vaccines, sera and naturally occurring drugs. Research expendi¬
ture totalled £22 million in 1970.
Notable British contributions to the development of new products include:
the discovery of penicillin by Sir Alexander Fleming and its evaluation by Sir
Howard Florey and E. B. Chain; the evaluation of sulphapyridme (M & B 693)
by Sir Lionel Whitby; the discovery of griseofulvin; and, more, recently, the
isolation of the penicillin nucleus and the development of several semi¬
synthetic penicillins and the cephalosporin antibiotics. Several of the larger
pharmaceutical companies in Britain are subsidiaries of overseas firms.
In 1970 exports of medicinal and pharmaceutical products and goods rose
by 19 per cent to the record level of ^139-8 million, of which £12-2 mi ion
worth were antibiotics. The largest purchasers were Japan (£9 f1'1 lon'’
Belgium (£8-5 million), France (£77 million), and the Republic of Ireland
{£7 million).
Notable discoveries by the British crop protection industry include the
insecticidal activity of BHC (benzene hexachloride), the first selective weed¬
killer, MCPA, and more recently Gramoxone, a non-residual general herbicide
based on paraquat. Sales of pesticides and allied products were valued at
rtf-l million in 1970, 10 per cent higher than in 1969; herbicides (^b-q
million) were the largest single category. Exports of insecticides, fungicides
and weedkillers in 1970 totalled £26-5 million, one-tenth more than in 1969.

Sales of toilet preparations were valued at £134-5 million in 1970, including
export sales of £19-6 million; home market sales of hair preparations totalled
about £33 million. Petroleum is the source of the principal raw materials
used in the manufacture of organic surface-active agents in detergents; the
other main constituent, polyphosphates, is derived from inorganic sources.
Sales of synthetic detergents amounted to 498,000 tons in 1970, including
81,000 tons for export. Deliveries of soap totalled some 262,000 tons. Sales
of polishes in 1970 were valued at £17 million, including floor and furniture
polishes worth £9 million. Exports of perfumery and toilet preparations, soap
and associated products were valued at £67 million.
The textile industries in June 1970 had a labour force of 663,000 persons, half
of whom are women; 45,000 employees are engaged in the production of man¬
made fibres, 81,000 in the spinning and doubling of cotton, flax and man-made
fibres, 64,000 in the weaving of cotton, linen and man-made fibres, 143,000 in
the woollen and worsted trades, 128,000 in hosiery and knitted goods, 57,000
in textile finishing and 44,000 in carpets. The total value of textile exports in
I97° at £397 million was 10 per cent more than in 1969. Production of textiles
rose by 1-i per cent in 1970 and was 25 per cent higher than in 1963. Con¬
siderable vertical integration has taken place connected with the increasing use
of man-made fibres. Four multi-fibre, multi-process groups, founded under
the leadership of man-made fibres manufacturers, control the bulk of Britain’s
spinning and warp knitting activities. Scientific and technical research for the
industry is carried out principally by the Cotton, Silk and Man-made Fibres
Research Association.
Cotton was Britain’s chief consumer goods industry and cotton piece-goods
its largest export during the nineteenth century. Increasing low-cost competi¬
tion has cut progressively into British markets and a global limit was placed
on imports of cotton goods from most countries during 1966-70.
Output in 1970 consisted of: 350 million lb. of single cotton yarn, 171
million lb. of spun man-made fibre and mixture single yarn, 222 million lb. of
doubled yarn, 182 million lb. of textured yarn, 686 million linear yards of
woven cotton cloth, and 530 million linear yards of man-made fibre and
mixture cloth. In 1970 exports of cotton yarn (excluding man-made fibres)
were worth £11 million, exports of woven cotton fabrics were valued at £26-7
million, with the Republic of Ireland and Congo (Kinshasa) the most important
markets.
Most of the industry is located in Lancashire, the north-east of the county
being mainly concerned with weaving and the south-east with spinning.
Manchester is the commercial centre and Liverpool is the chief port of entry
for raw cotton. Under legislation to assist the reorganisation of the industry,
Exchequer funds have paid for two-thirds of the cost of removing surplus
capacity, and have also provided grants of one-quarter towards the cost of
approved re-equipment and modernisation schemes.
The wool textile industry, one of the largest in the world, is the most ancient of
Britain’s staple industries and has been important since medieval times. There
are two main branches—woollen and worsted. The small or medium-sized
business predominates, with only a few large firms. While the West Riding of
Yorkshire is by far the most important producing area, Scotland and the West
of England remain famous as specialised producers of high-quality woollen

cloth. In recent years an increasing amount of man-made fibre has been
blended with wool.
In 1970 output included 176 million lb. of wool and hair tops and 285
million lb. of woollen yarn. Deliveries of worsted and semi-worsted yarn
amounted to 215 million lb. and of woven fabrics to 257 million square yards.
In addition, large, but declining, quantities of raw wool are scoured and
cleaned in Britain. Consumption of raw wool in 1970 was 346 million lb.
Exports in 1970 included wool yarns (£23-4 million), woollen fabrics (£43-4
million) and wool worsted fabrics (£26-7 million). The main buyers of woollen
and worsted fabrics were Japan (£11’6 million), the United States and the
Federal Republic of Germany. Raw wool (cleaned or scoured in Britain) and
other animal hair and tops exported had a value of £41 -4 million. Research is
carried on mainly by the Wool Industries Research Association.
Much of the early development of viscose rayon and acetate took place in
Britain. Production is spread throughout the country with Northern Ireland
of growing importance. Large firms predominate in the industry. There has
been a rapid expansion of output in recent years, the 1970 record total of 1,322
million lb. being 60 per cent more than in 1964. Output consisted of 754
million lb. of staple fibre and 568 million lb. of filament yarn in 1970. Of the
staple fibre, 375 million lb., and of the continuous filament, 367 million lb.,
were of fully synthetic materials.
Two main types of man-made fibres are manufactured: those made from
cellulose (such as rayon) and those produced by fully synthetic processes from
chemical substances (such as nylon). Viscose rayon is still the most widely
used of all man-made fibres and output in 1970 totalled 480 million lb. The
world’s largest rayon staple factory is at Greenfield (North Wales), with an
annual output of over 200 million lb., while other large rayon plants are at
Grimsby and Preston. Almost all the rayon produced in Britain is made by a
single company and its subsidiaries. _ ..
Production of nylon, the first fully synthetic fibre, in the form of nylon 66,
started in Britain in 1941; another type of nylon (nylon 6) has been manu¬
factured since 1963. Total productive capacity for nylon has increased from
160 million lb. a year in 1964, to almost 350 million lb. at the end of ^T0-
Terylene, a polyester fibre, was invented in Britain during the second world
war. It is resistant to fading and is particularly suited to blending with wool
Annual manufacturing capacity totals over 120 million lb. A group of fibres
of growing importance are the acrylic fibres: Courtelle (a British discovery)
and Acrilan are examples. Synthetic elastomerics or spandex fibres, which are
man-made textile fibres having inherent properties of stretch and recovery,
are now produced commercially. .
Exports of man-made fibre yarns had a value of ^63-1 million in 1970, and
woven fabrics £21 -5 million. Switzerland, the United States, the Republic of
Ireland and the Federal Republic of Germany were the most important pur¬
chasers of yarns.
The hosiery and knitwear industry is predominantly one of small-scale
enterprises. Although widely distributed, the industry is centred in the east
Midlands, the north-west of England and in Scotland. Sales of knitted goods
were valued at £308-5 million in 1970 including ^iSU2 million worth of outer¬
wear and fio2‘i million worth of socks and stockings. Sales of knitted fabrics
were worth £152-6 million in 1970. Exports of knitted clothing and accessories
were valued at £45 million in 1970; the largest buyers were the United States,

co-ordinates the export activities of the industry and organises overseas
missions. The Hosiery and Allied Trades Research Association, with labora¬

The linen industry is concentrated in Northern Ireland (the greatest linen¬
manufacturing region in the world), with most of the remainder in Scotland.
Broadly, the Northern Ireland industry concentrates on yarns and the lighter
types of fabrics, while in Scotland production is largely of coarse linens and
canvas, although household types are also produced. Northern Ireland manu¬
facturers produced 30 million linear yards of cloth in 1970, while weavers in
Great Britain delivered 24 million square yards, including 15 million square
yards of sailcloth and canvas. Exports in 1970 included ^6-9 million worth of
linen fabrics and ^4-3 million worth of flax yarns and linen thread.
Jute is manufactured on a large scale in the Dundee area—the centre of the
world’s oldest jute industry—and some 12,000 people are employed in all. Jute
is used in the manufacture of carpets, cordage, ropes and woven into fabrics for
a wide range of applications in the packaging, carpet, upholstery, building and
motor car industries. New uses for jute, as a plastic reinforcement for example,
have been developed. In 1970, 80,000 tons of raw jute were used, and exports of
jute fabric and yarn totalled £1-9 million.
Sales of finished lace goods amounted to ^147 million in 1970. The most
important lace product is from the warp knitting machines, with sales valued
at ^8-3 million. Exports were worth ^3’6 million in 1970.
In addition to the products mentioned above, British textile firms manufacture
a wide range of other goods, including many special yarns and fabrics, net,
household textiles such as blankets, tablecloths and curtains, and floor cover¬
ings other than carpets. Sales of narrow fabrics (including elastic machinery
belting and ribbon) totalled £48-8 million in 1970, including export sales of
^77 million. Sales of floor coverings of linoleum, vinyl and other synthetic
materials were valued at £31-3 million in 1970; just under one-sixth were for
export. The cordage industry is the largest in Europe. Exports of ropes, cord¬
age, nets and netting in 1970 were valued at ^4-5 million.
Over 150 enterprises are engaged in the manufacture of carpets and rugs,
including several large groups. Total sales in 1970 amounted to 155 million
square yards worth £214-1 million. Almost half of the volume of sales is
accounted for by tufted carpets, in the production of which the pile, usually
with a high man-made fibre content, is inserted into a pre-woven backing;
woven carpets, such as Axminster and Wilton make up most of the remainder
of sales, and form about one-third of the value of exports—£39-4 million in
1970. The principal manufacturing centres include Kidderminster (in
Worcestershire), Halifax and Dewsbury (in the West Riding of Yorkshire),
Glasgow and Kilmarnock (in Scotland) and several towns in Northern Ireland.
About one-quarter of the carpets produced (by quantity) are made pre¬
dominantly of wool and a growing proportion of traditional woven carpets
contain some man-made fibre.
There are 533,000 employees in the clothing, leather and footwear industries.
Some 383,000 are in the clothing industry, 96,000 in the footwear trade and
254
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
54,000 in leather, leather goods and fur manufacture. The aggregate value of
their exports in 1970 was £189-4 million.
Clothing The British clothing industry is the largest in Europe and total deliveries
of made-up clothing have increased by 11 per cent since 1963. Exports in 1970,
excluding knitted goods, were valued at ^617 million; Switzerland (£7-3
million) was the main purchaser. Substantial quantities of clothing are also
sent by parcel post.
Although there are some large firms employing mass-production methods
on an increasing scale, the typical firm is small. The principal manufacturing
centres are London, Leeds and Manchester, but several firms are also situated
on industrial trading estates throughout the country. Fashion is important in
the production of haute couture models and throughout the ready-to-wear
industry. The Clothing Export Council, representing over 300 companies,
organises promotions for various sectors of the industry.
Leather Leather tanning is one of Britain’s oldest industries. In 1970 some 11,300 tons
of sole and other heavy leather and about 403 million square feet of upper,
lining and other light leathers were produced. Britain is one of the world’s
leading exporters with exports in 1970 valued at £367 million. The United
States (£7-2 million) is the largest single market, followed by Canada (£3-9
million) and the Federal Republic of Germany.
Tanneries are situated in most parts of Britain, but there are important
concentrations in Lancashire, Cheshire, Yorkshire, the north Midlands and
the London area. Many different types of leather are produced, ranging from
the heavy types for industrial uses, such as machinery belting, to high quality
leather for footwear, leather goods, gloves and clothing. The British Leather
Manufacturers’ Research Association is the foremost of its type in the world.
Footwear The British footwear industry is among the largest in the world. In 1970
manufacturers’ sales of footwear totalled 191 million pairs. Exports of all
types had a value of £35-5 million; the United States (^8-i million), Canada
and the Soviet Union were the largest markets.
Factories are located throughout Britain. Some areas concentrate on pro¬
duction of particular types; for example, the Rossendale Valley region of
Lancashire on slippers, and Leicester and Norwich on women’s and girls
shoes. The Shoe and Allied Trades Research Association enjoys a world-wide
reputation in all matters connected with shoemaking.
FOOD, DRINK The food, drink and tobacco industries employ 848,000 persons in the pro-

1970 was £514 million. Exports of alcoholic and other beverages accounted
for C225 million; sugar, sugar preparations and honey for £307 million; cereal
and cereal preparations for £33 7 million; fruit and vegetables for £22 -2 million,
and coffee, cocoa, tea and spices for £41 -6 million.
Many of the industry’s leading firms have been involved in mergers in
recent years.

There are 156,000 employees in the bread and flour confectionery industry
and a further 34,000 in grain-milling.
There are 51,000 employees producing biscuits, and annual output has been
over 580,000 tons in recent years. Weekly consumption of cakes and biscuits
per head in Britain was 117 oz. (0-32 kilos) in 1970. British biscuits have
gained a world-wide reputation, and, despite the problem of import restric¬
tions in several overseas markets, exports in 1970 were valued at £13-5 million.
The cocoa, chocolate and sugar confectionery industry, which has 85,000
employees, is composed of a small number of very large manufacturers and
many medium-sized and small firms. The main ingredients used by the
industry are sugar, cocoa beans, glucose, milk, nuts and fats. Production of
chocolate and sugar confectionery was 668,000 tons in 1970. Consumption of
chocolate and sugar confectionery in the United Kingdom is among the
highest in the world, being equivalent to 7-6 oz. (0-20 kilos) per head per week.
The value of exports in 1970 of cocoa preparations (including chocolate)
was j£i6-7 million and of sugar confectionery, £19 million. The United States
and Canada were the main markets for sugar preparations. An estimated 30
per cent of total world exports of chocolate and sugar confectionery come from
Britain, the world’s largest exporter of these products.
Fruit and vegetable products include canned, frozen and dried fruit and vege¬
tables, jam, marmalade and pickles. The labour force numbers 75,000. Output
of jams and marmalade, which fell from 329,000 tons in 1949 to about 215,000
tons in 1956, has since remained little changed, totalling 187,000 tons in 1970.
Strawberry, raspberry, apricot and blackcurrant jams are the most popular.
Exports of jams and marmalade in 1970 were valued at £2-6 million.
In 1970, 804,000 tons of canned vegetables were produced. The British
Navy was using canned foods in 1813, but rapid development in the industry
did not take place until after 1935. Processed and fresh peas (287,000 tons) and
beans in tomato sauce (258,000 tons) are the vegetables most in demand as
canned products. In addition, output in 1970 included 93,000 tons of canned
and bottled fruit. Strawberries, plums and rhubarb are the most important
fruits used for canning, followed by fruit salad, prunes and gooseberries. Sales
of prepared fruit pie fillings are increasing.
Sales of frozen foods are rising in Britain, and nearly 212,000 tons of vege¬
tables and 2,000 tons of fruit were preserved by this method in 1970; peas
accounted for 42 per cent of all home-produced quick-frozen vegetables. Sales
of dehydrated products, including accelerated freeze dried foods, are also
increasing.
The industry comprises the curing of bacon and ham, the canning and pre¬
serving of meat and fish, the manufacture of sausages and pies and the pre¬
paration of extracts and pastes. The labour force numbers 107,000. Output of
canned meat and canned meat products in 1970 rose to 132,000 tons, and
the quantity of bacon and ham cured increased to 247,000 tons. There has
been a rapid expansion of quick-frozen fish output, and some 107,000 tons were
produced in 1970; small quantities (9,000 tons in 1970) are also canned.
Exports of fish and fish preparations had a value of £20-8 million in 1970 and
those of meat and meat products were worth £21 -3 million.
The industries producing beer, spirits, wines, cider and soft drinks have a
labour force of 155,000.

Exports of whisky (almost all of it Scotch whisky) totalled 62 million proof
gallons with a value of £194 million in 1970; over half went to the United
States (£98 million or 33 million proof gallons). Scotch whisky was first
distilled in the fifteenth century. It is blended from 20 or more different types,
some from malted barley and some from other grains. Whisky requires several
years to mature, and the 140 million proof gallons of Scotch whisky produced
in the 1970 distilling year will not be on sale for some years. Stocks of whisky
amount to more than 700 million proof gallons, representing 10 years’ con¬
sumption. About four-fifths of annual sales are to overseas buyers.
Production of gin in Britain has risen steadily since the early 1950s. The main
distillers are in London and one company accounts for a large proportion of
total output. Although the larger manufacturers also own distilleries abroad,
exports had a value of £10-1 million in 1970.
There are 87,000 employees in the brewing and malting industry. Recent
mergers have led to the creation of a few major brewery groups, marketing
their products throughout the country. In 197°, 34 million bulk barrels of
beer were produced, the highest since i945> •mcl consumers expenditure on
beer amounted to £1,258 million. Exports in 1970 of malt beer were 409,000
bulk barrels, worth £5-3 million. Firms are experimenting with new methods,
including continuous brewing processes, and automated batch production
plants are well established.
The main raw materials used in brewing are malt, hops and some sugar.
Malt is made almost entirely from home-grown barley. Some brewers make all
or part of their own malt, others purchase it from independent maltsters who
also supply distillers, vinegar brewers and malt extract manufacturers. British
malt is used by brewers throughout the world, and exports in 1970 amounted
to 51,000 tons, worth £2-6 million.
The soft drinks industry has expanded markedly in the last decade although
sales are liable to be seasonal. Output in 1970 included 72 million gallons of
concentrated liquid, and 268 million gallons of unconcentrated drinks. Though
there has been some amalgamation in recent years, there are still several
hundred firms supplying regional markets. There are two very large firms
among about 20 producing widely advertised brands which are marketed on a
national scale. There is also some degree of specialisation by firms in the pro¬
duction of various types, such as carbonated drinks, cola-based drinks, squashes
and cordials, tonic waters and ‘mixers’, and comminuted drinks (in which the
whole fruit is used).
The tobacco industry manufactures almost all the cigarettes and other tobacco
goods sold in Britain. In 1970 consumers’ expenditure on these goods amounted
to £1,720 million (of which about two-thirds was tax revenue) and, in addition,
exports worth £40-1 million (of which cigarettes accounted for 86 per cent)
were shipped to a large number of overseas markets 5 Saudi Arabia, Hong Kong,
and Kuwait were the most important. The main centres of production are in
and around Bristol, Liverpool, London, Manchester, Newcastle, Nottingham,
Glasgow and Belfast. The two biggest manufacturing groups account for over
90 per cent of total output. The industry has 38,000 employees.
The tobacco industry used 306-1 million lb. (138-8 million kilos) of un¬
manufactured tobacco in 1970, all of which was imported. In 197° the main
sources were the United States, Canada and India. Total consumption of
tobacco in Britain in 1970 amounted to 247-4 million lb. (112-2 million kilos),

including 215-4 million lb. (97-7 million kilos) consumed in cigarettes, 27-1
million lb. (12-3 million kilos) in pipe and hand rolling tobacco and 4-5 million
lb. (2 million kilos) in cigars. In 1970 127,900 million cigarettes were con¬

This group comprises the manufacture of bricks, fireclay, refractory goods,
pottery, glass, cement, abrasives, asbestos and other building materials. The
industries have a combined labour force of 330,000 which includes 57,000 in
the bricks, fireclay and refractory goods trades, 80,000 in the glass industry
and 60,000 in the pottery industry.
Firms in the industry manufacture such items as bricks, roofing tiles, chimney
pots, fireclay ware and heat-resisting products including furnace and kiln
linings. Brickmaking, one of Britain’s oldest industries, was introduced by
the Romans, and manufacturing methods vary from traditional hand fabrica¬
tion to highly mechanised systems. In 1970 about 6,500 million building
bricks were produced in Great Britain, 40 per cent of which were of the
Fletton type, made mainly in the Bedford and Peterborough areas. Refractory
goods (firebricks, silica bricks, magnesite bricks and chrome-magnesite bricks)
are manufactured mainly for home use.
The pottery industry, supplying almost all home needs for domestic and
industrial pottery, is a long-established and complex industry, largely located
in the Stoke-on-Trent area of Staffordshire. Much of its raw material is
indigenous, such as china clay, ball clay and china stone from Devon and
Cornwall.
Domestic pottery, including china, earthenware, stoneware, jet and Rocking¬
ham, accounts for about half of the industry’s output; the other main divisions
are glazed tiles, sanitary ware and electrical ware, and such specialised industrial
products as acid-proof stoneware, porous ceramics and laboratory porcelain
are also manufactured. Among famous makes of British pottery are Wedgwood,
Spode, Royal Worcester, Royal Doulton, Minton, Coalport and Royal Crown
Derby. Total sales of domestic pottery were £59-6 million in 1970 including
record export sales of £28-7 million, the highest ever; the United States and
Canada are important markets.
There has been considerable re-equipment; gas or electrically fired kilns
have replaced almost all the coal-fired kilns, and new decorating techniques
and automatic and semi-automatic machinery have been introduced.
Britain’s glass industry is the third largest in the world. The section of the
industry devoted to the manufacture of plate and sheet glass in their various
forms is organised for quantity production, much of it in the form of the
‘float’ glass process, which was developed in Britain and has been licensed
to glass makers throughout the world. Its use for internal decoration and as
a finish for internal and external walls has greatly increased in recent years.
Large quantities of safety glass are produced for the motor industry. Other
products include glass bricks, tubular glass (produced on a large scale),
mirrors, lamp and bulb glass, scientific and medical glassware, glass fibres,
and all types of glass containers (often made by fully automatic machinery).
A traditional product is hand-made lead crystal glassware of very high quality.
Direct exports of glass and glassware reached the record value of £42-i
million in 1970. Those of glass were worth ^22-8 million, the most important

included £7-5 million of float glass.
Collective research is undertaken by the British Glass Industry Research
Association, and much research work is also carried out by the Department
of Glass Technology of Sheffield University.
The cement industry of the United Kingdom with 18,000 employees is chiefly
concerned with the manufacture of Portland cement. Invented by Joseph
Aspdin and patented in 1824, this material and the methods of its production
have been the subject of continuous technical improvement and intensive
research. The capacity of the industry has expanded substantially in recent
years. The Dartford-Gravesend district of Kent is an important producing area.
Annual output totalled 17-1 million tons in 1970.
The paper, printing and publishing industries have 637,000 employees, in¬
cluding 84,000 in the manufacture of paper and board, 63,000 in the produc¬
tion of cardboard boxes and packing cases, 144,000 in the printing and
publishing of newspapers and periodicals, and 256,500 in other types of print¬
ing and publishing.
The manufacture of paper in Great Britain was not firmly established until
1678, but records show that some paper was produced as far back as 1492.
The British paper and board industry is the second largest in Europe. Total
production in 197® all types of paper and board amounted to 4‘8 million
tons. Of this, newsprint accounted for 738,000 tons, board for i-3 million tons
and other paper for the remainder. Exports of paper, board and manufactured
paper items were valued at ^89 million in I970, main purchasers were
the Republic of Ireland, Australia and South Africa.
Wood pulp is the main raw material, but large and increasing quantities of
waste paper are also used. A ^20 million integrated pulp and paper mill, the
first in Britain, was opened at Fort William, in the Scottish Highlands, in
1966. Two-thirds of the timber it uses is home-grown.
There are a few very large groups in the industry and many medium-sized
and small firms. The large groups hold considerable interests abroad, includ¬
ing pulp and paper producing mills in the United States, Canada and other
parts of the Commonwealth and Europe. Sales of household paper products,
including facial tissues, have continued to rise sharply. Sales of cardboard
boxes and cartons were valued at ^135 million in 197° while those of fibre
board packing cases totalled ^I4I million. Sales of manufactured stationery
totalled £153 million in 1970. Wallpaper manufacturing is dominated by
two firms; a recent development has been the introduction of plastic and
plastic-coated wall coverings. Research is undertaken by the Research Associa¬
tion for the Paper and Board, Printing and Packaging Industries.
The printing industry produces an immense range of goods, from national
newspapers and periodicals to books, catalogues and greetings cards. The
industry includes many very small enterprises. Mergers in recent years have
led to the formation of large groups in the newspaper, magazine and book
publishing sections. Three large firms each employ more than 20,000 persons.
General printing, publishing, engraving and bookbinding remains essentially
an industry of small firms.
Book publishers’ turnover in 1970 is estimated at £146 million, of which
export sales accounted for 3^62 million. Consumers expenditure on books,

newspapers and magazines totalled almost £420 million in 1969. Book titles
published in 1970 totalled nearly 331,500, over 23,500 of them new ones.
Popularity of paper-backed books has increased rapidly in recent years. Ac¬
cording to the overseas trade returns, exports of printed matter, manuscripts
and typescripts were valued at £89-9 million in 1970, including books and
pamphlets (^46-3 million), and newspapers and periodicals (£17-9 million),
but these figures do not include parcel post shipments, which are possibly as
large again as the recorded totals. Australia, the United States and Canada are
the most important overseas markets. The Book Development Council, formed
in 1965, promotes the supply and use of British books overseas. Firms have
introduced the latest developments in high-speed printing equipment, includ¬
ing electronic engraving machines and advanced processes of photographic
reproduction, and several newspapers are now set by computer.
Other manufacturing industries include the timber and furniture group, with
293,000 employees, rubber manufacture, with 124,000 employees, and a group
of miscellaneous manufactures which embrace some 220,000 employees, in¬
cluding 110,000 employed in plastics moulding and fabricating.
Britain’s rubber manufacturing industry is the oldest in the world, dating
from 1819. Macintosh invented waterproof garments, and Dunlop in 1888
devised the pneumatic tyre. Tyres and tubes represent more than half the
output of the industry but firms also make a variety of goods, the most
important being rubber footwear, conveyor belting, cables, hose, latex foam
products and other vehicle components and accessories.
In 1970 the industry’s consumption of rubber totalled 478,000 tons, com¬
prising 185,000 tons of natural rubber, 269,000 tons of synthetic rubber and
23,000 tons of reclaimed rubber; the proportion of synthetic rubber used is
increasing. In 1970, 241,000 tons of rubber were used in the production of
tyres and tyre products. Tyre manufacturers include several subsidiaries of
United States and other overseas companies. The largest tyre group in Europe
came into being in January 1971, following the merger of Britain’s leading
tyre producing company and its Italian equivalent. Direct export of all rubber
manufactures in 1970 were worth ^71-1 million, with Sweden, the United
States and Denmark as the main markets. This figure included tyres and tubes
valued at £52-5 million, but excluded large indirect exports on vehicles. In
addition, the industry exported about £4-9 million worth of rubber footwear
and £3-i million of rubber gloves and other miscellaneous products.
London is the largest centre for furniture manufacturing, but High Wycombe,
in Buckinghamshire, is important for domestic furniture.
Deliveries of domestic furniture rose by 22 per cent in volume between 1963
and 1970, and in the latter year their value was ^196 million. Exports of all
furniture were worth £25-3 million in 1970. Numerous enterprises manu¬
facture furniture in Britain (including domestic, upholstered, office, school
and other furniture) with a labour force of 89,000. The bedding industry
employs 20,000 people; sales of new bedding in 1970 were valued at £37-8
million. Many firms are small but in recent years there has been a tendency
towards concentration.
Scientific research and technical information services are provided by the
Furniture Development Council and the Furniture Industry Research Associa¬
tion. The Council is concerned with the management problems of the industry
and produces an annual statistical and economic review.

The brush industry is located throughout Britain, and embraces highly
mechanised establishments as well as small craft units. The value of sales in
1970 was £21-5 million, of which £3-2 million was for export..
The timber industry employs 105,000 people. Britain is mainly dependent
on imported supplies of timber (valued at £239 million in 1970) but sawmill
output of home-grown timber together with the output of home-grown pit-
wood totalled about 70 million cubic feet in 1970. Other products include
plywood and chipboard.
The number of people engaged in manufacturing toys and sports equipment
and children’s carriages in Britain is 48,000. Sales of toys in 1970 were worth
^72’5 million and exports had a value of £28 *9 million. The United States and
the Federal Republic of Germany were the main overseas markets. Current
trends are towards increased production of small-scale precision models of
vehicles and toys linked to television characters.
The value of manufacturers’ sales of games was £7-3 million and that of
sports equipment £26-2 million.
12 AGRICULTURE,
FISHERIES AND

THE LAND AND
ITS USES
Size and

of Farms
AGRICULTURE
Although Britain is a densely populated, industrialised country relying on
imports for nearly half its food supply, agriculture remains one of its largest
and most important industries. It occupies 670,000 people or 3 per cent of the
total working population, provides about 3 per cent of the gross national
product, and uses 47 million of the 60 million acres (19 million of the 24
million hectares) of land.
In Northern Ireland 2-8 million of the 3-3 million acres (i-i million of the
1-3 million hectares) of land are in agricultural use, and the corresponding
proportions for employment and gross product are 9 per cent and 8^ per cent.
The soils of the country are extremely varied. Many of those in the west and
north, overlying hard rocks, are poor and thin. The lowlands and river
valleys are usually fertile, varying in texture from clay through silt to sandy
loam. There is also some peat. Clay soils often require under-drainage. Land
used for farming is conventionally divided into improved land suitable for
cultivation (crops and grass) and rough grazing. In hill country the area of
improved land is often small, but is usually supplemented by grazing on a
comparatively large area of hill land.
In the United Kingdom as a whole there are 30 million acres (12-2 million
hectares) under crops and grass. Improved land, rough grazing, woodlands
(ancillary to farming) and other land used for agriculture together represent
80 per cent of the land area. The rest is mountain and forest, or put to urban
and kindred uses. The area available for farming is gradually decreasing to
meet the needs of housing and industry; however, the loss is more than
outweighed by the increase in output from what remains. Rough grazing,
nearly all of which is hill or mountain land with a native herbage of coarse
grasses, rushes, bracken, heather or scrub trees, has a low potential output—
usually assessed at about one-sixth of that of agricultural land—but is valuable
for sheep. In England and Wales only one-sixth of farming land is classified as
rough grazing. In Northern Ireland the proportion is slightly less than one-
quarter, but in Scotland it is nearly three-quarters.
For many centuries the bulk of land in Britain lay in estates ranging in size
from a few hundred acres upwards, comprising farms of varying sizes let to
tenants. Social changes of the past half-century have completely changed the
pattern of rural life in England and Scotland. Estate duties have been a
principal factor in the breaking up of estates. Most surviving estates are still
owned by private individuals or family trusts, but the Crown, local authorities,
and other corporate bodies hold considerable areas. Of the farms sold, many
have been bought by the tenants already in occupation. About half the farms
in Great Britain today are owner-occupied.
262
Types of
Farming
AGRICULTURAL
PRODUCTION:
CROPS AND
LIVESTOCK
Production
BRITAIN 1972'. AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
There are about 310,000 significant farming units in Britain. Just under
half are very small units, mostly farmed part-time by occupiers who have
another source of livelihood besides farming, and accounting for less than a
tenth of the industry’s total output. About half of the total output comes from
the 10 per cent of holdings classified as large farm businesses, capable of
employing four or more full-time men. There are estimated to be some
171,000 full-time farm businesses in Britain including about 54,000 medium¬
sized (two-three men) and 84,500 small businesses. The number is falling
by about 2 per cent a year.
The average size of full-time holdings in England and Wales is 165 acres
(67 hectares) of crops and grass. In Scotland the crops and grass area of the
22,100 full-time farms averages 171 acres (70 hectares) and the average for the
16,200 part-time and other holdings is only 24 acres (10 hectares).
In Northern Ireland the land is divided into about 63,000 holdings, almost
all of which are owner-occupied. About 40 per cent of these holdings are
either very small or let in conacre (seasonal lettings for crops or grazing), so
that the number of effective farm businesses is about 37,000 of which half
provide a full-time occupation for the owner. The typical farm size is between
40 and 70 acres (16 and 28 hectares) of crops and grass.
Mainly because of economic forces, the majority of British farms have gone
over to a measure of specialised production and the old concept of a general or
mixed farm has, since the second world war, largely disappeared. A feature of
farming over the last 25 years has been the increasing use of intensive methods
of production, both in crops and animal husbandry. In England the farms
devoted primarily to arable crops are in the eastern part of the country in
East Anglia, Kent, Lincolnshire and the East Riding of Yorkshire—although
cereal growing and other arable cropping is a feature of most areas. In
Scotland the rich lowlands of the east coast are also primarily arable. Potato
and vegetable growing on a substantial scale marks the farming of the Fens
(south Lincolnshire and Cambridgeshire), the alluvial areas around the rivers
Thames and Humber and the peaty lands in south Lancashire. Elsewhere,
horticultural crops are widely dispersed amongst agricultural crops.
Dairying and the rearing and fattening of beef cattle are other enterprises
which are widely followed, predominantly in Scotland and western districts of
England. The parts of England bordering the Pennine hills and most of
Wales are also sheep-rearing areas, though a good deal of dairying, based
on purchased feedingstuffs, is also done there. In Northern Ireland mixed
farming is practised, the most important products being milk, fat and store
cattle, pigs and eggs, with sheep and stock raising in the hill areas.. Oats and
barley are widely grown, mainly for livestock feeding, and the only important
cash crop is potatoes, both ware and seed.
The increase in production which has occurred over the past 30 years is a
result of the effort of individual farmers, of farmers’ organisations, of research
workers and advisers and of government action. The role of the Government
is described on pp. 271-76.
The steady expansion in production and in yield per acre of arable land which
has taken place since 1936 is summarised in Table 17. Apart from a slight
decline between 1961 and 1964 and another in 1968 total cattle stocks have
risen steadily each year since 1953. The milk-producing herd has been
fairly constant in size since i960 despite heavy losses in the foot-and-mouth

epidemic of 1967-68. The beef herd is expanding steadily. Numbers of sheep
and lambs reached their highest level in 1966 but have since declined appreci¬
ably. Numbers of pigs and poultry have both expanded by about a third over
the past decade. There has been a considerable increase recently in the size
of the national turkey flock. Arable production has shown a greater diversifica¬
tion since the second world war. Total cereals production (13 million tons in
r970-7!) has increased considerably since i960 reaching a peak of nearly
14^ million tons in 1967-68. Increases in wheat and barley production have
been partly at the expense of oats. Potato production is very susceptible to
weather conditions but on average adequate supplies are being maintained
from a steadily declining area. Between i960 and 1970 output of pigmeat
increased by over one-third and eggs by about one-sixth and these, together
with the increase in beef and milk output, resulted in higher consumption of
feedingstuffs, mostly from home resources. About 6 million tons of con¬
centrated feeds are imported each year depending on the size of the home
crop of cereals.
The index of agricultural net product (all holdings) at constant prices has
risen steadily. By 1953-54 it was about 56 per cent above the immediate
pre-war average. Based on the average of 1954-55 t0 I956-57=IOO> 11 was
135 in 1966-67. On a rebased index, 1964-65 to 1966-67=100, no is forecast
for 1970-71.
Since 1939 the population of the United Kingdom has increased by nearly
8 million, or 16^ per cent. In spite of this growth Britain now produces just
over half of its total food requirements or two-thirds of all that can be grown
in temperate climates; this latter figure comparing with about one-half before
the second world war. Home production of the principal foods is shown as a
percentage by weight of total supplies in Table 18.
Table 19 shows how the level of the main food supplies passing into
consumption has changed since the end of war-time rationing. Rising living
standards have led to increased consumption of high protein foods, such as
meat and eggs. More recently the pattern of food consumption has tended to
stabilise but with a more pronounced trend towards partly prepared and
‘convenience’ foods.
The British climate suits grassland farming, especially in the moister west and
north, where many farms are based almost entirely on grassland production.
Even in the regions devoted largely to arable cropping, grassland forms an
important section of the economy of most farms, whether as permanent grass
mostly occupying land less suitable for cultivation, or as sown grassland
(leys), often part of the arable rotation. Temporary grass may occupy the
ground for only one year or up to seven years before being broken for cropping
or for re-sowing direct to a new ley. A wide range of herbage species and
varieties, including many from British plant breeding establishments, is
available in the seed trade; the main species used in grassland seedings are the
perennial and Italian rye-grasses.
Grassland production, both from permanent and temporary swards, has
been greatly enhanced over recent years by the development and application of
new techniques, notably the use of fertilisers (especially nitrogenous), methods
of grazing control, systems of herbage conservation for winter feed and, on
some farms, irrigation. .
Rough grazings, mostly in the higher country, remain as semi-natural
grassland used for extensively grazed flocks and herds, producing young

Temporary grass has, since 1947, greatly increased at the expense of
permanent grass much of which was of poor agronomic quality. It has also
made some inroads into the rough grazings.
Wheat is grown mainly in the eastern half of the country. There was a sharp
fall in the area under wheat in 1969 following bad weather during the previous
winter and spring. The acreage has since been restored and about 4-1 million
266
Fodder Crops
Sugar Beet
Potatoes
Dairy Farming
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
tons were harvested in 1970, with average yields estimated at 32-9 cwt. per
acre (4-1 tonnes per hectare). Between one-third and one-half of the wheat
crop is used for flour milling, the remainder going mainly for animal feed.
Since i960 the area under barley has increased by over 60 per cent and
in general production has risen faster due to improved yields. The important
malting and distilling market currently absorbs about one-fifth of the crop,
most of the remainder being used for animal feeding purposes.
The widespread use of combine harvesters has necessitated the installation
of drying and storage facilities on many farms. Such equipment is also widely
used on a co-operative basis.
In England, Wales and Scotland the total area of fodder crops has fallen
because in many cases farmers can provide winter feed more economically
by increased grass production and improved methods of conservation. In
Scotland greater use is made of turnips and swedes for sheep and cattle
feeding.
Beet is grown mainly in East Anglia and Lincolnshire where most of the beet
sugar factories are situated. The crop is grown under contract to the British
Sugar Corporation, which takes the entire output at guaranteed prices and also
provides technical advice and assistance. Precision drilling is the usual method
of sowing and more than three-quarters of the crop is mechanically harvested.
Potatoes are grown in most parts of Britain. First supplies of early potatoes,
for immediate marketing, normally come from Pembrokeshire, Cornwall and
Kent at the end of May and these are followed by liftings from other early
growing areas. The lifting of main crop potatoes, which may be stored for use
throughout the season, usually starts in September; the main area for the
production of maincrop potatoes is the eastern side of the country. Seed potato
production for Britain and for export is chiefly centred in Scotland and Northern
Ireland.
Britain is self-sufficient in maincrop potatoes. As yields are gradually
increasing, requirements can be met from a steadily declining acreage. The
area planted with potatoes has declined from 829,000 acres (335,000 hectares)
in i960 to 669,000 acres (270,000 hectares) in 1970. A record yield of 11 tons
an acre for the 1970 crop resulted in a substantial surplus of supplies. A
greater interest in convenience foods has led to an increased demand for
processed potato; home production is expanding to meet the demand but some
is imported. Although the planting, cultivation, harvesting and grading of the
potato crop are becoming increasingly mechanised, much hand labour is still
needed.
Milk is much more valuable when sold on the liquid milk market than when
converted into cheese, butter or other milk products. In Great Britain milk
is produced primarily for liquid consumption, but in Northern Ireland the
greater part of the milk is used for manufactured products. Average consump¬
tion of liquid milk per head is 4-6 pints per week.
Average yields per dairy cow have increased during the last decade by
about 10 per cent and now average some 830 gallons (3,75° litres) a year.
Freedom from tuberculosis has reduced herd wastage, and a campaign to
eradicate brucellosis is under way. Through the artificial insemination (AI)
centres, operated by the Milk Marketing Boards and other organisations, the
influence of a relatively small number of high-potential bulls is widely
disseminated. It is estimated that about two-thirds of Britain s total cattle are
Livestock
Beef Cattle
Sheep
Pigs
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 26j
bred by AI. The Friesian breed is dominant in the dairy herds of England,
Wales and Northern Ireland, but in Scotland the Ayrshire breed is the most
numerous. Average herd size is 30 cows and is expected to increase. Milk
production has also been stimulated by advances in grassland management,
intensive grazing techniques and new methods of making high quality hay and
silage. Most dairy farmers practise some degree of intensive grass manage¬
ment, but hay or silage of the traditional type remain the basic winter feeds;
they are supplemented with purchased concentrates.
Clean dairy farming methods and hygienic standards for equipment and
buildings used in milk production are prescribed by regulations made by the
appropriate ministers.
A great number of specialised breeds of livestock have been developed over
the centuries in Britain. It has been found that they meet the needs of breeders
in most countries and substantial export sales of animals and semen are made
to buyers seeking to replenish and improve their herds.
In the hill regions hardy herds of beef cattle are kept, especially of the Galloway
and Welsh Black breeds and their crosses; in marginal land and lower areas
the sires used are predominantly of the Aberdeen Angus and Hereford breeds.
About two-thirds of home-fed beef production derives from the dairy herds,
some females being mated to beef sires, the majority by AI. There is a large
and complex trade in store cattle (increased by animals imported from the
Irish Republic), a typical movement being from the upland west to grazing
areas in the Midlands.
British breeds have recently been joined by continental breeds, such as the
Charolais, Limousin and Simmental, in the hope that these will, in due course,
make a useful contribution to the British livestock industry. The demand for
lean tender beef at an economic price has stimulated the development of
intensive and semi-intensive systems of production, leading to increasing
popularity for the larger, fast-growing breeds.
Britain has outstandingly good pastures for sheep. Moreover, veterinary
research has provided vaccine and sera protection against nearly all the
epidemic diseases to which sheep are subject. More than 30 breeds and
innumerable crosses are to be found in Britain, each breed having originated
within a circumscribed area.
In the hills, and especially in the Highlands, winter conditions are usually
severe. Draft ewes and lambs are brought from the hill areas every autumn
to swell the lowland flocks, usually in two stages; first, to farms at inter¬
mediate altitudes, where they are mated with rams of a larger and more
rapidly maturing breed; then, the cross-bred progeny pass on in due course
to the more genial lowland conditions and especially to the Midlands and the
south and east of England, where they become crossed again with Down
rams for fat lamb production. The hill breeds bring in hardiness and the
lowland sires fecundity and early maturity. Fat lamb production provides the
main source of income for sheep farmers but wool is also of considerable
importance, especially to farmers in hill areas.
Pig production is carried on in most parts of Britain but is particularly
important in the eastern and southern counties of England. In the past pigs
were found on the majority of farms but there is now an increasing concentra¬
tion into specialist units and larger herds. The most frequently used breeds are
the Large White and the Landrace though considerable cross-breeding takes
268
Poultry
Horticultural
Crops
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
place. Pig improvements are fostered by the Meat and Livestock Commission
and by leading commercial firms through schemes for progeny and perform¬
ance testing, litter recording and other development work. Attention is focused
on utility qualities, such as size and weight of litters, and on food consumed
per pound of liveweight gain. AI is available as a nationwide service.
Carcases are used for curing as bacon, for sale as fresh pork and for manu¬
facturing into sausages and other processed forms. In terms of pig meat, about
30 per cent is used for bacon and 70 per cent for pork and manufacturing.
The British poultry industry has expanded rapidly in the last ten years, largely
owing to the application of improved husbandry and management techniques
in intensive production units and to genetic improvements in stock. There is a
continuing trend towards vertical integration. There are about 60 flocks of
over 100,000 birds and only a small proportion of total production is in the
hands of the smallest producers. About 80 per cent of the laying birds on farms
are in flocks of 1,000 or more. With the rise in the poultry population and in
the yield of eggs per bird (now averaging well over 200 eggs a year), the
estimated production of eggs has more than doubled the 1938 level and for
several years nearly all eggs consumed in Britain have been home-produced.
About 290 million broilers and other special table chickens were produced in
1970.
Horticultural crops occupy only a small fraction of the cultivated land of
the country—about 2% per cent of the area under crops and grass—but their
value in terms of output per acre is very high. The total value of horticultural
crops sold in 1970-71 is estimated at about ^286 million, out of an estimated
total value of £2,364 million for all output from agricultural holdings in
Britain. The June 1970 Census of open-grown crops showed that there were
about 505,000 acres (205,000 hectares) of vegetables (excluding potatoes),
about 204,000 acres (82,500 hectares) of fruit, and 37,000 acres (15,000
hectares) of flowers and nursery stock.
Vegetable and fruit-growing are concentrated chiefly in rural areas with
favourable soil and climatic conditions. Eastern counties continue to be the
most important areas for vegetables with a large degree of specialised growing
for the canning and deep-freeze trade. Other important vegetable areas are
Bedfordshire, Kent, Yorkshire and the Vale of Evesham. Districts with mild
climates such as the Penzance region of Cornwall are favoured for the produc¬
tion of selected early crops. Traditional market-gardening which once
flourished around the large centres of population, notably in the Lea Valley
near London, has declined over the years due mainly to the growth in the
field scale production of vegetables which has accelerated in recent years to
meet the demands of the processing industries.
Specialised horticultural holdings range in size from a few acres to 300
acres (120 hectares) or more. Output per acre of many crops has increased
steadily in response to the introduction of improved planting material, new
techniques of cultivation and environmental control, and to the widespread
use of machinery.
There are about 4,000 acres (1,600 hectares) under glass in England and
Wales, with about 10 per cent in the Lea Valley (in Essex and Hertfordshire)
and other significant concentrations in West Sussex and Hampshire, Lanca¬
shire, the rest of Essex, the East Riding of Yorkshire and Lincolnshire
(Holland). Seventy-five per cent of all glass is heated, and the use of automatic
temperature and ventilation control is now widespread. The use of wide-span
Hops

AND EARNINGS

houses and other technological advances has enabled growers to achieve the
flexibility required in the choice of cropping programme.
Fruit production is concentrated in Kent, Cambridgeshire, Essex and
Worcestershire. Half the cooking apple acreage in Britain, more than one-
third of the dessert apple acreage, more than half of the pear acreage and a
quarter of the plum acreage is located in Kent. About 23,000 acres (9,300
hectares) of varieties of cider apples are grown mainly in Devon, Herefordshire
and Somerset. Soft fruit production is fairly widely distributed but raspberries
are exceptional in that of some 9,000 acres (3,640 hectares) grown in Britain
over five-sixths are in Scotland, mainly in the Blairgowrie district of Perthshire
and in Angus.
Hop-growing for the brewing industry is confined to two main areas, in Kent
and Sussex and in Herefordshire and Worcestershire. Capital outlay and
cultivation costs are very high, but marketed crops per acre average about
12 cwt., worth some £440. The total annual value of the crop is about £7
million.
Estimates of farm expenses and sales and the aggregate net income of agri¬
cultural producers are prepared annually by the agricultural departments
(see Table 20). In June 1970 the scope of the agricultural census was widened
to cover holdings producing commercially significant quantities of agricultural
produce on one acre or less of agricultural land, previously excluded in Great
Britain. On the old basis the aggregate net income of farmers rose from £392
million in 1960-61 to £561^ million in 1969-70. Net income on the new basis
for 1969-70 is £574 million, rising to £589 million in 1970-71. The annual
cost of direct support to agriculture from public funds has averaged £260
million during the past five years. The figures given in Table 20 show that
Britain’s farming is predominantly based on livestock enterprises. About two-
thirds of total farm output is in the form of livestock or livestock products.
Of farm expenses, purchased feedingstuffs amount to about one-third,
wages to about one-fifth and machinery (including depreciation) and equip¬
ment to about one-sixth. Since i960 male agricultural earnings have risen by
about 80 per cent, offsetting the manpower economies made possible by
mechanisation and increasing farm size, while labour productivity has risen
by about 6 per cent a year since 1964-65.
The capital required for land and buildings may be provided by the farmer,
if he is an owner-occupier, or by the landlord, if the farm is let to a tenant.
In 1970 ‘fixed capital’ totalling nearly ^106 million was added to the value of
land and buildings and ^116 million was invested in new plant, machinery
and vehicles. The bulk of the capital required to stock and run the farms
is provided by the occupiers. Bank advances are an important source of
outside capital, both fixed and working; about two-thirds of the total bank
advances to agriculture are believed to be for short-term purposes. Agricultural
merchants are also an important source of short-term credit. Mortgage loans
form the chief source of long-term credit and are provided by specialised
financial institutions (see p. 274) and private sources.
Accounts of some 2,000 farms in England and Wales, collected by university
agricultural economists in 1969-70, show average valuations of occupiers’
capital ranging from just over £10 to more than £70 per acre (£25 to £175 per
hectare), or well over £100 (£250) for intensive holdings. In Scotland a
similar sample of 800 accounts shows a wide range in valuations per acre,

from about £3 (£7-4 per hectare) on hill sheep farms with extensive rough

from over £100 on the more intensive farms to £55 per acre (£250 to £136 per

a heavy item: on dairy and arable farms it averages nearly £20 per acre
(£5° Per hectare); on stock-rearing farms it may amount to £7 per acre
(£17 per hectare).
Britain has one of the heaviest tractor densities in the world, with over half a
million tractors in 1970, or one to every 35 acres (14-2 hectares) of arable land.
Power-take-off implements now characterise arable farming; and some
65,000 combine harvesters were in use in 1970. A wide variety of machines for
harvesting and preservation of grass are employed. Milking machines are
installed on all except the smallest farms, many with mechanical means of
handling milk.
Over 90 per cent of the farms in Great Britain have an electricity supply
and accompanying equipment. There are about 1,100 farmers machinery
syndicates through which farmers have the use of expensive equipment
without tying up their own capital.
Research, development and testing of farm machinery are carried out by
the National Institute of Agricultural Engineering.
The range of net incomes between individual farms is very wade, varying
