AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 271
with the type and size of farm, quality of land, and managerial ability of the
occupier. The average net income for farms of different types is mostly within
the range of £6 to £16 per acre (£15 to £40 per hectare) with the exception
of pig and poultry farms and horticultural holdings, which are more in¬
tensive in their use of land. Net income per acre on dairy and arable farms
has nearly always been higher than on stock-rearing farms, which are generally
larger than the other types and are situated on poorer land.
By the beginning of the 1930s the need for some form of State assistance to
agriculture had become pressing: it was during this time that the Govern¬
ment initiated the various forms of protection and financial assistance for agri¬
culture.
During the second world war and the immediate post-war years, agri¬
cultural production was closely controlled by the State, with County War
Agricultural Executive Committees, composed of landowners, farmers and
farm workers, acting as the Government’s local agents.
The functions of government in relation to agriculture are mostly exercised
by the agricultural ministers, that is to say, for England and Wales the
Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food and the Secretary of State for
Wales, for Scotland the Secretary of State for Scotland, and for Northern
Ireland the Home Secretary, who is the Minister responsible for United
Kingdom aspects of Northern Ireland agriculture, local aspects being the
responsibility of the Northern Ireland Minister of Agriculture. In England
and Wales, the Agricultural Advisory Council and the Horticultural Advisory
Council advise the Minister on the experimental, development and advisory
functions of the Ministry including the identification of subjects on which
further information is required.
The headquarters of the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food is
divided functionally, each division being responsible for a particular sub¬
ject or service. Its relations with individual farmers are conducted mainly
through its local offices, grouped in England in regions, with line management
through regional managers. Local offices in Wales are grouped under a Welsh
Secretary with similar functions and with special responsibility for Welsh
affairs.
In Scotland most of the agricultural functions of the Secretary of State are
discharged through the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries. The
Secretary of State for Scotland also appoints the members of the Crofters
Commission (see p. 275) and the Red Deer Commission, which deals with the
conservation and control of red deer.
The Northern Ireland Ministry of Agriculture is responsible for imple¬
menting agricultural policy inaugurated by the Northern Ireland Govern¬
ment. It is organised on similar lines to the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries
and Food, for which it acts as agent in the administration in Northern Ireland
of United Kingdom agricultural schemes.
In November 1966 an Economic Development Committee for agriculture
was established, comprising representatives of farmers, workers and land-
owners, as well as official members.
Government policy today is founded on the Agriculture Acts 1947 and 1957,
the Agriculture and Horticulture Act 1964 and the Agriculture Acts 1967 and
1970. The main objective, as set out in Section 1 of the 1947 Act, continues to
be ‘a stable and efficient agricultural industry capable of producing such part
272
Annual Review
Price
Guarantees
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
of the nation’s food and other agricultural produce as in the national interest it
is desirable to produce in the United Kingdom, and of producing it at mini¬
mum prices consistent with proper remuneration and living conditions for
farmers and workers in agriculture and an adequate return on capital invested
in the industry’. To this end, the Government is empowered to provide, for
the main agricultural products, guaranteed prices determined in the light of
annual reviews (see below). To facilitate long-term planning, the last Act gave
statutory effect to assurances that set limits to reductions in the price deter¬
minations that may be made after an annual review.
The Agriculture and Horticulture Act 1964 gave the Government powers to
introduce minimum import prices and levy arrangements for agricultural and
horticultural products. Before 1971 these powers were used in the case of
cereals and for eggs and certain egg products. The present system of support
is being changed gradually to one relying increasingly on import levies. To
this end interim levies were introduced in July 1971 on beef, veal, mutton,
lamb and milk products other than butter and cheese, while an existing scheme
for cereals was modified. Understandings with overseas suppliers on the
sharing of the bacon, butter and cheese markets became effective in 1964 and
were renewed in 1969.
In February each year, in accordance with the 194? Act, the agricultural
ministers review the economic condition and prospects of the industry. In
holding reviews, the ministers are required to consult with representatives of
agricultural producers—in practice, the three farmers’ unions in the United
Kingdom. The ministers consider such factors as production trends and
market requirements, world market prospects, the cost of subsidies, income
trend in the industry as a whole, the increasing efficiency of the industry and
changes in production costs. In the light of their conclusions from the review,
ministers determine guaranteed prices for fat cattle, fat sheep, fat pigs, eggs,
wool, milk, cereals, potatoes and sugar beet. These guarantees apply to live¬
stock and livestock products for the ensuing 12 months, and to crops to be
harvested in the current year. Consideration is also given to the relevant
production grants (see p. 273) which are broadly those connected with current
farming activities (for example, the fertiliser subsidy) as opposed to grants for
longer-term improvements, and they are taken into account in calculating the
total value of the guarantees. The Government s conclusions and its decisions
on changes in guaranteed prices and relevant production grants are published
each year.
The cost of government support to the industry in 1970-71 was about
£270 million; the estimate for 1971-72, made before the 1971 review de¬
cisions, forecast an increase to about £297 million.
In general, the present support system acts by means of deficiency payments
to stabilise prices to farmers at appropriate levels. These payments make up
the deficit between the open market price of a commodity and the price
guaranteed by the Government. To encourage orderly marketing of home
supplies the deficiency payments are in certain cases limited to the difference
between the guaranteed price and a target indicator price set by the Govern¬
ment.
The aim of the interim import levy schemes is to limit and reduce the call
on the Exchequer for agricultural support by transferring more of the cost to
the consumer. The guaranteed prices will continue to be the main influence
on producers’ returns.
Production
Grants
Capital Grants
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 273
The deficiency payments scheme for cereals is administered directly by the
agricultural departments, and payment is made on the acreage harvested or
available for harvesting as grain. Deficiency payments for fatstock are made
weekly to producers on certified sales on a liveweight or deadweight basis. For
eggs, a subsidy, based on the difference between the guaranteed price and the
estimated producer price, is paid to producers through registered packing
stations. The Government intends to phase out the subsidy and remove eggs
from the guarantee by the end of March 1974*
For most of the remaining commodities and for fat pigs in Northern
Ireland, the Government operates the guarantee through the appropriate
marketing board, which takes account of any payments from or to the Govern¬
ment in deciding what to pay producers for their produce. In the case of milk
there are five boards, and the full guaranteed price is paid only on a ‘standard
quantity’ relating to the volume of liquid milk sales plus a reasonable reserve.
Milk produced in excess of the standard quantity is sold for manufacturing
below the full guaranteed price. The retail price of liquid milk is determined
by the Government so as to cover the full cost of the guarantee and, taking one
year with another, there is no Exchequer subsidy. Support is provided for
maincrop potatoes (excluding new potatoes) through a system of acreage
limitation and the purchase of surplus potatoes, as many as possible of which
are then sold for stockfeed. The Potato Marketing Board undertakes support
activities in Great Britain and the Ministry of Agriculture in Northern Ireland
in order to bring the average market price for the season up to the guaranteed
price. The Government pays the greater part of the cost.
For wool a fixed price is guaranteed to the British Wool Marketing Board
for every pound of fleece wool it buys from producers. This enables it to fix in
advance a schedule of producers’ prices, based on types and quality, after
making allowance for the Board’s marketing costs.
Under the Sugar Act 1956 and the Agriculture Act 1957 the British Sugar
Corporation contracts to buy the whole of the sugar beet crop produced from
a specified acreage—at present 443,000 acres (179,000 hectares) at a scale
of fixed prices, determined as a result of the annual review and related to
sugar content. Refined sugar produced by the Corporation is sold, under
market-sharing agreements with the refiners, at a price based on the world
price.
The Sugar Board buys Commonwealth sugar under the Commonwealth
Sugar Agreement and sells it commercially. The deficits or surpluses which
result from the transactions of both the Corporation and the Board are
ultimately reflected in the Board’s accounts. When these accounts show a
deficit a surcharge is made on all sugar, imported or home-produced, entering
the British market, including the sugar content of composite sugar imports,
and when there is a surplus a distribution payment is made correspondingly,
so that taking one year with another the Board balances its accounts.
The price supports outlined above relate only to current production. To
increase productivity, however, the Government offers to farmers a wide
range of inducements, known as production grants. In 1970-71 the contribu¬
tion in the form of production grants was £114 million of which ^57 million
was provided as an inducement to maintain breeding herds of cattle and flocks
of sheep (particularly in upland areas). It included a calf subsidy on animals
suitable for beef production.
Grants are available under the farm capital grant scheme, introduced by the

Agriculture Act 1970, towards capital expenditure incurred on a wide range
of work and facilities for agricultural businesses. Among the items eligible for
grant are farm buildings, farm waste disposal systems, facilities for the supply
of gas and electricity, field drainage, roads, fencing, reclamation of waste land
and land improvement. The standard rate of grant under the scheme is 30 per
cent but there are rates up to 60 per cent for certain work. Until March 1972
the rates will range from 40 per cent to 70 per cent. The scheme, which came
into effect on 1st January 1970, replaced many of the old capital grant arrange¬
ments including the Farm Improvement Scheme, Hill Land Improvement
Scheme and field drainage and farm water supply grants, under which total
grants of about £42 million were paid in 1970-71.
A farm amalgamations and boundary adjustments scheme offers grants to
encourage the voluntary amalgamation of small uncommercial farms with
other land to form commercial units. The grant is at the rate of 60 per cent of
the approved costs of the amalgamation until 18th March 1972, after when it
will be 50 per cent. Under a related scheme lump sums or annuities are paid to
farmers who give up uncommercial holdings for approved amalgamations.
Horticultural produce, because it is perishable and liable to seasonal variation
in quantity and quality, does not lend itself to a system of guaranteed prices.
Prior to the 1964 Act the principal means of support was tariffs on imports,
but greater emphasis has since been placed on the need to strengthen the com¬
petitive efficiency of the industry so as to reduce its dependence upon tariffs.
To this end grants of one-third are available to meet the capital cost of a wide
range of buildings, plant and equipment used in the production, storage, pre¬
paration for market and transport of horticultural produce. Additionally,
small-scale horticulturists who are prepared to undertake a three-year pro¬
gramme for improving the efficiency of their businesses may qualify for a grant
of up to £500. The cost to the Exchequer of these schemes is over £4 million
a year.
A number of facilities for specific purposes enjoy government encouragement
and support.
In England and Wales finance for the purchase or improvement of agri¬
cultural land and buildings is available from the Agricultural Mortgage Cor¬
poration Ltd. The Corporation’s funds are derived mainly from public
issues of stock, but it receives some government support. Similarly in
Scotland, loans for agricultural purposes secured on agricultural land in
Scotland are granted by the Scottish Agricultural Securities Corporation Ltd.
Improvement loans for carrying out improvements to agricultural land and
buildings are also available to landowners from the Lands Improvement
Company, whose funds are provided privately.
In Northern Ireland loans are available to farmers from the Agricultural
Loans Fund, administered by the Ministry of Agriculture and financed out
of public funds. Half of the loans issued are short-term for agricultural
machinery and the remainder are medium- or long-term loans for such
purposes as the purchase of livestock, the erection and improvement of farm
buildings and farm dwellings, and the purchase of land for amalgamation and
subsequent restructuring.
Under the Agriculture Act 1967 the Government can make loans in Great
Britain to help finance the purchase of land acquired for approved amalgama¬
tions of small farms (see above), and approved remodelling expenditure.

AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 275
These loans may be granted up to 90 per cent (100 per cent for certain small
amalgamations) of the valuation of the combined unit determined by the
Agricultural Mortgage Corporation Ltd. in England and Wales and the
Scottish Agricultural Securities Corporation Ltd. in Scotland, which act as
the Government’s agents.
Since 1892 county councils and county borough councils in England and
Wales have had powers to provide land for smallholdings. For financial
assistance in improving smallholdings, authorities can obtain the amalgama¬
tions and capital grants available to farmers generally and these are supple¬
mented for certain smallholdings. In England and Wales, about 12,250
smallholdings are provided by local authorities and about 800 lettable holdings
by the Ministry. The Minister and local authorities may make loans for work¬
ing capital to their smallholding tenants. In this way the tenants can be helped
to obtain livestock, machinery, implements and other necessary items;
tenants must, however, have available at least 25 per cent of the capital
required.
Land settlement in Scotland has always been carried out by the central
Government, which now owns and maintains about 420,000 acres (170,000
hectares) of land settlement estates, comprising some 3,355 crofts and holdings.
In the seven Scottish crofting counties—Argyll, Caithness, Inverness, Orkney,
Ross and Cromarty, Sutherland and Shetland—much of the land is farmed
by crofters, tenant farmers whose holdings are generally either rented at a cost
of not more than £50 a year or have an area not exceeding 75 acres (30 hectares).
The Crofters Commission, with headquarters in Inverness, is responsible
for the administration and regulation of crofting. The Commission’s functions
are to reorganise, develop and regulate crofting in the crofting counties, to
promote the interests of crofters and to keep under review matters relating to
crofting. The Commission’s statutory powers include supervising the letting
of crofts and collaborating with other organisations whose activities affect
crofting interests. It also acts as the Secretary of State’s agent in administering
grants and loans for cropping and land improvement.
Land drainage (including flood protection) in England and Wales is the
responsibility of 27 river authorities (see p. 231), two catchment boards
(which exercise the functions of river authorities) and about 370 internal
drainage boards. Local authorities also have general land drainage powers.
There are no comparable authorities in Scotland, where arterial drainage of
agricultural land is the owners’ responsibility. River authorities have powers
to maintain and improve watercourses designated as main rivers. Their work
is concerned with the improvement of land drainage by increasing the capacity
and efficiency of rivers and erecting pumping stations, the prevention of
inland flooding and the construction and maintenance of defences to protect
low-lying areas from tidal flooding. River authorities also have powers relating
to water resources generally, freshwater fisheries and river pollution.
Internal drainage boards are concerned with very much smaller areas and
their work is chiefly in low-lying agricultural districts. Their main function is
to keep the land drained in their area by improving the main drains and,
where necessary, by pumping from low-lying land.
River authorities and catchment boards obtain most of the funds needed for
drainage purposes from local authorities. The Government pays grants to¬
wards the cost of improvement schemes carried out by these authorities. The
276
Land Tenure
MARKETING
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
grants vary from 10 per cent to 80 per cent according to the financial position
of the authority, with an additional premium for sea defence works. Internal
drainage boards levy drainage rates on owners and occupiers and also receive
government grants at a flat rate of 50 per cent. Local authorities receive grants
ranging from 20 per cent to 50 per cent. In Scotland 50 per cent grants are
available to owners or occupiers of agricultural land.
In Northern Ireland the Ministry of Agriculture is the drainage authority
in respect of watercourses designated by the Drainage Council as main or
minor watercourses.
In Great Britain more than half, and in Northern Ireland almost all, farms are
owner-occupied. The traditional form of tenancy in England and Wales runs
from year to year; in Scotland longer leases for terms of 10 to 14 years are
more common, although most tenants farm on a year-to-year basis. The
tenancy agreement may be either written or verbal (in Scotland it must be
written if the period of the lease exceeds one year) and may (but need not)
include provisions about such matters as rights of cropping, liability for repair
and maintenance, and compensation for tenant’s improvements.
In order to protect the respective interests of landlords and tenants and to
eliminate uncertainty as to their rights and liabilities, a code of landlord and
tenant relationships has been written into legislation. The Agriculture Acts
1947 (England and Wales) and 1948 (Scotland) lay down the basic rules of
good estate management and good husbandry for owners and occupiers
respectively. The Agricultural Holdings Acts 1948 (England and Wales) and
1949 (Scotland) as amended by the Agriculture Act 1958 and the Agriculture
(Miscellaneous Provisions) Acts of 1963 and 1968 contain more detailed
provisions concerning the rights and obligations of landlords and tenants.
The Acts provide for any tenancy of agricultural land, with the exception
of certain short-term lettings to which exemption can be given by the Minister
or Secretary of State, to continue in force from year to year until terminated
by a valid notice to quit. With certain exceptions the tenant can contest it by
serving a counter-notice; the notice to quit then becomes inoperative unless
the landlord can satisfy an independent body (in England and Wales the
Agricultural Land Tribunal and in Scotland the Scottish Land Court) that
his claim for possession is in the interests of sound estate management or good
husbandry or that the land is required for certain purposes specified in the
Acts
The Acts lay down a code of compensation to which the tenant is entitled
on termination of the tenancy. Rent is a matter for negotiation between
landlord and tenant and may be varied by agreement at any time or, failing
agreement, by arbitration at intervals of not less than three years in Englan
and Wales and five years in Scotland.
Agricultural products are marketed mainly through private trade channels
such as corn merchants, livestock auctions and markets, and bacon factories;
or through producers’ co-operative organisations. A fairly recent development
has been the growth of contract farming, the growing, for example, of fruit or
vegetables under contract for the freezing and processing industries. For certain
commodities, however, marketing arrangements are influenced by boards
operating under the Agricultural Marketing Act 1958 (which consolidated
earlier legislation). These marketing boards are producers’ organisations with
statutory powers to regulate the marketing of particular products. The schemes
under which they are constituted and operate must be approved by Parliament
Co-operation
CONTROL OF
DISEASES AND
PESTS
Animals
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 277
and confirmed by a poll of the producers. Most of the members of the boards
are elected by the producers but a minority are appointed by the minister or
ministers concerned. Further safeguards serve to protect consumers and other
interests affected by schemes and the public interest generally.
Marketing boards fall into two broad categories: first, those which are sole
buyers of the regulated product from all producers not specially exempted
or, alternatively, those exercising a comparable influence by controlling all
contracts between producers and first buyers; and, secondly, boards which
maintain only a broad control over marketing conditions, leaving producers
free otherwise to deal individually with buyers. The boards for hops, milk and
wool fall into the first category and the potato board into the second. Northern
Ireland has its own marketing boards, based on local legislation, for milk, pigs
and seed potatoes.
The Home-Grown Cereals Authority, established under the Cereals
Marketing Act 1965 to improve the marketing of home-grown cereals,
operates a scheme of bonuses and provides market intelligence. It has reserve
trading powers.
The Meat and Livestock Commission, established under the Agriculture
Act 1967, is charged with improving the production, marketing and distribu¬
tion of livestock and meat in Great Britain. It has a range of executive functions
extending from breeding to retail distribution, one of the most important of
which is to evolve a general scheme of carcase classification. It is not em¬
powered to trade in either livestock or meat.
Since April 1971 eggs have been covered by a broadly based Eggs Authority
which is restricted to support buying and more general market matters.
Grants of up to one-third are available for the modernisation of major
wholesale horticultural markets; Covent Garden market is being moved to a
new site at Nine Elms in south London, which should be in use in the early
1970s.
National statutory grades have been introduced for apples, pears, tomatoes,
cucumbers and cauliflowers to improve the competitive position of home¬
grown horticultural produce as against imported supplies and to speed its
transit through distributive channels.
The Central Council for Agricultural and Horticultural Co-operation was
established under the provisions of the Agriculture Act 1967 to promote and
develop co-operation in agriculture and horticulture and to administer a
scheme of grants. The Agricultural and Horticultural Co-operation Scheme
1971, which superseded the 1967 scheme, provides grants for co-operative
production and marketing of agricultural and horticultural produce, including
capital grants on the same terms as are available to individual producers under
the Horticultural Improvement and Farm Capital Grant Scheme.
The day-to-day work of treating animal disease is the responsibility of the
veterinary profession in private practice. The State veterinary service,
inaugurated in 1865 and covering Great Britain, deals with situations beyond
the control of the individual veterinary surgeon. Centred on London and
Edinburgh, it is able to deal promptly with outbreaks of notifiable diseases.
For many years Britain has been free from many serious animal diseases,
including rinderpest, sheep scab and glanders. Two cases of rabies in imported
dogs occurred in 1969-70 after an absence of cases for nearly 50 years. A
prohibition on imports of dogs, cats and certain exotic species of animal was
imposed but was lifted for dogs and cats in September 1970. The campaign
278
Plants
Infestation
Control
Agricultural
Chemicals
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
to eradicate swine fever has been successful. A major epidemic of foot-and-
mouth disease was experienced towards the end of 1967 but was eradicated
successfully by a stringent slaughter policy supported by other vigorous
control measures; the last case of the disease occurred in June 1968. In i960
the whole of the United Kingdom became a bovine tuberculosis attested area.
The incidence of bovine tuberculosis is now very low; cattle (except for certain
categories) are tuberculin tested at regular intervals and reactors to the test are
slaughtered, compensation being paid to the owners. A voluntary Brucellosis
(Accredited Herds) Scheme, introduced in 1967 as a first stage towards
eradication of the disease, was replaced in 1970 by an incentives scheme which
offers payments for healthy herds rather than compensation for reacting
animals. On 1st November 1971 a start will be made with eradication schemes
in three areas—in north-west England, in south-west Wales and in western
Scotland, including certain of the Western Islands. Fowl pest, which had
declined,considerably since 1963, reappeared in epidemic proportions in a
series of outbreaks in 1970 and early 1971 after which outbreaks declined.
The work of the service is backed by the extensive facilities of the Central
Veterinary Laboratory at Weybridge, Surrey, and those of its subsidiary
laboratory at Lasswade, near Edinburgh. In addition, there are 22 investiga¬
tion centres with well-equipped laboratories in England and Wales. These
centres perform work requiring specialist knowledge and give advice on
disease problems to private practitioners. In Scotland a similar service is
provided by the investigation centres of the three Scottish agricultural colleges.
In Northern Ireland the veterinary services are organised similarly to those
in Great Britain but are administered separately by the Northern Ireland
Government. Animal health control policies and the geographical situation
have kept the country free from nearly all the major epizootic diseases. A
scheme for the eradication of brucellosis was virtually complete by mid-1971.
The full-time veterinary service is supplemented by the central veterinary
laboratory at Stormont, Belfast.
The plant health services, operated by the Agricultural Departments, are
responsible for statutory controls designed to limit the spread of plant pests
and diseases present in Britain and prevent the introduction of new ones from
abroad. They also issue the health certificates required by other countries to
accompany plant material imported from Britain. Voluntary certification
schemes are operated to encourage the development of healthy vigorous and
true-to-type planting stocks, particularly of crops subject to degenerative
diseases. The Plant Pathology Laboratory at Harpenden, Hertfordshire, and
the Agricultural Scientific Services Station, East Craigs, Edinburgh, provide
scientific and technical advice on which statutory controls and certification
schemes are based.
The problems of controlling mammalian and avian pests are studied at the
Ministry of Agriculture’s Pest Infestation Control Laboratory at Tolworth,
Surrey, and its Land Pests Department at Worplesdon, Surrey; a branch
at Slough, Buckinghamshire, studies insect infestation of stored food pro¬
ducts. The laboratories provide information to and liaise closely with Regional
Pest Officers who in turn advise local authorities, farmers and others on
modern control techniques.
Safeguards against the dangers which could arise from uncontrolled use of
pesticides have been devised and are operating successfully. Regulations made
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 279
under the Agriculture (Poisonous Substances) Act 1952 provide protection
for workers using the more toxic chemicals. The voluntary Pesticides Safety
Precautions Scheme, operated by the Government with the support of
industry, ensures that new pesticides intended for use in agriculture, forestry
and food storage, or new methods of using existing pesticides, are not intro¬
duced until enough experimental work has been done on their possible hazards
(including those to users, consumers of treated produce, livestock or domestic
animals and wild life) to allow the Government to make recommendations for
their safe use. Products approved for safety may then be submitted through the
Agricultural Chemicals Approval Scheme for efficiency approval. The purpose
of this scheme is to enable users and advisers to choose efficient proprietary
brands of agricultural chemicals for the control of pests and diseases, the
destruction of weeds, for growth regulation and for the control of insects and
mite pests of stored grain.
Under a similar voluntary scheme, veterinary products on direct sale to
farmers are scientifically considered and recommendations made for safe use.
Since 1969, stricter controls on the use of antibiotics in animal husbandry
and veterinary medicines have been and are being introduced. As a result an
increasing number of antibiotics formerly used freely in feedstuffs are now
available only on prescription or with veterinary authority.
A key role in the administration of the safety schemes is played by the
Government’s Advisory Committee on Pesticides and Other Toxic Chemicals.
Its report, published in 1969, concluded that there was no evidence that the
use of certain persistent organochlorine pesticides had any adverse effects on
human beings. However, to reduce amounts in the environment the Committee
recommended that certain of these chemicals (including DDT, aldrin and
dieldrin) should be withdrawn. Its recommendations will have been im¬
plemented by the end of September 1971.
The Medicines Act 1968 provides for the safety, quality and efficacy of
medicine products for both human and veterinary use, including use in animal
feedingstuffs, mainly through a system of licensing and control of sale and
supply. It is being brought into effect on a series of ‘appointed days’ as
necessary subordinate legislation is introduced. The British health and
agriculture ministers are advised by a Medicines Commission and by expert
licensing committees. The new arrangements will, in due course, replace and
amplify the voluntary scheme and certain statutory controls.
AGRICULTURAL
ADVISORY
SERVICE
In England and Wales technical advice on all agricultural and horticultural
matters is available through the Agricultural Development Advisory Service
(ADAS), a unified service which has operated since March 1971 and which
comprises the former National Agricultural Advisory Service, the Agricultural
Land Service, the State Veterinary Service and the Drainage and Water
Supplies Service. ADAS, which operates mainly from the Ministry’s regional
and divisional offices, provides free advice when no alternative commercial
source of advice exists. It charges only for certain services, such as soil
sampling and laboratory analysis.
When possible ADAS concentrates on group rather than individual advice.
In Scotland the agricultural advisory service is provided by the three
regional independent colleges which are financed almost entirely by public
funds. The service is similar to that provided by the ADAS and covers all
branches of advice.
In Northern Ireland advisory work is organised by the Ministry of Agri¬
culture on a county and district basis.

Basic agricultural research in Britain is described on p. 32^- The ADAS
operates 22 experimental husbandry farms and horticulture stations, and two
sub-stations whose functions are to investigate local and national problems, to
test research findings and integrate them into improved production systems
and to communicate them to advisers and the industry. In England and Wales,
research in agricultural economics is undertaken by 12 university Depart¬
ments of Agricultural Economics. Ten of these conduct work on farm incomes
and the economics of particular products for the Ministry of Agriculture,
Fisheries and Food (see p. 269). In Scotland, agricultural economists are on
the staff of the three agricultural colleges. The agricultural departments in
England and Wales and Scotland have economics and statistics units.
The Northern Ireland Ministry of Agriculture also has an Economics and
Statistics Division and nine other research divisions dealing with different
aspects of agricultural research and development and responsible for university
teaching of agriculture.
There are four types of institution which provide full-time education in
agricultural subjects: universities; non-maintained agricultural colleges,
in England and Wales, county agricultural colleges and institutes; and in
Scotland, farm schools. Ten universities in Britain provide degree and post¬
graduate training in agriculture. A National College of Agricultural Engineer¬
ing was established in i960 at Silsoe, Bedfordshire, and it offers degree and
postgraduate courses in agricultural engineering. In Northern Ireland there
are three agricultural colleges offering non-degree courses while Queen s
University, Belfast, provides degrees.
The three agricultural colleges in Scotland which provide advisory services
are also teaching establishments whose prime function is to provide diploma
and post-diploma courses.
A new pattern of three-year sandwich courses leading to Ordinary and
Higher National Diplomas has been introduced at the four non-mamtamed
agricultural colleges and at 17 of the county agricultural colleges and institutes
in England and Wales. Similar courses are provided at the three agricultural
colleges in Scotland and at two of the colleges in Northern Ireland. The older
two-year courses will be phased out in a year or two as the new pattern be¬
comes established. The 34 county colleges and institutes in England and the
six in Wales also provide one-year residential courses in general agriculture or
horticulture with supplementary courses covering the various specialisms in
greater depth and five of them offer a new pattern of two-year sandwich
courses leading to the award of the National Stockmans Certificate in Pou try
Practice. Local education authorities also provide short courses, block-release,
day-release and other part-time classes for farmers, farm workers and horti¬
culturists, as well as an advisory service for domestic producers.
An Agricultural, Horticultural and Forestry Industry Training Board was
set up in 1966 under the Industrial Training Act 1964 (see p. 395)- Grants are
available to employees on recognised courses in agriculture, horticulture or
forestry. Where possible the Board arranges courses through industrial or
local authority facilities but otherwise runs its own courses. The Board s
expenses in respect of forestry are met by a levy on employers within
the private sector. This is the usual method of financing training boards
but, owing to special circumstances in agriculture, agricultural and horti¬
cultural training is financed by a direct grant through the annual review
mechanism. , , , . v-

Under the terms of the Sugar Act 1956 research and education on home¬

FISHERIES
The sea fishing industry is of especial importance to the economy of Scotland.
In the rest of the United Kingdom it is an important source of employment in
the major fishing ports. The industry falls into three main divisions, concerned
respectively with white fish, herring and shellfish. The major element of the
catch (about 82 per cent by weight) is white fish: the catches of herring and
shellfish, although important, are relatively small. White fish are demersal fish
(such as cod, haddock, plaice, turbot and sole) which live on or near the sea
bed, and also pelagic fish (such as pilchards, mackerel and sprats) which live
mainly in intermediate waters or near the surface. Herring is a pelagic species
and constitutes a separate fishery. Shellfish include Crustacea (such as
lobsters, nephrops and crabs) and molluscs (such as escallops, mussels, cockles,
clams and oysters).
The white fish section of the industry is made up of three main groups:
the distant water, the near and middle water, and the inshore fisheries. The
distant waters are those round Iceland and in the west Atlantic, Greenland,
Bear Island and the north coast of Norway, and the Barents Sea; the middle
water grounds lie around the Faroe Islands; and the near water grounds are
those in the North Sea, the Irish Sea and in the coastal areas around Britain.
The herring fishing grounds are almost entirely in Scottish waters. The in¬
shore waters also yield considerable quantities of shellfish.
The principal fishing ports in England and Wales are Hull, Grimsby, Fleet-
wood, North Shields, Lowestoft and Milford Haven. In Scotland the chief
centres for white fish are Aberdeen, Granton, Fraserburgh, the Moray Firth,
the west coast and Shetland Islands; herring landings are made mainly at the
east coast port of Fraserburgh, the west coast ports of Ullapool, Mallaig,
Oban and Ayr and in the Shetland Islands. In Northern Ireland the main
fishing ports are Kilkeel, Portavogie and Ardglass.
The chief methods of catching fish are by trawling, seining, lining and ring
netting. Trawling is carried out throughout the year in the distant and near
waters for all species of demersal fish. Seining is also used for catching
demersal fish all the year round, mainly in the North Sea, the Minches, the
Firth of Clyde and the Irish Sea. There are about 550 Scottish and Northern
Ireland seiners, and about 170 operating from English ports.
The pelagic fisheries are seasonal. There is summer fishing for herring
based on the Shetlands, the east coast ports of Scotland and the north-east
coast ports of England. Other seasonal fisheries take place off the west coast
of Scotland, in the Isle of Man area and off southern Ireland.
The inshore fisheries comprise a great diversity of types of vessels and
282
The Fishing
Fleet
Supplies
Sea Fish
Processing
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
methods of capture; in addition, there are extensive fisheries for crabs,
lobsters, shrimps, mussels, escallops, cockles and oysters, and, off Scotland,
north-east England and in the Irish Sea there are valuable catches of nephrops
(‘Norway lobsters’ or Dublin Bay prawns).
Distant water vessels, which operate mainly from Hull, Grimsby and Fleet-
wood, numbered 161 at the end of 1970. They are over 140 feet (42-5 metres)
in length and most of them make voyages of 17 to 23 days to fishing grounds
in the Arctic Circle, Newfoundland, Labrador, Greenland and the Norway
coast. Freezer trawlers and factory ships, which spend from one to three
months at sea and freeze much or all of their catch, in some cases as fillets, have
become an important part of the distant water fleet in recent years At the
same date, near and middle water vessels numbered 352; they are between
80 and 140 feet (24*5 and 42-5 metres) long and most of them work nearer
home, making voyages of from a few days up to more than two weeks, although
some of the larger vessels fish regularly off the Faroes and seasonally as far
afield as Iceland. Included in the near water group are vessels engaged in
fishing for herring which normally make daily landings. The inshore group
consists of vessels of under 80 feet (24-5 metres) which, except for seiners are
seldom at sea for longer than two or three days and more usually make daily
landings, often fishing within sight of land.
In the British fishing industry in 1970 there were about 18,000 fishermen
in regular employment and some 4,000 occasionally employed; about two-
fifths of the former and one-third of the latter were from Scottish ports. In
Northern Ireland there are about 500 regular fishermen.
In 1970 landings of all types of fish (excluding salmon and trout) by British
fishing vessels totalled 960,000 tons (719,000 tons of demersal fish 185,000
tons of pelagic and 56,000 tons of shellfish), valued at about £76 million.
Imports totalled about 108,000 tons of fresh and frozen fish (including
60 000 tons brought direct from the fishing grounds), valued at about £26
million. Cod accounted for 47 per cent of the total value of demersal and
pelagic fish landed by British vessels; haddock (20 per cent) and plaice (9 per
cent) were the other most important sources of earnings to the industry.
Imports of fish and shellfish (fresh, frozen, salted, canned or otherwise
preserved) in 1970 amounted to about 183,000 tons valued at £73 million,
including 24,000 tons of canned salmon to the value of £21 million and other
canned fish and shellfish worth £14 million.
Weekly disposals of fresh, frozen and cured fish (excluding shellfish an
imported canned fish) in Britain averaged about 16,000 tons landed weight
in 1070. Consumption has been declining slightly, on an edible (fillet) weig
basis; it was 16-2 lb. (7-3 kg.) per head in 1970 (see Table 19) in comparison
with a peak total of 28*7 lb. (13 kg.) in 1948.
Processing and packaging of fish-curing, kippering, canning and quick-
freezing for consumer packs—are the subject of continuing research and
development. The growth of quick-frozen fish production has altered radically
the structure of the industry. With the increase in quick-freezing (which now
processes just over a quarter of all white fish landings) new export out ets have
opened up for white fish, which in 1970 accounted for almost half the total
exports of fish and fish preparations, valued at £21 million. Exports of mos
forms of fish increased in 1970.
A valuable by-product of the industry is the manufacture of fish meal tor
Freshwater
Fisheries
Distribution
System

AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 283
animal food and, to a much lesser extent, for fertilisers. Home production of
white fish meal and herring meal in 1970 was 84,000 tons.
The most valuable freshwater fish are salmon and sea-trout, especially when
caught by rod and line. Sea fishing for salmon by drift net and other methods
is prohibited in a wide area off the coast of Scotland and, outside national
fishery limits, off England, Wales and Northern Ireland; drift netting within
the limits is controlled by licence. In Scotland, where salmon fishing is a
private right, the main commercial methods are fixed nets on the coast outside
estuaries and sweep netting within estuaries and in rivers. River authority
licences are required for the limited amount of estuary and river netting
carried out in England and Wales. In England and Wales the landed value of
the salmon catch is approximately £275,000 a year, in Scotland it amounts to
about £1-5 million, and in Northern Ireland to some £270,000. In Northern
Ireland, eels worth about £400,000 a year are captured by long lines and by
eel nets placed in river weirs.
The principal inland wholesale distributing centre for fish is Billingsgate
Market in London, which handles about 250 tons a day, but other large cities
also have central fish markets. The principal method of distribution is through
wholesalers, located at the ports, who buy at the auctions and sell to inland
wholesalers; the port wholesalers prepare the fish for onward shipment. Fish
lorries, including insulated and refrigerated vehicles, transport the catch daily
from the ports to inland centres, although rail transport is still used from some
ports. Retail sales are handled by some 18,000 to 22,000 fishmongers and fish
friers; the latter use about a third of the landings of white fish.
Trawler-owning companies have entered into the marketing and distribu¬
tive system. This process has been encouraged by the growing popularity of
quick-frozen consumer packs, which are sold by other retail outlets, such as
grocers, as well as by fishmongers.
The government departments mainly responsible for the administration of
legislation concerning the fishing industry are the Ministry of Agriculture,
Fisheries and Food, the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries for Scotland
and the Ministry of Agriculture for Northern Ireland. The safety and welfare
of crews of fishing vessels are provided for under the Merchant Shipping Acts
administered by the Department of Trade and Industry. A committee of
enquiry into deep-sea trawler safety reported to the then Board of Trade in
1969. This led to amendment of the Acts to provide for the making of detailed
regulations containing additional safety measures. These regulations are under
consideration.
The Herring Industry Board was set up under the Herring Industry Act
1935 now consolidated in the Sea Fish Industry Act 1970 to reorganise,
develop and regulate the herring industry. The Board consists of a chairman
and three other members, all part-time and independent of the industry, who
are appointed jointly by the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, the
Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales, and the Home Secretary. The
Board, whose activities are financed partly by levies and licence fees and
partly by government grants and loans, is advised by the Herring Industry
Advisory Council, consisting of 32 members representing all sections of the
industry and consumers.
The functions of the Board include the promotion of sales of herring, both
284
The White Fish
Authority
Operating
Subsidies
BRITAIN I972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
at home and abroad, and the application of the benefits of technical progress
to the industry, including the adoption of new methods of catching, processing
and distributing herring. The Board administers the government grant and
loan schemes which provide for assistance towards the purchase of new fishing
vessels, and the improvement of existing vessels. Fishermen may also obtain
loans from the Board towards the purchase of second-hand vessels under
80 feet in length and towards the cost of new nets and gear. Up to 31st March
1971 £2,510,728 in loans and £2,221,913 in grants had been advanced.
The White Fish Authority and the Committee for Scotland and Northern
Ireland of the Authority were set up in 1951 under legislation now con¬
solidated in the Sea Fish Industry Act 1970. The function of the Authority is
to reorganise, develop and regulate the white fish industry, and that of the
Committee to advise the Authority about the exercise and performance of its
functions in Scotland and Northern Ireland. The Authority is composed of a
chairman and six members, and the Scottish and Northern Ireland Committees
of five members and a chairman who is a member of the Authority. They are
appointed jointly by the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food the
Secretary of State for Scotland, the Home Secretary and (in the case of the
Authority) the Secretary of State for Wales. The White Fish Industry Advisory
Council was also set up under the 1951 Act to advise the Authority about the
exercise and performance of its functions. It normally consists of 53 members
representing the various interests of the fishing industry.
The White Fish Authority administers government grant and loan schemes
for the purchase of new fishing vessels and engines and the improvement of
existing vessels. It also administers loans for the purchase of nets and gear and
processing plants. Up to 31st March 1971, £35‘9 million in loans and £32-4
million in grants were approved for these purposes by the Authority. Its
other activities are financed by levies on first-hand sales of most white fish, an
a government grant towards research and development.
Subsidies are paid to the inshore fishing industry under the provisions of the
Sea Fish Industry Act 1970 at the rate of so much per day at sea according
to the length of the vessel or at so much per stone (6-35 kg.) of fish landed,
which varies according to the kind of fish, from certain vessels under 60 feet
(18-5 metres) in length. No subsidy is paid for shellfish. Subsidies for white
fish cost £1 -18 million in 1970-71 and those for herring £200,000.
The White Fish Subsidy (Deep Sea Vessels) (United Kingdom) Scheme
came into operation on 1st April 1968 for a period of three years. Subsidies
payable up to 31st July 1971 were at a basic £2 million a year and were adjusted
by reference to the level of profitability of the industry, subject to a maximum
total of £4 million. Payment was related to the operating efficiency of vessels and
not to their classification. These arrangements replaced the previous policy of
progressively decreasing operating subsidies to deep-sea vessels. Subsidies cost
£1-53 million in 1970-71. A new scheme to be run on broadly similar lines is in
preparation.
FORESTRY
The estimated total area of productive woodland in Great Britain is 3-6
million acres (1 -46 million hectares), or about 6^ per cent of the total land area.
If account is taken of areas of scrub and old felled areas, including those cut
down in the second world war, the total rises to 4-52 million acres (1-83 million
hectares), or 8 per cent of the land area; about half of the area is in England,
The Forestry
Commission
and Forestry
Policy
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 285
two-fifths in Scotland, the remainder in Wales. The high proportion of un¬
productive woodland is largely a legacy of two wars and, while rehabilitation
of these areas continues to proceed, it is unlikely that all areas (for instance,
because of remoteness and poor site conditions) will be replanted.
The area of productive forest managed by the Forestry Commission, at
1-79 million acres (0-72 million hectares) represents 50 per cent of the total.
The annual rate of productive forest expansion is currently about 53,000 acres
(21,000 hectares) by the Commission mainly in Scotland, and about 56,000
acres (22,000 hectares) by private woodland owners. The Commission’s
programme includes considerable planting in upland areas, and consists mainly
of conifers because of the difficult site conditions encountered and because
over 90 per cent of industrial demand is for softwoods. The major species used
are Sitka spruce, Lodgepole pine, Scots pine and Norway spruce. In the older
woodlands and taking the country as a whole, the most common coniferous
trees are Scots pine, Sitka spruce, Norway spruce and the larches, while,
among the broadleaved, beech and oak occur widely.
Total employment in state and private forests was 25,000 in 1971 and a
further 11,000 were engaged in the transport and milling of home-grown
timber.
Except for the period of the two world wars, when much over-felling took
place, home woodlands have until recent years made only a limited contribu¬
tion to the nation’s total requirements of wood and wood products. Some
25 per cent of the Commission’s woodlands are now in production. Britain
imports 90 per cent of its needs by volume and a higher proportion still by
value, the total import cost of wood and wood products including pulp and
paper being over £743 million in 1970, of which £237 million was accounted
for by timber imports.
The Forestry Acts 1919 to 1945 established the Forestry Commission as the
national forestry authority charged with promoting the interests of forestry,
the development of afforestation and the production and supply of timber in
Great Britain (the Forestry Acts 1919 to 1963 were consolidated in the
Forestry Act 1967). As more and more of its coniferous woods reach the
production stage the Commission has assumed an increasingly important role
as a timber seller and has encouraged the setting up of some 20 new timber¬
using industries in the past 12 years. The Commission consists of a part-time
chairman, a full-time director general, three full-time executive commis¬
sioners and five part-time commissioners. The Commissioners comply with
directions given by the forestry ministers, who are the Minister of Agriculture,
Fisheries and Food and the Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales.
Northern Ireland has its own separate organisation (see p. 287).
The Commission’s total estate covers some 2-9 million acres (1-2 million
hectares) and includes 2-1 million acres (0-85 million hectares) of forest land,
of which about 1-79 million (0-72 million hectares) are under trees in 380
forests distributed throughout England, Scotland and Wales. All these forests
are covered by management plans, which provide for such work as planting,
road construction, thinning, fire protection and timber production, facilities
for public recreation, wildlife conservation and the landscaping of plantations.
As already stated, a substantial amount of the Forestry Commission’s new
planting is carried out in Scotland, much of it in the Highland counties. The
poorer types of land are being used, such as sour, peaty soil which is unsuitable
for agricultural purposes, but has become suitable for forestry as a result of
advances in the technique of deep ploughing.

BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Production of felled and thinned timber from commission woodlands is
expected to rise from about 1 -3 million tons in 1969-70 to about 2-2 million tons
by 1980 and to 4 million tons by 1990. Some ofthis produce is meeting traditional
requirements of the coal mines but much is taken by the paper pulp industry
and by factories established to make chipboard, fibreboard and wood wool.
The Forestry Fund was constituted under the 1919 Forestry Act; from it is
paid all the expenditure of the Forestry Commissioners and into it are paid
amounts voted annually by Parliament, together with the Commissions
receipts from sales of produce, rentals and other sources. In the period ending
31st March 1970, drawings from funds voted by Parliament amounted to
£15-1 million, and receipts were £7-6 million.
Privately owned woods comprise nearly 60 per cent of the total forest area m
Great Britain and contain most of the mature and semi-mature timber. The
size of woodlands in individual ownership ranges from a few acres to several
thousand acres, and a high proportion of the private woodland area is in small
ownership—that is, owners of up to about 250 acres (100 hectares).
Impetus was given to the effective management of private woodlands by
the Dedication of Woodlands Scheme, initiated in 1947. Under this scheme,
owners are invited to put their land permanently to timber production and to
manage their woods in accordance with a plan agreed with the Forestry Com¬
mission, in return for the provision of planting and management grants and
technical advice. By March 1971 the total area dedicated was 1-06 million
acres (424,000 hectares). In addition, there are the Approved Woodlands
Scheme and the Small Woods Scheme under which a planting grant, but no
management grant, is paid. More than i-2 million acres (494,000 hectares)
are managed under the first two schemes. Woodland owners are represented,
in their relations with the Forestry Commission, by the Forestry Committee
of Great Britain, which co-ordinates the work of two associations of woodlan
owners: the Timber Growers’ Organisation (for owners in England and Wales)
and the Scottish Woodland Owners’ Association. .
The Trees Act 1970 allowed for tree preservation orders to be imposed,
with the consent of the Commission, on dedicated and other grant-aided
There are a number of forestry co-operative societies providing for and-
owners and farmers the services of skilled staff, centralised purchasing facilities,
and a central agency for the disposal of forest produce. The Forestry Com¬
mission also co-operates with the principal forestry societies, such as the
Royal Forestry Society of England and Wales and the Royal Scottish Fores ry
Society, in disseminating technical knowledge.
Under the Forestry Act 1967 the Commissioners maintain national com¬
mittees for England, Scotland and Wales, composed partly of Forestry
Commissioners and partly of persons outside the Commission. These commit¬
tees act in an advisory capacity, particularly as to the social, recreational
and amenity aspects of the Commissioners’ activities and relationships with
other land users. The Commissioners also maintain a regional advisory
committee for each Conservancy.
Other bodies have been set up to provide for consultation on the marketing
and utilisation of home grown timber. The Home Grown Timber Advisory
Committee (HGTAC) is a statutory body and includes representatives of
associations of landowners, timber merchants and processors and the trade

unions under an independent chairman. The Advisory Committee on Utilisa¬
tion of Home Grown Timber, a sub-committee of the HGTAC advises on
measures designed to promote utilisation of produce from British woodlands.
Under a scheme agreed upon in 1961 for consultation on proposals for affor¬
estation of land within National Parks (see p. 177), the Timber Growers’
Organisation and the Country Landowners’ Association advise their members
to notify the park planning authorities about their planting proposals.
Forestry training is the responsibility of the Department of Education and
Science. A three-year sandwich course providing education at the supervisory
level and other courses are run at Newton Rigg, near Penrith.
An Agricultural, Horticultural and Forestry Industry Training Board and a
Furniture and Timber Industry Training Board provide training in forestry for
employees of private woodland owners and in the home-grown timber trade.
Higher education in forestry is provided at several universities; a propor¬
tion of graduates is recruited by the Commission as forest officers.
The Commission’s Forest Research Station at Alice Holt Lodge, near
Farnham, Surrey, was opened in 1946. Expenditure on research work at this
station, at the Northern Research Station and in experimental areas in many
forests in Great Britain amounted to £o-g million in 1969-70. This sum
included grants for special forestry research work to various institutions and
to university departments including the Commonwealth Forestry Institute at
Oxford, which is also financed by the university, the Foreign and Common¬
wealth Office and overseas governments. A Northern Research Station was
opened near Edinburgh in May 1970. Research into the qualities of home¬
grown timber is carried out by the Forest Products Research Laboratory at
Princes Risborough, Bucks, and also by grant-aided research associations.
When the Government of Northern Ireland was formed in 1922, the new
Ministry of Agriculture became the forest authority working with similar
powers and duties to those of the Forestry Commission. At that time the
Ministry took over some 4,000 acres (1,625 hectares) for afforestation, of which
700 acres (285 hectares) had been planted.
Forest policy is carried out under the authority of the Forestry Act (Northern
Ireland) 1953, which replaced earlier legislation. This Act provides the
Ministry with powers to acquire and manage land, and to give financial and
technical assistance for private planting. It introduced measures for the
protection of all woodlands, whether owned by the State or privately owned,
against destruction by over-cutting, fire or depredation by animals.
The state forest area has grown steadily and at a greatly accelerated pace
since the end of the second world war. By 1971 over 150,000 acres (60,750
hectares) had been acquired, of which over 100,000 acres (40,600 hectares)
had been planted. It has been officially proposed that 300,000 acres (120,000
hectares) of state and private forest be established by the end of the century.
Financial provision is made by sums voted annually by Parliament and
from receipts from forest produce and other sources. About 900 people are
employed in field labour and ancillary work. The area of exploitable private
woodlands is at present about 30,000 acres (12,000 hectares), and private
planting, which is gaining impetus, is assisted by schemes for the supply of
young trees from the Ministry’s nurseries at a low cost, by grants towards the
cost of the establishment of new plantations, and by free technical advice.
The public may visit almost all the forests, five of which have been desig¬
nated Forest Parks, and use the amenities provided.

Technical
Trends
Inland and overseas transport and communications employed 7 per cent
of the total labour force in Great Britain in June 1970. Of the i-6 million
persons so occupied, 32 per cent were engaged in road passenger transport
and road haulage contracting, 16 per cent in railways and 29 per cent in
postal services and telecommunications 5 sea and air transport each absorbed
5 per cent; port and inland water transport and miscellaneous transport
services and storage absorbed 13 per cent. Transport and communications
contribute about 9 per cent of the gross national product and are responsible
for a rather higher proportion of the nation’s gross fixed capital formation.
SEA TRANSPORT
Of the world’s active sea-going tonnage of 100 gross tons1 and over nearly
10 per cent is registered in Britain, making the British merchant fleet the
third largest in active employment after those of Liberia and Japan.
The British shipping industry meets severe international competition and
encounters difficulties from practices such as flag discrimination and the use of
‘flags of convenience’. While the British fleet increased by 20 per cent to
25-8 million gross tons between i960 and 1970 total world tonnage rose by
over 70 per cent to 227-5 million gross tons. However, the British fleet is now
increasing more rapidly than world tonnage—by 9 cent in 197®- Britain
has the world’s second largest oil tanker fleet, at 12 million gross tons, and the
fourth largest ore and bulk carrier fleet, at 3-9 million gross tons.
Technological change has been proceeding rapidly. Vessels are becoming
obsolete over a shorter period and as they do so are being replaced by larger
ships, with generally lower building costs per ton; labour-saving devices,
greater speeds and faster turn-round facilities are reducing operating costs.
The tendency to greater average size has been the most marked in tankers and
dry bulk cargo ships. Vessels are specially built to carry ore, cement, wine and
various kinds of chemicals. Many ships have been designed to carry fully
loaded road vehicles, pallets and containers. In particular the use of containers
on door-to-door journeys can result in speedier, safer and cheaper carriage of
a wide range of goods. Two consortia of British shipping companies are
operating specially designed deep-sea cellular container ship services, several
British companies are involved in international container consortia, and a few
are operating services of their own. Similar arrangements exist in bulk carrier
services.
1 One gross ton (g.t.) = 100 cubic feet. One deadweight ton (d.w.t.) = 1 long ton
(2 240 lb.). Gross tonnage indicates the total capacity of the enclosed spaces on a ship.
Deadweight tonnage denotes the maximum load which a vessel can carry before sub¬
merging the load-line.

The Department for Trade and Industry is the government department
responsible for most matters connected with merchant shipping. Under the
Merchant Shipping Acts, it administers many regulations for marine safety
and welfare, for instance: certifying the load-line (or Plimsoll line) that shows
that a ship is not overloaded; ensuring that standards of safety are observed
in ship construction; ensuring the provision of adequate life-saving, fire¬
fighting and radio equipment; and dealing with the discipline, professional
standards, health and accommodation of seamen. Most of the work which
these responsibilities entail is carried out by the staff of the Marine Survey and
Mercantile Marine offices at the ports. There is also a Registrar-General of
Shipping and Seamen, in whose office at Cardiff a complete record of all
British ships and seamen is kept. Abroad, certain parts of the Merchant
Shipping Acts are administered by H.M. Consuls and by officers of Common¬
wealth Governments.
Much of the law relating to employment at sea is being revised under the
Merchant Shipping Act 1970, in particular some disciplinary provisions are to
be relaxed and arrangements for welfare and safety of seamen improved.
A committee of enquiry reported in May 1970 in favour of the establish¬
ment of a Ship Research and Development Institute, an Industrial Training
Board for Shipping, a Statutory Marine Authority for safety control, and an
international code of practice for shipping conferences.
Britain’s merchant fleet has been increasing rapidly in response to new
methods of handling goods. Gross tonnage of ships delivered to British
owners in 1970 is estimated at 2-75 million, about a quarter of which was built
in British yards. Over half of the fleet is diesel driven.
In June 1970, 21-4 million gross tons of trading vessels of 100 gross tons and
over were both owned and registered in Britain.1 These ships are usually
employed as follows: 6-4 million gross tons as foreign-going passenger and
cargo liners; 4-2 million gross tons as foreign-going tramps; 10 million gross
tons as foreign-going tankers; and o-8 million gross tons in coasting and trade
with ports between the Elbe and Brest (home trades).
The Queen Elizabeth 2 (66,000 g.t.), the most advanced and one of the
largest passenger liners ever built, designed for the transatlantic route and for
cruising, went into service in 1969.
About 85,000 United Kingdom personnel are employed by the merchant fleet.
A considerable number of other nationals are also employed.
The Department of Trade and Industry holds examinations for, and issues
certificates of competency to, ship’s officers as master, first mate and second
mate of foreign-going ships, or master and mate of home trade ships and as
first-class engineer and second-class engineer. Officers may not normally
serve on board ships in these grades unless they hold the appropriate, or a
higher, certificate.
Radio officers are required to hold certificates of competency in radio¬
telegraphy issued by the Minister of Posts and Telecommunications on the
results of an open examination.
1 The remaining tonnage included fishing vessels, tugs, river and estuary craft, Admiralty
vessels (mostly tankers) not usually engaged in the commercial carriage of cargo, and
shipping registered in Britain but owned in other Commonwealth countries (including
over 1 million gross tons of tankers).

A seaman may not be rated as A.B. (Able Seaman) in United Kingdom
registered ships unless he holds a certificate of competency as A.B. granted
by the Department of Trade and Industry, or an equivalent certificate. To
obtain this certificate a seaman must, among other qualifications, have served
three years at sea on deck, have obtained a certificate of efficiency as lifeboat-
man and have passed a qualifying examination. Seamen qualify by seniority
for promotion to the rating of petty officer. Service as a deck rating qualifies
for the purpose of admission to the examination for a second mate’s certificate.
The Merchant Navy Training Board promotes the instruction and studies
of apprentices, cadets and ratings who are preparing for their examinations
for the various certificates of competency.
Wages and conditions of employment of the majority of seafarers are negoti¬
ated by the National Maritime Board. Minimum wages and holidays with pay
are guaranteed for both officers and ratings. Moreover, the Merchant Navy
Established Service Scheme, introduced by the Board in 1947, has removed a
great deal of the uncertainty formerly associated with a seafaring life. Officers
and men can now take contracts of at least one year s duration, not only with
individual shipping companies but with the Merchant Navy Establishment
Board, and get special benefits between voyages in addition to the normal
unemployment insurance benefit.
About one-third of British-owned shipping registered in the United Kingdom
consists of foreign-going passenger-cargo and cargo liners, mostly the latter.
Practically all these ships are owned by large liner companies. Many operate
wide networks of scheduled cargo and passenger services which, between
them, cover every ocean. The 4’2 million gross tons of foreign-going tramp
ships are operated by a large number of private owners, some having only a
small number of ships and some only one ship.
Examples of major British liner shipping companies operating scheduled
services from the United Kingdom are: Cunard, to North America; Blue
Funnel, to Australia and the Far East; Peninsular and Oriental (P. & O.) and
the British India lines, to India, Australia and the Far East; Union Castle, to
South and East Africa; Elder Dempster, to West Africa; Furness Withy, to
North America and the West Indies; the New Zealand line, to Australia and
New Zealand; and Shaw Savill and Albion, to Australia and New Zealand.
These and the other major liner companies have for the most part amalga¬
mated to form a small number of major groups, of which the largest and best
known are the P. & O., the Furness Withy, the Ocean S.S., and the British
and Commonwealth groups.
Over two-thirds of the total tanker fleet belong to the oil companies,
although there are a few important independent United Kingdom tanker¬
owning companies.
The main organisations concerned with the activities, interests and common
problems of the industry are as follows:
Lloyd’s Register is an organisation (distinct from the Society of Lloyd’s, see
P- 357) which surveys and classifies ships with particular regard to their
safety and operational efficiency. It will accept responsibility for surveying
and giving technical advice on vessels of all flags from the initial stages o
building, at regular intervals during their service, and after casualties. A
satisfactory Lloyd’s classification is a guarantee to an underwriter that he

may accept the risk of a vessel, and this forms a strong link between the
Register and the Society of Lloyd’s.
The representative body speaking for shipowners generally (excluding, for
the most part, owners of fishing vessels) is the Chamber of Shipping of the
United Kingdom. There are a number of local associations of shipowners
centred around the main port areas. Other organisations represent companies
specialising in a particular trade or type of cargo.
The British Shippers’ Council, formed in 1955, represents the shipping
interests of exporters and importers in matters of both national and inter¬
national concern.
The British Shipping Federation Limited is the employers’ organisation
concerned with labour relations and the regulation of employment. It is
responsible for the administration of the Merchant Navy Established Service
Scheme, under which shipowners engaging crews for ships of 200 gross tons
and above engage them through the Merchant Navy Establishment Administra¬
tion unless they are prepared to offer company service contracts.
The National Maritime Board is composed of equal numbers of representa¬
tives of the shipowners and seafarers’ unions and is responsible for negotiations
of wages and conditions of service.
British shipping companies operating liners have associated with each other
and with the companies of other countries operating on the same routes in a
series of ‘conferences’ designed to secure standardisation and stability of rates,
and to maintain frequency and regularity of services. The essential principle
of a conference is the establishment of a common tariff of freight rates or
passenger fares from each port of departure. Each conference meets from
time to time to review and revise existing rates, or to compile new ones. Some
of the conferences are connected by rate agreements, or have joined together
to form wider groupings. There are over 60 conferences dealing with trade to
and from the United Kingdom.
The Baltic Mercantile and Shipping Exchange, which originated in one of
London’s seventeenth-century coffee houses, is the world’s largest market
for the chartering of ships of all nationalities. Shipbrokers and merchants’
representatives meet here to arrange the chartering of dry-cargo tramp ships
for the carriage of goods to and from all parts of the world. In addition sale
and purchase of ships, chartering of aircraft and trade in certain commodities
are carried on there.
The Department of Trade and Industry’s responsibilities for safety include
administration of the Coastguard Service, and certain administrative functions
concerning lighthouses and pilotage. The Department makes regulations to
ensure safety and navigation and to prevent oil pollution, and conducts
enquiries into accidents at sea.
The Coastguard Service co-ordinate search and rescue measures for vessels in
distress off the coasts of Britain, and gives direct assistance where appropriate.
There are some 550 regular coastguards and about 7,000 part-time auxiliary
coastguards. Constant watch is maintained all the year round at certain main

BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
stations and where necessary at a number of others. During the year ended
31st March 1971 life-saving action was taken on 2,919 occasions.
The Coastguard calls upon shipping, the lifeboats and inshore rescue boats
of the Royal National Life-boat Institution, and service aircraft to assist as
necessary. It has at its disposal a civilian rescue helicopter based at Mansion
in Kent. The Royal National Life-boat Institution is supported entirely by
voluntary contributions, and depends for its operation on voluntary workers.
From its foundation in 1824 to the end of 1970 it saved 92,983 lives. Lifeboats
and inshore rescue boats were launched 2,633 times in 1970 and rescued 1,250
people.
The general lighthouse authority for England and Wales, the Channel Islands
and Gibraltar is the Corporation of Trinity House, which received its first
Royal Charter in the sixteenth century and is administered by a Board of ten
Elder Brethren, elected from the Royal Navy and the Merchant Navy.
Lighthouses in Scotland and Ireland are the responsibility respectively
of the Commissioners of Northern Lighthouses and the Commissioners of
Irish Lights. These authorities control about 180 lighthouses, many minor
lights and buoys, and a number of lightships, some of which are being replaced
by unattended sea marks or by light towers.
Trinity House is the chief pilotage authority, licensing some 700 pilots in
41 districts in England and Wales, including London, Southampton and
Milford Haven. In some cases the harbour authority or local council is the
pilotage authority. In Britain there are 48 pilotage authorities for the 92
pilotage districts and over 1,700 licensed pilots.
Every year some 300,000 vessels pass through the Dover Strait, one of the
most congested stretches of water in the world. Recommended one-way routes
were marked in 1967 by navigational aids provided by the French and British
lighthouse authorities—a scheme worked out jointly by the Institutes of
Navigation of France, the Federal Republic of Germany and Britain and
agreed upon by the Inter-Governmental Maritime Consultative Organisation
(IMCO), a United Nations agency with headquarters in London. Following a
succession of accidents early in 1971 the British Government proposed to
IMCO that the scheme be made mandatory and its area extended.
POLLUTION OF The discharge of oil into British territorial waters was first restricted in 1922.
THE SEA Britain is a party to the 1954 International Convention for the Prevention of
the Pollution of the Sea by Oil which came into force in 1958. Under amend¬
ments made in 1962 and put into force in 1967 the nations ratifying this
convention (now numbering over 40) agreed to prohibit their national fleets
from discharging persistent oil within 100 miles (161 kilometres) of any coast,
or in some cases more; ships of 20,000 gross tons and over, built after 18th
May 1967, were prohibited from discharging persistent oil anywhere at sea.
Britain enforces these restrictions on British ships through the Oil in Navigable
Waters Acts of 1955 and 1963.1 Amendments agreed upon in 1969 prohibit the
discharge of persistent oil at sea except at a rate which has been shown not to
cause harmful pollution; no oil whatever may be discharged from cargo spaces
of tankers within 50 miles (80 kilometres) of land. These amendments, not yet
enforceable internationally, will be applied to British ships under the Oil in
Navigable Waters Act 1971.1 In 1969 Britain signed the International Con-
1 Now consolidated within the Prevention of Oil Pollution Act 1971.
