vention Relating to Intervention on the High Seas in Cases of Oil Pollution
Casualties, enabling a state to take action on the high seas to prevent pollution
of its coastline by oil from a damaged tanker, and the International Convention
on Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage, facilitating the obtaining of com¬
pensation for damage by oil pollution. Britain will give effect to the latter
convention under the Merchant Shipping (Oil Pollution) Act 1971.
There are some 250 port authorities or public wharf operators in Britain, and
about 1,400 other undertakings engaged in various harbour operations, such as
stevedoring, towage, warehousing and lighterage. Port authorities are of four
main types: nationalised bodies, public trusts, local authorities and private
companies.
Public trust port authorities consist mainly of representatives of users of the
port, such as shippers, importers, exporters, and shipping companies and
members of the relevant local authorities. Examples of such public trusts are
the Port of London Authority, the Mersey Docks and Harbour Board (Liver¬
pool), and the Belfast Harbour Commissioners. Local authorities own about
one-third of Britain’s ports, including the major port of Bristol, and Preston
and Boston; ports owned by private and limited liability companies include
Manchester and Felixstowe. Many private ports deal with the traffic of
individual industrial firms in commodities such as petroleum, china clay and
paper pulp.
Since 1948 about a quarter of total port capacity has been owned by the
Government; the majority of these ports, including Southampton, Hull,
Immingham, Cardiff, and Swansea, are owned by the British Transport Docks
Board (see p. 297). In 1970 shipping arrivals and departures at the Board’s
docks totalled nearly 113 million net registered tons (including fishing vessels)
and total cargo handled was over 86 million tons. The British Railways Board
controls certain ports, which are largely used for the cross-Channel services of
the railways: (for example, Folkestone, Holyhead, Heysham, Stranraer and
Parkeston Quay at Harwich) while the British Waterways Board owns
Sharpness (Gloucester) and Weston Point (Manchester).
Port authorities, in the main, operate with statutory powers and responsibili¬
ties set out in private Acts of Parliament. Most are members of the Docks and
Harbour Authorities Association, formed in 1917 to further the common
interests of port authorities in their relations with the Government, shipowners
and traders.
The National Ports Council, set up as a statutory body under the Harbours
Act 1964, is financed by a levy on port authorities. It advises the Government
on major port developments and has various responsibilities in relation to
research, training, statistics and charges. It has encouraged the amalgamation
of harbour authorities in certain estuaries into single port authorities, as on the
Forth, Clyde and Tees, and is at present engaged in drawing up, in co¬
operation with the port authorities, a programme of financial, commercial and
management improvements.
Large-scale modernisation of the port transport industry has been taking place
in recent years, as a result both of the increase in Britain’s trade, especially
with other European countries, and of technological changes affecting sea¬
going traffic. The growing size of tankers and bulk carriers has necessitated
more deep-water berths, while development of mechanical handling methods,
packaging of general cargo, containers and ‘roll-on, roll-off’ services has created
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
a demand for new types of port facilities. Capital investment in ports has risen
from about £18 million a year in the early 1960s to some ^40 million in 1970.
A major development at Tilbury, port of London, costing £30 million oyer
a number of years, has provided 12 deep-water berths, including a riverside
grain terminal, four of them for container traffic. Another major scheme is
the construction of the new Seaforth docks at Liverpool, costing ^4° mibion
and due to come into use at the end of 1971; it will provide ten deep-water
berths, four to handle containers, two to handle bulk grain and meat carriers,
and others to handle computer-controlled general cargo and packaged timber.
Container facilities are being expanded at a cost of some £14 million for the
Far East traffic at Southampton, where a computer-linked harbour surveillance
and shipping information system is being installed to provide radar and VHF
radio coverage over 20-miles (32-kilometres) of port area. Deep-sea container
facilities have also been constructed at Felixstowe, the Clyde, and Manchester.
In addition over 70 specialised container roll-on berths have been constructed
for the short-sea trades with continental Europe, including Scandinavia and
Ireland. A £20 million deep-water harbour at Port Talbot, South Wales, serves
as an ore terminal for the British Steel Corporation. Other ore terminals are
to be built at Redcar, Yorkshire, and possibly at Hunterston on the Clyde.
Labour About 100,000 people are employed in the port transport industry of the
United Kingdom. At the end of 1970 46,000 dock workers were registered
with the National Dock Labour Board. They were responsible for the physical
and mechanical handling of cargo. The remainder included administrative,
technical, clerical and commercial staff.
The system of casual labour common among dock workers in the past has
gradually been superseded. A start on ‘decasualisation’ was made in 1941 when
war-time controls were imposed. In 1947 the National Dock Labour Board
was established, with members appointed by the then Minister of Labour and
representing both employers and employed, to administer a scheme under
which registered dock workers received a minimum wage for attendance even
when no work was available. In September 1967 each registered dock worker
was placed in employment on a permanent basis with an employer licensed by
the port authority, under the provisions of the Docks and Harbours Act 1966.
Port Traffic Some 330 million tons of cargo a year pass through the ports of Great Britain.
Of this total coastal traffic of over 100 million tons consists mainly of petroleum
and coal. Of about 180 million tons of imports from overseas over 100 million
tons consists of petroleum and petroleum products. Manufactured goods form
about two fifths of exports.
The total of vessels in the foreign trade entering and leaving with cargo at
United Kingdom ports rose by over 5 per cent during 1970 to over 212 million
net registered tons. The corresponding figure for coastal trade was over 90
million.
A large proportion of the general cargo traffic through British ports, is
handled by unitised transport methods in containers and roll-on goods
vehicles, which carried 15-4 million tons of goods in 1970. British ports handle
more containers than the rest of northern European ports together and account
for the largest share of the container traffic across the North Atlantic. London,
with i-6 million tons, was the leading port for this type of traffic in i97°>
followed by Liverpool, Preston and Felixstowe, each with 1-4 million tons.
Principal Ports Britain’s largest port is that of London. In 1970 some 60 million tons of goods
were handled, including 29 million tons of petroleum and 8 million tons of coal.

TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 295
Liverpool is the second largest port and Britain’s major export outlet,
especially to deep-sea trading areas. In 1970 26 million tons of goods were
handled, about one-half consisting of dry cargo—grain, chemicals, iron and
steel, and other manufactures.
Southampton is the chief port for ocean passenger traffic, and specialises
in trade with South Africa; it has the advantages of deep water and double
tides. Bristol, with Avonmouth, has a large traffic in grain imports, and is
Britain’s main port for imports of animal feedingstuffs. The South Wales
ports import much of Britain’s requirements of iron ore, especially through
Port Talbot and Newport (Monmouthshire). Swansea is important for the
export of coal, iron and steel and tinplate and for imports of oil. Milford Haven,
handling 41 million tons, has now become Britain’s major oil port. The in¬
land port of Manchester, reached from the Mersey via the 36-mile (58-
kilometre) Manchester Ship Canal, has at Eastham Britain’s largest oil
dock, covering 19 acres (8 hectares), and exports manufactured goods and
chemicals.
In Scotland the Clyde is the principal port, serving the central industrial area
and possessing a crude oil terminal at Finnart. On the Forth, Grangemouth
is associated with petroleum, petro-chemicals and timber, while Leith is the
port for Edinburgh.
Newcastle and other ports on the Tyne serve England’s industrial north¬
east, and the port of Tees and Hartlepools handles iron ore, steel and engineer¬
ing products, and chemicals, especially fertilisers. Hull and Grimsby on the
Humber handle nearly half the wet fish landed in Britain and are among the
largest white fish ports in the world. With Immingham they serve the industrial
areas of Yorkshire and the Midlands, especially in trade with Scandinavian and
Baltic ports. Belfast is the principal port of Northern Ireland and handles the
main traffic across the Irish Sea.
Most of the oil tankers coming to Britain to discharge crude oil are berthed at
special tanker terminals owned and operated by the oil companies to serve
their own refineries. Facilities have been extended to accommodate larger
vessels, and a new terminal at Immingham (Humberside) will eventually take
tankers of 250,000 d.w.t.
British ports offer the deepest water access in Northern Europe for fully
laden tankers to pipe crude oil direct to refineries. Milford Haven in Wales,
after a £12 million dredging scheme, can accommodate fully laden vessels of
250,000 deadweight tons on all tides at four private oil company terminals.
Finnart on the Clyde will also accept vessels of this size and can be readily
adapted to accept the half-million-ton tankers of the future; it is frequently
used in lightening operations to allow part-laden vessels to proceed with
shallower draft to other ports in Northern Europe.
Pipelines connect Finnart with the refinery at Grangemouth on the Firth
of Forth, Angle Bay with the refinery of Llandarcy (near Swansea) and Stan-
low (Merseyside) with the refinery at Heysham (Lancashire).
The hovercraft, a vehicle which rides on a cushion of air over both land and
water surfaces, has been in regular public passenger service around the coasts
of Britain since 1965. Services are run by several privately owned firms, these
include Hoverlloyd Ltd., which has a purpose-built hoverport at Pegwell
Bay in connection with its car and passenger ferries between Ramsgate and
Calais, and Hovertravel Ltd., which operates across the Solent to the Isle of
Wight and has a subsidiary which does training and charter work. Two

publicly owned bodies, the British Railways Board and the Scottish Transport
Group, have hovercraft interests. British Railways’ subsidiary, British Rail
Hovercraft Ltd. (‘Seaspeed’), was set up in 1966, and is the world’s largest
commercial hovercraft operator. It also runs regular services across the
Channel between Dover and Boulogne, using two 165-ton Mountbatten
(SRN4) hovercraft, the largest in the world, carrying passengers and accom¬

INLAND TRANSPORT
The dense passenger and freight traffic of Great Britain1 is carried mainly by
road and rail, although coastal shipping and, to a lesser extent, pipelines and
inland waterways are important in carrying certain types of freight, particularly
bulk goods. A small but increasing proportion of freight goes by air.
Part of the inland transport system of Great Britain is publicly owned;
namely, the railways, a large proportion of road passenger and some road
haulage services, most of the inland waterways and some of the vessels on them.
Road haulage is largely, and coastal shipping almost entirely, in the hands of
private enterprise.
In the third quarter of 197° there were nearly 15 million vehicles licensed
for use on the roads. Of these 11*5 million were motor cars and i-i million
motor cycles; 2 per cent of the 1 ’6 million road goods vehicles and two-thirds
of the public road passenger vehicles (excluding taxis) were publicly owned.
In 1970 61 per cent of freight, in terms of ton-mileage,2 travelled by road,
20 per cent by rail, 17 per cent by coastal shipping, and 2 per cent by pipeline
and inland waterway.
Since 1945 the rapid growth of private and commercial motor traffic, causing
congestion problems of increasing severity, especially in cities and towns, and
the changing pattern of demand for transport services have led successive
Governments to undertake or commission fundamental studies of probable
trends in transport and problems which may arise therefrom. The Buchanan
report, published in November 1963, was the result of a study group set up to
examine the problems of traffic in urban areas. It estimated that Britain would
have 40 million vehicles on its roads by a.d. 2010 and proposed radical
measures to rebuild and adapt cities and roads to handle the growth of traffic.
It is expected that the number of vehicles on the roads will double by 1990.
Total passenger mileage is expected to grow by over 50 per cent during the
next ten years with demand for public transport diminishing and travel by
private transport still rising fast. Total freight ton-mileage is expected to
increase substantially, although fuel traffic will fall as a result of structural and
technological change.
Research is being carried out into new forms of inter-urban travel, such as
high-speed passenger trains, tracked hovercraft, and vertical take-off aircraft.
The railway network has been reduced by over a third in the past decade
but it was decided in 1967 to fix a basic network of some 11,000 route-miles
(17,700 route-kilometres) for modernisation and development.

The present role and structure of the nationalised transport undertakings are
the result of a series of legislative measures, starting with the 1947 Transport
Act under which they were taken into public ownership. In accordance with
this Act the British Transport Commission (BTC) was established on 1st
January 1948 and assumed control of Britain’s railways, all railway-owned
steamships, docks, hotels and road transport interests, most of the country’s
canals (including all those owned by the railways), certain rivers (as navigation
authority) and the whole of the London passenger transport system. It was also
to arrange for the gradual acquisition of privately owned long-distance road
haulage firms.
Changes of policy following the coming into power of a Conservative
Government in 1951 were put into effect under the Transport Act 1953 which
modified the functions of the BTC. A considerable part of the publicly owned
road haulage fleet was denationalised between 1953 and 1956.
Over the next few years it became widely held that the BTC’s activities
were so large and diverse that they could not be run effectively as a single
undertaking. The Transport Act 1962 therefore dissolved the BTC and set
up four boards, for British Railways, London Transport, British Transport
Docks and British Waterways. Each of these was responsible to the Minister
of Transport, who appointed the members.
The shipping services operated by British Railways and certain ports and
docks used for them passed to the British Railways Board.
The hotel property of the BTC was transferred to British Transport Hotels
Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary, first of the BTC and later of the British
Railways Board.
Road passenger, haulage and other undertakings, such as British Road
Services, the Tilling Bus Group, the Scottish Omnibuses Group, Thomas
Cook and Son, were operated as companies incorporated under the Companies
Act, with their own boards; they were grouped under a Transport Holding
Company, responsible to the Minister of Transport.
The 1968 Transport Act has considerably altered the transport pattern laid
down by the 1962 Act. The 1968 Act provided for a capital reconstruction and
reorganisation of British Railways; the setting up of Passenger Transport
Authorities to control and co-ordinate local transport arrangements; three new
nationalised bodies—a National Bus Company, a Scottish Transport Group
and a National Freight Corporation; a new licensing system and safety pro¬
visions for road haulage operators; and new grants for public transport. Most
of the functions of the Transport Holding Company have been distributed
among the new bodies, and the Government intends to wind it up once its
remaining interests have been sold.
Britain was the pioneer of railways. The opening of the Stockton to Darlington
Railway in 1825, and of the Liverpool and Manchester line in 1830, when
George Stephenson’s famous ‘Rocket’ locomotive was used, began a century
of widespread railway development. The great period of railway building was
from 1840 to 1875.
The railways first came under centralised government direction during the
first world war, and afterwards some 130 private companies were amalgamated
into four large regional groups under the Railways Act 1921. Thereafter they
suffered from the prolonged industrial depression and growing competition
from road transport, and following the second world war the Transport Act
298
Operations
Development
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
1947 brought the railways under public ownership as a single enterprise,
British Railways, operated under the overall management of a Railway
Executive established as the agent of the BTC. Under the Transport Act 1962
the British Railways Board was set up and came into existence on 1st January
1963 with sole responsibility for managing railway affairs.
In spite of technical and operational advances the Board’s financial position
remained unsatisfactory and, following a detailed review of railway policy,
the 1968 Transport Act made far-reaching changes. Capital debt was written
down from £1,627 million (of which £705 million had already been suspended
under the 1962 Act) to £365 million. Grants for rail passenger services which
are unremunerative but which are regarded as socially necessary were intro¬
duced; £62 million was so paid in 1970. Grants not exceeding a total of £50
million may be paid to the Board on a gradually diminishing scale during the
years 1969 to 1973 towards the cost of maintaining surplus track and signalling
equipment pending their elimination; £12 million was paid in 1970. Deficit
financing, which had been in operation since 1963, ceased in 1968 and the
Board is now expected to pay its way. Other provisions of the Act removed
certain restrictions on the Board’s powers to manufacture and to run hotels,
and reduced the size of the Board.
The process of rationalisation arising from changing public transport require¬
ments is reflected in the reduction of over 6,400 miles (10,300 kilometres) of
standard-gauge route since 1961. A total of 824 million passenger journeys
was made and 199 million tons of freight traffic conveyed on the railways in
1970; total receipts amounted to £57! million. The Board made a profit of
£9-5 million following interest payments of £42 million. At the end of 1970
it employed 273,000 people. , , r
In 1970 a subsidiary, British Transport Hotels Ltd., owned 34 hotels of
which it managed 33. It also managed the catering facilities on trains (includ¬
ing Pullman trains) in addition to station refreshment rooms.
British Railways’ subsidiary, British Rail Hovercraft Ltd., runs regular
hovercraft services (see p. 296). ... ■ ^ t? ■ u
The Railways Board and the shipping subsidiaries of the National Freight
Corporation have between them a fleet of about 100 vessels, providing
passenger and freight services on most of the important routes between
Great Britain and the Continent and the Republic of Ireland, as well as on
many domestic routes. Ownership of domestic services in Scotland was
transferred to the Scottish Transport Group under the Transport Act 1968;
its two shipping subsidiaries own some 4° vessels between them.
In December 1970 the Board produced its first five-year corporate plan, which
will be revised annually and which analyses all sectors of business, setting
targets for them. The plan stressed the need for continuing investment in
modernisation of the railways. In recent years the most important develop¬
ments have been the replacement of steam by diesel and electric traction
completed in 1968; the improvement of inter-city passenger services with the
emphasis on speed, reliability and comfort; the introduction of express freight
services (‘freightliners’) enabling freight to be handled throughout transit in
standard containers (now the responsibility of Freightliners Ltd., see p. 300),
and increased mechanisation in the carrying of coal and other bulk com¬
modities. Capital expenditure in 1970 amounted to £76 million.
At the end of 1970 there were 4,126 diesel, 323 electric and 50 diesel-electric
locomotives. In addition there were 3,621 diesel passenger-carrying multiple
unit vehicles and 7,358 electric multiple unit vehicles.

TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 299
The Board’s current programme includes the replacement of old passenger
coaches by new stock with improved amenities, and the construction of new
electric multiple unit stock to replace old vehicles. On certain sections of the
London-Bristol-South Wales line and of the London-Edinburgh line pass¬
enger trains are permitted to run up to 100 mph (161 kmph). Similar speeds
are also in operation on the London Midland Region’s services on the electrified
line between London, Birmingham, Manchester and Liverpool. This electri¬
fication scheme, costing some £160 million and completed in 1967, was the
largest individual capital investment project ever undertaken by the British
Railways Board and included station reconstruction, bridgeworks, a new
colour-light signalling system and new rolling stock. A 70 per cent increase
in numbers of passengers has resulted. Electrification is being extended by
235 route-miles (378 route-kilometres) to Glasgow at a cost of £25 million;
a ^30-4 million route rationalisation and resignalling scheme is associated
with it.
Motorail services (carrying both passengers and cars) increased their traffic
by 10 per cent in 1970 and have a current capacity of 107,000 cars on 22
services.
The efficiency of freight services is being improved as new vehicles come into
service and as facilities for concentrating traffic at fewer and better equipped
and sited marshalling yards and terminals are completed. The freightliner
services, the responsibility of Freightliners Ltd. (see p. 300), serve a network
of over 20 main terminals. Services are operated throughout the country and
to the Continent. The first freightliner ran in November 1965.
The London International Freight Terminal, opened in 1967, links the
British Railways Board container port of Harwich with the main freightliner
network. The first fully cellular container ships built in a British yard are
being used in the Board’s container services between Harwich and Zeebrugge,
opened in 1968.
Bulk products traffic is increasing. Oil is being moved from refineries under
long-term contracts, while coal is being fed direct from collieries to power
stations in ‘merry-go-round’ trains, on which coal is loaded and discharged
automatically from a new type of high-capacity wagon. Long-term contracts
are in operation for the carriage of cars, china clay, milk, grain, newspapers,
steel, chemicals and other goods.
British Railways Board’s subsidiary, British Rail Engineering Ltd., has 14
main workshops, employing some 37,000 people, mostly on repairs and con¬
struction of rolling stock, locomotives and containers.
The Railway Technical Centre at Derby covers 20 acres (8 hectares) and
employs about 2,000 people. Work is proceeding on a large number of projects,
a major one being the development of a 150 mph (241 kmph) gas turbine
‘advanced passenger train’ to run over existing tracks. Like the associated
train control system and a number of smaller projects, it is being given govern¬
ment financial help.
The National Freight Corporation was set up under the 1968 Transport
Act to provide and promote the provision of integrated road and rail freight
services, making the maximum economic use of rail. The Corporation took
over all the road haulage and most of the shipping interests of the Transport
Holding Company, and from the Railways Board the depots, vehicles, ware¬
houses, containers and other equipment, though not the actual trains used,
in the freightliners and sundries services, and also the Board’s road haulage

vehicles. It has a capital of about £100 million, and employs 66,000 people;
annual turnover amounts to some ^17° rnillion.
Freightliners Ltd., a company jointly owned by the Freight Corporation
and the Railways Board (with 51 per cent and 49 per cent of the shares
respectively), is responsible for the marketing and management of freight-
liner services. The Railways Board makes a charge for providing and hauling
the trains, and profits are divided between the Board and the Corporation in
proportion to their holdings. In 1970 some 480,000 containers were carried on
about 60 routes.
A Freight Integration Council, set up under the 1968 Act, advises the Depart¬
ment of the Environment and the Secretary of State for Scotland on the
provision of integrated freight services by publicly owned bodies. It consists
of several independent members with an independent chairman, the chair¬
men of the Freight Corporation and the Railways Board, and members
representing union interests.
The British and French Governments have chosen an international group of
banking and other interests with which to pursue the project for a rail tunnel
between Britain and France under the Channel. Final studies for the project
began in April 1971. The tunnel would provide ferry train services for road
vehicles in addition to through rail services.
The advent of the motor vehicle made it necessary for the Government to
set up a central road authority; accordingly, the Road Board was established
by the Development and Road Improvement Funds Act 1909. In 1919 the
Board’s responsibilities were taken over by the newly established Ministry of
Transport (see p. 51).
Roads are classified according to their traffic value. Trunk roads provide
a national network of routes for through traffic; other roads are divided for
grant purposes into principal and non-principal roads.
In June 1971 Great Britain had nearly 208,000 miles (334,743 kilometres)
of public highway. There were 9,000 miles (14,484 kilometres) of trunk roads,
of which 829 miles (1,334 kilometres) were motorways; 20,000 miles (32,186
kilometres) of principal roads of which some 10 miles (16 kilometres) were
motorways, and 179,miles (288,072 kilometres) of other roads, including
unsurfaced roads.
The Secretary of State for the Environment is the highway authority for
trunk roads in England and on these roads he administers expenditure, which
is provided wholly from central Government sources, although for many pur¬
poses he employs local authorities as his agents. The Secretary of State for
Scotland has corresponding responsibilities for roads in Scotland and the
Secretary of State for Wales for roads in Wales. Work on major trunk road
schemes in England, including motorways, is controlled by regional road con¬
struction units, manned jointly by Department of the Environment and county
council staff. The highway authority for principal roads is, in general, the
council of the county or county borough in whose area the roads lie. The
Secretary of State makes specific grants towards approved expenditure on con¬
struction and major improvement of these roads and contributions from public
funds towards maintenance and other expenditure is made through grants to
local authorities. Roads other than trunk and principal roads are entirely the
responsibility of the local authority in whose area they lie.
A large and steadily expanding road-building programme has been in progress

ROAD

since 1955. Public expenditure on new and improved roads in Great Britain
is estimated at over £470 million in 1971-72. The current programme
includes a considerable mileage of motorways constructed for the use of
limited classes of traffic under powers granted by the Special Roads Act 1949
(consolidated in the Highways Act 1959).
The motorways form part of a programme designed to provide a national
network of modern through routes. At the same time, work done under this
programme is eliminating some of the worst bottlenecks in urban areas and
thus helping to give free outlets from the big cities and from other main
sources of traffic to the trunk routes.
At the end of June 1971 in England 740 miles (1,190 kilometres) of motorways
had been opened for traffic and construction had started on a further 262 miles
(421 kilometres). Schemes for an additional 599 miles (964 kilometres) were
being prepared. In Wales 23 miles (37 kilometres) were in use. In Scotland
137 miles (220 kilometres) of motorway are planned, of which over 66 miles
(106 kilometres) are in use. (See map on inside of back cover.) Some 160 miles
(257 kilometres) of motorway are due to be opened to traffic by the end of
1971.
A comprehensive programme of trunk road improvements is also well
advanced. Over 1,200 miles (1,931 kilometres) of all-purpose trunk roads in
Great Britain now have dual carriageways, in addition to 700 miles (1,127
kilometres) of principal roads.
A large programme of bridge and tunnel building has been undertaken in
recent years. The bridges include the Medway Bridge on the M2, the sus¬
pension bridge across the Firth of Forth, the Severn Bridge incorporating
major advances in suspension bridge design, and the 7,000-ft (2,134-metre)
bridge across the Firth of Tay. A £7 million bridge over the Clyde at Erskine
was opened in 1971, a ten-lane bridge at Glasgow was opened in 1970, and the
new ^4 million London Bridge is to be completed in 1972. The Western
Avenue extension in London, a motorway viaduct 2^ miles (4 kilometres) long,
was opened in 1970.
Major tunnels, including one under the Thames and one under the Tyne,
have been built in recent years. Work on a second Mersey crossing began in
1967; the first of the twin tunnels was opened in 1971 and the second is due
for completion in 1974.
Research on roads is carried out at the Road Research Laboratory (see p. 320).
Its aims are to find more economical ways of designing, constructing and
maintaining roads and of facilitating the flow of traffic on them and to reduce
road accidents. The layout of roads, their traffic, the safety features of road
vehicles and the behaviour of road users are investigated, and new methods,
materials and processes are developed for building roads and providing them
with a smooth, safe and durable surface. The Laboratory has a Tropical
Section, which undertakes research and advises on road problems in countries
overseas.
In 1970 there were nearly 15 million motor vehicles licensed to use Great
Britain’s roads. Of these, i-6 million were goods vehicles and 200,000 were
public road passenger vehicles (that is, buses and taxicabs).
The first world war stimulated the development of motor vehicles, which
became serious competitors of the railways. Government regulation of public
road transport began with the passing of the London Traffic Act 1924, which

BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
gave the then Minister of Transport power to control the number of buses and
their journeys in London; this was followed in 1933 siting up of the
London Passenger Transport Board (see p. 305).
The Road Traffic Act 19301 ended the licensing of public service vehicles
(that is, buses and coaches) by local authorities and set up instead traffic areas
each under the control of three traffic commissioners. The commissioners
regulate, by means of a licensing system, public road passenger transport
services, and they sanction routes and time-tables in order to secure proper
co-ordination of services and eliminate unnecessary competition; they may
control fares. .
The Road and Rail Traffic Act 1933 established a system of licensing tor
road haulage vehicles designed to restrict vehicle operations to proved needs.
Under the Act the licensing authority (that is, the chairman of the appropriate
body of traffic commissioners) could grant licences to public haulage vehicles,
where their services appeared to be needed and grant automatically, on
application, licences for the carriage of the licensee’s own goods.
Under the 1968 Transport Act a new licensing system, with the sole aim of
improving safety, has replaced the system described above. Over 900,000
goods vehicles not exceeding 3} tons gross loaded weight have been exempted
from licensing. Operation of larger vehicles requires an operator’s licence
certifying ability to maintain vehicles adequately, control loading and the hours
worked by their drivers, and adequate financial resources to enable them to
maintain vehicles properly. There are now no quantitative restrictions of any
kind; under the new system holders of operators’ licences may carry their own
or other people’s goods subject only to restrictions imposed to ensure safety.
New rules effecting the reduction in hours worked by drivers of goods and
public service passenger vehicles laid down by the 1968 Transport Act came
into force in March 1970, together with a new system of written records to be
kept by goods vehicle drivers and their employers. The restrictions on hours
have since been modified to ease certain practical difficulties. Regulations con¬
cerning the fitness and loading of vehicles have been made more stringent
under recent legislation.
From September 1956 to January 1963 the nationalised road haulage services
were controlled by British Road Services (BRS), a division of the British
Transport Commission, and operated through five companies, which together
owned about 16,000 vehicles. Under the Transport Act 1962, these organisa¬
tions operated companies incorporated under the Companies Act, with their
own boards, and were grouped together under the Transport Holding Com¬
pany, responsible to the then Minister of Transport. The road haulage
interests of the Holding Company have been transferred to the National
Freight Corporation (see p. 299), which operates some 30,000 vehicles.
The 1968 Transport Act enables Passenger Transport Authorities (PTAs) to
be set up to control and co-ordinate the different forms of transport in any
particular area. The first PTAs were set up in April 1969 in south-east
Lancashire—north-east Cheshire, Merseyside, the West Midlands and
Tyneside. The constituent local authorities appoint most of the members,
but up to one-seventh may be appointed by the Secretary of State for t e
1 Consolidated in the Road Traffic Act i960.
Road Safety
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 303
Environment (or by the Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales). Each
appoints its own chairman, with the relevant Secretary of State’s approval.
The PTAs control policy and finance, and appoint professional executives—
Passenger Transport Executives—to be responsible to them for day-to-day
operations. The Executives may operate services themselves and enter into
agreements with other bodies, such as British Railways or the National Bus
Company, to operate others; they have taken over all the former municipal
bus undertakings in their areas.
The National Bus Company was formed to take over the former bus
operating and manufacturing subsidiaries of the Transport Holding Company
in England and Wales, and operates through locally based subsidiaries.
A separate Scottish Transport Group has been set up to control bus and
some shipping services in Scotland, and has taken over the relevant interests
of the Transport Holding Company, operating through subsidiaries.
The National Bus Company and the Scottish Transport Group operate
about 21,000 and 4,700 vehicles respectively. The PTAs control 6,300 vehicles.
The remainder of the industry, excluding London Transport, comprises 4,800
operators owning 35,000 vehicles; 79 of these operators are local authorities
outside PTA areas operating 11,000 vehicles, and 3,500 are small concerns
operating not more than five vehicles.
Capital grants may be made by the Government towards the cost of invest¬
ment in public transport, at rates of up to 75 per cent of approved cost. Eligible
schemes include improvements or extensions of railway lines, new fixed track
rail and bus systems, interchanges, stations, and car parks. Grants at the rate
of 25 per cent are available towards the cost of new buses complying with
specifications approved by the Department of the Environment. Local
authorities may assist unremunerative bus services in rural areas, and the
central government may make 50 per cent grants in such cases.
Britain has one of the highest densities of road traffic in the world. Road
accident statistics are compiled and published by the Department of the
Environment, the Scottish Development Department and the Welsh Office
from reports made by the police. In 1970, 7,501 people were killed on the
roads and about 93,500 seriously injured. The fatal accident rate per vehicle
is lower than that in most other European countries.
Modern roads, designed for present-day traffic and segregating pedestrians
from vehicles, are safer than the roads they replace and surveys have shown
they result in a marked fall in casualties. The more important measures
directed primarily towards road safety include speed limits of 30 and 40 mph
(48 and 64 kmph) in built-up areas and 50 mph (80 kmph) on certain trunk
and important classified roads in rural areas; a 70 mph (113 kmph) speed limit
on all motorways and on ordinary main roads where no lower limit applies;
the provision of pedestrian crossings—usually illuminated by flashing beacons
and marked with conspicuous white stripes (‘zebra’ crossings); and the system
of road markings and traffic signs which are being replaced by greatly im¬
proved signs in accordance with general European practice. The Road Safety
Act 1967 made it an offence to drive with more than a prescribed level of
alcohol in the blood, at present 80 milligrammes of alcohol per 100 millilitres
of blood.
The design of vehicles, their use on the roads, and the maintenance of their
mechanical condition are controlled by regulations. The regulations are kept
under constant review, and amended whenever necessary in the interests of
safety or for control of pollution and noise. Private cars and light vans which

Control of Traffic
LONDON
TRANSPORT
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
are three or more years old must be tested annually at private garages author¬
ised as test stations. Heavy goods vehicles are tested annually at government
test stations. Public service vehicles must be specially approved before being
licensed to carry passengers, and are tested at regular intervals. Any vehicle
may be stopped on the road at any time by the police and examined.
All drivers of motor vehicles, unless they have either held a full British
licence or passed the driving test in the last ten years, are required to pass the
test before being granted a full licence to drive. Until they pass the test they
must obtain a ‘provisional’ licence which necessitates their displaying ‘L’
(Learner) plates on their vehicle, and in all cases, except solo motor-cycles
and motor-cycle combinations, where vehicles are constructed to carry pass¬
engers, learner drivers must be accompanied by a qualified driver. (Newly
arrived residents of Britain may drive under their overseas driving licences for
three months before becoming subject to these rules.) A learner driver of a
solo motor-cycle is restricted, until he passes the driving test, to a machine not
exceeding 250 cc. Professional driving instructors must be approved by the
Department of the Environment. A scheme for special licensing and testing of
drivers of heavy goods vehicles, which lapsed in 1939, was reintroduced in
February 1970.
The Road Traffic Acts, which embody the law relating to road users, are
enforced by the police and the courts. A person convicted of any of the 26
most serious offences is liable to be disqualified from driving for a period. The
standard of conduct for all road users and a summary of the requirements of
the law is set out in easily understandable form in the Highway Code, which
was revised in 1969. A failure to observe the code does not of itself render a
person liable to criminal proceedings but may be taken into account in any
such proceedings.
National campaigns to persuade people to take greater care on the roads are
conducted by the Department of the Environment and the Royal Society for
the Prevention of Accidents with assistance from the local authorities, which
also help by arranging courses of instruction, especially courses for children.
The Road Traffic Regulation Act 1967 empowers traffic authorities to make
orders regulating traffic and imposing parking control. With the exception of
trunk roads, which are the concern of the central Government, traffic is the
responsibility of local authorities. Extensive schemes are being undertaken
for the improvement of road safety and the relief of traffic congestion. These
include: ‘fly-overs’ at road junctions; new outlet roads from cities; and traffic
management measures, including comprehensive control of street parking,
‘one-way’ systems, peak hour ‘clearways’ prohibiting waiting on busy roads,
and ‘tidal flow’ arrangements. A Traffic Advisory Unit set up in 1965 in the
then Ministry of Transport advises local authorities. In most town centres
street parking is permitted for limited periods only, and in London and some
other towns on payment at parking meters usually under the supervision of
traffic wardens. Disc schemes providing free but limited parking facilities are
in operation in some towns, including Cheltenham, Devizes, Harrogate and
Ripon. Off-street facilities are being increased, including multi-storey car
parks. A computer-controlled system to regulate traffic was installed in west
London in 1968. Similar systems are operating in Glasgow and Liverpool.
London is one of the world’s four largest cities. The area known as Greater
London, within a radius of about 15 miles (24 kilometres) from Charing Cross,
contains just over 7+ million people.

TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 305
London’s passenger transport system, in its modern sense, began in 1829
when the first omnibus, horse-drawn, appeared on the London streets. The
first regular tram service, also horse-drawn, began in 1870. In 1863 the first
underground steam railway, the Metropolitan, was opened. It was built by
digging a great trench for the line and roofing it over. In 1870 the world’s
first tube railway, the Tower Subway, under the river Thames opened; it was
cable-operated and ran for only a few months. The first electric tube railway
in the world, the City and South London Railway, was opened in 1890, and
this was followed in 1900 by the opening of the Central London Railway.
Shortly afterwards the original steam-operated underground lines were
electrified. Meanwhile horse-drawn trams were being replaced by electric
trams, and later horse-drawn buses by motor buses.
Until 1933 there were many separate undertakings providing passenger
transport facilities in London, but in that year they were all vested in a single
public corporation, the London Passenger Transport Board. In 1948, with the
establishment of the British Transport Commission, the London Transport
Executive took over control as an agency of the Commission.
Under the Transport Act 1962 the London Transport Executive was re¬
placed by a financially independent board, the London Transport Board.
Exchequer loans financed the Board’s external capital needs. From 1965 to
1969 the Board ran a deficit, due mainly to competition from the private car
and to increasing traffic congestion. The deficit was met by Government
grants.
Under the Transport (London) Act 1969, which came into effect on 1st
January 1970, the Greater London Council (GLC) became the overall
transport planning authority for London and assumed responsibility for the
central bus and underground rail services formerly operated by the London
Transport Board (LTB). These services are managed and operated by the
London Transport Executive, appointed by and responsible to the GLC.
The LTB’s country bus and Green Line coach services were transferred to
London Country Bus Services Ltd., a subsidiary of the National Bus Company
(see p. 303). Under a financial reorganisation the Government has written off
the entire capital debt of the former LTB, some j£27° million.
The London Transport undertaking operates all road and rail passenger
transport services in the London area with the exception of the London lines
of the British Railways Board, the Green Line coach services and the taxicabs.
Some 8,250 taxicabs that ply for hire in the streets are privately operated by
companies or owner-drivers and are licensed annually by the Metropolitan
Police. There are about 13,300 licensed cab drivers.
London Transport’s railway network stretches over 20 miles (32 kilo¬
metres) from north to south and 35 miles (56 kilometres) from east to west. In
March 1971 the total length of the railway over which London Transport
trains operated was 254 miles (409 kilometres), of which 100 miles (161 kilo¬
metres) were underground. London Transport trains serve 276 stations and its
buses travel over 1,702 miles (2,739 kilometres) of roads. To carry traffic over
all this area London Transport owns 4,423 railway cars and 6,428 buses. The
total staff employed is over 60,000.
Improvements being carried out by London Transport have included
extension and modernisation of parts of the Underground system, and the
introduction of automatic fare collection and automatic trains. One-man
operation of buses is being steadily extended over a period of years. The
306 BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
first one-man-operated double decker buses were introduced at the beginning
of 1971.
Work on a new 14-mile (23-kilometre) underground railway between
Walthamstow in north-east London and Brixton in south London was
completed in 1971 (except for one station), and work begun on a scheme to
link Heathrow airport with the underground railway system.
London Transport set up an international advisory service for city transport
in 1969.
INLAND In 1761 James Brindley completed the Bridgewater Canal to take coal from
WATERWAYS t|ie collieries owned by the Duke of Bridgewater at Worsley to Manchester.
This marked the beginning of canal building in modern Britain, with which
the names of Brindley, Telford, Rennie, Jessop and other great engineers are
associated. Canals played an important part in promoting industrial and
commercial expansion in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries.
The whole canal system was practically complete by 1830. As a result of
developing competition from the railways, however, about one-third of the
canal mileage had passed to the control of the railway companies by the middle
of the nineteenth century. During the two world wars government control
of railways included railway-owned canals. Under the Transport Act 1947,
most of the country’s canals passed to the British Transport Commission in
January 1948. Under the Transport Act of 1962, control has been vested
in the British Waterways Board since January 1963. Under the Transport
Act 1968 a grant-in-aid is being paid primarily to enable the Board to main¬
tain an extensive network of amenity waterways; in 1970-71 ^1-85 million
was paid and a further £1*1 million for the costs of improving bridges.
The System There are about 2,500 miles (4,023 kilometres) of navigable inland waterways
in Great Britain,1 some 2,000 miles (3,219 kilometres) of which belong to the
British Waterways Board; the remainder are mainly still in the hands of
local authorities or private companies. Many of the Board’s canals are narrow
waterways which can generally be used only by boats not exceeding 7 ft
(2*13 metres) in width, the remainder are broad waterways and canalised rivers,
some of which can be used by craft of up to about 75° tons capacity. The
Caledonian and Crinan Canals in Scotland are broad waterways. Of the
inland waterways under the control of the British Waterways Board some
340 miles (547 kilometres) are commercial waterways. A substantial additional
mileage (1,100 miles—1,770 kilometres—known as cruising waterways) is to
be maintained for recreational purposes; a statutory Inland Waterways
Amenity Advisory Council advises the Secretary of State for the Environment
and the Board. _ ,
Engineering, commercial and estate work is directed from the Board s
headquarters in London and Watford, and through regional offices at Leeds
and Gloucester. In Scotland the canals (other than the Caledonian, which is
run by a manager) are, for engineering purposes, under the control of the
engineer-in-charge at Glasgow; estates work is supervised centrally from
In 1970 traffic on the Board’s waterways amounted to just oyer 6-4 million
tons, of which 27 million tons were coal, 1 -4 million tons liquids in bulk and
2 7 million tons general cargo. Some 97 per cent of the traffic is carried on

340 miles (549 kilometres) of commercial waterways, which are mainly
canalised river navigations.
Although the British Waterways Board is the largest single carrying
operator, most of the traffic is handled by independent carriers or by traders
in their own craft. The Board at the end of 1970 owned 542 freight-carrying
craft (including tugs) with a carrying capacity of 25,739 tons. It operates
2 docks and 25 warehouses.
The Board is anxious to develop its cruising waterways for purposes of
recreation and amenity. These include the Llangollen branch of the Shrop¬
shire Union Canal, the Oxford Canal, and the Leeds and Liverpool Canal.
The principal commercial waterways are the river navigations and broad
canals in the Yorkshire-Humberside area, the Trent Navigation, and the
Gloucester and Sharpness Canal. Freight traffic is declining, but some im¬
provements to facilities are being carried out.
The total turnover of the British Waterways Board in 1970 amounted to
£5 million, of which £0-3 million arose from the Board’s own freight¬
carrying activities, £1 -2 million from warehousing and terminal services, and
£o-y million from the docks. The sale of water for industrial and agricultural
purposes brought in £o-g million. Receipts from pleasure boating were
£170,300. The number of pleasure craft licensed in 1970 was 12,607.
Reorganisation of public transport in Northern Ireland was completed in
1968. Under the Transport Act (Northern Ireland) 1967 the Ulster Transport
Authority was wound up and its assets and liabilities transferred to a new
company, the Northern Ireland Transport Holding Company. Responsibility
for operating services on the 200 miles (322 kilometres) of railway track was
given to the Northern Ireland Railways Company Ltd., a subsidiary of the
Holding Company. The Act also provides for a licensing system for road
passenger operators.
Ulsterbus Ltd., another subsidiary of the Holding Company, has taken
over the road passenger operations of the Authority, which formerly provided
all public road passenger services, apart from those of the City of Belfast. A
number of privately owned bus companies now operate in addition.
In 1966 the Authority’s monopoly of road carriage of freight was replaced
by a licensing system. About 1,900 operators and 4,150 vehicles have been
licensed, the biggest single operator being Northern Ireland Carriers Ltd.,
owned jointly by the Northern Ireland Transport Holding Company and
the British National Freight Corporation.
On 31st March 1971 there were 14,160 miles (22,287 kilometres) of public
roads in Northern Ireland, comprising 379 miles (610 kilometres) of trunk
roads, 1,018 miles (1,638 kilometres) of Class I roads, 1,736 miles (2,794
kilometres) of Class II roads, 2,883 miles (4,640 kilometres) of Class III roads
and 8,144 miles (13,107 kilometres) of unclassified roads.
The Ministry of Development is directly responsible for the trunk road
system and bears the entire cost of maintenance and construction work on
these roads. In addition to major construction schemes on trunk roads, an
extensive system of motorways is planned including an urban motorway
system in Belfast. About 54 miles (87 kilometres) of motorway were in use by
the middle of 1971.
The Ministry of Development administers the Road Fund (the proceeds of
motor vehicle taxation, driving licence fees, etc.), from which grants are paid

CIVIL AVIATION
British airmen were among the first to carry mails (at the time of the Corona¬
tion of King George V in 1911) and among the first to operate regular mail
and passenger services, which were inaugurated on 25th August 1919, when
a daily passenger service was opened between London (Hounslow) and Paris
(Le Bourget).
In April 1924 four small British companies merged to form Imperial Airways
Limited and this company pioneered the commercial development of inter¬
continental air routes. By 1929 there was a through service from England to
India. The first passenger service to Australia started in 1935.
The British Overseas Airways Corporation (BOAC), a public corporation,
took over the undertakings of Imperial Airways Limited and British Airways
Limited in 1940. British European Airways (BEA) was established under the
Civil Aviation Act 1946 as a separate public corporation to cover the United
Kingdom and Europe. In addition to the two nationalised corporations, 46
independent air transport operators hold Air Operators’ Certificates.
General responsibility for the development of United Kingdom civil aviation
rests with the Department of Trade and Industry, which has certain statutory
powers and duties in respect of the air corporations, including the power, very
seldom used, to give directions of a general character as to the exercise and
performance of their functions in relation to matters affecting the national
interest. The Department appoints the Boards of the corporations and, with
the approval of the Treasury, has power to make loans within the limits laid
down by Parliament to finance capital investment. It is responsible for
approving the lines of the corporations’ capital expenditure, and also sets, after
consultation with the corporations, their financial targets and, in BOAC’s case,
approves the amount payable annually as dividend. There is close consultation
on overseas traffic rights and air safety. Day-to-day matters concerning the
corporations’ activities are the responsibility of the commercial management
of BOAC and BEA. . . . . .
The Department plays an important part in the activities of the International
Civil Aviation Organisation and other international aviation bodies.
Under the post-war nationalisation legislation the air corporations had a
statutory monopoly of British scheduled services, and independent operators
were confined, broadly, to charter work. From 1949, and increasingly from
1952, the independents were allowed to develop new scheduled services,
provided they secured ministerial approval and operated, technically, as

associates of the corporations. The Civil Aviation (Licensing) Act i960
abolished the corporations’ monopoly and provided for a licensing system,
administered by an Air Transport Licensing Board, to which the nationalised
and independent operators could apply on an equal footing for licences for
scheduled or charter services, or for revocation or variation of existing licences.
The ATLB is an independent body of six to ten members appointed by the
Department of Trade and Industry. Its main function is to consider and decide
on applications for licences (or their revocation or variation). The ATLB
must have regard to an applicant’s financial resources, staffing, organisation,
the need for the proposed services, the adequacy of, and possible effect on,
existing services, and any objections or representations made by interested
parties. It also has the general duty of furthering the development of British
aviation. There is provision for appeals on ATLB decisions to the Department,
which appoints independent commissioners to hear appeals publicly and report
with recommendations upon them.
A committee set up to enquire into the affairs of the civil air transport
industry reported in May 1969. On the basis of its recommendations, under
the Civil Aviation Act 1971, a new Civil Aviation Authority is to be set up
in April 1972 to take over general control of the industry, in particular of
safety regulations and licensing. It will absorb the present Air Registration
Board (see p. 313) and Air Transport Licensing Board. At the same time a
new British Airways Board is to assume powers of general supervision over
BOAC and BEA. The committee also recommended that a privately owned
‘second force’ airline be set up from among the independent operators. Such
an airline was formed in December 1970 through a merger of British United
Airways and Caledonian Airways.
The constitution and functions of BOAC and BEA are laid down in the Air
Corporations Act 1967, which consolidates, with certain exceptions, the
provisions of the Air Corporations Acts 1949 and 1966, and in the Air
Corporation Act 1969. Each corporation consists of 5 to 11 members, includ¬
ing the chairman. The chairman of each board is a member of the other.
As a result of BOAC’s capital reconstruction in 1966, £35 million ‘Exchequer
Dividend Capital’ on which a variable dividend, related to each year’s
earnings, is payable, was created, together with a reconstruction reserve of
some £30 million and appropriate loan capital. The introduction of Public
Dividend Capital (now £65 million) is experimental. The statutory limit on
BOAC’s total borrowings is ^120 million. BEA’s borrowing limit is ^200
million, which can be increased by Order to £230 million.
Total capacity-ton-miles offered on all services by British airlines has more
than trebled since 1959, and had risen to 3,960 million capacity-ton-miles in
1970. In 1955, 2-5 million passengers entered or left the United Kingdom by
air, compared with 5-7 million who arrived or departed by sea; in 1962 there
were for the first time more air than sea passengers, and by 1970 the figures
had risen to 21-7 million by air and 11-5 million by sea.
BOAC is engaged on long-haul operations. Its scheduled services link Britain
with continental Europe, the Middle East, the Far East, Australasia, Africa and
North and South America, and it also provides complete round-the-world
services. It co-operates closely with airlines of several other Commonwealth
countries; it also has financial interests in seven companies operating local and

years in one of the most advanced airline computer systems in the world
(BOADICEA). Applications include seat reservations, departure, cargo, an
stock control, message switching, payroll and costing.
In 1070-71 BO AC earned an operating surplus of £5 million and net profits of
rv2 million after interest on borrowings and taxation. Of its gross tra c
revenue (£196 million), £131 million was earned in foreign currencies.
BEA and its associates operate services to some 100 destinations m35 countries
in Britain and the rest of Europe, North Africa and the Middle East. Its
services in Britain include a number which cannot be operated on a commercia
basis but which meet a vital social need, mainly the services to the Highland
and Islands of Scotland. BEA also co-operates with other airlines in order to
create ‘through travel’ facilities. It has a financial interest in several associated
companies, most of which collaborate with BEA in providing a network o
services. Two major subsidiaries are British Air Services, operating secondary
domestic services, and BEA Airtours Ltd., a new tours company.
For the year ended 31st March 1971 increases in capacity offered and
passenger-miles flown on scheduled services were 6-5 per cent and o-5 per
cent respectively over the previous year; fre.ght-ton-m.les flown fell by 12 5
per cent. In the same year some 87 million passengers were carried.

In 1970-71 the corporation earned over £133 million in revenue and made
a net profit of £520,000. It has earned a profit in 7 out of the past 10 years.
Although the two State corporations had a statutory monopoly up to 1961
there has been a significant expansion in recent years not only of the number
of passengers and volume of freight carried but also in the diversity of services
operated by the independent operators. As well as a wide network of domestic

and international services they provide vehicle ferry services; specialised air
cargo facilities; and enable travel agents to offer low-cost all-in holidays
abroad. The independent companies compete with BEA over several domestic
routes, including the busiest internal route in Europe, from London to
Glasgow. In 1970 they carried some 3 million passengers. British Caledonian
Airways, the new ‘second force’ airline (see p. 309), has a fleet of 31 aircraft,

some 275 million passengers a year.
In addition to the public transport operators there are a large number of
companies engaged in miscellaneous aviation activities such as crop-spraying,
aerial survey and photography, and flying instruction. About 30 companies
carry out air-taxi operations.
The proportion of Britain’s overseas trade carried by air is increasing steadily.
In 1956, 17 per cent of imports and 2-9 per cent of exports (by value) were
carried by air. In 1970 the corresponding percentages were 13-6 in both, and
the total value of exports, imports and re-exports by air was £2,324 million.
The chief export items are expensive machinery and parts, aircraft and vehicle
parts, and electrical and electronic products; furs and skins account for a large
proportion of the total value of re-exports.
At Heathrow, London, freight traffic is increasing at an annual rate of 12
per cent and totalled 335,670 metric tons in 1970. Scheduled services of
British airlines carried about 267,000 tons of freight in 1970, compared with
240,000 tons in i960.
The estimated number of aircraft on the United Kingdom register used for
business and private purposes is over 1,000, while approximately 860 are
owned by clubs, groups and training schools. About 15,000 private pilots
hold licences. About 130 companies use private aircraft and some 80 companies
are members of the Business Aircraft Users’ Association. There are some
4,000 glider pilots.
The Department of Trade and Industry has a general responsibility for civil
aerodromes. It may itself establish and maintain airports, and local authorities
may also do so subject to its approval. Aerodromes which are municipally or
privately owned and which are used for the public transport of passengers and/
or flying instruction are subject to government licensing, inspection and
regulation. The Department is also responsible for navigation facilities at a
number of main municipal airports.
The British Airports Authority, an independent statutory body operating
on a commercial basis, took over on 1st April 1966 the ownership and manage¬
ment of London’s two major airports (Heathrow and Gatwick), Prestwick in
Scotland and Stansted in Essex. In April 1971 it took over Edinburgh airport.
At these airports the Department of Trade and Industry is responsible for the
provision of navigation services and may direct the Authority to take measures
to control noise and vibration.
There are approximately 140 civil aerodromes in the United Kingdom; in
addition, 56 Service aerodromes are available for civil use. Those under civil
control include 12 directly controlled by the Department of Trade and
Industry, 3 in the Channel Islands and 1 in the Isle of Man administered by
the local island governments, and 40 aerodromes licensed for public use, of
which 24 are owned by municipalities. Two of the Department’s aerodromes

In April 1971 the Government announced that a third London airport
would be built at Foulness, on the Essex coast; the first runway should be in
use by 1980.
Aircraft and passenger movements at the principal airports have risen very
markedly in the last five years, and in 1970 United Kingdom civil airports
handled 32-4 million passengers. The number of movements of aircraft
engaged on commercial transport operations was 606,700.
For international scheduled services Heathrow and Gatwick are the mam
airports, and Heathrow is the busiest centre of international travel in the
world. The number of passengers handled at Heathrow, 14 miles (22 kilo¬
metres) west of central London, has increased from 5-4 million in i960 to
ic-6 million in 1970 of which 12-6 million were international passengers. The
British Airports Authority plans to spend nearly £80 million on improve¬
ments to Heathrow and its other airports in the period ending in 1973. The
shorter of the two main Heathrow runways was extended to 12,800 feet
(3,900 metres) in 1971. An fn million passenger terminal primarily for British
short-haul airlines and Aer Lingus was completed in 1969, and extensions
have been made to several other buildings. To accommodate the rapid
expansion expected in freight movements, £25 million has been invested in
a new cargo terminal and associated developments, which came into use in
1969. New facilities costing some £13 million have been provided for handling
Boeing 747 (jumbo jet) aircraft, which began to use the airport early in 1970.
Work has begun on the extension of London’s underground railway to
The airport at Gatwick, 28 miles (45 kilometres) south of London, was
opened in June 1958 as the second airport for the London area. Built along¬
side the main London to Brighton railway and the A23 road, Gatwick airport
was the first in the world to contain road, rail and air transport in one unit.
In 1970 it handled 37 million passengers. The existing runway has been
extended; a further extension is under consideration.
A privately owned helicopter terminal (or ‘heliport’) is in operation at
Battersea on the south bank of the Thames.
Prestwick airport in Scotland has been developed to accommodate large
jet aircraft. Already one of the best equipped freight airports in the world, a
new cargo terminal is being built there. The airport at Abbotsinch, owned and
run by the Glasgow Corporation, handled 17 million passengers in 1970.
A new main runway and other improvements are to be provided at Edinburgh.
Manchester and Luton airports each handled nearly 2 million passengers
in 1970; Birmingham, Edinburgh, Prestwick and Stansted each handled over
500,000.
The role of the Government in promoting air safety lies in research and in
setting up and supervising standards for both aircraft and personne .
Research on aircraft design and construction is done at the Royal Aircraft
Establishments at Farnborough and Bedford, which are exceptiona y we
equipped with testing facilities.
The Department of Trade and Industry determines the policy and legislative
requirements for the safe operation of civil aircraft, analyses accidents and
initiates preventive measures and research in flight safety.

All aircraft registered in the United Kingdom must have a valid certificate
of airworthiness issued (or rendered valid) by the Department on the recom¬
mendation of the Air Registration Board (ARB), which was set up in 1937
and consists of 18 members, four of whom are independent, including the
chairman. No aircraft built in Britain is granted a certificate of airworthi¬
ness unless it has been constructed in accordance with British Civil Air¬
worthiness Requirements, a code compiled and frequently reviewed by the
ARB. Continued airworthiness is ensured by regular inspection and by re¬
quiring aircraft to be maintained in accordance with a schedule approved by
the ARB.
Every operator of aircraft above a certain weight used for public transport
must possess an Air Operator’s Certificate which is granted by the Director of
Aviation Safety when he is satisfied that the operator is competent to secure
the safe operation of his aircraft. The Director is advised by the Department
of Trade and Industry’s flight operations inspectors (who are experienced
airline pilots) on all matters affecting the operation of aircraft, except aircraft
maintenance, which is the responsibility of the Air Registration Board.
Each member of a flight crew must hold the appropriate official licence. Flight
operations inspectors check the standards maintained by the operators, which
must be adequate for purposes of the Air Operator’s Certificate.
In order to supplement the diminishing supply of well-trained pilots for civil
airlines from the Royal Air Force, the College of Air Training was set up at
Hamble in i960. It is sponsored by the Government and the two airways
corporations. Commercial pilots must attend a course of training approved by
the Department of Trade and Industry. Such courses have been approved at
the training schools at Carlisle, Oxford and Perth, in addition to Hamble.
The corporations set up a new engineering apprentice school at Cranebank,
near Heathrow, in 1970.
An Air Transport and Travel Industry Training Board has been established
under the Industrial Training Act 1964.
Responsibility for policy planning and execution of both civil and military
air traffic control over the United Kingdom and the surrounding seas rests
with the National Air Traffic Services, under the joint control of the Secretary
of State, Department of Trade and Industry and the Secretary of State for
Defence.
In 1950 a system of airways covering the main traffic routes with control zones
around the major airports was introduced. Subsequently, the airway system
has been revised and extended to meet traffic requirements. There are three
main air traffic control centres: at London for southern England, at Preston
for the north of England and Wales, and at Prestwick for Scotland and the
Atlantic Ocean to 3o°W.
A variety of radar installations and other equipment provide the means by
which the system can accept the increasingly heavy load of air traffic. Britain
was the first country to use radar for the control of civil air traffic. During
the next few years, under a scheme (Mediator) which will eventually cost some
£50 million, virtually the whole of the airspace over Britain above 5,000 feet
(1,524 metres) will be brought under surveillance by the latest types of primary
and secondary radar equipment, which will provide data to be used in two air
traffic control centres, located at West Drayton (near London) and Prestwick.
The first stage was introduced in February 1971. A subsidiary centre will be

located at Manchester to deal with traffic in the Manchester terminal control
area. Extensive use will be made in these centres of automatic data processing
and other advanced electronic techniques. The Department of Trade and
Industry provides radio navigational aids to help pilots navigate in all weat er
conditions, and has installed the Instrument Landing System (ILS) at all its
m Britain^has pioneered in the development of all-weather landing systems.
The Blind Landing Experimental Unit of the Royal Aircraft Establishmen
at Bedford and private industry have worked towards fully automatic land¬
ing, which has now been achieved with passenger-carrying aircraft, in goo
visibility.
Britain is a member of Eurocontrol, a European international agency con¬
cerned with the traffic control problems arising from the increasing use of
high-flying, high-speed jet aircraft. Set up in 1963 it provides control at the
higher flight levels for civil aircraft and for military aircraft operating accor¬
ding to civil procedures.
From 1st January 1971 all new types of subsonic aircraft using British airports
are required to hold a ‘certificate of quietness’. The noise standards laid down
in the certificate follow the recommendations of the special meeting held by
the International Civil Aviation Organisation in Montreal in 1969.
Noise abatement measures in force at various airports include limitations
on noise levels at take-off, route restrictions, procedures designed to lessen
noise on the ground, and limits on the number of jet movements during
summer nights.

THE POST OFFICE
The Post Office, founded in 1657, provides postal, public telecommunications,
data processing and Giro services. It was formally set up as a public authority
under the Post Office Act 1969, having previously been a government depar
ment.
The Post Office is headed by a chairman and board, appointed by and respon¬
sible to the Minister of Posts and Telecommunications. It has some 420,000
employees and approaching 25>ooo post offices.
The Post Office has authority to borrow up to £2,300 million. At 31st March
1971 it had borrowed £2,193 million. Over 90 per cent of total exPeijdlture
on fixed assets is accounted for by telecommunications. The postal, tele¬
communications and data processing services are now managed separate y.
The development of postal communications in Britain can be traced from
the time when horsemen carried dispatches to the Tudor Court up to modern
airmail transport. The first dispatch of mails by train was made in 1830
between Liverpool and Manchester. The inauguration of the penny post
(the uniform charge for any inland distance being prepaid by means of postage
stamps, which originated in Britain) in 1840 was followed by a rapid exten¬
sion of the scope of the postal services. The registered P^st, ensuring a 1-
tional safety for valuable mail, was introduced in 1841. The money ord
system which had operated as a private venture from 1792 to 1838 was
supplemented in 1881 by the issue of postal orders for fixed amounts. Letter¬
boxes had been instituted in London in 1855, and in 1883 the parcel post was
Counter
Services
Telegraph
Services
Telex Service
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 315
introduced. In 1919 the Post Office inaugurated its own motor transport
fleet and the first mail was carried by air in Britain in 1911.
Approaching 11,000 million items of correspondence are carried annually
by the inland postal services. Each year about 7,500 tons of mail are carried
by air within the United Kingdom. Out of the 523 million items of overseas
mail carried in 1970-71, 69-5 per cent was carried by air.
The air parcel service now operates to all countries in Europe and to over
190 countries outside Europe.
Several new highly mechanised sorting office buildings were opened in
1970 and 1971. Letter segregating and facing machines are being installed at
over 60 centres. Postal address coding is being continuously extended, and
will cover over 13^ million addresses by the end of 1971; the remainder of
Britain’s 18 million addresses are to be included by the end of 1972. A two-
tier letter service was introduced in 1968 consisting of a faster, more highly
priced service for first-class mail and a cheaper one for less urgent items. Some
^50 million is being invested in an improved parcels service.
A ‘Datapost’ special delivery service for computer data was started in 1970.
A Postal Consultancy Service offers facilities to overseas countries to aid
them in the planning and mechanisation of their services.
At the post office counter, besides making use of its postal and telegraph
facilities, the citizen can draw his pension and his family allowance, buy a
licence for his dog, or television receiving set, renew his car licence and buy
national insurance stamps. He can also use the wide range of facilities for
savings and investments (see p. 352) offered by the Department for National
Savings, and the money transmission services of the National Giro. In much of
the work at its counters the Post Office acts as agent for government depart¬
ments or local authorities.
All private telegraph systems in Britain were transferred to the control of
the Postmaster General in 1870. Teleprinter-working for the transmission
of inland telegrams was introduced generally in 1928 and conversion to the
present automatic switching system was completed in mid-1954. It is now
one of the most up-to-date systems in the world and gives direct connection
between any of the 320 or so larger telegraph offices. The international
telegraph services were shared until 1950 between the Post Office and Cable
and Wireless Ltd. This company was brought into public ownership in 1947.
The Post Office, which acquired the British services, operates all telegraph
services from the United Kingdom, except those offered by foreign telegraph
companies. Cable and Wireless Ltd. continues to operate its cable and wireless
services in many dependencies and foreign countries.
Telegraph services to countries overseas are operated from Electra House in
London, the world’s largest overseas telegraph office, and from nine other
London and provincial area telegraph offices. Direct connection via the Centex
system between these British offices and the larger towns in Belgium, France,
Federal Republic of Germany, Holland, Luxembourg, Italy and Norway
minimises delivery delay. In addition, the Post Office is well to the fore in the
development of telegraph message relay techniques for services beyond Europe.
The Telex Service (opened in England in 1932) combines the speed of the
telephone with the accuracy of the printed word. Calls may be made direct
between the rapidly increasing number of telex users in Britain (about 32,000
by the end of 1970) and also to well over 300,000 subscribers throughout the
