world. Britain is linked to over 140 countries by telex. For call charging
purposes Britain is divided into 50 charging areas, each with its own telex
centre. The United Kingdom telex service is fully automatic and immediate
connection is made by direct dialling to any subscriber in this country and to
many subscribers in Europe, New Zealand, the United States, Canada,
Australia and South Africa. Calls to countries without an automatic service
are connected through the International Telex Exchange in London. Overseas
telex traffic is growing annually by about 20 per cent; the Post Office is plan¬
ning for a system of about 140,000 United Kingdom subscribers by 1980
A radioteleprinter service extends the use of telex to ships at sea (see p. 318).
The demand for facilities enabling digital data for computers to be trans¬
mitted over telephone and telegraph lines has greatly increased; to meet it
the Post Office has developed a range of datel services providing for trans¬
mission at speeds of up to 50 bits per second over telegraph-type circuits
and up to 2,400 bits per second over speech-type circuits. Speeds ot 4°>°00
bits per second can be accommodated by special arrangement. Datel facilities
are available to a number of European countries and over speech-type circuits
to North America and Australia. In the year ending March 1971 the number ot
British Post Office datel terminals amounted to some 15,000.
When the Post Office bought the property of the National Telephone Com¬
pany in 1912 it became the owner of almost the whole telephone service.
Hull Corporation was the only municipality to exercise its option of operating
its own service under licence from the Postmaster General; this service is
connected to the Post Office trunk network.
At the end of March 1971 there were 6,151 local telephone exchanges and
nearly 15 million telephones. On that date, only 86 exchanges remained to be
changed to automatic working. All London’s exchanges are now automatic.
Trunk dialling by subscribers (STD) began in Bristol in December 1958; by
March 1971 the facility had been extended to 3,402 exchanges, serving 90 per
cent of all subscribers. STD brings the advantages of quicker service, auto¬
matic accounting and cheap long-distance calls of short duration. Telephones
in London and five other large cities have been given all-figure numbers in
which exchange names are replaced by figures, to facilitate handling of rapidly
expanding domestic and international traffic. . ,
The first operational electronic exchange in Europe was opened at Amber-
eate Derbyshire, in December 1966. New small and medium-sized exchanges
are being ordered as electronic exchanges. Similar equipment for larger
exchanges is being developed. #
Pulse code modulation systems are being used to increase the circu
capacity of lines on short-distance routes between exchanges. Over 1,000
should be installed by the end of 1971. A new time-division electronic
switching system for interconnecting routes equipped with pulse code modu¬
lation systems has been used experimentally. Research is proceeding in o a
new digital transmission and waveguide system to increase capacity.
International subscriber dialling operates from London, Edinburg ,
Birmingham, Glasgow, Liverpool and Manchester, and to most of Western
Europe and the United States. Britain has two automatic Internationa
telephone exchanges in use and a third under construction. It is expected that
by 1975 75 Per cent of international calls will be dialled by the subscriber,
compared with 62 per cent in 1971. . , _ ,
Operator-connected calls are handled at the London Continental Exchange,

from which well over 2,000 direct telephone circuits give service to European
countries, and at the London International Exchange, which has direct links
via the transatlantic and Commonwealth cable networks, communications
satellites and high frequency radio to over 70 countries. Almost every country
can be reached from these two exchanges, via intermediate points where
necessary.
A radio tower, 620 feet (189 metres) high, in London provides microwave
radio links for carrying long-distance telephone and television circuits. There
are over 100 Post Office communications masts and towers in use, including a
tower of 500 feet (152 metres) in Birmingham.
Several specialised services are available by telephone, including the *999
emergency dialling service enabling subscribers to be connected as quickly
as possible, and free of charge, to the police, ambulance or fire brigade
services. A public radiotelephone service operating in London and south
Lancashire enables users of vehicles fitted with suitable equipment to make
or receive calls to or from any telephone in the United Kingdom network.
Recorded information services include: the speaking clock, weather forecasts,
motoring information, recipes, ‘Test match’ cricket scores, Financial Times
share index and business news summary and ‘Dial a Disc’. In London a
recorded service provides details in five languages of events taking place, and
a similar service, in English only, is provided in Edinburgh during the summer.
There are over 100,000 private circuit stations not connected with the public
exchange networks. These are associated with circuits rented for private use
for telephone conversations, teleprinter connections, photo-telegraphy, tele¬
vision, music, or for the transmission of signals which represent data for
computers or operate other devices.
The first transatlantic telephone cable, TAT 1, connecting Britain with Canada
and the United States, was laid in 1956. Many submarine telephone cables
have been laid in succeeding years. Cable and Wireless Ltd., in co-operation
with the Post Office, carried out a comprehensive Commonwealth telephone
cable plan. The plan was agreed upon in 1958, and covered the construction
of three long-distance telephone cable systems: CANTAT (2,100 nautical
miles), from Scotland to Canada, was opened in 1961; COMPAC (8,130
nautical miles), connecting Canada, Hawaii, Fiji, New Zealand and Australia,
opened in 1963; and SEACOM (7,070 nautical miles), connecting Australia,
New Guinea, Guam, Hong Kong, Malaysia and Singapore, was completed
in stages from 1965 to 1967 and opened as a complete system in March 1967.
All three can provide 80 telephone circuits throughout, apart from the heavily
used section of SEACOM between Guam and Australia, which can provide
160. The submarine cables are linked overland across Canada and Australia
by radio microwave systems. CANTAT was the first single-cable ocean
telephone system to use the new lightweight cable and rigid two-way re¬
peaters, both developed by the Post Office.
Submarine cable systems using transistors in place of thermionic valves
have been developed by British manufacturers in consultation with the Post
Office Research Station and are used in many new systems. High capacity
submarine cable systems capable of providing 1,800 telephone circuits have
now been developed and the first systems brought into service during 1971.
There are 350 underwater cables in the national network, totalling over
2,000 miles (3,218 kilometres).

The Goonhilly satellite communication earth station in Cornwall was brought
into operation in 1962, and took part in the first experiments in satellite
communications using the Telstar and Relay satellites The station now
provides commercial telephone and television circuits via high-capacity, geo¬
stationary satellites positioned over the Atlantic and Indian Oceans. By May
1971 Britain had satellite links with 26 countries via 20 earth stations. A third
large aerial at Goonhilly is expected to come into service early in I972-^
satellites used in the global communications systems are provided by
SAT (International Communications Satellite Consortium) of which Britain
is the second largest shareholder. The number of satellite circuits used by
Britain has risen from 30 at the end of 1965 to some 650 by the end of 1971-
In addition to the radio stations for overseas telecommunications, the Post
Office has 11 coast radio stations in the United Kingdom. These stations
provide radiotelegraph and radiotelephone communications with ships at sea
at ranges of up to some 500 miles (805 kilometres) and 250 miles (402 kilo¬
metres) respectively. There is also the long-distance radiotelegraph and radio¬
telephone station, Portishead Radio, which communicates with ships in all
parts of the world; facilities were improved in 1970.
These coast stations play an important part in the services concerned with
safety of life at sea. They keep continuous watch on the international radio¬
telegraph and radiotelephone frequencies for distress calls from ships or
aircraft and take immediate action to obtain assistance for zny vesstl m
distress. During 1970-71 the stations handled 202 urgent and SOS calls.
In addition to the services for safety of life at sea, the stations exchange
radiotelegrams with ships and connect radiotelephone ca Is between telephone
subscribers ashore and suitably equipped ships; they also broadcast nav g
tional warnings and weather bulletins. , , , * „
The stations operate a free medical advice service whereby the master of a
ship of any nationality may obtain advice from appropnate “ed“'
on the treatment to be given in cases of sickness or injury aboard ship. Dur g
1970-7!, 588 medical cases were dealt with in this service.
Since the Post Office in 1957 set up an installation to process payroll, pensions
and statistical work, it has become one of the largest users of automatic data
processing equipment and techniques in Britain. Its computer organisation is
divided into two parts: the Post Office Data Processing Service for its own
internal services, and the National Data Processing Service for services
business firms and other external users.
In addition to stock control and telephone billing computer systems are
used for large-scale document and information retrieval systems, the G
system, scheduling of mail vans in London, and control of tsvenue collecMn
from television licences. In its 14 regional computer centres he Post Office
operates over 30 computers and is processing some 50 projects. Techniques
and equipmem deployed by the staff of over 3,000, of whom over . 000 are
systems analysts and programmers, include optical and magnetic ^ ctatac'er
reader/sorters; direct keying of data on to discs and magnetic tapes, and the
direct recording of data from magnetic tapes to microti m.
The Post Office is spending nearly £n million a year on research and develop¬
ment, in collaboration with industry and the universities. A new £8 mdlion
research centre is being built at Martlesham Heath, Suffolk, to rep
eventually the laboratories at Dollis Hill.

The Government is the main source of funds for scientific research and
development as a whole though private industry contributes a larger propor¬
tion of funds for civil research and development. Considerable sums are also
provided by public corporations, independent trusts and foundations, and
learned societies. The Government also keeps under review facilities for
training scientists and ensures that adequate research is directed to matters of
national interest.
Total expenditure in Britain on scientific research and development has risen
from ^6577 million in 1961-62, to £1,016 million in 1968-69, while remain¬
ing at about 27 per cent of the gross national product at factor cost. The pro¬
portions of total research and development carried out in the various sectors
have not changed appreciably since 1964-65 with the Government (including
the research councils) carrying out 25 per cent and universities and establish¬
ments of further education between 7 and 8 per cent. The proportion of
research and development financed by the Government remained at about 50
per cent in 1967-68, a decline in defence research and development being
balanced by the rise in civil research and development. The total grant-in-aid
to the research councils for 1970-71 is shown in Public Expenditure ig6g~yo to
iqy^-yg as about £110 million; an increase to £129 million by 1974-75 is
also provided for. Although this represents an increase of 17 per cent over five
years, the annual rate of growth will decrease from 47 per cent to 3 -2 per cent.
The Central Advisory Council for Science and Technology was established in
January 1967, under the chairmanship of the Chief Scientific Adviser to the
Government, to advise the Government on the most effective national strategy
for the use and development of the country’s scientific and technological
resources. The Council includes members who are also members of the
Council for Scientific Policy (see p. 320), and the Royal Society (see p. 322),
and independent members.
Under the Science and Technology Act 1965 central responsibility for
basic and applied civil science rests with the Secretary of State for Education
and Science, who, advised by a Council for Scientific Policy in relation to
the natural sciences as a whole, is responsible for directing and financing the
research councils. Responsibility for technology rests with the Secretary of
State for Trade and Industry. Other government departments are responsible
for research and development related to their executive responsibilities.
The Department The Department of Education and Science (see also p. 50) is responsible,
of Education among other things, for Government policy regarding the universities and for
and Science promoting civil science throughout Great Britain. The Department’s relations
with the universities are conducted through the University Grants Committee
(see p. 159); and its responsibilities for basic and applied civil science are
discharged mainly through the five research councils: the Science Research

Council (see p. 325), the Medical Research Council (see p. 327), the Agricul¬
tural Research Council (see p. 328), the Natural Environment Research
Council (see p. 332), and the Social Science Research Council (see p. 332).
Others may be established under the terms of the Science and Technology
Act. The Department also has, in consultation with other departments,
general governmental responsibility for Britain s scientific space research
programme, which is co-ordinated by the Science Research Council. The
Department is responsible for some aspects of international scientific relations
(see p. 334), and for Government policy regarding libraries and information
systems, including the Office for Scientific and Technical Information.
In the exercise of responsibilities for the formulation and execution of govern¬
ment scientific policy the Secretary of State for Education and Science is
advised by the Council for Scientific Policy (CSP), which replaced the former
Advisory Council on Scientific Policy. The Council, which was set up in
January 1965, consists of a chairman and 13 independent members. There are,
in addition, assessors from the research councils and from the University
Grants Committee. Among the issues with which the Council is concerned is
the balance of scientific effort in those areas for which the Secretary of State is
responsible. The CSP has conducted an enquiry into the present methods of
funding the research councils.
The Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) (see also p. 5b), which came
formally into being in 1970, took over responsibility for the United Kingdom
Atomic Energy Authority (AEA) (see p. 329) an<^ National Research
Development Corporation (see p. 334) and most of the non-aviation functions
of the former Ministry of Technology. The responsibilities of the DTI now
include that for civil aviation and the sponsorship of most industries (excluding
aircraft) in both the public and private sectors.
The DTI, among other things, has responsibility for engineering standards
and weights and measures for the British Standards Institution (see p. 211)
and for the Metrication Board set up in 1969 to facilitate the transition to the
metric system of weights and measures in Britain by 1975 (see P* 4^3)* ^ ^as
direct control of a number of research stations and establishments (see p. 32b) ">
it also aids with grants autonomous industrial research associations.
Besides its responsibility for defence research establishments (see p. 119),
some of which are mentioned below, the Ministry of Defence has resumed
responsibility for aviation supply for defence purposes (including research).
A number of other government departments remain responsible for certain
branches of research.
The Department of the Environment (see p. 51) *s concerned with research
and development relating to inland transport and ports. Research into road
construction, traffic flow, safety, transport systems and new transport tech¬
nology is carried out mainly at the Department s Road Research Laboratory
(see p. 301) at Crowthorne, Berkshire. There are also collaborative arrange¬
ments for research in inland transport with the DTI. Economic, technical
and operational research studies are carried out also in the headquarters of the
Department and some are commissioned from consultants and universities.
The Ministry of Defence is responsible for sponsoring research and devel¬
opment in aviation.

Research on radio aids for marine navigation is undertaken by the Ministry
of Defence, which is also responsible for inter-Service electronic valve research
at the Services Electronics Research Laboratory. Research on marine nuclear
propulsion is undertaken by the AEA. The Civil Aviation Research and
Development Board now responsible to the Department of Trade and Industry
was set up in February 1970 to co-ordinate research and development work for
civil aviation equipment other than aircraft and engines.
The Department of the Environment has a Directorate General of Research
and Development (see p. 235) and is responsible for the Building Research
Station, Garston, Watford, Hertfordshire, which is concerned with the
techniques of building design and construction, and the organisation, pro¬
ductivity and economics of building work.
The Department of the Environment sponsors certain geographical, geolo¬
gical, economic and sociological research relating to the use and development
of land in England. Similar arrangements are made in Scotland by the Scottish
Home and Health Department, in Wales by the Welsh Office, and in Northern
Ireland by the Ministry of Development. A Centre for Environmental Studies
has been set up as an independent educational trust for research into the
problems of urban planning and dealing with the effects of a fast-growing
mobile population. The Centre focuses attention on the economic and social
aspects of environmental subjects and its grant has been increased by the
Government.
A permanent Royal Commission on Environmental Pollution, was set up in
1970 to advise on matters both national and international concerning the
pollution of the environment; on the adequacy of research; and the future
possibilities of the danger to the environment. The Commission published its
first report in 1971 (see Bibliography p. 480). Research on pollution problems
is carried out in many different institutions, both public and private. Govern¬
ment departments with laboratories concerned with pollution include the
Department of the Environment (Water Pollution Research Laboratory and
Road Research Laboratory), the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food
(Fisheries Laboratories) and DTI (Warren Spring Laboratory which works on
air pollution, clearance of oil and recycling of waste). Research Councils,
especially the Medical and Natural Environment Research Councils, are also
involved in such research. The Department of the Environment has a small
central unit on environmental pollution to co-ordinate the work of all govern¬
ment departments on the control of environmental pollution, and to co¬
ordinate the British contribution to international discussions on the subject.
A Clean Air Council was set up in 1956 and an Advisory Council on Noise
in 1970.
The Department of Trade and Industry (see pp. 56 and 320) is responsible
for research into safety and health of mineworkers. The coal, electricity and
gas industries are required to settle their general programmes of research in
consultation with the Secretary of State, who is assisted by an Advisory
Council on Research and Development. Sir liar provisions apply to the British
Steel Corporation’s general programme ^ research and technological develop¬
ment.
The Ministry of Defence finances the Meteorological Office, which is respon¬
sible for research in meteorology and geophysics, mainly for civil purposes.
The headquarters of the Office and most of its research sections are at

Bracknell, Berkshire. The Ministry also makes grants for fundamental
meteorological research carried out under the auspices of the Royal Society
or in university departments.
The Post Office undertakes research and development on many aspects of the
science and engineering of communications, both in its own laboratories and
in close association with industry, the universities and government depart¬
ments. The main research station is at Dollis Hill, London, and there are
laboratories at Backwell, near Bristol, at Castleton, near Cardiff, and also at
Martlesham, near Ipswich, where a new research station is being built.
The Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew (founded in 1759), together with its 400-
acre estate at Wakehurst Place, Ardingly, Sussex, is administered by the
Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food and has the largest collection
of living plants in the world. Its research departments are: the herbarium,
concerned primarily with the classification and accurate determination of
plants; and the Jodrell Laboratory, for the study of plant anatomy and plant
physiology, cytology and genetics. There are two museums concerned mainly
with the economic exploitation of plants. The library, attached to the herbar¬
ium, was founded in 1852; it consists of more than 100,000 botanical books,
about 140,000 reprints and separately issued items and a collection of over
160,000 drawings and paintings of plants. The Royal Botanic Garden,
Edinburgh, founded about 1660, has, since April 1969, been administered by
the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries for Scotland.
A Select Committee of the House of Commons on Science and Technology
was set up in December 1966 and has been re-appointed in each subsequent
Parliamentary Session. It is one of the specialist committees established to give
back-bench Members the opportunity to investigate the policies and adminis¬
tration of the Government and to participate in the formation of policy. The
Members of the Committee (not more than 15 in number) are nominated by
the House. The Committee has power to call witnesses, generally takes
evidence in public, and reports its findings to the House from time to time.
The Parliamentary and Scientific Committee, founded in 1939, provides for a
regular exchange of information between members of Parliament and
scientists. Membership is open to members of Parliament of any party in both
Houses, and also to nominated representatives of such non-profit-making
scientific and technological organisations in Britain as may be affiliated under
its constitution.
Although today most research is conducted under other auspices, the learned
societies have retained their traditional function of facilitating the spread of
knowledge. At present there are over 200 of them in Britain with approxi¬
mately 400 scientific publications. The most eminent of those concerned with
science in its broadest aspects (as distinct from those societies with specialised
interests and activities) are the Royal Society, Royal Society of Arts, Royal
Institution and British Association.
The Royal Society, or, more fully, the Royal Society of London for the
Improvement of Natural Knowledge, founded in 1660, occupies a unique
place in the country’s scientific affairs and corresponds to national academies
of sciences in other countries. Election to it is regarded by scientists as a high
honour. The Queen is Patron. There are today three main categories of

Royal Society
of Arts
Royal

Fellowship: Royal Fellows, comprising the Queen Mother and three Royal
Dukes; Foreign Members, of whom there are about 70, and the main body of
Fellows numbering about 730. Election to the Fellowship, which is for life,
was for many years restricted to 25 persons a year and the foreign membership
to four a year but in 1965 the former was increased to 32 with the intention of
awarding some of the new places to applied scientists in both the physical and
biological sciences. The Society is governed by a council of 21 members.
Its activities include the holding of scientific meetings; publication of
research work, mainly in the Philosophical Transactions and the Proceedings’,
the presentation of medals; the giving of endowed lectures; and the award of
research appointments and grants. Among its research appointments are the
Foulerton, Wolfson and Sir Henry Dale Research Professorships and ten
other research professorships supported by parliamentary grant-in-aid. The
highest medal awarded is the Copley Medal, for which scientists from all
countries are eligible; there are also three Royal Medals, and the Rumford,
Darwin, Buchanan, Sylvester, Hughes, Leverhulme and Mullard Medals.
There are six lectureships: the Croonian (biology); the Bakerian (physical
sciences); the Ferrier (nervous system); the Wilkins (history of science); the
Leeuwenhoek (microbiology); and the Bernal (social functions of science).
The Society has set up committees, some of them jointly with other bodies, to
promote improvements in education in science and to emphasise the im¬
portance of applied sciences, especially engineering.
Although an independent private corporation, the Society has always had
a special relationship with the Government, which makes grants for certain of
its activities. The President of the Society is consulted on scientific appoint¬
ments to research councils and Fellows serve on most governmental advisory
councils and committees concerned with research.
The international relations of the Royal Society are extensive. It represents
the United Kingdom in the international unions comprising the International
Council of Scientific Unions and appoints national committees for each of
them. It also plays a leading part in international scientific programmes such
as the International Biological Programme (1965-70), and promotes exchange
visits of scientists with many academies throughout the world. Its Inter¬
national Fellowship Scheme to foster relations with scientists of Western
European and other countries receives financial support from the Government
and other sources.
The Royal Society of Arts (properly, the Royal Society for the Encouragement
of Arts, Manufactures and Commerce) has a character at once scientific,
artistic, technical, industrial and commercial. Since its foundation in 1754, one
of the Society’s principal objects has been to promote the progress and
application to useful ends of all departments of science. Today it fulfils this
purpose chiefly by disseminating new scientific knowledge. The Society
regularly holds lectures, and publishes a monthly Journal, thus providing
effective media for the exposition and assessment by leading authorities of
developments which have a public as well as a specialist interest.
The Royal Institution was founded in 1799 as a public body for facilitating
the introduction of useful mechanical inventions and improvements, and for
teaching the application of science to everyday life. Later it undertook the
‘promotion of chemical science by experiments and lectures for improving
arts and manufactures’, and ‘the diffusion and extension of useful knowledge’.
Its character, however, was largely determined by the work of Sir Humphry

BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Davy and Michael Faraday, who established a tradition of research. Today,
the Royal Institution has extensive research laboratories, and lectures are
given on recent developments in science and other branches of knowledge. Its
library includes many early scientific works and manuscripts.
The British Association for the Advancement of Science was founded in 1831
to promote general interest in science and its applications. One of its chief
activities is the Annual Meeting, attended by many young students as well as
by eminent scientists. In addition the Association plans special lectures,
exhibitions and discussions (some designed for young audiences), the publica¬
tion of pamphlets, the organisation of conferences, the appointment of study
groups and liaison with the Press and with sound and television broadcasting
services. The Association has area committees and three lectureships for
young scientists—the Kelvin, the Darwin and the Lister lectureships, dealing
respectively with the physical, biological and sociological sciences to en¬
courage scientists to make their activities known to wider audiences. The
British Association has an organised relationship with over 150 scientific
bodies and learned societies. It has also made an important contribution to the
development of science by taking or recommending action to remove obstacles
to the discovery and application of scientific knowledge.
There are numerous technical institutions and professional associations, many
of which are playing a distinguished part in promoting their own disciplines
or are interested in the education and professional well-being of their members.
The Council of Engineering Institutions, the federal body for the chartered
engineering institutions established in I9^5» promotes the co-ordination of the
engineering profession. The Council of Science and Technology Institutes
a federal body with five member institutes representing biologists, chemists,
mathematicians, metallurgists and physicists—was formed in 1969.
Of total estimated university expenditure on scientific research in the Academic
year 1969-70 (over £90 million), the largest government contribution (£60-2
million) was through the University Grants Committee (see p. 159)'
Scientific research in the universities is also supported through the research
councils. This support takes two forms. First, about half the postgraduate
students in science and technology in the universities receive maintenance
awards from the research councils, through postgraduate scholarships,
studentships or fellowships. These awards are in some cases for periods of up
to three years of training in research work and in others for shorter periods
for advanced studies. The cost of these awards is currently about £9-5 million
a year. Second, grants are given to the universities by the research councils
for specific projects, particularly in new or developing fields of research. In
recent years the research councils, in addition to making grants of this kind,
have made funds available for expensive items of university equipment
required for specific programmes of research. The research councils support
for research in the universities, excluding expenditure by the Medical
Research Council and the Agricultural Research Council on their own research
units within the universities (which remain under the control of, and are
wholly financed by, the councils), amounted in 1970-71 to ^29-8 million.
The other main channels of support for scientific research in the universities
are various government departments, the Royal Society, industry and the
independent foundations. The contributions from sources other than the
University Grants Committee amount to about a third of the total university
expenditure on research.

INDUSTRIAL
RESEARCH
Universities in industrial centres have tended to acquire outstanding
reputations in studies relating to their local industries, and on a national scale
close relationships are fostered between the universities, industries and the
Government in numerous joint projects. The DTI’s industrial liaison officers
(see p. 334) are based on universities or technical colleges. Seven Industrial
Units have been opened (six at universities and one at the College of Aero¬
nautics, Cranfield) under a Government scheme. They offer consultancy and
research and development resources and are expected to become self-support¬
ing within a few years.
According to estimates in a survey1 published in 1971 there were in 1968 just
over 400,000 persons with qualifications in engineering, technology and science
in Great Britain, of whom one-half were qualified in science and one-half in
engineering. Of those economically active (350,000), 53 per cent (185,000) held
engineering qualifications, 1-2 per cent (4,140) were out of employment, 35
per cent employed in manufacturing. Education employed over 20 per cent
and over the years 1959 to 1968 there was a rapid increase in the service
sectors (commerce and consultancy). Within manufacturing the largest in¬
crease was in electrical and electronics industries (6 per cent a year). Over the
period 1959 to 1968 there was a net gain of scientists from migration and a net
loss of engineers and technologists.
The Science Research Council (SRC), which came into formal existence in
1965 and consists of a chairman and up to 15 other members, covers all
branches of fundamental science other than those for which the other research
councils are responsible. It also supports research projects in the universities,
polytechnics and technical colleges. Provision is made for it to carry out
research and development through its own establishments; to encourage and
support similar research by any other person or body; to provide and operate
equipment for common use by universities, polytechnics, technical colleges
and similar institutions; to make grants for postgraduate studies; and to
disseminate knowledge of science and technology. Its establishments include
the Royal Greenwich Observatory, Herstmonceux, the Royal Observatory,
Edinburgh, the Radio and Space Research Station, the Rutherford High
Energy Laboratory, the Daresbury Nuclear Physics Laboratory, the Atlas
Computer Laboratory, and the Astrophysics Research Unit. The SRC also
co-ordinates the British scientific space research programme (see p. 330) and
provides the United Kingdom contribution to the European Organisation
for Nuclear Research (CERN) and the European Space Research Organisation
(ESRO) and the civil science programme of the North Atlantic Treaty
Organisation (NATO).
The greater part of industrial research in Britain is undertaken in the research
organisations of the larger firms and in government research establishments.
Research organisations in industry vary widely between the largest firms
employing thousands of qualified staff and some employing very few; though
the emphasis is on commercial development, some fundamental research is
done. Other main agencies are universities and technical colleges, industrial
research associations, independent institutes for sponsored research and con¬
sultant laboratories.

BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) has direct control of six
industrial research establishments. These are the National Engineering
Laboratory (which includes the Birniehill Institute), the National Physical
Laboratory, Warren Spring Laboratory, the Laboratory of the Government
Chemist, the Safety in Mines Research Establishment and Torrey Research
Station. The total net expenditure of the DTI for 1970-71 on these establish¬
ments was about £12 million.
Besides research and development for industry the industrial research
establishments are engaged on the application of techniques and discoveries
to design, production, quality control and distribution. The DTI also sponsors
research by grants-in-aid to research associations and by extra-mural contracts
with industry and universities.
On 1 st January 1971 some research stations of the former Ministry of
Technology were transferred to the Department of the Environment, namely,
the Water Pollution Research Laboratory, the Hydraulics Research Station,
the Forest Products Research Laboratory and the Fire Research Station.
The scheme by which the Government gives financial help to firms with
similar interests to form organisations known as research associations, to carry
out industrial research co-operatively, was started in 1917. There are now 32
such associations whose grants are administered by the DTI. In addition there
are four (Water; Construction; Heating and Ventilating; and Timber) whose
grants since 1st January 1971 have been administered by the Department of
the Environment, and four (Flour Milling and Baking; Fruit and Vegetable
Preservation; British Food Manufacturing Industries; and British Industrial
Biological Research Association) whose grants since 1st April 1971 have been
administered by the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food. Suitably
specialised associations are now available for about 50 per cent of British
industry. The largest are those dealing with production engineering, ships,
welding, electrical manufacturing, cotton and man-made fibres, non-ferrous
metals and scientific instruments. (Particulars of these and other associations
are given in Chapter 11, Industry.) The amounts of the government grants are
related to the contributions made by the industries concerned.
The research associations are autonomous bodies governed by their own
councils, the members of which are mostly representatives of industry,
although government departments are also represented. The councils are
advised in preparing research programmes, for which they have complete
responsibility, by research committees representative of their industrial
members, often with the addition of university or government scientists.
Nearly all research associations admit to membership manufacturers in
Commonwealth countries and many also admit those in foreign countries. A
Conference of Industrial Research Associations was set up in 1969. Govern¬
ment grants to research associations are being reduced so that each industry
bears an increasing proportion of the cost of its associations.
Some of the public corporations which run the nationalised industries have
their own research organisations (see Chapter 11), in particular those con¬
cerned with fuel and power, steel and transport. They also give support to
organisations concerned with research on matters of interest to them.
According to Economic Trends (November 1970), expenditure on research and
development carried out within private industry (excluding enterprises of less
PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES

MEDICAL
RESEARCH
Medical

Council
than 25 employees) in 1968-69 was ^601-9 million—an increase of 6 per cent
compared with the previous year. Expenditure in individual industries was as
follows (in £ million): aerospace 164-7; electronics 120-7; other electrical
engineering 32; petroleum products 11-9; other chemical products 79;
mechanical engineering 52-4; motor vehicles 43-7; scientific instruments 14-8;
food, drink and tobacco 18-8; textiles 11*7. For these groups the increase since
1966-67 was 3 per cent. These figures include funds from government sources.
Firms in science-based industries commit large private funds to research and
development in the course of business.
A number of institutes for sponsored research have been established to
extend the facilities for private research for industrial firms by studying
problems which are not within the scope of the average industrial laboratory.
In these institutes research for private firms is carried out confidentially, the
results remaining the property of the sponsor.
A Medical Research Committee was appointed in 1913 to administer the
research funds provided under the National Health Insurance Act 1911. In
1920 the Committee was superseded by the Medical Research Council
(MRC), established under Royal Charter and supported by a grant-in-aid
provided by Parliament, now through the Secretary of State for Education and
Science. The MRC was granted a new charter in 1966.
In addition to financing the MRC, the Government gives substantial
support to medical research through block grants to universities distributed
through the University Grants Committee; and to clinical research through
the National Health Service. Certain government-financed research for defence
purposes, for example, at the Microbiological Establishment at Porton,
Wiltshire, has civil applications related to medical science.
Important contributions to the support of research in particular subjects
are made by industry, especially the pharmaceutical industry, and by private
charities or voluntary organisations, such as the Nuffield Foundation and the
British Empire Cancer Campaign.
The Medical Research Council is responsible to the Secretary of State for
Education and Science and consists of a Chairman, a Deputy Chairman, and
from 10 to 14 other members. Not less than three-quarters must be scientific¬
ally qualified, representative of the different branches of medical knowledge
and actively engaged in research. All members are appointed by the Secretary
of State, the scientific members after consultation with the President of the
Royal Society and the existing Council; and the Chairman and Deputy Chair¬
man after consultation with the Council.
The MRC’s chief function is to promote research into all aspects of health
and disease. In planning and carrying out its research programme the Council
is assisted by bodies specially appointed to advise on particular subjects. Three
of the more important of these are the Clinical Research Board, set up in con¬
sultation with the health departments to assist the development of clinical
research; the Tropical Medicine Research Board, appointed in consultation
with the Overseas Development Administration, to advise on the promotion
and co-ordination of research in this field; and the Biological Research Board,
which advises on the promotion of research in the non-clinical field. In
addition, the MRC is advised by committees concerned with particular aspects
of its work. The MRC’s arrangements for the support of research fall under
four main headings: (1) investigations by members of its scientific staff, mostly
working in its own establishments; (2) short-term grants to workers in
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
universities and elsewhere; (3) long-term grants in support of specific research
programmes in university medical departments (‘programme grants’ and
‘research groups’); and (4) fellowships and scholarships tenable both at home
and abroad. The research undertaken ranges from basic biological research at
the molecular level and the extensive laboratory work that forms the scientific
basis of the practice of medicine to the study of patients and epidemiological
and population surveys carried out in the field.
The MRC’s main research establishments are the National Institute for
Medical Research, at Mill Hill and Hampstead, London, and the Clinical
Research Centre at Northwick Park in north-west London (the first patients
were admitted in 1970) which forms an integral part of the new district
hospital for the North West Metropolitan Regional Hospital Board. In
addition the Council has over 70 smaller establishments, known as research
units, which are in most cases located in university departments, medical
schools and hospitals in Britain.
The MRC also undertakes work overseas and, with additional support from
the Overseas Development Administration (see p. 335), maintains laboratories
in The Gambia and units in Uganda and Jamaica.
AGRICULTURAL
RESEARCH
Agricultural research is carried out by the Agricultural Research Council, the
government agricultural departments and by private industry.
Agricultural
Research
Council
Government
Agricultural
Departments
The Agricultural Research Council (ARC), established in 1931, consists of not
less than 15 and not more than 18 members, including the Chief Veterinary
Officer and certain appointments made by the Ministers of the agricultural
departments. In addition to distinguished scientists, the membership includes
people with practical farming experience. The ARC is under the general over¬
sight of the Secretary of State for Education and Science.
The ARC is responsible for 14 independent state-aided agricultural research
institutes and also has eight institutes under its direct control and 11 units
which it has established under distinguished scientists associated with
universities. Also there are eight independent institutes in Scotland financed
by the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries for Scotland with advice
from the ARC on their scientific programmes, staffing and equipment.
The ARC makes special research grants to support promising new lines of
work in university departments. It makes a limited number of postgraduate
training awards.
The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food does both applied and basic
research. At its Central Veterinary Laboratory at Weybridge, research and
laboratory investigations are carried out into the causes, pathology, epi-
zootiology and control of diseases of farm livestock, including poultry; the
diagnosis of animal and poultry diseases (other than foot-and-mouth disease);
and the making and supplying of certain biological products. The Laboratory
is, by appointment of the World Health Organisation (WHO), the third
international laboratory for biological standards. There is a related Ministry
Veterinary Laboratory at Lasswade, Midlothian. The Plant Pathology
Laboratory at Harpenden, Hertfordshire, is concerned with plant quarantine
matters, the standards for improved crop planting material, pest and disease
assessment work, the clearance of pesticides for safety and their official
approval for biological efficiency; while at its Pest Infestation Control
Laboratory at Tolworth, Surrey, and Slough, Buckinghamshire (with a field
station at Worplesdon), it co-ordinates work on the control of insect pests of
PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES
329
NUCLEAR
ENERGY
stored food and conducts research on the control of harmful mammals and
birds. In Scotland research work at East Craigs, Edinburgh, by the Agricul¬
tural Scientific Services of the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries is
mainly concerned with the problems of cultivar taxonomy, seed testing, healthy
seed potato production, plant pathology, and the ecology of birds, mammals
and insects harmful to agriculture and stored products. In Northern Ireland
the Ministry of Agriculture is responsible for the promotion of agricultural
research and has research divisions dealing with a variety of aspects.
The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food maintains five laboratories
for marine fisheries and shellfish research and two for salmon and freshwater
fisheries research. There are four marine research ships and several smaller
vessels for inshore and estuarine work. The Department of Agriculture and
Fisheries for Scotland maintains a marine research laboratory and six research
ships at Aberdeen, and a freshwater fisheries research laboratory at Pitlochry.
With the guidance of the Chief Scientific Adviser (Food), the Food
Standards and Science Division of the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and
Food is responsible for formulating the Ministry’s general policy on the
acquisition and dissemination of scientific and technical information about
food and the food handling and processing industry; for furnishing scientific
advice to the other divisions of the Ministry; and for sponsoring or carrying
out experimental work. The division has its own experimental laboratories in
London and Norwich: in addition, four food industrial research associations
are grant-aided by the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food.
The Forestry Commission undertakes experimental work relating to
silvicultural and allied problems (see p. 287). By means of grants, it also aids
forest research work undertaken by various universities and other institutions,
including the Commonwealth Forestry Institute, Oxford.
The United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority (AEA), set up under the
Atomic Energy Authority Act 1954, is responsible for research and develop¬
ment in nuclear energy. It is answerable to the Secretary of State for Trade
and Industry, who is responsible under the Atomic Energy Acts 1946, 1949
and 1971 for promoting and controlling the development of nuclear energy
and ensuring that the proper degrees of importance are attached to its various
applications. As an essential part of the British Government’s nuclear power
programme, the AEA has carried out research and developed new types of
nuclear power stations for the generation of electric power on a commercial
scale and for this purpose it builds and operates experimental and prototype
nuclear reactors. Construction of commercial nuclear power stations is carried
out by industry to the order of the electricity generating boards which operate
them. Under the Science and Technology Act 1965 the functions of the AEA
have been extended so that the Government may, after consultation, require
it to undertake research and development outside nuclear energy. Non-nuclear
work is absorbing a rising proportion of the AEA’s research resources and
includes research into desalination, hydrostatic extrusion, satellite design,
tribology, non-destructive testing, ceramics, atmospheric pollution, biomedical
technology and carbon fibres. Two new design and construction companies,
with AEA participation, to design and construct nuclear power stations were
formed in 1968 and 1969.
The Atomic Energy Authority Act 1971 provided for the transfer to two
new companies (British Nuclear Fuels Limited and the Radiochemical Centre
Limited) of the assets and liabilities of the UKAEA’s trading fund. The
establishments transferred to British Nuclear Fuels Limited include those at

High Energy
Physics
SPACE
ACTIVITIES
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Springfields, Capenhurst, Chapelcross and the Windscale and Calder Works.
Those transferred to Radiochemical Centre Limited include the Radio¬
chemical Centre, Amersham, and its facilities at Harwell.
The Secretary of State for Defence became responsible for the development
and production of nuclear weapons for the Services in 1966; in practice,
however, the AEA produces the explosive nuclear material and assemblies for
nuclear weapons under contract and carries out weapons research.
A national Radiological Protection Board has been set up under the
Radiological Protection Act 1970, which amalgamates the former Radiological
Protection Service, part of the AEA’s Central Health and Safety Branch and
the former Radioactive Substances Advisory Committee. The Board is funded
by the Secretaries of State for Social Services and for Scotland, the AEA and
the Medical Research Council. Expert advice on radiation hazards is provided
by the Medical and Agricultural Research Councils.
The Department of Trade and Industry and the AEA are jointly responsible
for co-operation with other countries in nuclear energy, partly through the
medium of bilateral agreements with a large number of individual countries
and partly through British membership of bodies such as the International
Atomic Energy Agency and the European Nuclear Energy Agency.
The provision of facilities for research in high energy physics is the function
of the Science Research Council (see p. 325). The Science Research Council
(SRC) establishments concerned are the Rutherford High Energy Laboratory,
Chilton, with a 7 GeV (thousand million electron volt) proton synchrotron
(particle accelerator), completed in 1963, and the Daresbury Nuclear Physics
Laboratory, Cheshire, with a 5 GeV electron synchrotron, completed in 1966.
Experiments at higher energies are carried out at the European Organisation
for Nuclear Research (CERN) to which the United Kingdom contributes
through the SRC.
Government responsibility for space activities is divided between the Secretary
of State for Education and Science, the Secretary of State for Defence, the
Secretary of State for Trade and Industry and the Minister of Posts and
Telecommunications. Total expenditure on space activities in 1969-70 was
about ^28 million; of this, over ^14 million represented contributions to
international bodies. Of these bodies two were set up to give European
countries the opportunity of participating more fully in space research and
technology. The European Space Vehicle Launcher Development Organisa¬
tion (ELDO) was established to develop large satellite launchers; the British
Blue Streak has been used as the launching vehicle for ELDO’s Europa
rockets.
The Government announced in 1968 that it could not undertake additional
financial commitment to ELDO. The European Space Research Organisation
(ESRO) was founded to provide facilities for scientific experiments in space;
it has a programme of launchings of sounding rockets and satellites of various
sizes. Britain and 78 other countries participate in Intelsat (the International
Telecommunications Satellite Consortium), set up under two inter-related
international agreements reached in 1964 in Washington. New definitive
arrangements for Intelsat, reached in May 1971, were opened for signature in
August 1971 and have been signed by some two-thirds of members.
The execution of the civil scientific space research programme is the
responsibility of the Secretary of State for Education and Science, through
PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES
331
the Science Research Council. It provides opportunities for research workers
to carry out experiments in satellites and sounding rockets both in the United
Kingdom national programme and through bilateral and multilateral arrange¬
ments with other countries.
Scientific space experiments are arranged by scientists in the universities
and in government research establishments; the programme is under the
general supervision of the Space Research Management Unit of the SRC.
In addition to participating in ESRO activities Britain is co-operating with
the United States in a programme which includes the launching of the Ariel
series of satellites and the incorporation of British experiments in US satellites
and the analyses of lunar surface samples. Sounding rocket programmes are
also undertaken in collaboration with other Commonwealth countries.
The Ministry of Defence provides technical advice and support in relation
to the space research programme and space applications work; it is responsible
for executing satellite and sounding rocket programmes for customer Depart¬
ments and for the development of the space technology required in support of
current and future programmes. The Ministry’s National Space Technology
Programme includes the development of experimental satellites and a launch
vehicle {Black Arrow). The Ministry of Defence leads the UK delegations to
the European Space Conference and also provides the UK representatives and
contributions to ELDO.
The Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications, through the Post Office, is
responsible for the use of satellites for civil communications purposes and
undertakes research work in connection with communications systems using
satellites. The Post Office ground stations at Goonhilly in Cornwall are among
the most successful in the world, and British firms have built and are building
such stations overseas.
The DTI is responsible for civil aerospace policy and for the use of satellites
for the control of civil air and marine traffic.
The Radio and Space Research Station of the SRC operates the United
States National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) Satellite
Tracking and Data Acquisition Network (STADAN) station at Winkfield.
Optical tracking of satellites is undertaken by many individual observers in
Britain and by the Royal Edinburgh Observatory’s outstation (see below); the
prediction and co-ordination centre for this activity is at the Radio and Space
Research Station, Slough, which is also the home of one of the three World
Data Centres for space research.
The Royal Society represents Britain in non-governmental international
scientific groups such as the Committee on Space Research (COSPAR) of the
International Council of Scientific Unions (ICSU).
OPTICAL AND
RADIO
ASTRONOMY
Optical astronomy is carried out with Science Research Council (SRC)
support in a number of universities and at the two Royal Observatories. The
Royal Greenwich Observatory, Herstmonceux, is equipped with the 98-inch
Isaac Newton Telescope; British astronomers have access to the 74-inch
Radcliffe Observatory in South Africa. The Royal Observatory, Edinburgh,
has developed modern instrumentation, including the Galaxy measuring
machine. The SRC is building a 150-inch telescope as a joint venture between
Britain and Australia, and a 48-inch Schmidt telescope, in New South Wales.
Radio astronomy is carried out mainly at two universities, Manchester and
Cambridge. The 250-foot Mark 1 radio telescope (Manchester) is being
modernised, and a new 5km radio telescope using the techniques (evolved at
Cambridge) of aperture synthesis is under construction, at Cambridge.

BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Natural Environment Research Council (NERC) was established by
Royal Charter in 1965 under the Science and Technology Act 1965 to en¬
courage, plan and conduct research in those sciences, both physical and
biological, that relate to man’s natural environment. The work of the NERC
falls into five main groups: the solid earth, its physical properties and mineral
resources (geology, geophysics and geochemistry); the inland waters and their
living resources (hydrology, freshwater biology, ecology and fisheries); the
terrestrial communities, their resources and amenities (terrestrial ecology,
forestry and conservation); the seas and oceans, their behaviour and their
living and mineral resources (oceanography, marine biology and ecology); and
the atmosphere (some aspects of meteorology). The Nature Conservancy
forms part of the NERC which is also responsible for the British Antarctic
Survey, the Institute of Geological Sciences, the Institute of Hydrology, the
Institute of Tree Biology, the Institute of Marine Environmental Research,
the National Institute of Oceanography, the Institute of Coastal Oceanography
and Tides, the Unit of Coastal Sedimentation, the Culture Centre of Algae
and Protozoa and the Research Vessel Unit. It is also responsible for support¬
ing the Marine Biological Association, the Scottish Marine Biological Associa¬
tion, the Freshwater Biological Association, the Fisheries Helminthology Unit
and the Marine Invertebrate Biology Unit, the Fisheries Biochemical Research
Unit and the Insect Pathology Unit.
Many of the activities of the NERC are related to university research in the
environmental sciences, which it supports by postgraduate training awards,
research grants and fellowships.
The Social Science Research Council (SSRC) was set up in December 1965,
to encourage support and to carry out research in, and to disseminate know¬
ledge about, the social sciences. It provides grants for research projects at
universities and other institutions, and makes training awards to postgraduate
students. It has also set up three research units: the Industrial Relations
RU, the Race Relations RU and the Survey Unit. The SSRC’s fields of
interest include economics; political science; psychology; social anthropology;
social and economic statistics; sociology and social administration; social
science and government; education; management and industrial relations;
human geography; planning and various aspects of a wide range of other
disciplines.
Several government departments have funds allocated for social research
related to their responsibilities, including the Home Office, which has a large
research unit which carries out a wide variety of sociological studies. The
Social Survey conducts sample survey enquiries at the request of government
departments and from time to time also carries out studies in collaboration
with universities and other independent research organisations.
Zoological research is among the activities of the world-famous Zoological
Gardens, extending over 34 acres in Regent’s Park, London, which were
opened by the Zoological Society of London in 1828. A natural zoo of 500
acres was opened in 1931 at Whipsnade, in Bedfordshire, by the Society.
Among other well-known zoos are those at Edinburgh, Bristol, Chester and
Dudley, and a small, private one at Chessington, Surrey. There is also an
increasing number of ‘Safari parks’ containing reservations of wild animals
through which the public can pass in closed motor cars.
The British Museum (Natural History) is the principal centre in the Common¬
wealth for the general study of natural history; it has extensive collections of
PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES
DISSEMINATION
AND APPLICA¬
TION OF
RESULTS OF
RESEARCH
Information
Services
333
extant and fossil animals and plants and of minerals, rocks and meteorites. The
Science Museum illustrates the development of pure and applied science in all
countries, but chiefly in Britain, which has always held a leading place in
engineering, agriculture, navigation, mining, aeronautics, and in the develop¬
ment of industrial machinery and processes. The geology of Britain is probably
known in more exact detail than that of any other country in the world, and
the Geological Survey has an outstanding collection of exhibits in its Geological
Museum. These three museums are in South Kensington, London. Other
important collections are those of the Museum of Science and Industry, in
Birmingham, and the Museum of the History of Science, at Oxford.
The dissemination of the results of research to other research workers and
to ultimate users has become a problem of some magnitude as the volume of
information has grown. The traditional method of scientific publication, in
which results are written up into papers and published in journals, is still
the main means of communication among scientists. The leading learned
societies have for long been important agencies for communicating scientific
information.
The Office for Scientific and Technical Information (OSTI) was set up in the
Department of Education and Science in 1965 to promote research; develop
new techniques and systems; improve existing services and experiment with
new ones; to stimulate training of scientists for information work and in the
use of information sources; and help to co-ordinate information activities at
home and overseas.
The National Lending Library for Science and Technology (NLL) at
Boston Spa, Yorkshire, also within the Department, aims to collect for loan
purposes all literature which is likely to be of interest to the practising
scientist and technologist, covering all branches of science and technology
(including agriculture and medicine) and, since 1967, the periodical literature
of the social sciences. Besides collecting all available translations of Russian
scientific literature the library is responsible for arranging the translation of
some Russian periodicals, books and articles. Details are published monthly
in the NLL Announcement Bulletin. The Library acts as a centre for
MEDLARS, a computerised medical literature search service, produced by
the US National Library of Medicine. (A description of general library ser¬
vices which also cater for scientific needs is given on p. 425.)
Aslib, representing special libraries and information units in industry,
government departments, universities, colleges and other institutions, carries
out research into the collection, utilisation and dissemination of information,
provides consultancy and advisory services and training courses and offers
members an enquiry and reference service covering all subjects. Publications
include directories to sources of information, research reports, handbooks and
monographs on information science. It also operates the Commonwealth Index
to Unpublished Translations.
The National Reference Library of Science and Invention, administered
by the British Museum, is at present divided between two separately housed
divisions. The Holborn Division, formerly the Patent Office Library, is one
of the great scientific libraries of the world. The Bayswater Division has sub¬
stantial collections, especially in the life sciences.
An Advisory Committee for Scientific and Technical Information was set
up in October 1965 to advise the Secretary of State for Education and Science
particularly in relation to the work of OSTI and the co-ordination of this

BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
work with other government departments and independent organisations.
The Department of Trade and Industry and the AEA devote considerable
sums to advisory information services. The former has nine regional offices
and sponsors over 70 industrial liaison centres, based on universities or
technical colleges which make contacts with local industries to promote greater
use of existing scientific and technical knowledge. A Production Engineering
Advisory Service equipped with mobile demonstration units brings knowledge
of new techniques directly to the workshop floor. The grant-aided industrial
research associations circulate research reports and provide information
services to members. Besides information services provided by its various
groups, which include the Ceramics Centre and the Non-destructive Testing
Centre at Harwell, the AEA has an information centre at its London head¬
quarters, and a network of regional advisers on the use of radioisotopes.
In agriculture, the Commonwealth Agricultural Institutes and Bureaux (see
p. 335) provide abstracts and an information service in various branches of
agricultural science. The ARC publishes an Index of Agricultural Research
in Progress, and gives an account of current developments in its annual reports.
The advisory services of the agricultural departments bring research results
directly to the farmer.
Medical research results are communicated mainly through journals and
periodicals; but the MRC issues special reports and includes special articles
in its annual reports.
The National Research Development Corporation (NRDC) is an independent
public corporation financed by Government loans through the DTI. Set up
under the Development of Inventions Act 1948 its borrowing power, origin¬
ally £5 million, has been progressively increased to £50 million.
The NRDC’s functions are to promote the adoption by industry of new
products and processes invented in Government laboratories, universities, and
elsewhere, advancing money where necessary to bring them to a commercially
viable stage; and to speed up technological advance by investing money with
industrial firms for the development of their own inventions and projects.
Projects so far sponsored include the Cephalosporin C antibiotic, hovercraft,
computers, advanced types of electric motor, diesel engines, insecticides,
microelectronics and fuel cells.
Inter-governmental organisations involved in scientific co-operation with
which the Government is concerned include: specialised agencies of the United
Nations, for example, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural
Organisation (UNESCO), the World Health Organisation (WHO), the Food
and Agriculture Organisation (FAO); nuclear energy, for example, the Inter¬
national Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), the European Nuclear Energy
Agency (ENEA) and the European Organisation for Nuclear Research
(CERN); space research, for example, ESRO; and the International Agency
for Research on Cancer (IARC). There are agreements between the United
Kingdom AEA and other atomic energy authorities, including that of the
Soviet Union (and there are permanent representatives of the United States
Atomic Energy Commission in London and of the United Kingdom AEA in
Washington). Also, there are inter-governmental agreements with Euratom,
and bilateral agreements with other countries. Britain is also represented on the
three scientific committees of the OECD. In areas of non-governmental
collaboration, the primary representative of the United Kingdom is the Royal
Society.

The Commonwealth Scientific Committee (CSC) consisting of the heads of
the national research organisations of Commonwealth countries, formed in
1958 from the previous Standing Committee set up in 1946, meets biennially.
Operating under the CSC is a consultative sub-committee, membership of
which consists of officials responsible for scientific matters in the Common¬
wealth Missions in London, and representatives from British Government
departments, the research councils and the Royal Society. There are various
specialist committees. The secretariat for the Committee and its executive
sub-committee is provided by the Commonwealth Scientific Liaison Offices.
A British Commonwealth Scientific Conference held in 1946 recommended
the continuance and extension of the scientific collaboration of the war years
by the creation of the Commonwealth Scientific Liaison Offices, a group at
present consisting of the Scientific Liaison Offices in London of Australia,
Canada and New Zealand together with the International Scientific Relations
Division of the Department of Education and Science.
The Commonwealth Agricultural Bureaux, financed by contributions from
all Commonwealth countries, comprise three Institutes and twelve Bureaux, all
of which except one Institute are in Britain and each of which is concerned
with a particular branch of agricultural science. They act as clearing houses
for the interchange of information of value to research workers in agricultural
science throughout the Commonwealth and increasingly throughout the world.
Seventeen Abstract Journals, one Primary Journal and an Index are published
periodically and have a combined annual circulation of about 29,000 copies.
The Institutes and Bureaux also issue monographs on their own particular
subjects and deal with enquiries received from research workers in all parts
of the Commonwealth.
The promotion by the Overseas Development Administration (ODA) of the
Foreign and Commonwealth Office of scientific research in the interests of
developing countries covers specialist advice from Britain, advisory visits, con¬
ferences for exchange of information, training scientists from overseas in
universities and research institutions in Britain, recruiting scientific staff from
Britain, and providing support for existing research services and research
projects overseas, for example, in East Africa and the Caribbean. Some equip¬
ment is also given to encourage scientific training and applied research. The
Anti-Locust Research Centre in London, internationally recognised as a world
centre for locust research since 1931, is part of ODA and so is the Tropical
Products Institute in London, which aims at improving the economic viability
of the less-developed tropical countries, especially those within the Common¬
wealth, by research into new uses for tropical plant and animal products. The
ODA provides over £4-5 million a year for research for the benefit of developing
countries.
The principal aims of the British Council (see p. 164) in the sciences (including
agriculture, medicine and technology) are to foster co-operation between
British scientists and scientists of other countries, to promote among overseas
specialists a better understanding and knowledge of Britain and its scientific
achievements, and, in the developing countries, to assist in curriculum reform
at school level and in the training of teachers of science and mathematics.
Overseas, a staff of 41 with science or science teaching qualifications, assist
in scientific and educational development and in scientific collaboration.

Emphasis is placed on facilitating the interchange of scientists and teachers
and on the provision of library and information services related to advances in
science and science education in Britain. Overseas tours are arranged for
British specialists to advise, run courses or discuss matters of common interest,
and scientists are recruited or seconded to posts in overseas universities, teacher¬
training colleges, education authorities, schools or curriculum reform centres.
The Council invites senior overseas specialists to Britain, and makes awards
to postgraduate students; it also administers the programmes of a large number
of senior specialists and students who travel to Britain under the auspices of
the UN specialised agencies, or under various bilateral technical assistance
schemes, or as private individuals. The Council is also responsible for ad¬

In Britain, advisory and information retrieval facilities are provided by
