15 FINANCE
PUBLIC FINANCE
Public finance is concerned with the way public authorities (central Govern¬
ment, local authorities, nationalised industries and other public corporations)
finance their activities—how their expenditure is decided upon and how their
revenue is obtained.
Money administered by public authorities1 can be roughly divided into:
1. The funds of the Government raised mainly by taxation which are paid
into and out of the Consolidated Fund in accordance with the proposals of
the Government as approved by Parliament (principally the House of
Commons); and the Government funds raised by borrowing and paid into
the National Loans Fund set up under the National Loans Act 1968. Prior
to April 1968 the funds from both these sources were paid into the Ex¬
chequer. (The term ‘Exchequer’ comes from the ‘chess-board’, or table with
chequered cloth, round which the King’s financial officials sat for accounting
purposes in the twelfth century.)
There are also funds administered for special purposes by government
departments and wholly or partially maintained by receipts which do not
pass through the Consolidated Fund. The most important one is the
National Insurance Fund, administered by the Secretary of State for Social
Services and used for the payment of benefits under the National Insurance
Scheme.
2. The funds of local authorities, obtained from: rates (local taxes on dwelling-
houses and other real estate) and income from property and trading receipts;
grants and loans from the Government; and loans raised in the open market
(see p. 73).
3. Funds for the investment programmes of nationalised industries and other
public corporations. Such finance of their capital expenditure programmes
as cannot be met from internal sources is mainly provided in the form of
loans from the National Loans Fund, bank advances being used to cover
seasonal and other short-term fluctuations in working capital.
The following broad account of government finance is concerned mainly
with government taxation and borrowing, and only incidentally with local
government and other public funds.
Financial control, as exercised by the House of Commons, is based on law,
parliamentary rights and custom.
As the power of Parliament grew in late medieval and Tudor times, the
principle that taxation by the Crown required parliamentary consent was
gradually evolved. The principle was established at the end of the constitu¬
tional struggles of the Stuart period by the Bill of Rights 1689.
In medieval, Tudor and Stuart times, it is broadly true to say that once the
king was granted the right to raise a given sum by taxation, he was free to
spend it as he chose. In the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, the House of
Commons gradually developed the modern system of controlling expenditure
1 For an account of public finance in Northern Ireland and its relationship to that of the
United Kingdom, see p. 348.
338
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
through the device of Appropriation which was embodied in the Exchequer
and Audit Departments Act 1866. But by a Standing Order of the House of
Commons dating from the early eighteenth century the Crown’s consent is
required for all proposals involving new spending from the Consolidated Fund.
The House of Commons cannot, therefore, initiate expenditure, which must be
proposed by a Minister.
From the very early days of Parliament it was established that such financial
control as Parliament possessed should be exercised by the House of Com¬
mons. This control of taxation existed in the seventeenth century, but control
of expenditure was not effective until the nineteenth century. The controlling
power of the House of Commons is acknowledged today in the Speech from
the Throne at the opening of a new session of Parliament, which is addressed
to both Houses but contains a special paragraph on expenditure addressed to
the Commons alone.
The Commons have traditionally claimed that the Lords have no power to
modify financial provisions, though they may reject such provisions; thus, to
minimise the chance of rejection, the practice was started in 1861 of embodying
the main financial provisions for the ensuing year in a single Bill. Since the
passing of the Parliament Act 1911, however, if the Finance Bill is certified by
the Speaker to be a Money Bill, it may be presented to the Queen for the Royal
Assent and become law without the consent of the House of Lords if it has
not been passed by them within one month (see p. 38).
Today, the authority of the House of Commons has to be obtained for all
expenditure by the Government itself and for the raising of revenue by
taxation or borrowing. All government revenue, other than the proceeds of
borrowing and sums received by government departments in the course of
their normal activities (known as appropriations-in-aid), is paid into an account
with the Bank of England (known as ‘The Account of Her Majesty’s Ex¬
chequer’) which forms the Consolidated Fund. With certain exceptions (the
main ones being the service of the national debt, government loans and national
insurance benefits), all payments by the Government come out of this account.
The following sections outline the machinery by which expenditure and
revenue are authorised and controlled, the purposes on which public money
is spent and the sources from which revenue is obtained.
ESTIMATES AND
EXPENDITURE
Classification of
Expenditure
Central government expenditure falls into three main categories:
1. The largest part of government expenditure which is authorised by annual
Appropriation Acts and includes expenditure on the general administration
of the country, defence and on the social services. These are called the
Supply Services because the House of Commons, when voting money, is
granting to the Crown ‘such aids or supplies as are required to satisfy . . .
the pecuniary necessities of the Government’. It should be noted that some
of this expenditure may also depend on legislation, such as the National
Health Service Acts, which relates to a specific object of expenditure.
2. Expenditure which is specifically authorised by Acts of Parliament other
than annual Appropriation Acts. There are the Consolidated Fund Standing
Services which represent a direct charge on the Consolidated Fund, cover¬
ing: the residual cost of servicing the National Debt,1 the financial provision
1 The servicing of the National Debt is charged in the first instance to the National
Loans Fund. After taking account of certain receipts by the Fund, including interest
received on loans to nationalised industries and local authorities and the profits or the
Issue Department of the Bank of England, the residue is charged to the Consolidated
Fund.
FINANCE
339
Authorisation
of Expenditure
Scrutiny of
Expenditure
The Treasury
made for members of the royal family, and salaries and pensions of judges
and certain high officers, such as the Speaker of the House of Commons
and the Parliamentary Commissioner, whose independence of the Govern¬
ment is thought to be better guaranteed by permanent grant than by annual
vote. This group also includes expenditure from the National Insurance
Fund and similar special funds.
3. Government lending and service of debt, which under the National Loans
Act 1968 are channelled through the National Loans Fund. These transac¬
tions include most of the Government’s domestic lending to the nationalised
industries, local authorities and public corporations, principal repayments
of the Government’s own borrowing and the payment of interest and other
charges arising from the National Debt.
The Estimates for the Supply Services are considered by the House of
Commons during the 29 days (known as Supply days) which are allotted by
Standing Order of the House to consideration of Supply business in each
session. The choice of subject for debate on these days rests with the Opposi¬
tion. The House usually discusses general questions of policy relevant to the
Estimates, though any Estimate may be examined in detail if members wish
and if time allows (see p. 40).
Estimates for Supply Services in the financial year beginning on 1st April
are submitted to the Treasury by each department in the preceding December.
Estimated expenditure is grouped under main headings called ‘Votes’ which
are further broken down into subheads and items. If the House of Commons
approves the Estimates, the sums asked for are voted and later confirmed in
the Appropriation Act; this Act appropriates the money to specific Votes. No
department may spend money granted on one Vote for the purposes of another.
Within each Vote the spending of money on one subhead instead of on another
(virement) is permissible so far as Parliament is concerned, but only with
Treasury consent.
An insufficient Estimate, or a new service not covered by the Vote, or
virement of a magnitude or character which the Treasury considers should be
brought to the attention of Parliament, requires a Supplementary Estimate.
The Treasury exercises the same power of scrutiny over this as over the
ordinary Estimates.
Control of expenditure is maintained by the Treasury, by the Comptroller
and Auditor General, and by the Public Accounts and Expenditure Committees
of the House of Commons.
The power of the Treasury to control expenditure derives from the responsi¬
bility of the Chancellor of the Exchequer for financial policy.
A central function of the Treasury is to present the Estimates to the House
of Commons. In considering the Estimates submitted by departments, the
Treasury has to examine the proposals for expenditure in relation to the results
of the public expenditure surveys and to eliminate any overlapping or un¬
economic expenditure that may have escaped the net of departmental financial
control. Apart from the scrutiny of Estimates, the Treasury exercises through¬
out the year general supervision of all departmental expenditure. The Treasury
also lays down general rules of financial and accounting procedure for de¬
partments and prescribes the principles on which departmental contracts shall
be made.
In 1961 the Plowden Committee on the Control of Public Expenditure
BRITAIN I972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
recommended in its report {Cmnd. 1432) that regular surveys should be made
of public expenditure in relation to prospective resources, and that decisions
involving future expenditure should be taken in the light of these surveys.
Surveys, therefore, are now made annually and have become an established
part of government procedure for the planning and control of public expendi¬
ture. Proposals for changes in the presentation and the procedures for con¬
sideration by Parliament of public expenditure estimates were published in
April 1969. These proposals were embodied in a White Paper on public
expenditure published in December 1969. The second in the series was
published in January 1971 {Public Expenditure 1969-JO to 1974-75).
These White Papers cover all public expenditure—the capital and current
expenditure of central and local government and the capital expenditure of the
nationalised industries and other public corporations. That of January 1971
gave expression to the Government’s policy that expenditure on public services
should grow at an annual average rate of 2-6 per cent. This rate is less than the
rates estimated in the previous White Paper (3 per cent for 1968-69 to 1971-72
and provisionally 3-5 per cent in 1972-73 and 1973-74) and rather less than
the rate of increase in productive potential in recent years.
Control over issues of money to departments and the audit of accounts is
exercised by the Comptroller and Auditor General, which is a permanent
Crown appointment. Since 1866 he has had two functions: as Comptroller he
controls receipts and issues of public money to and from the Consolidated
Fund and the National Loans Fund, and as Auditor General he audits
departmental accounts and submits his report on the Appropriation Accounts
and other accounts, as required by statute, to Parliament. His statutory
function is to ensure that all expenditure is properly incurred, for example,
that no payments are made which go beyond any relevant statutory authority,
and that Treasury sanction has been obtained wherever necessary. In addition,
however, he has been encouraged by successive Public Accounts Committees
to examine departmental expenditure with a view to drawing attention to any
cases of apparent waste or extravagance.
The Public Accounts The accounts of each department and the reports on the accounts made by
Committee the Comptroller and Auditor General are considered by a select committee
called the Public Accounts Committee. This was first set up in 1861, on the
motion of Mr. Gladstone, for the purpose of ensuring that expenditure was
properly incurred in accordance with the purpose for which it was voted and
with any relevant Acts of Parliament. The terms of reference of the committee
are to examine the accounts and these terms have been widely interpreted by
successive committees which have investigated whether full value has been
obtained for the sums spent by departments and have examined cases in which
the administration appears to have been faulty or negligent. The committee
has therefore become a powerful instrument for the exposure of waste and
inefficiency. It embodies its findings in reports which may be debated in the
House of Commons. Its recommendations are considered by the Treasury in
consultation with departments and put into effect, so far as they are accepted,
according to Treasury instructions. A reply to each report is submitted by the
Treasury to the committee of the following session and where the recommen¬
dations have been unacceptable to the Treasury the committee may either ac¬
cept the objections or return to the charge in subsequent reports.

THE BUDGET
The Committee’s functions are to consider any papers on public expendi¬
ture presented to the House of Commons and such of the estimates as may
seem appropriate to the committee. In particular it is to consider how, if at
all, the policies implied in the figures of expenditure and in the estimates may
be carried out more economically, and to examine the form of papers and of
the estimates presented to the Commons. In discharging its responsibilities it
can send for persons, papers and records, sit notwithstanding any adjournment
of the House, appoint people with technical knowledge either to supply
information which is not readily available or to elucidate matters of complexity
within its terms of reference. It can appoint sub-committees to assist it in its
work and unless the committee orders otherwise the public are admitted to its
meetings.
The sub-committees appointed by the Expenditure Committee are, in ad¬
dition to a steering sub-committee: Public Expenditure (General); Trade and
Industry; Employment and Social Services; Defence and External Affairs;
Education and Arts; and Environment and Home Office. Each has eight
members, including the chairman. According to the special report of the
Expenditure Committee, the titles of the sub-committees are not intended to
be restrictive, but are indicative of the general area of administration assigned
to each. Their work has involved, in the first instance, acquainting themselves
with the general practices of financial control and budgeting which are current
in the various government departments and the relevant policy decisions.
The Public Expenditure (General) Sub-Committee concerns itself mainly
with studying the central area of government financial control at Treasury
and Cabinet levels, and within the Civil Service Department. In this connec¬
tion it takes note of financial techniques employed outside government and
outside the United Kingdom.
‘Budget’ is an old word meaning a bag containing papers or accounts. The
use of the word in public finance originated in the expression ‘The Chancellor
of the Exchequer opened his Budget’, which is applied in Parliament to the
annual speech of the Chancellor of the Exchequer explaining his proposals for
raising revenue.
The annual Budget speech is normally the main occasion of the year for
reviewing the central Government’s finances and the economic state of the
nation, and its formal basis is the Chancellor’s proposals for raising money by
taxation. In recent years it has become the practice for Chancellors to discuss
in the Budget speech the future prospects for the economy in some detail. By
the time the Budget is introduced usually in April, the Estimates of expenditure
under various headings will have been presented to Parliament and published,
and the expected total of government expenditure for the year will be known.
The Chancellor estimates the yield of the revenue on the basis of existing
taxation and proposes such changes in taxation as he considers desirable on
economic grounds. These proposals are later embodied in detail in a Finance
Bill. The interval between the Budget Statement and the Royal Assent to the
Finance Bill (usually given in July) is covered by legislation (mainly the Pro¬
visional Collection of Taxes Act 1968), whereby changes in income tax, cor¬
poration tax, purchase tax, selective employment tax and customs and excise
duties have statutory effect before the passing of the Finance Bill if adopted by
Resolution of the House of Commons.
Details of the Government lending for the years 1968-69 to 1971-72 were
given in a White Paper, Loans from the National Loan Fund 19JI-J2, issued on
Budget day. For 1971-72 it is estimated that nearly half of the net lending from
342
Budget Policy
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
this Fund would be loans to nationalised industries; more than 40 per cent
would be loans to local and harbour authorities; and the remainder loans to
other public corporations, the private sector, and certain advances within the
central Government.
The original purpose of the Budget was purely financial—to provide money
for government expenditure. From an early stage, however, it was appreciated
that taxation affected the distribution of income and property and the level of
expenditure on particular goods and services. At a later period it was realised
that taxation also affected the nation’s total expenditure and therefore the
general level of economic activity. Since the second world war, Budgets have
been designed to relate the total demand for goods and services to total
national output.
The Budget affects the general level of expenditure and, therefore, the total
demand for goods and services in the following way: if there is an increase in
government expenditure without an increase in taxation then total demand for
goods and services will tend to rise; the same thing will happen if there is a
decrease in taxation without a decrease in government spending. On the other
hand, if there is an increase in taxation without an increase in government
expenditure, or a decrease in government expenditure without a decrease in
taxation then the total demand for goods and services will tend to fall. In this
way the Budget may be used to produce changes in the economy which the
Chancellor judges to be desirable in the light of the developing economic
situation.
The main objectives of British budgetary policy in recent years have been
to maintain a strong balance of payments and to guide the economy into in¬
creasing growth. With these objectives in view successive governments have
adopted a more flexible attitude towards fiscal policy and have not hesitated to
use budgetary measures between annual Budgets. In October 1970 the Chan¬
cellor of the Exchequer announced a wide range of measures to implement the
Government’s new policies for public spending. These measures included a
cut of 2-5 per cent in corporation tax and a cut from 41 -25 per cent to 38-75 per
cent, effective on 6th April i97I> standard rate of income tax.
The 1971 Budget heralded far-reaching changes in the structure of personal
taxation and in taxes on expenditure. The changes will constitute the most
comprehensive reform of the British tax system in this century. The present
system of income tax and surtax will be replaced by a single graduated personal
tax. Company taxation will be reformed so as to remove the discrimination
against distributed profits. As from April 1973 it is intended that both selective
employment tax (SET) and purchase tax will be abolished and that a value-
added tax (VAT) will become operative. The measures having more immediate
effect included proposals for reducing taxation by about £680 million in a full
year, with the intention of raising the rate of expansion of output to the rate of
growth of Britain’s productive potential. The principal measures included the
halving of SET, which became effective on 6th July 1971, a further reduction
of 2 • 5 per cent in the rate of corporation tax to 40 per cent and an increase of £40
in child allowances. Full details of the Budget proposals, and their economic
and financial background, were published in the Financial Stateme?it and Budget
Report and public discussion and comment have been encouraged by
the publication of government papers on Reform of Corporation Tax and
Value-Added Tax.
Reflationary measures were introduced by the Government in July 1971 to
strengthen the economy by stimulating consumer demand and industrial in-

Income Tax
vestment. These measures, which could result in an increase in national out¬
put of 4-4-5 per cent between the first halves of 1971 and 1972, entailed an 18-2
per cent cut in purchase tax; the removal of hire purchase controls; a tem¬
porary increase from 60 to 80 per cent in the rate of first year allowance for
capital expenditure on plant and machinery; and the extension of free depre¬
ciation for immobile plant and machinery in use by service industries in the
development areas. The new tax changes brought total tax reductions an¬
nounced since the autumn of 1970 to about £ 1,100 million for 1971-72 and to
more than £1,400 million for 1972-73. The measures were taken in the con¬
text of Britain’s strong external position and of an initiative taken by the Con¬
federation of British Industry (CBI) which had proposed a period of voluntary
price restraint over the next 12 months. Also announced in July 1971 were new
measures to assist the development and intermediate areas by the expenditure
of a further £100 million over the period up to March 1973.
The three principal sources of revenue are first, taxes on income, which
include income tax, surtax and corporation tax; second, taxes on capital,
which include estate duty and capital gains tax; and third, taxes on expenditure
(including taxes on the ownership or use of certain assets)—these include not
only customs and excise duties and the purchase tax, but also the selective em¬
ployment tax, local rates, stamp duties and licence duties (for example, on
motor vehicles). Taxes on individual (but not corporate) incomes are progres¬
sive taxes in that larger incomes and estates bear a proportionately higher rate
of tax. The Board of Inland Revenue collects the taxes on income and capital
and the stamp duties; the Board of Customs and Excise collects the most im¬
portant taxes on expenditure, the customs and excise taxes and the purchase
tax, while a variety of authorities are responsible for the collection of the re¬
mainder, including the Department of Health and Social Security for the
selective employment tax.
Income tax is imposed at a standard rate for the year of assessment beginning
on 6th April, which is at present 38-75 per cent. The effective rate on earned
income, after taking two-ninths earned income relief into account, is approxi¬
mately 30 per cent. The tax imposed on an individual is graduated by means
of personal allowances and reliefs, and by the surtax. In the case of a married
couple the incomes of husband and wife are aggregated and are treated as one
income, but higher allowances are given than for a single person. A special
allowance is given against any earnings of a married woman.
A single person earning £1,000 a year pays £175 in income tax, while a
married man with the same earned income pays £121; if he has two children
under the age of 11, his tax (after taking into account the receipt of family
allowances) falls to £31; when the children are between the ages of 11 and 16,
the tax is £12; if the children are over 16 and receiving full-time education, no
income tax is paid. The range of tax payable by a single person varies from, for
example, £25 on an earned income of £500 a year to £1,409 on an earned
income of £5,000; if the income is from investment, tax liability on £500 will
be £36 and on £5,000 will be £2,324.
Most wage and salary earners pay their income tax under a PAYE (‘Pay as
You Earn’) scheme, under which tax is deducted at source, thus enabling them
to keep up to date on tax payments.
In general, income tax is charged on all income which originates in the
United Kingdom and on all income arising abroad of persons (including
companies) resident in the United Kingdom. The main exceptions are that

BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
interest on certain United Kingdom government securities belonging to
persons not ordinarily resident in the United Kingdom is exempt; and income
from certain classes of possessions abroad is chargeable not on the amount of
income arising but on the amount of income remitted to the United Kingdom.
The United Kingdom has entered into agreements with many countries
providing for relief from double taxation; where such agreements are not in
force unilateral relief is allowed.
The surtax, which is essentially an income tax at higher rates, is charged on
personal incomes exceeding £2,500 a year after deducting certain personal
allowances in excess of the single person’s basic allowance. In addition, the
same earned income relief as for income tax and a special earnings allowance
(not exceeding £2,000) are deductible from earned income only. Surtax is
imposed at rates which increase progressively until, on the portion of taxable
income above £15,000, the combined rate of income tax and surtax payable
in 1971-72 (being income tax for 1971-72 and surtax for 1970—71) reaches
88-75 percent.
Companies are liable to corporation tax on both their profits and their capital
gains. In addition, a company deducts income tax from dividends and other
distributions and pays it over to the Inland Revenue as a separate matter from
its own liability. The rate of corporation tax is fixed retrospectively in the
Budget for the past financial year; for 197° ^ 4° Per cenk The tax is assessed
on the profits of accounting periods, the rate of tax being the rate for the
financial year in which the accounting period falls. The basic rule for the
calculation of income for corporation tax purposes is that, except for special
provisions, it is computed in accordance with income tax principles.
Estate duty is chargeable on the value of all property which passes at death.
The charge to duty is not limited to property owned by the deceased but may
extend to other property, for example, to trust funds from which the deceased
received income in his lifetime and to gifts made by the deceased within seven
years of his death (one year in the case of a gift for public or charitable pur¬
poses). Since the 1971 Budget estates not over £12,500 are exempt from duty,
but on estates of a higher value duty is chargeable by reference to rates ranging
from 25 per cent to 85 per cent applied to successive slices of the estate.
Capital gains accruing on the disposal of assets are liable to capital gains tax
or, in the case of companies, to corporation tax. Where assets were acquired
before 6th April 1965, the charge is restricted to the part of any gain attribu¬
table to the period since 6th April 1965* The rate of tax for persons other than
companies is 30 per cent, but in the case of individuals may be less, depending
on their circumstances. Certain assets are exempt from tax including the
principal private residence, chattels worth less than £1,000 (and any chattels,
except those used for the purpose of a trade, with a predictable life of less than
50 years), private motor cars, and National Savings Certificates. The 1971
Budget also exempted from capital gains tax, an individual where the total
proceeds of disposals do not exceed £5°° in anY year- The distinction between
short- and long-term capital gains tax was removed by the 1971 Budget; thus
all gains are now subject to long-term capital gains tax whatever the length of
period of ownership except for gains on gilt-edged securities which continue
to be exempt from capital gains tax if held for more than 12 months.
The largest group of taxes on expenditure are those administered by the
Customs and Excise Department, namely, the duties on tobacco, hydrocarbon
FINANCE
Purchase Tax
Betting and
Gaming Duties
Motor Vehicle
Licence Taxes
Selective
Employment Tax
345
oil, alcoholic drinks, purchase tax, protective duties, betting and certain
miscellaneous items.1 In British usage the distinction between customs and
excise depends on whether the goods are imported (customs duties) or British
produced (excise duties). These taxes are sometimes known as indirect taxes
since they are normally paid by the importer, manufacturer, or wholesaler,
who adjusts the prices charged to customers accordingly. In 1971 the tax
burden was equivalent to about £0-22% on a gallon of petrol, £0*24 on a packet
of 20 standard plain cigarettes, £2-20 on a bottle of whisky, and 360*044 on a
pint of beer of average strength.
The Chancellor of the Exchequer has power to vary by Order by up to 10
per cent the rates of purchase tax and any of the other main groups of customs
and excise duties (that is, tobacco, alcoholic drinks, oil and the minor revenue
duties). This power, known as the ‘regulator’, requires annual renewal.
Purchase tax is charged on a wide range of goods, nearly all of them consumer
goods, at four rates, which are currently per cent, 18 per cent, 30 per cent
and 45 per cent of the wholesale value. Articles subject to revenue duties of
customs and excise are in general exempt from this tax; other goods free of
purchase tax include food (other than confectionery, soft drinks, ice cream
and crisps), fuel, books and newspapers, young children’s clothing and
footwear, certain non-proprietary drugs and medicines, and some household
appliances.
The principal betting duties are: the pool betting duty (which applies to
football pools and betting by coupon at fixed odds) charged at a rate of 334 per
cent of the stake money; and the general betting duty, which is charged at the
rate of 6 per cent of stake money except for on-course betting which is charged
at 5 per cent. Gaming is taxed at different rates mainly by licence fees.
Taxes on motor vehicles are collected by the local taxation authorities (the
county or county borough councils in England and Wales and the correspond¬
ing councils in Scotland); the proceeds are paid by the local authorities into
the Consolidated Fund. The licence duty on a private motor car is £2$ a year;
motor cycles and three-wheel vehicles, etc., pay 362*50, £$ or £10 a year
according to engine capacity.
The selective employment tax was introduced in the 1966 Finance Act. Its
rates were halved in the 1971 Budget when it was also announced that the
tax would be abolished as from April 1973. Following the 1971 Budget reduc¬
tion, which took effect on 5th July 1971, it is paid by all employers throughout
the United Kingdom at a rate per week of £1-20 for men, ^o*6o for women
and boys and 360-40 for girls. However, the tax is refunded to eligible employers
in manufacturing industries, most of transport and communications, agriculture
and the extractive industries. Most activities of the nationalised industries and
local authorities also receive repayment of the tax. Employers in construction,
distribution, insurance, banking and miscellaneous services pay the tax without
refund, except that two-thirds of the tax is refunded for all employees aged 65
and over and for part-time staff working fewer than 21 hours a week.

Capital expenditure consists chiefly of loans to the nationalised industries, the
local authorities and other public corporations, such as the New Towns
Development Corporations. These loans, less repayments, are financed from
the National Loans Fund by any surplus of revenue over expenditure,
by the proceeds of government borrowing including borrowing from extra-
budgetary funds, such as the National Insurance Fund, and by the sterling
receipts, if any, accruing to the Exchange Equalisation Account.
Central government borrowing may be in the form of borrowing from the
public either through the National Savings Movement (see p. 352) or by bor¬
rowing on the market by means of new issues of securities. New issues of
government securities are made from time to time for the purpose of refinan¬
cing maturing issues (conversion issues) or to raise new money (issues for
cash). The capital requirements of the nationalised industries are met by the
central Government while those of the local authorities are met partly through
the Public Works Loan Board (see p. 73) and partly by borrowing direct from
the public, although some nationalised industries and local authorities have
obtained statutory power enabling them to borrow, with Treasury consent, in
foreign currencies.

The National
Debt
PUBLIC FINANCE
IN NORTHERN
IRELAND
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The National Debt increased particularly rapidly during and immediately
after the first and second world wars. It rose from £650 million in 1914 to
£7,435 million at the end of the first world war, and from £7,131 million in
1939 to £23,637 million in 1946. On 31st March 1971 the total National Debt
(provisional) was £33,425 million, of which £2,148 million was repayable in
currencies other than sterling, mainly to the United States and Canadian
Governments. Of the £31,277 million of internal debt, £3,847 million was
short-term debt, mainly in the form of 91-day Treasury bills, while the long¬
term loans included a variety of stocks, bonds, loans and certificates carrying
fixed rates of interest (ranging from 2^ to 9 per cent) and with fixed or in¬
determinate dates of repayment.
The general system of public finance in Northern Ireland is, in its main
features, similar to that operating in the United Kingdom as a whole, under
which public revenues, with a few minor exceptions, are paid into the Ex¬
chequer Account, from which no money can be withdrawn except on the
authority of Parliament. That authority is expressed in the case of Consolidated
Fund charges in permanent legislative form, and in the case of Supply Services
by annual Appropriation Acts based on estimates prepared by departments
and sanctioned by the Ministry of Finance.
The major sources of revenue flowing into the Northern Ireland Exchequer
are the main national taxes imposed by the United Kingdom Parliament over
the whole country and paid, in the first instance, into the United Kingdom
Consolidated Fund. These taxes, which are referred to in the Government of
Ireland Act 1920 as ‘reserved’ taxes (that is, reserved to the United Kingdom
Parliament), comprise the Inland Revenue group (income tax, surtax, corpora¬
tion tax and capital gains tax) and customs and excise duties on goods. After
the cost of collecting these taxes in Northern Ireland (and the cost of some
other reserved services) and an Imperial Contribution have been retained in
the United Kingdom Consolidated Fund, the balance, termed the ‘Residuary
Share of Reserved Taxes’, is paid to the Northern Ireland Exchequer where
it joins up with the ‘transferred’ taxes (that is, where taxation powers have been
transferred to the Northern Ireland Parliament) to form the public income.
Among items of Transferred Tax Revenue are estate duties, stamp duties,
betting duties, various excise licence duties, motor vehicle duties and selective
employment tax.
A joint Exchequer Board, representative of the Treasury and the Ministry
of Finance for Northern Ireland, constituted in accordance with the Govern¬
ment of Ireland Act 1920, determines the amount of Reserved Revenue and
the cost of Reserved Services attributable to Northern Ireland for each year, the
amount of the Imperial Contribution, and such other questions affecting the
financial relations of the two Governments as may be referred to it.
In the Northern Ireland Budget for 1971-72 (year ending 31st March), total
revenues were forecast at £419'1 million and expenditure at £4!9 milll°n’
After allowing for the Imperial Contribution, provisionally estimated at £1
million, there was a Budget surplus of £116,000.
The Public Debt of Northern Ireland, totalling £378-1 million on 31st
March 1971 is covered by repayable advances and investments held by the
Ministry of Finance.
Outside the Exchequer system in Northern Ireland, various funds have been
established, in addition to statutory Reserve and Sinking Funds, for specific
purposes. In general, these funds follow the United Kingdom pattern, the
principal funds being those relating to National Insurance and government
FINANCE
349
loans. The latter constitutes a pool of capital money available mainly for local
and public authority borrowings; on 31st March 1971 a sum of approximately
£284 million was outstanding against such borrowers.
THE CENTRAL BANK
The British banking system is long established and well integrated. It comprises
a central bank; commercial banks which carry on the usual main banking
services; the United Kingdom offices of banks whose main business is in other
countries; merchant banks and other specialised institutions.
The Bank of England was established in 1694 by Act of Parliament and
Royal Charter as a corporate body; the entire capital stock was acquired by
the Government under the Bank of England Act 1946. As the central bank,
the Bank acts as banker to the Government, to overseas central banks and to
commercial banks; it is the note-issuing authority and the registrar for some
200 government, nationalised industry, local authority, public board and
Commonwealth government stocks. As agent for the Government the Bank
administers exchange control and the voluntary arrangements to limit invest¬
ment in the more developed countries of the sterling area. On behalf of the
Treasury it manages the Exchange Equalisation Account (EEA), which holds
Britain’s official reserves of gold and foreign exchange; using the resources of
the EEA the Bank designs its interventions in the foreign exchange market
both to prevent undue fluctuations in the exchange value of sterling and to
conserve the means of making payments abroad.
As banker to the Government the Bank examines and seeks to anticipate
banking and financial problems and to undertake the appropriate operations
in the money, capital and the foreign exchange markets; consequently the Bank
has a major responsibility for advising the Government on the formulation of
monetary policy and for its subsequent execution.
In implementing monetary policy the Bank is ready to act daily in the money
market, by buying or selling Treasury bills, and similarly in the market for
government stocks. A prime concern is to maintain orderly conditions and,
when necessary, the Bank also exerts influence on interest rates; an important
instrument in this context is Bank Rate, which is the minimum rate at which
the Bank will discount approved bills of exchange for the members of the
London Discount Market or will normally lend to them; a wide range of other
short-term interest rates is related to it.
As the recognised channel of communication between the commercial banks
and other financial institutions of the City of London on the one hand, and
the Government on the other, the Bank has been called on in recent years to
administer direct control of credit. This has been achieved by means of ‘special
deposits’ which the London clearing banks and Scottish banks are called upon
to make with the Bank; through requests to the banks and other financial
institutions not to extend credit above stipulated quantitative ceilings; and by
general guidance to them on lending policy. In May 1971, following a govern¬
ment announcement that the authorities wished to explore with the banks and
finance houses the possible development of new techniques aimed at combin¬
ing effective control over credit conditions with greater scope for competition
and innovation, the Bank published proposals towards this end {Competition
and Credit Control, April 1971). They would involve a shift from existing
liquidity and quantitative lending controls to a system placing more reliance
on changes in interest rates supported by calls for special deposits on the
basis of a minimum reserve assets ratio across the whole of the banking system.
35°
BRITAIN I972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The minimum reserve is intended to provide the authorities with a known firm
base for the operation of monetary policy.
The Bank of England has the sole right in England and Wales of issuing
bank notes. The note issue is fiduciary, that is to say, it is no longer backed by
gold but by government securities and other assets. The Scottish and Northern
Ireland banks have limited rights to issue notes; these issues, apart from an
amount specified by legislation for each bank, must be fully covered by Bank
of England notes and by coin. The provision of coin for circulation is the
responsibility of the Royal Mint, a government department.
The Deposit
Banks
BANKING AND PRIVATE FINANCE
The primary business of the deposit banks is the receipt, transfer and encash¬
ment of deposits. The principal deposit banks are the six London clearing
banks, three Scottish banks and two Northern Ireland banks. Recent mergers
have resulted in the formation of six banking groups, four based in London
and two in Scotland. The two Northern Ireland banks are owned by London
clearing banks, but two groups of banks based in the Republic of Ireland also
operate in Northern Ireland. .
At the end of 1970 current and deposit accounts with the deposit banks
operating in Britain amounted to over £12,768 million, and accounted for
nearly 40 per cent of the total deposits (in sterling and foreign currencies) of the
banking sector, which also includes the National Giro, the accepting houses,
overseas banks, other banks and the discount market. The deposit banks
provide full banking services throughout Britain, and operate through over
14,000 branches. Several of them have interests in British overseas and Com¬
monwealth banks, and in other banks which have been formed specially to
compete in international markets. They have also acquired substantial interests
in hire-purchase finance houses, and some have set up their own unit trusts.
Together with the Bank of England the London clearing banks make up the
membership of the London Bankers’ Clearing House. In 1970 cheques, drafts,
bills and bankers’ effects passing through the clearing system averaged in value
£64,424 million monthly, while the average monthly value of the credit transfer
clearing was £1,199 million. ,, , ,
Current account balances with the deposit banks are repayable on demand
and no interest is paid on them, but on deposit account balances interest is paid
at a rate generally 2 per cent below Bank Rate. The London clearing banks
maintain a ratio of about 8 per cent between cash reserves and total deposits.
It is also a convention among the London clearing banks that at least 28 per
cent of deposits should be held in the form of liquid assets.
The banks’ profits are largely earned through their advances to customers
partly in the form of overdrafts and partly in the form of loans (with or
without collateral security); these are normally for a short term only unless
renewed. The ratio of London clearing bank advances to total deposits
declined from about 43 per cent in 1938 to 17 per cent at the end of the
second world war but it has since risen and in May 1971 it was around 53 per
cent. In recent years the banks have several times been asked to restrain the
growth of their lending and to ensure that, within the total priority is given
to finance for exports and for productive investment in manufacturing industry
and agriculture: this has involved the restriction of advances to the personal
sector. In the 1971 Budget, it was stated that the general guidance on the
direction of lending remained unchanged, and that the rate of growth o
FINANCE
351
Overseas
Banks
National Giro
The Merchant
Banks
restricted lending would still be limited. The banks’ ‘liquid’ assets, that is,
those that are quickly realisable comprise cash, balances at the Bank of
England, money at call (mainly loans to discount houses), and their holdings
of Treasury and commercial bills and certain export and shipbuilding credits
refinanceable with the Bank of England: they also hold a proportion of their
assets as portfolio (mainly British Government securities) or trade invest¬
ments.
The bank giro, originally introduced as the credit transfer scheme, and the
direct debiting system, by which a creditor with the prior approval of the
debtor may claim money due to him direct from the latter’s banking account,
have helped to improve the money transmission services. Another fairly
recent banking innovation has been the introduction by some banks of
automatic cash dispensing machines, which allow customers to obtain cash
at any time. Credit cards have become increasingly popular for the settlement
of accounts in retail shops. Cheque cards, which enable the card holder to
cash a cheque not exceeding £30 at any office of the major British and Irish
banks, are also becoming more widely used.
There are also some 37 British overseas and Commonwealth banks, many of
them having their headquarters in London. They provide a comprehensive
banking service in many parts of the world and engage in the financing of
trade not only between Britain and other countries but also between third
countries. There are also currently in London about 33 United States banks,
50 European banks, 11 Japanese banks and over 30 other foreign banks.
The Post Office National Giro was opened in October 1968 to provide a
low-cost current account banking and money transfer service which can be
operated through most post offices in Britain. All accounts and transactions
are maintained by means of a computer complex at the National Giro Centre
at Bootle, near Liverpool. Giro now has more than 350,000 accounts, one-
sixth of which are business accounts. In April 1970 a scheme was introduced
to make available personal loans from a finance company for credit-worthy
Giro customers. In May 1970 a scheme was begun to encourage the payment
of wages through Giro. In October 1970 Giro’s international transfer service
was extended to Japan. This service now provides British account holders with
direct money transfer facilities between themselves and some 14 million
overseas account holders in Europe and the Far East.
The merchant banks have helped to give London an international reputation
as a world financial centre for short-term and long-term borrowing. They
are of two kinds, and are known as accepting houses and issuing houses
according to whether they specialise predominantly in the work of acceptance
credit1 or in transactions involving the sponsoring of capital issues on behalf
of their customers. They arrange to issue and themselves underwrite long-
and short-term loans both to governments and to enterprises in overseas
countries in sterling (where permitted by exchange control regulations) or in
other currencies which have been deposited with them. They are also engaged
in the work of the gold and foreign exchange markets, and they have many
1 Acceptance credit has been defined as fundamentally a three-month operation finan¬
cing exports from and imports to Britain and to other markets. The expression is derived
from the method of financing trade by which commercial bills are ‘accepted’ or guaran¬
teed by a merchant bank against documents, after which they may be discounted for
cash by a discount house.
352
The Discount
Market
The National
Savings
Movement
National Savings
Securities
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
other functions in connection with the financing of trade, investment manage¬
ment and insurance.
The London discount or money market is a distinctive part of the British
banking system. It consists of 11 discount houses and its principal function
is to marry the needs of lenders of money for short periods with those of the
borrowers of such money.
The discount houses borrow ‘at call’ from banks and other financial
institutions at a relatively low rate of interest. To them the Bank of England
acts as a lender of last resort. The clearing banks do not borrow money
directly from the Bank of England; if they need to add to their cash resources
they call in part of their loans to the discount market. If, as a result, any
particular discount house is unable to cover its needs for cash elsewhere, it is
obliged to borrow from the Bank of England, normally at Bank Rate for
seven days, but the Bank may charge a higher rate and has also at times lent
overnight, or for short periods, at the rates of interest prevailing in the market.
An important part of the money borrowed by the discount houses is
invested in British Government Treasury bills. The discount houses accept as
an informal responsibility that they should cover the Government’s need to
borrow on Treasury bills, which are offered on tender each week. The clearing
banks do not buy Treasury bills at the weekly tenders except on behalf of
customers, but they purchase, from the discount market, bills which are of a
maturity required by them.
The discount houses provide a specialised market in commercial bills and
in short-dated Government bonds (that is, those with not more than five years
to run before repayment), local authority bonds, and certain other negotiable
instruments.
The National Savings Movement started in 1916 to help finance the war by
promoting savings. The present movement encourages the widespread invest¬
ment of savings in Trustee Savings Banks and the National Savings Bank
(see p. 354) and in National Savings securities. The movement is led by the
National Savings Committee for England and Wales and similar committees
for Scotland and Northern Ireland.1 The committees are bodies of independent
persons representing regional savings organisations and various national insti¬
tutions connected with such matters as finance, industry and education. They
are assisted by a salaried staff of civil servants. Voluntary local savings com¬
mittees, often assisted or promoted by local authorities, co-ordinate the work
of voluntary local savings groups.
The administration of the National Savings Bank and other forms of national
savings is carried out by the Department for National Savings. Four forms
of National Savings securities are currently on sale: the National Savings
Certificate, the British Savings Bond,2 and the Premium Savings Bond and
National Savings Stamps. National Savings Certificates, in units of £1,
are encashable at par at any time; interest, which is free of income tax, surtax
and capital gains tax is only paid on encashment; the limit on individual
holdings is 1,000 units of the current issue. British Savings Bonds, sold in units
1 The Northern Ireland Ministry of Finance is responsible for the administration of
Ulster Savings, but the furtherance and organisation of the savings movement in
Northern Ireland is the concern of a central voluntary committee, which is assisted by
county and local committees and district groups.
2 These bonds, which were introduced in 1968, are similar to the earlier National
Development Bonds and the Defence Bonds.

There is a maximum holding of £10,000 on British Savings Bonds (First
Issue) which were on sale from April 1968 to May 1971 and a separate limit of
£10,000 on British Savings Bonds (Second Issue) introduced in May I971*
If the Bonds are held to maturity (five years from the date of purchase) they
are repaid with a bonus of £3 per cent tax free. Premium Savings Bonds are in
units of £1 and individual holdings are limited to £2,000. After a qualifying
period of three months the bonds give investors a chance to win tax-free prizes
instead of receiving interest. There is now a weekly draw for a prize of £25,000
and a monthly draw for prizes ranging from £25 to £50,000. At the end of
March 1971, £805-1 million was invested in this form of savings. A selection
of British Government securities is held on the National Savings Register and
can also be bought or sold through the Bonds and Stock Office. Trustee
Savings Banks also deal in stock on the National Savings Register.
A contractual savings scheme, known as ‘Save as You Earn’ (SAYE),
enables savings to be made in regular monthly amounts within a minimum of
£1 and a maximum of £20 in deposits with the Department for National
Savings or Trustee Savings Banks by means of deductions from pay or by
other regular payments. At the end of five years, savings will qualify for a
bonus equivalent to one year’s savings free of tax. Completed savings which
are not withdrawn will qualify for a double bonus at the end of seven years,
that is, two years’ savings. For example, contributions totalling £60 payable
over five years at a rate of £1 per month will qualify for a bonus of £12 at the
end of that period, or £24 if left on deposit for a further two years. Savers who
wish to stop payments will be able to withdraw the total sum saved (but there
cannot be partial withdrawals). Tax-free compound interest will be paid at the
rate of 2% per cent on amounts withdrawn after the first but before the end of
the fifth year, or at 4^ per cent where the contributions cease but the savings
are left invested for the remainder of the five years or where the saver dies
before the contributions are completed. A separate ‘Save as You Earn’ scheme
(with the same maximum limit) is operated by the building societies.

BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The National Savings Bank is the largest organisation of its kind in the world.
It provides a countrywide system for depositing and withdrawing small
savings and has over 22 million active accounts. Ordinary Accounts bear
interest at 3^ per cent and the first £21 of interest is tax-free. Up to fzo can
be withdrawn on demand at any savings bank post office, but a few days’ notice
is required for larger amounts. The moneys are lodged with the National Debt
Office and are invested in government securities. Deposits up to a limit of
^10,000 bearing a higher rate of interest may be made in Investment Accounts
where investors have a qualifying deposit of in an Ordinary Account. All
deposits carry a government guarantee; at the end of June 1971 sum °f the
two accounts totalled £1,794 million.
The Trustee Savings Banks, most of which were founded in the nineteenth
century, operate under their own trustees but are subject to statutory provi¬
sions and National Debt Office surveillance. There are 75 individual banks
with over 1,500 Trustee Offices and 12^ million accounts. Deposits can be
made either in the Ordinary Department, the Special Investment Depart¬
ments or the Current Account Department. Savings in the Ordinary Depart¬
ment earn interest at 3-2 per cent and the first £21 of interest is tax-free.
Withdrawals can usually be made on demand though notice is required for
large sums. Deposits are invested with the National Debt Commissioners and
both capital and interest are guaranteed by the Government. The Special
Investment Departments offer a higher rate of return, which is taxable.
Deposits are limited to £10,000, but are not government guaranteed. At
the end of June 1971 total sums in the Ordinary Departments of the Trustee
Savings Banks were £1,123 million and in the Special Investment Departments
£1,542 million. Most Trustee Savings Banks operate cheque services on
deposits in the Current Account Departments. In January 1968 the Trustee
Savings Banks set up their own unit trust (see p. 356).
At end-June 1971 National Savings totalled £8,872 million. The diagram
on p. 353 shows the distribution of National Savings between the different
outlets in 1958 and 1970.
It has been the policy of the commercial banks to leave the provision of many
special financial facilities to other financial institutions. These facilities,
which are supplementary to the credit facilities of the banking system, are
mainly provided through the savings banks, finance corporations, hire-
purchase finance companies, the stock exchanges, investment trusts, building
societies and the insurance market. The firms engaged in such activities are
in the main highly specialised, for example, discount and other finance houses,
stockbrokers, insurers, insurance underwriters and brokers.
Two corporations, the Finance Corporation for Industry Limited (FCI) and
the Industrial and Commercial Finance Corporation Limited (ICFC), were
set up in 1945 to assist in dealing with the problems of post-war reconstruction
and development. The corporations are ordinary limited companies with no
official representation on their boards and no recourse to public funds.
Another corporation, the Commonwealth Development Finance Company
Limited (CDFC), was established in 1953 to assist development projects in
the Commonwealth.
The FCI was formed to assist in the provision of capital (in amounts of
£200,000 and upwards) for the re-equipment and development of industry.
The FCI has an authorised and issued capital of £25 million and may
FINANCE
355
Industrial and
Commercial Finance
Corporation
Limited
Commonwealth
Development
Finance Company
Limited
The Stock
Exchanges
borrow up to four times this amount, making a possible total of resources of
£125 million. The share capital is held by insurance companies, by invest¬
ment trust companies and by the Bank of England. At 31st March 1971 the
capital called and paid up was 10 per cent (^2-5 million); the Bank of England
paid £5 million in advance of call in 1958. The liability of the shareholders
in respect of the uncalled capital represents security to the banks providing
loans for the corporation’s working capital. The value of its loans and invest¬
ments at 31st March 1971 was £70 million.
The main function of the ICFC is to invest long-term capital in British based
small- and medium-sized companies which are capable of using additional
resources profitably. In addition it provides a wide range of financial and
other specialist services. It has a number of subsidiaries, including Technical
Development Capital Ltd. established in 1962 to provide venture capital for
the commercial development of technological innovation. The shareholders
of ICFC are the Bank of England, the English Clearing and the Scottish
Banks. At 31st March 1971 the ICFC had nearly £150 million invested in
2,200 British companies.
The Commonwealth Development Finance Company was established in
1953. Its activities are no longer confined to the Commonwealth. It aims to
support business enterprise overseas by providing finance in the form of share
capital and loans on mutually acceptable terms. Its authorised share capital is
£30 million, of which about 14^ million ‘A’ ordinary shares of (£o-io paid)
are held by industrial, shipping, mining and banking interests in the United
Kingdom, and nf million ‘B’ ordinary shares of £1 (^0-50 paid) are held by
the Bank of England and certain central banks in the Commonwealth. At
31st March 1971 CDFC held investments worth nearly ^27 million spread
over a wide range of industries placed in more than 30 countries.
There are seven stock exchanges in the British Isles. In addition the Provincial
Brokers’ Stock Exchange operates in many cities and towns throughout Britain
and the Irish Republic. The Federation of Stock Exchanges in Great Britain
and Ireland, comprising with one exception all these organisations, was set up
in July 1965 to co-ordinate their work.
The London Stock Exchange is by far the most important of these stock
exchanges and is one of the world’s two foremost free markets in securities.
Some 9,000 securities are quoted on the London Stock Exchange; at the
end of March 1971 these had a total market value of £120,504 million. About
7,770 securities of companies are quoted, including a number of leading
overseas companies. Company issues represented more than four-fifths of the
securities at market valuation, the remainder being United Kingdom and over¬
seas government and corporation stocks.
The London Stock Exchange is linked by cable or telephone with stock
exchanges all over the world. Therefore, a quoted company, subject to any
limitations imposed by the exchange control regulations, has a world-wide
market for its issues. This is an important factor in the raising of new capital
by government and commercial borrowers. Arbitrage transactions by brokers
—the buying or selling of a particular security on one stock exchange with the
intention of reversing it on another—play an important part in equating
price differentials between different markets and maintaining a continual
flow of business between centres.
The stock exchanges do not fix dealing prices; the terms on which bargains
are made between members reflect the interaction of supply and demand for
356 BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
the securities concerned. All the stock exchanges operate under strict rules of
conduct which they formulate themselves.
There has been substantial growth in demand in the post-war period for
ordinary (equity) shares, partly in expectation that such shares will maintain
their real value or increase in value in periods of rising prices. Insurance
companies and pension funds invest a larger proportion than formerly of their
assets in these shares, and the Trustee Investments Act 1961 permits trustees,
under certain conditions, to invest up to half the funds they hold in trust in
equity shares.
The ownership of securities on the London Stock Exchange is much more
widespread than formerly: it is estimated that there are about 2^ million
shareholders in the United Kingdom and that their shareholdings are widely
distributed.
Investment
Trusts and
Unit Trusts
Through investment trusts and unit trusts, investors may spread their risks
and obtain the benefit of skilled management.
The ordinary type of investment trust is constituted as a public company
registered under the Companies Acts with limited liability; its business is
to invest its capital in a range of stocks and shares. Like other companies,
it may issue several types of stocks or shares and may retain part of its profits
to build up reserves. Investment trusts grew to importance in the latter half
of the nineteenth century and have been prominent in directing capital
towards overseas investment.
Unit trusts are constituted by trust deed between a management company
and a trustee company which holds the securities. Normally, the managers
sell units to the public and invest the proceeds in a fairly wide range of
Stock Exchange securities. The costs of running the trust are defrayed partly
by an initial charge which forms part of the price of a unit, and partly by a
semi-annual service charge which is taken usually out of the income of the
trust. The level of both charges is controlled by the Department of Trade and
Industry, whose authorisation is required before units can be offered to the
public; this is only granted if the trust deed is satisfactory to them.
The first British unit trust was formed in 1931 and by 1939 there were
98 trusts, with assets estimated at £80 million. This medium of saving has
grown considerably since 1957. At the end of April 1971 there were 2*38
million unit holdings. The value of the funds invested in authorised trusts has
risen from £60 million in 1958 to £1,593 million at the end of April 1971; it has
more than doubled since the end of 1966. There are now a wide variety of trusts,
both as to the range of investments covered and the ways in which they cater
for the differing needs of investors.
The Insurance
Market
Insurance
Companies
Although a certain amount of insurance is provided by friendly societies and
trade unions, most insurance services in Britain are in the hands of mutual or
joint stock companies or Lloyd’s underwriters.
There are about 570 insurance companies incorporated in the United
Kingdom but most of the business is in the hands of about too companies.
This figure includes companies which became subject to the provisions of the
Insurance Companies Acts 1958-67 as a consequence of the extension of
those Acts to all classes of insurance business. Most British insurers write
several of the main classes of business although some specialise in one class,
particularly in life assurance, where about 100 companies write only that type
of business. A few specialise in re-insurance.
FINANCE
357
Lloyd's
Insurance Brokei's
International
Insurance Services
In addition about 170 overseas companies carry on business (and even more
companies are represented) in the United Kingdom, thus emphasising the
international nature of the London market. Some of the large British com¬
panies, however, have their administrative headquarters in the provinces.
In 1968 the total assets of the British insurance companies amounted to
about £14,832 million, the bulk of which is life assurance business.
There is no government control over the investment policy of insurance
funds at home and these represent one of the most important sources of funds
for investment in commerce and industry. Almost a half of the total assets
of British insurance companies is now invested in equity shares and debentures.
Lloyd’s is an incorporated society of private insurers in London. The name
‘Lloyd’s’ is derived from Edward Lloyd’s coffee house, established in the late
seventeenth century, where merchants with maritime and other interests
gathered to transact business. By the middle of the eighteenth century,
Lloyd’s coffee house had become the principal centre of underwriting
business and intelligence of shipping movements. Although in its earlier
history the activities of Lloyd’s were confined to the conduct of marine
insurance business, there has also been built up at Lloyd s a very considerable
world-wide market for the transaction of other classes of insurance business
in its non-marine, aviation and motor markets.
Lloyd’s is regulated by a series of special Acts of Parliament starting in
1871; the affairs of the Society of Lloyd’s in its corporate capacity are adminis¬
tered by the Committee of Lloyd s, which does not itself transact insurance
business.
Lloyd’s is not a company but a market for insurance, where business is
transacted by individual underwriters for their own account and risk and
in competition with each other. Insurance may only be placed through
Lloyd’s brokers, who negotiate with Lloyd’s underwriters on behalf of the
insured. Only elected underwriting members of Lloyd’s, who must transact
insurance with unlimited liability and who have met the most stringent
financial regulations laid down by the Committee of Lloyd s, are permitted to
transact business at Lloyd’s 5 these financial safeguards give a security behind
the Lloyd’s policy which is second to none. Since 1969 non-Commonwealth
underwriters have been admitted to membership of Lloyd’s, if they satisfy
the requirements. >
Today there are about 6,000 underwriting members of Lloyd’s grouped
into some 280 syndicates and represented at Lloyd’s by underwriting agents
who accept risks on behalf of the members of their syndicates.
In conjunction with its marine insurance business Lloyd’s has built up a
world-wide organisation for the collection and diffusion of shipping intelli¬
gence.
The insurance market is completed by the insurance brokers, acting on behalf
of the insured; brokers are an essential part of the Lloyd’s market and a
valuable part of the company market. Many brokers specialise in re-insurance
business, acting as intermediaries in the exchange of contracts between
companies, both British and overseas, and often acting as London repre¬
sentatives of the latter.
Two-thirds of the fire, accident and marine insurance business is carried on
overseas, partly by re-insurance on the London market and partly through
branches and agencies established in over 100 countries. The basic principle
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
of this international business is that resources capable of meeting any potential
loss are instantly available for use in any part of the world.
Behind this large and international volume of business stand the very
substantial assets of the companies, in addition to substantial reserves of
uncalled capital, and the deposits, underwriting trust funds and other re¬
sources of Lloyd’s underwriters.
The principal function of building societies is to supply long-term loans on
the security of private dwelling-houses purchased for owner-occupation,
though loans are occasionally made on the security of commercial and
industrial premises and farms. The funds of building societies are derived
mainly from the general public who invest in shares or deposits. The amount
of share capital is not fixed; shares, which have a fixed value, are not dealt
with on the Stock Exchange but may be withdrawn in cash if notice is given.
The Building Societies Act 1962, which consolidated a number of earlier Acts,
prescribes the general way in which societies must conduct their business.
The Chief Registrar of Friendly Societies has discretionary powers to stop
a society either advertising or accepting money from investors if he considers
that the way in which the society’s business is conducted is jeopardising
investors’ money. The rapid expansion of building society activity in the
twentieth century has been accompanied by a concentration of most of the
business in the hands of a few large societies. At the end of 1970, 481 societies
were in operation, with total assets of ,£10,819 million. Ten of the largest
societies, however, each with assets of over £250 million, account for well over
half of the total funds. The amount advanced on mortgage in 1970 was £1,954
million.

TRADE AND

OVERSEAS TRADE
Although relatively small in area and accounting for less than 2 per cent of
the world’s population, the United Kingdom is the world’s third largest trading
nation, conducting over 11 per cent of international trade in 1970.
For well over a century international trade has been of vital importance to
Britain’s economy. Britain relies upon imports for about half its total con¬
sumption of foodstuffs and nearly all the raw materials needed for its industries.
Its exports of goods and services together represent about a fifth of the gross
national product. It is a major supplier of machinery, vehicles, aircraft, metal
manufactures, electrical apparatus, chemicals and textiles. It is the world’s
largest market for foodstuffs, and among the largest for metals and ores,
textile raw materials, petroleum and many other products.
Changes in value, volume, composition and geographical distribution of
imports and exports are outlined in the following paragraphs.
In 1970 Britain’s exports were valued at about £8,000 million (f.o.b., that is,
excluding the cost of freight and insurance outside the United Kingdom) and
imports at about £9,000 million (including the cost of freight and insurance to
the United Kingdom). Valued on the same basis (f.o.b.) as exports, imports in
1970 were also about £8,000 million. The value of both imports and exports
have approximately doubled since 1961, while the volume of trade (dis¬
counting price changes) is estimated to have increased by 57 per cent for
exports and 55 per cent in the case of imports.
The growth in trade has not, however, been even. There was a particularly
rapid expansion of imports in 1964 (14 per cent in value and n per cent in
volume) and again in 1968 (23 per cent in value and 10 per cent in volume)
after the devaluation of the pound. Exports increased steadily from 1961 to
1966, but in 1967 they declined slightly in value as well as in volume. Follow¬
ing devaluation in November 1967, they proceeded to rise rapidly—by 23 per
cent pound sterling in value or 6 per cent in volume in 1968; by 14 per cent
in value or 10 per cent in volume in 1969; and by 10 per cent in value or 3 per
cent in volume in 1970. From 1964 to 1967 there was a steady improvement in
Britain’s terms of trade, that is, export prices rose faster than import prices.
After devaluation, both export and import prices in pounds sterling at first
rose sharply and then more steadily and it was not until May 1970 that export
prices were higher in dollar terms than in 1967.
The value and volume of exports and imports in selected years from 1959
to 1970 are shown in Table 23.
The expansion of domestic agricultural production has reduced Britain’s
dependence on imported food supplies and the ratio of imported food¬
stuffs to total imports has fallen from 39 per cent in 1954 to 23 per cent in
1970 when imports of foodstuffs (including beverages and tobacco) were

Trade between Britain and Western Europe has been increasing in recent
years, and conversely there has been a decline in the proportion of Britain’s
exports going to primary producing countries. In 1958, 27 per cent of exports
went to Western Europe, but in 1962, for the first time, these exports began
to exceed those to the sterling area and by 1970 they formed over 41 per cent
of the total. Exports to Western Europe increased by over 15 per cent in 1970,
following increases of about 19 per cent in 1968 and 1969. Exports to the
European Economic Community (EEC) increased by 15 per cent in 1970
compared with 18 per cent in 1969 and 24 per cent in 1968, and to the European

Relatively, trade with other members of the Commonwealth and with the
sterling area as a whole has tended to decline. Exports to the sterling area
increased by 87 per cent in 1970 but as a proportion of total exports dropped
slightly to 27-5 per cent, compared with 30 per cent in 1967 and with 42 per
cent in 1958; there has been a similar relative fall in respect of imports.
Canada, Australia, South Africa and the Republic of Ireland, however, are
still among Britain’s most important trading partners, but since 1957 the
United States has been Britain’s largest single market and source of supply.
The proportion of total exports going to North America in 1970 was just under
16 per cent, slightly less than that of 1968 and 1969. Exports to Latin America
increased by 14 per cent in 1970 but imports from that source fell by 8 per cent.
Britain’s trade with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe though still small
in relation to its total trade has been growing rapidly over the past decade.
Trade with Japan continues to grow; exports rose by 31 per cent in 1969 and
15 per cent in 1970, while imports rose by 29 per cent in 1970 having fallen
by 9 per cent in 1969.

For nearly two centuries Britain has usually been able to earn a surplus from
its invisible overseas transactions, that is, transactions in services, including
the provision of finance. This has provided it with the means to pay for part
of its imports of goods and to finance the purchase of capital assets overseas.
Invisible transactions are divided for statistical purposes into six main
groups: government; transport (shipping and civil aviation); travel; other

for the first time in 1968 and again in 1969 and 1970. Over half the net deficit
