other substantial items of expenditure are grants to developing countries and
subscriptions to international organisations.
Tourism yields a substantial income from overseas; in the ten years 1961-70
overseas visitors spent nearly £2,600 million in Britain. For 1970 these travel
and tourist receipts, excluding fares, are estimated at about £433 mil ion.
United Kingdom residents on holiday, or travelling for business or other
purposes overseas, spent about £388 million (excluding fares) in the same
Year. Both receipts and expenditure in 1970 were some 20 per cent grea er
than in 1969. The continuing increase in both the average expenditure per
visitor and in the number of travellers visiting Britain caused travel credits to
exceed debits in 1968, 1969 and 1970. The estimated total number of visits to
the United Kingdom in 1969, including visitors from the Republic of Ireland,
was a record figure of nearly 6-5 million-more than twice the level of 1956
and an increase of 16 per cent over the 1969 level.
Britain’s national tourist organisation consists of four independent govern¬
ment-financed statutory bodies-the British Tourist Authority which is
responsible for the overseas promotion of tourism in Britain and for certa
general matters affecting the country as a whole, and the English, Scott
and Wales Tourist Boards which are responsible for encouraging the develop¬
ment and improvement of facilities and amenities for tourists in their respective
countries, and for tourist promotional work and publicity within Britain
Northern Ireland has its own statutory Tourist Board financed by t
Northern Ireland Government.
The English, Scottish and Wales Boards administered a scheme of incentives
for hotel investment until 1971 and now have powers to give financial assis¬
tance to selected tourist projects in Development Areas.
Britain’s prosperity depends on the prosperity of those who buy its exports
which in turn depends on how they sell their exports elsewhere. Thus Br ta
is a strong advocate of the removal of artificial barriers to trade and to this end
has taken a leading part in the setting up and subsequent activities of sue
organisations as thf International Monetary Fund (IMF), the General Agree¬
ment on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) and the Organisation for Economic
General Agree¬
ment on Tariffs
and Trade
TRADE AND PAYMENTS 365
Co-operation and Development (OECD). It has also played a full part at the
two plenary sessions of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Develop¬
ment held in 1964 and 1968 and is a member of the Trade and Development
Board which acts on behalf of the Conference between sessions.
Customs duties on imports into Britain are divided into two broad cate¬
gories: revenue duties (to which there correspond excise revenue duties on
comparable British-produced goods) and protective duties. Purchase tax is
chargeable on imported as well as home-produced goods but in the main the
charge on imports is deferred until the goods are sold by a registered to a
non-registered trader. In the financial year 1970-71 revenue duties charged
on imported goods yielded about £2,720 million, by far the greater part of
which came from tobacco and hydrocarbon oils (petroleum products). The
yield from protective duties was £261 million, or about 2’6 per cent of the
value of all imports.
At the beginning of the twentieth century the only customs duties were
those imposed for revenue purposes on a small range of products. Certain
duties were imposed during the first world war (the McKenna Duties), in
1921 (for strategic reasons) and in 1925 (initially for revenue purposes) but it
was not until the Import Duties Act 1932 that any serious departure was made
from the principle of free trade. This measure provided a degree of protection
for British industry and, at the same time, a basis for negotiations with foreign
countries already in possession of a tariff structure. A series of bilateral trade
negotiations between 1932 and 1939 led to some modification in the level of
protection but in the next ten years, because of government purchase and
import controls introduced during and immediately after the second world
war, the tariff lost much of its importance. The substantial relaxation of
quantitative import controls from 1949 onwards re-established the tariff as
the main instrument of protection.
The Import Duties Act 1958 replaced existing legislation relating to the
protective tariff and brought it up to date in a single measure. The tariff was
recast into an internationally agreed form (the Brussels Nomenclature), which
came into use from 1st January 1959. Under the Customs Duties (Dumping
and Subsidies) Act 1969, the DTI is empowered to impose duties on imported
goods of any description which are being dumped or subsidised if it is satisfied
that this is causing or threatening material injury to a particular industry and
that such action would be in the national interest. The Act also empowers the
DTI to take provisional action where a prima facie case of dumping or subsi¬
disation and consequent material injury has been made out.
The United Kingdom’s protective tariff has been considerably modified in
recent years as a result of a series of international tariff negotiations held under
the auspices of the GATT, which seeks to increase the volume of world trade
by reducing tariffs and other barriers to trade, and by eliminating discrimina¬
tion in international commerce. Tariff reductions, and bindings against
increase, negotiated between countries under the GATT are applied equally
to all other GATT countries under the ‘most favoured nation’ clause.
As a result of the latest series of GATT tariff negotiations, the ‘Kennedy
Round’ (May 1964-June 1967), average reductions of over 30 per cent are
being made by the major trading countries in their tariffs on industrial goods.
The reduction to be made in the British tariffs on dutiable industrial goods
imported from the EEC, the United States and Japan will amount to about
37 per cent, 40 per cent and 34 per cent respectively. This is closely in line
with the reductions which these countries are making, which will affect well

BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
over 70 per cent of British exports of dutiable industrial goods to these coun¬
tries. Some reductions in the tariffs on agricultural goods are also being made.
The implementation of the British tariff reductions commenced on 1st July
1968 with the remainder scheduled for 1st January 1970, 1971 and 1972.
The principle of Imperial Preference was introduced into the United Kingdom
customs duties in 1919 and at the Ottawa Conference in 1932 agreements
were concluded with independent Commonwealth countries providing for
reciprocal preferential tariff treatment over a wide range of goods. The
Import Duties Act 1932 had already provided for the duty-free entry of goods
from the United Kingdom dependencies.
Most imports into Britain from the Commonwealth preference area (which
includes the Republic of South Africa, Burma and the Republic of Ireland)
enter free of duty although levies may be charged on imports of certain
foodstuffs from the Commonwealth. Some two-fifths of the value of imports
from the area enjoy a tariff preference of about 11 per cent (defined as the
difference between the full duty rate and the preferential rate—in this case
generally nil—expressed as a percentage of the import value). It is estimated
that approximately half of Britain’s exports to the Commonwealth preference
area enter free of duty and about the same proportion enjoy an average tariff
preference of 12 per cent.
In 1964 at the first United Nations Conference on Trade and Development
(UNCTAD) in Geneva, Britain declared itself prepared to extend tariff
preferences on a non-reciprocal and non-discriminatory basis to all the
developing countries if other major industrialised countries would do jhe
same, if the Commonwealth countries concerned would agree and provided
that preferences were not given in such a way as to impede the continuing
reduction of tariffs on a most-favoured-nation basis. The establishment of a
system of generalised preferences for manufactures and semi-manufactures
exported by developing countries was agreed in principle at the second
UNCTAD conference in New Delhi in 1968. The detailed arrangements are
nearing completion and many countries have already begun to introduce the
legislation necessary for the implementation of the scheme by early 1972.
Arrangements are being made to implement Britain’s offer, which provides for
duty-free entry from developing countries for practically all industrial goods
and raw materials other than wool textiles and goods subject to revenue
duties, as well as duty-free entry and tariff reductions on a range of processed
agricultural products.
The European Free Trade Association (EFTA) was set up under the Stock¬
holm Convention of January i960 by Austria, Denmark, Norway, Portugal,
Sweden, Switzerland and Britain, with the object of creating an industrial free
trade area between the members and of working towards a wider European
settlement. Under the Convention, protective tariffs and quotas on trade m
industrial products between members of EFTA were to be eliminated by
1st January 1970. The first tariff cuts were made in July i960, and duties were
finally removed (with certain minor exceptions) on 31st December 1966, three
years earlier than originally planned. Finland, which joined EFTA in 1961 as
an associate member, made its final cuts in December 19 7. was e
first completed free trade area in the world and forms a single market of almost
100 million people. Since 1959 intra-EFTA trade has nearly treblef .^hl ®
trade between EFTA and non-member countries has doubled. Iceland joined
EFTA as a full member on 1st March 1970.

A free trade agreement between the United Kingdom and the Republic of
Ireland came into operation on ist July 1966. On that date the United
Kingdom removed all protective import duties on goods of Republic of
Ireland origin imported from that country. After ist July 1975, with certain
exceptions, the Republic of Ireland will not apply any protective duties on
goods of United Kingdom origin.
In August 1961 the British Government applied formally to join the Euro¬
pean Communities but negotiations were suspended in January 1963. A
renewed application for membership was made in May 1967. At the meeting
of the Council of Ministers in December 1967 five of the member states favoured
the opening of negotiations with Britain, but the French Government did not
agree, and the request for accession remained on the Council’s agenda.
At a Community summit meeting at The Hague in December 1969 the
heads of state or government of the Community nations reached agreement and
in a joint communique set out guidelines for the future development of the
Community envisaging its enlargement. Negotiations between the Council of
Ministers and the applicant states, Britain, the Republic of Ireland, Denmark
and Norway were formally opened in Luxembourg on 30th June 1970. By
mid-1971 acceptable solutions had been found to the major questions in the
negotiations with Britain including those of participation in the Community
institutions, transitional arrangements for industry and agriculture, Britain’s
contribution to the Community budget, safeguards for the interests of Com¬
monwealth countries notably the Commonwealth sugar producers and New
Zealand’s dairy and lamb exports, the future of sterling, capital movements and
the arrangements for accession to the European Coal and Steel Community and
Euratom.
In July 1971 the British Government issued The United Kingdom and the
European Communities setting out the main terms of entry and advocating
British membership. Given an affirmative vote in Parliament in the autumn of
1971 the Government foresees a timetable leading to British accession to the
Communities on ist January 1973. Negotiations are continuing with Britain
over certain outstanding matters including the question of fisheries, and
between the Community and the other applicants.
The export trade and virtually all the import trade of the United Kingdom are
conducted by private firms.
Methods of export trading vary considerably, according to the firm, the
industry, the product and the market. A good deal of United Kingdom export
trade, especially of the smaller manufacturing firms, is conducted through
export merchants in the United Kingdom; many firms, however, sell to
importers and consumers abroad through their own agents or resident repre¬
sentatives in the countries concerned; in other cases, sales are made through
a firm’s own branch offices, distributing organisations or subsidiary companies
established in overseas markets.
Similarly, in import trade, many large firms engaged in manufacture or
domestic trade buy directly from overseas suppliers, while smaller firms may
find it more convenient to buy through intermediaries such as import/export
houses, commission agents, and the representatives of overseas firms.
Most of the restrictions imposed on the movement of goods and services
during and immediately after the second world war have been progressively
abolished.

BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL FIANDBOOK
Exchange control is confined mainly to transactions between residents of the
United Kingdom and residents of countries outside the sterling area. The
latter may settle transactions between themselves in sterling, and to comply
with Britain’s obligations to the IMF regarding freedom of current inter¬
national transactions, any sterling held on an external account is freely
convertible into other currencies, including dollars.1
The remaining important restrictions relate to the movement of capital
from the United Kingdom to non-sterling area countries. Because of the
balance of payments deficits, exchange control requirements for investments
outside the sterling area have, since 1961, been revised and made more
stringent although the improving balance of payments position made some
relaxations possible early in 1971. Exports of goods to destinations outside the
sterling area are subject to exchange control and, in general, have to be paid
for within six months in any foreign currency (except Rhodesian currency)
or by sterling from an external account. Control is also exercised over imports
to ensure that currency authorised for their payment is used for that purpose.
There are certain restrictions on dealings in gold bullion and on the use of
gold for manufacturing and industrial purposes. The buying, selling and
holding of gold coins does not require Exchange Control permission, althoug
their export remains controlled.
Exchange control policy is the responsibility of the Treasury, but the
detailed administration is delegated to the Bank of England as agent of the
Treasury; in turn, the Bank of England has delegated to the commercial banks
a wide variety of powers to deal with applications.
Under the Import, Export and Customs Powers (Defence) Act 1939 the
Department of Trade and Industry is empowered to prohibit or regulate the
import or export of goods.
In accordance with its international obligations under the GAT1 and the
IMF the United Kingdom Government has progressively removed quanti¬
tative restrictions from almost all its imports from the countries of the free
world. There has also been a continuing substantial relaxation of quantitative
controls on imports from the Soviet Zone. The very short list of goods on
which controls remain includes some items of special difficulty and a few
where restrictions are recognised internationally, such as arms, ammunition
and radioactive materials. They require a specific import licence and quotas
have been set up for many of them. Some quotas refer specifically to individual
countries and are usually shared out among exporters by the authorities of the
countries concerned. Others are accorded on an overall or global basis, and
are generally allocated by the United Kingdom authorities to United Kingdom
importers, usually on the basis of their share of the trade in the commodity
in the past. Apart from these quantitative controls, some further restrictions
or prohibitions are applied on health grounds (for example, on animals, plants
and drugs). There is also a general import restriction on goods from Rhodesia.
Except for the control necessary to ensure that exports to destinations outsi e
the sterling area are paid for in the proper manner most United Kingdom
exports are not subject to any government control or direction. 1 he few
controls that are in operation are imposed to supervise exports of military
and strategic importance; to conserve materials which may be in short
1 Following the dollar crisis of August 1971, certain special exchange control measures
were taken to discourage speculative inflows of foreign currencies into the United
Kingdom.

supply; to assist exchange control operations in preventing the export of
capital in the form of valuable goods; to ensure the humane treatment of
cattle, sheep and pigs; and to prevent the export of antiques (including
works of art) on grounds of national importance. Normally, individual licences
are required for specific consignments of goods subject to export licensing
control. Goods controlled for strategic reasons, not included in the category
of atomic energy materials and appliances, arms and ammunition, may, with
certain exceptions, be exported to the Commonwealth, the Irish Republic,
the Republic of South Africa and the United States of America without
licence. There is also a general export restriction on goods to Rhodesia.
The British Government1 assists exporters by its efforts to create conditions
favourable to the export trade and by providing credit insurance facilities and
information and advice about opportunities for trade in other countries.
Facilities exist for the repayment of protective duties paid on goods which
have been imported for export trade purposes.
Exporters wanting assistance and advice can consult DTI offices throughout
Britain and, through these offices, the commercial posts of Her Majesty’s
Diplomatic Service overseas. There are over 200 posts located in all the
principal cities and trade centres abroad and they supply the DTI with
information of every kind affecting trade with their territories.
Overseas officers regularly report on local economic and commercial
conditions, pay special attention to local demand for particular commodities,
and generally assist the exporter to overcome any difficulties he encounters
in trade with the country in question, particularly those arising out of govern¬
mental regulations. These officers investigate potential markets for British
products, advise about methods of trading with particular areas, and seek out
and pass on opportunities for export business and enquiries for British goods.
Assistance is also given to United Kingdom exporters in appointing agents
and locating potential importers. From records kept up to date in London by
reports from its overseas commercial officers, the Export Services Division of
the DTI can provide information concerning any country on the prospects
for exports and requirements of particular markets, government regulations
affecting trade (including import restrictions and tariffs and duties on particu¬
lar commodities), methods of trading, local tastes and preferences in design,
and the commercial standing of firms with which an exporter contemplates
business relations.
The Government’s official information services overseas are used exten¬
sively to promote Britain’s export trade.
The Export Credits Guarantee Department (ECGD) is a government
department, responsible to the Secretary of State for Trade and Industry,
which provides insurance for exporters against the main risks in selling over¬
seas, and guarantees to banks providing finance for export credit. It covers
more than a third of the country’s export trade. The ECGD is required to
carry on its business on a self-supporting basis and is therefore not a charge
on the taxpayer.
The risks covered include insolvency or protracted default of the buyer,

United Kingdom exporter, imposition of new import licensing restrictions
in the buyer’s country, war between the buyer’s country and the United
Kingdom, cancellation or non-renewal of a United Kingdom export licence,
additional handling, transport or insurance charges incurred after shipment
through interruption or diversion of voyage or ‘any other cause of loss occur¬

or the buyer, and not normally insurable with commercial insurers’. Cover
may commence from the date of contract or (at lower premiums) from the
date of shipment. . .
Policies may be comprehensive, covering all export business in all markets
(or in an agreed group of markets) on goods sold on six months’ to five years’
credit, or specific, covering large, single capital transactions sold on credit
terms of five years or more.

Over 300 exhibitions, of which about 100 were major trade fairs, were held in
Britain in 1970. Some of the shows attracting the general public, such as the
Boat Show and the Motor Show, are also attended by many trade buyers from
overseas. These exhibitions provide an important means of advertising and
selling British goods. . . .
United Kingdom products are shown at most of the large international
trade fairs throughout the world and United Kingdom manufacturers have
been prominent at the many specialised fairs held in Europe and North
America. Special displays of British consumer goods have also been presented
in hotels in North America and elsewhere.
Participation in trade fairs, ‘British weeks’ and store promotions overseas is
a form of export promotion for which the Government provides information,
financial assistance and, in certain cases, free facilities. (‘British weeks’ differ
from trade fairs and exhibitions in that they are primarily designed to promote
sales of consumer goods in shops overseas.) In 1970 the DTI assisted 6,000
British firms at 286 specialised and general trade fairs in 37 countries; and gave
practical help to 3 ‘British Shopping Weeks’, and to some 57 overseas store
promotions. The amount allocated to the DTI for these purposes has risen
from £60,000 in 1955-56 to £475 million in 1970-71.
A British Export Board has been set up to take over at the beginning of 1972
the full range of export promotional activities formerly divided between the
Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) and the British National Export
Council and its 12 area committees.
The board will direct export intelligence work, the work on trade lairs and
other promotional activity overseas, the schemes for financial support for
firms to participate in missions overseas and for inward commercial visits to
Britain. The board will consist of businessmen and DTI and Foreign and
Commonwealth Office representatives. It will operate under the general
authority of the Minister for Trade who will be the President.
FINANCING OF In the nineteenth century, the rapid growth of British industry, commerce
INTERNATIONAL and shipping under the stimulus of the industrial revolution made Britain
TRADE the market as well as the workshop of the world. It became the site for the
chief world markets in raw materials (see below), freight, insurance and
precious metals. A sound commercial banking system and a flexible system
of central bank control have been built up, while specialised institutions such
as discount houses, merchant banks, accepting houses, the stock exchanges,
TRADE AND PAYMENTS
371
Commodity
Markets
The Foreign
Exchange
Market
The London
Gold Market
The Sterling
System
investment trusts and finance corporations have evolved to satisfy particular
needs for short-term or long-term finance. The facilities provided by merchant
banks and accepting houses, for example, have long been used to finance
shipments of goods not only to and from Britain, but also between other
overseas countries.
At the same time, the banks which were already engaged in financing trade
were able to assist in raising finance for longer-term ventures. British capital
invested in overseas countries has furthered their development, increased
their output and exports, and provided markets for manufactured goods. A
number of specialised institutions help in providing financial services for
overseas countries.
Britain is the traditional centre for marketing many of the world’s basic
commodities. Among the more important are the Baltic Exchange (the market
for shipping and air transport, grain, seeds and vegetable oils), the London
Commodity Exchange (cocoa, coffee, copra, hides and skins, rubber and
sugar), the London Wool Exchange, the London Metal Exchange, the
Liverpool Cotton Exchange and the Liverpool Corn Exchange. A soya bean
oil futures market opened in London in 1967 and a coconut oil futures
market in 1969. These markets not only cater for the import of goods for
home consumption but do much business in effecting transactions between
buyers and sellers in other countries. In addition to these formal markets,
there is scarcely any product which cannot be traded through an intermediary
in Britain. For example, London is the world’s most important philatelic
market and also the leading international centre for the sale of works of art.
The market consists of approximately 195 authorised banks and nine firms
of foreign exchange brokers all linked together by telephone in the United
Kingdom, and by telephone, telex and cable with overseas centres. The
turnover of the market has increased progressively since the introduction in
December 1958 of external convertibility for the principal European currencies.
The Foreign Exchange Market is subject to United Kingdom exchange control
regulations governing the purchase and sale of foreign currencies.
The London Gold Market, which had remained closed from the outbreak of
war in 1939, was reopened in March 1954, under the general supervision
of the Bank of England. All authorised banks may deal in gold but, in practice,
dealings are largely concentrated in the hands of the five members of the gold
market. The five members meet twice daily to fix a price for all transactions
which customers ask to have executed at the fixing.
A gold pool was set up in 1961 to co-ordinate the gold operations in London
(including supplying gold to private buyers) of certain European central banks
and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Following heavy world-wide
speculation in gold at the end of 1967 and the beginning of 1968, the gold pool
was terminated in March 1968. Officially held gold is now used only to effect
transfers between monetary authorities where these are not replacing gold
sold in private markets.
As a result of Britain’s early lead in international trade and finance, several
countries tended not only to use sterling as their natural currency for inter¬
national transactions, but also to maintain central currency reserves in
Britain. When Britain abandoned the gold standard in 1931 these countries,
which came to be known as the ‘sterling bloc’ and later as the ‘sterling area’,
372
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
did likewise, and pegged their currency exchange rates to the pound sterling.
In 1939, after the outbreak of war, the pound sterling was no longer tree y
convertible into other currencies and the sterling area became more formally
defined as a currency area for exchange control purposes. The United
Kingdom imposes no exchange control on transactions with residents of other
sterling area countries though there is a system of voluntary restraint on
capital investment in Australia, New Zealand, the Republic of Ireland and
South Africa. Sterling became convertible again in December 1958 but there
is still exchange control on transactions, effectively capital transactions, wit
the non-sterling area. , \ -
All the Commonwealth countries (except Canada and Rhodesia), together
with Iceland, the Republic of Ireland, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, the Republic o
South Africa, South West Africa, the People’s Republic of Southern Yemen,
and certain States in the Persian Gulf, are members of the sterling area. The
main features of the sterling area are that much of the overseas trade of mem er
countries is financed in sterling, while much of their foreign reserves is he
in sterling. Member countries sell their foreign currency earnings in London
in exchange for sterling and purchase for sterling the foreign currency they
Within the total of the sterling balances there have been considerable
changes in ownership since the second world war, and there have also been
some sizeable fluctuations. Thus the balances of the non-sterling area have
fallen, while the balances of sterling area governments also dropped sigm -
cantly in 1968. This drop led to the series of agreements concluded between
the United Kingdom and the countries of the sterling area in September 19
bv which each country undertook to maintain an agreed proportion ot its
official reserves in sterling, and the United Kingdom undertook to provide
a dollar-value guarantee of the bulk of official sterling holdings.
BALANCE OF PAYMENTS
Estimates of Britain’s balance of payments and its main constituent items are
given in summary since 1964 in Table 26 and in greater detail since 1968 in
Tables 27 and 28. The balance of payments statistics emphasise two indica¬
tors of particular importance. The first is the balance on current account,
covering both visible (exports and imports of goods) and invisible (trade in
services, investment income and transfers) transactions, which provides a
measure of how far Britain is paying its way abroad and thus adding to or using
up overseas assets. (Since 1945 Britain has usually had a deficit on visible trade
and a surplus on invisible earnings.) The second is the total currency flow
This is the net result of all external flows, that is the current account, investment
and other capital flows (including official long-term capital transactions, invest¬
ment flows, trade credit, changes in United Kingdom external banking and
money market liabilities in sterling) and other flows which are unidentified
transactions reflected in the balancing item. The total currency flow shows e
impact of all external flows on the reserves and debt position, that is how muc
is available to add to the reserves and to repay any official borrowing in the case
of a net inflow or how much must be financed by drawing on the reserves or y
borrowing if there is an outflow. Allocation of the IMF Special Drawing
Rights (SDR) and gold subscriptions to the IMF are shown separate y.
Table 28 gives details of the current account since 1968. Both exports and im¬
ports have risen strongly since the devaluation of sterling at the end of 19 7-
In 1968 the value of exports rose strongly but that of imports rose at about the

The total currency flow was outward in each of the years 1963-68 and in¬
ward in 1969 and 1970. In the period 1963-68, there was an outward flow of
/3 778 million (including a gold subscription of £44 nulhon ^ the )
financed mainly by official borrowing totalling £3+34 million, but also by
transfers to the reserves of the dollar portfolio totalling £520 million; and a
reduction of £124 million in the reserves. Approximately one-quarter o
outflow stemmed from current account deficits. In 1969 there was a reversal o
the currency flow, and a rapidly increasing currency inflow reached conside
EXTERNAL
ASSETS AND
LIABILITIES
External
Liabilities
TRADE AND PAYMENTS 375
able proportions in 1970. This inflow continued in the first half of 1971. During
these two and a half years almost all short- and medium-term official borrow¬
ing was repaid, and there was a substantial increase in the reserves.
Britain’s official reserves fluctuated during the 1960s, but stayed on the
whole a little above £1,000 million. In 1970 they began to rise, and in the first
seven months of 1971 rose strongly. By the end of July the reserves had reached
the record level in terms of sterling of £1,613 million which, in dollar terms,
was the highest level since 1945.
Britain is a participant in the Special Drawing Rights scheme which came
into effect in 1970 and which is estimated to have added so far some 5 per cent
to world reserves. Special Drawing Rights are reserve assets created and
distributed by decision of the members of the IMF. Any member of the IMF
may join the scheme, and its share is based on its IMF quota. Participants in
the scheme accept an obligation to provide convertible currency, when desig¬
nated by the IMF to do so, to another participant in exchange for SDRs up to
a total amount equal to twice the net amount of their own allocation of SDRs.
Only those countries with a sufficiently strong balance of payments are so
designated by the IMF. SDRs may also be used in certain direct payments be¬
tween participants in the scheme and for payments of various kinds to the IMF.
In recent years the United Kingdom has incurred short- and medium-term
debt to cushion the reserves against currency outflows. Britain has drawing
rights in the IMF based on its IMF quota which was raised at the end of 1970
to $2,800 million (£1,166 million). Britain is able to make drawings, subject to
certain conditions, up to 125 per cent of the value of its quota, and has made
such drawings on several occasions.
Britain has also taken part since 1961 in the international network of re¬
ciprocal credit (swap) facilities arranged between central banks. Facilities
available to the United Kingdom include one of $2,000 million (£833 million)
with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Under these arrangements each
central bank is able to exchange on request its own currency for the currency
of another country up to a maximum agreed for a limited period. It agrees to
reverse the transaction at a specified date at the same rate of exchange. The
currencies so obtained can be retained in the reserves or used in exchange
operations.
United Kingdom official short- and medium-term debt outstanding at the
end of August 1971 was £417 million all of which represented outstanding
drawings from the IMF. Thus, by August, the short- and medium-teim debt
had been reduced by £2,946 million from the peak of £3,363 million reached
at the end of December 1968.
The significance of any inventory of Britain’s aggregate external assets and
liabilities1 is limited because a variety of claims and obligations are included
that are very dissimilar in kind, in degree of liquidity and in method of valua¬
tion. The inventory for the end of 1970 shows that Britain had a substantial
net creditor position estimated at some £3,600 million.
Identified external liabilities at the end of 1970 totalled some £16,970 million,
against assets of about £20,525 million. Total official short- and medium-term
liabilities to the IMF and other monetary authorities were £1,369 million.

£353 million to Canada. Other public sector liabilities of £2,557 million com¬
prised overseas holdings of United Kingdom government and public corpora¬

totalled £3,892 million.1 Liabilities in the form of overseas investment in the

Liabilities in sterling comprise both public sector and banking and money-
market liabilities within the totals above. Sterling held in the United Kingdom
by foreigners in the form of bank deposits, deposits with local authorities and
hire purchase companies, Treasury Bills and British Government securities
(where these were held by central monetary institutions and international
organisations other than the IMF) totalled £4,289 million at the end of March
1971. Of this, £679 million was held by residents of the non-sterling area and
£3,610 million by residents of the sterling area. The total of these liabilities
(excluding the counterpart of borrowing) has remained broadly constant since
the end of the second world war. They reflect the international trading and
reserve role of sterling and in part the financial services of the City.
Overseas liabilities arising from investment in the private sector of the British
economy rose from £3,165 million in 1962 to £7,185 million at the end of 1970.
Overseas investors in Britain are free to repatriate the proceeds of the sale
of their investments, including any capital gains that they may have accrued.
Earnings and dividends are transferable irrespective of their size. In 1970
the inflow of direct, portfolio and other private investment, including oil,
amounted to £727 million.
The value of overseas investment in the United Kingdom private sector at
the end of 1970 comprised: the book value of direct investment in Britain by
companies incorporated abroad—£3,300 million (excluding oil, banking, and
insurance); portfolio holdings of British securities—£2,100 million; the book
value of the net assets in Britain of overseas oil companies—£1,350 million;
and the balance of £435 million which included borrowing by United King¬
dom companies overseas and identified investment in real estate and in the
insurance industry in Britain.
About three-quarters of the direct investment of £3,300 million came from
North America and about one-fifth from Western Europe. Of the £317 million
inflow of direct investment into Britain in 1970 £303 million originated in the
non-sterling area and £14 million from the overseas sterling area. Foreign
investment inflow presents British industry with many opportunities to match
new competitive standards which in turn will strengthen the economy and its
balance of payments position.
Private investment abroad may take several forms: portfolio investment, that
is, investment in overseas securities including the loans raised by overseas
countries on the London capital market; or direct investment by the establish¬
ment of subsidiary companies abroad; or by acquiring an interest in an over¬
seas enterprise.

Although investment in the developing countries of the sterling area is in
general free from control, proposals to invest in Australia, South Africa, New
Zealand and the Republic of Ireland are, under the voluntary programme, dis¬
cussed with the Bank of England. Approval is readily given for financing pro¬
jects both in these countries and in the non-sterling area by borrowing abroad on
appropriate terms, and for financing from Britain where the project is expected
to yield substantial and continuing benefits to the United Kingdom balance
of payments. There is also considerable scope for the investment of retained
profits of subsidiary companies overseas and in recent years more than 60 per
cent of net direct investment outflow has been financed in this way from un¬
remitted profits.
Estimates prepared by the Department of Trade and Industry show that
direct investment outflow, excluding oil, was £547 million in 1969, ^311
million of this being placed in the overseas sterling area and £236 million in
non-sterling countries. Within the latter figure the flow to the EEC area was
^105 million, to EFTA ^14 million and to Latin America £21 million. In the
same year the flow to Western Europe of £139 million was more than twice the
flow to North America of £54 million. Direct investment outflow (excluding oil)
in 1970 was below the 1969 level, although still substantial at £486 million.
With the inclusion of oil, portfolio and other investment aggregate private
investment outflow in 1970 totalled ^714 million.
Britain’s assets arising from private investment overseas are estimated to have
been £14,400 million at the end of 1970. This compares with a figure of
£8,070 million at the end of 1962. Direct investment, including oil, accounted
for £8,950 million of the £14,400 million figure, the balance consisting of
£5,450 million of portfolio investment.
United Kingdom banking and commercial claims at the end of 1970 totalled
£3,607 million. Within this total banking claims in sterling and overseas
sterling area currencies were £1,905 million; suppliers’ export credit to un¬
related firms was £1,303 million. With the increase in recent years in British
aid to developing countries, inter-governmental loans of £874 million form the
largest item among official external assets, which at the end of 1970 were
£1,341 million. The latter figure, together with official reserves of £1,178
million, £3,607 million in banking and commercial claims and private invest¬
ment overseas of £14,400 million resulted in aggregate identified external
assets at the end of 1970 of £20,525 million.
Britain’s aid programme to the developing countries consists of loans and
grants for economic and social development, technical assistance, budget
support and contributions to multilateral agencies providing financial aid and
technical assistance to these countries. In addition to this official aid pro¬
gramme, an important contribution is made to economic development by
private investment and by private voluntary organisations engaged in relief,
development and educational work.
Since 1945 total official aid disbursements have amounted to nearly £3,000
million. The average gross annual disbursement over the four years 1967-70
was about £212 million (see Table 29). In 1970 the total was nearly £219
million, of which bilateral aid accounted for £199 million including £46
million technical assistance; assistance provided through multilateral agencies
was £20 million. Repayments of capital and payments of interest during the
year on loans made previously totalled about £59 million. The strategy for the
Second UN Development Decade, adopted in 1970, included a recommenda-

GNP in 1969 and, provisionally, in 1970. The Government does not accept the
need for a separate target for official aid, though it has announced its intention
to maintain official aid as a substantial part of total flows. Private investment is
also expected to play a major part.

Total net British official and private flows in 1970 amounted to 1-03 per cent
of gross national product; official flows were 0-37 per cent. Public expenditure
on economic aid is to be progressively raised from £245 million in 1971-72 to
^340 million in i974~75* This represents gross official flows only, the volume
of private flows, although influenced by government policies, is not determined
by the Government and is difficult to predict, as also is the future level of the
gross national product.
Bilateral Bilateral financial aid in 197° totalled ^199 million; over 43 per cent was in
Financial Aid grants and the rest in loans. Budgetary aid, £$ million in 1970, is provided in
the form of grants. Development aid is in grants or loans, depending on the
economic and constitutional circumstances of the recipient countries; the
greater part of it is in loans. The terms of new development loans from Britain
have been progressively softened since 1958 and a policy of making interest-
free loans to lighten the repayment burdens of the poorer developing countries
was introduced in June 1965* *97® ^*e total value of loan commitments
entered into by the British Government, excluding investments by the
Commonwealth Development Corporation (see below), was ^94 million and
of this over 94 per cent was on interest-free terms. The recipients included
India, Pakistan, Mauritius, Ghana, Turkey, Guyana, Ceylon and Indonesia.

379
Commonwealth
Countries
Technical
Assistance
Where loans bear interest it is at fixed concessionary rates ranging from 2
per cent to 7^ per cent, and both kinds of loan may carry grace periods during
which repayments of capital are not made. Of all loans committed in 1970,
99 per cent by value carried grace periods averaging 6 years for capital repay¬
ments while the weighted average maturity of loans was 25 years. Britain more
than fulfils the recommendations of the Development Assistance Committee
of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD),
made in February 1969, on easing the terms of financial aid.
Loans and grants are tied to the purchase of goods, equipment and services
from Britain, although there may be a limited element for local costs and for
procurement from third countries in appropriate cases. Between 1958 and the
end of 1970, 307 loans were negotiated involving a commitment of £910
million, of which £768 million has been disbursed. The recipients of the
largest amounts have been India and Pakistan. During the same period
bilateral grants amounted to around £975 million.
Historically, Britain’s aid programme began as part of the discharge of its
responsibilities towards dependent territories, and the main emphasis
remains on Commonwealth countries. In 1970 £176 million (89 per cent) of
the bilateral programme was disbursed to Commonwealth countries and
dependencies.
In the past, development aid to the dependent territories was given under
the Colonial Development and Welfare (CD & W) Acts, largely in the form
of grants but also in loans. When CD & W legislation terminated on 31st
March 1970, the total amount committed under it was nearly £486 million.
The aid requirements of the remaining dependencies, which are regarded
as a first charge on aid funds, will be provided under the authority of the
Overseas Aid Act 1966. In 1970 the territories received £18 million in
bilateral financial aid and technical assistance (9 per cent of the bilateral
programme), including about £9 million under the CD & W Acts.
An important role in development assistance is played by the Common¬
wealth Development Corporation (CDC), set up by the British Government
in 1948, which provides finance and management for development projects
in Commonwealth countries and dependencies, often in partnership with
governments or private enterprise. In 1970 the CDC’s borrowing powers
were increased and the area of its operations was extended to non-Common-
wealth countries. By the end of 1970 some £138 million had been invested
out of a total commitment of ^172 million. Of the latter, £30 million was in
the Far East, £41 million in the Caribbean and virtually all of the remainder
in Africa. New investment approved in 1970 totalled over £17 million.
Expenditure on bilateral technical assistance (the provision of skilled person¬
nel, advice and training) has increased in recent years and was £46 million,
21 per cent of total aid, in 1970. The largest component of expenditure (£23-8
million in 1970) was on sending or maintaining experts, including volunteers;
the next largest was for students and trainees in Britain (£8-4 million).
Under the Overseas Service Aid Scheme (OSAS) and associated schemes
Britain meets the additional costs of employing experienced expatriate British
personnel in the public services of developing countries. The schemes cost
£15 million in 1970.
At the end of 1970, of the 11,621 British persons other than volunteers who
were working in developing countries and financed by the British Govern¬
ment, some 4,929 were engaged in the field of education, 2,536 in public
380
Multilateral
Contributions
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
works and communications, 1,284 in public administration, 956 in agri¬
culture and allied fields, and 990 in health services.
In addition, the British Volunteer Programme has continued to expand (the
first volunteers were sent overseas in 1958) and in 1970 there were 2,130
volunteers, mainly graduates or otherwise qualified, working in developing
countries, the majority of them teaching. Recruitment, training and placing
overseas is undertaken by a number of voluntary bodies; 75 per cent of the
British costs (£0-9 million in 1970) are met by the British Government.
Britain receives large numbers of students and trainees from developing
countries. Over 12,056 were financed in Britain in 197° under regional
programmes of technical assistance, by awards under the Commonwealth
Education Co-operation Scholarships and Bursary Schemes, and under the
various schemes of the British Council.
Britain is the second largest contributor (after the United States) to the
World Bank group of institutions—the International Bank for Reconstruction
and Development, the International Finance Corporation and the Inter¬
national Development Association (IDA). The British commitment to IDA
in the three years 1968-70 was nearly £65 million; the proposed contribution
for the three years 1971-73 is nearly £130 million. Britain has contributed, or
has agreed to contribute, to the Asian Development Bank, the Inter-American
Development Bank, the Caribbean Development Bank and the African
Development Bank. Britain has contributed £52 million to the United Nations
Development Programme since its inception in 1950 and has provided more
experts and training places under multilateral schemes than any other country.
Some 1,321 British nationals were serving in developing countries under the
United Nations and its specialised agencies in 1970. Other contributions
include those to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine
Refugees (UNRWA), the World Food Programme and the United Nations
Children’s Fund (UNICEF).
INTERNAL TRADE
Britain’s internal trade can be divided into two broad categories: trade in raw
materials, capital goods and intermediate products (for example, vehicle
components) and trade in consumer goods, involving the network of distribu¬
tive trades by which home produced or imported goods reach the consumer.
(For the pattern of consumers’ expenditure, see p. 199.)
The latest estimates of the value of trade flows at current prices, to inter¬
mediate as well as final customers, show total sales of goods and services to
intermediate buyers amounting to -£26,616 million and total sales to final
buyers of £47,154 million, divided between private consumption (£23,129
million), public authorities’ current expenditure (£7,373 million), gross
domestic capital formation (£7,928 million) and exports (£8,723 million).
The metals, metal goods, mining and chemical industries sold predominantly to
intermediate buyers. The engineering industries sold mainly components to
intermediate buyers and capital goods to final buyers. About 70 per cent of the
output of the textile industries was divided almost equally between inter¬
mediate buyers and private consumption, while over a quarter went to exports.
Agricultural output was divided equally between intermediate buyers and
final buyers (mainly private consumption), while the food and clothing
industries sold predominantly for private consumption.
There have been a number of official statistical enquiries into the distributive
TRADE AND PAYMENTS
WHOLESALE
TRADES
RETAIL TRADE
Types of
Retailers
38i
trades. The latest censuses taken in Great Britain refer to the wholesale trades
in 1965 and the retail trades and certain service trades in 1966. Sample
monthly and annual enquiries are also undertaken, covering such aspects of
the distributive trades as turnover, stocks and capital expenditure. Most of the
figures given in the following pages derive from either the last published
censuses or the sample enquiries. A full census of distribution is to be taken in
1972 for the year 1971.
The first census of retail distribution and other services to be taken in
Northern Ireland relates to 1965 (see p. 384).
Only a proportion of the trade in consumer goods passes through wholesalers:
sales are also made to consumers through producers’ own selling organisations
(including their own retail outlets and mail order businesses); and other sales
are made directly by producers to retailers. The 1965 enquiry showed that a
total of 23,643 business units were engaged in wholesale distribution in Great
Britain; 3,435 dealt in clothing, footwear and textiles, 2,007 in grocery and
provisions, 2,630 in vegetables and fruit, and 3,469 in other food and in drink.
In addition, there were 8,282 dealers (wholesale or retail) in coal, builders’
materials, grain or agricultural supplies, and 9,117 dealers in other industrial
materials and machinery. The value of stocks held by wholesalers and dealers
at the end of 1970 is estimated at £1,670 million; expenditure on capital assets
during the year was about £124 million.
Methods of wholesale distribution vary according to the type of merchandise
handled. Fish, for example, is auctioned at the ports to port wholesalers (who
sell to inland wholesalers at the main distribution centres) or, increasingly, is
sold by contract to fryers and processors, or direct to retailers. Fruit and
vegetables may be sold by growers to commission agents (who dispose of the
produce either to wholesalers or direct to retailers) or the grower may deal
only with wholesale firms. The sale of some agricultural products is regulated
by statutory marketing boards (see p. 273).
London’s wholesale markets play a leading part in the distribution of
foodstuffs, particularly imported supplies. Every year Covent Garden (see
p. 277) handles about i*2 million tons of fruit and vegetables, and over
340,000 tons of meat and poultry pass through Smithfield market; Billingsgate
is the principal distributing centre for fish. Others in London include Leaden-
hall Market (poultry) and Spitalfields Market (fruit and vegetables).
The co-operative movement in Britain has established its own wholesale
societies, the two largest being the Co-operative Wholesale Society Ltd.
(CWS) and the Scottish Co-operative Wholesale Society Ltd. (SOWS), to
serve the needs of retail societies, membership being restricted to incorporated
co-operative organisations. The CWS had sales of £535 million in 1970 and
the SCWS had sales of some £82 million.
Since the early 1950s, many wholesalers have joined, either singly or in
groups, with numbers of retailers to form voluntary groups to help to preserve
the existence of retail outlets for the wholesaler and to give to retailers the
advantages of the lower costs of large-scale trading without significant loss of
independence. The 1966 Census of Distribution showed that about 27 per
cent of the turnover of independent grocers was attributable to wholesaler-
sponsored voluntary groups and chains.
Retail businesses in Britain may be classified under four headings: (1) multiple
traders with ten or more branches; (2) retail co-operative societies (see below);
(3) independent retail businesses, including for this purpose the small multiple
stores (that is, chains of stores with nine or fewer branches) and (4) department
382
Multiples and
Large Establish¬
ments
Retail

Societies
Independent Shops
Department Stores
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
stores. Other retail outlets include gas and electricity showrooms owned by the
area gas and electricity boards, and mail order houses (see p. 383).
The findings of the 1966 Census of Distribution (Table 30) show that, in
comparison with 1961, a larger volume of trade had been handled by rather
fewer shops. A notable feature is the continuing expansion of large multiple
firms relative to other types of shop. Independent shops, however, still account
for over half of Britain’s retail trade.
A very wide range is covered in the size of retailing establishments. Four
shops had sales in 1966 exceeding £10 million (equivalent to takings of more
than £4,000 an hour) at the other extreme there were more than 16,000 shops
with sales of less than £200 a week. In addition there were market and street
traders, whose volume of business may be very small.
According to the Census of Distribution there were nearly 74,000 shops
owned by multiples (including multiple department stores) in 1966 with
a total turnover of nearly £4,000 million. This form of organisation showed the
largest rise in numbers between 1961 and 1966 and their share in total sales
went up from 29 per cent to 34 per cent. Their turnover increased faster than
that of independent businesses between 1966 and 1970, and in 1970 their
share of total sales rose to over 36 per cent.
The share in total retail trade of co-operative stores dropped from 11 to 9 per
cent between 1961 and 1966 which was rather less than the relative decrease in
the number of stores. Between 1966 and 1970 their turnover increased slightly.
The retail co-operative societies are voluntary organisations controlled
by their members. Membership is open to anyone paying a small deposit
on a minimum share, which entitles the member to an equal voice with other
members in the society. Share investment by individual members is limited
to £1,000 (less in some societies) and only a low rate of interest is normally
paid on the shares.
In the past the trading surplus, after allocation to reserves and common
activities, has been paid out periodically to members in the form of a dividend
in proportion to their purchases. Some societies have used a system of
differential dividends by reducing prices in some departments such as food¬
stuffs. More recently a large number of societies, accounting for four-fifths of
total co-operative sales, have introduced dividend stamps redeemable for cash,
other goods, or credit to a share account, at different redemption rates.
At the end of 1970 there were about 400 retail co-operative societies.
Amalgamations are rapidly diminishing the number of societies (the total in
1958 was 1,015). The largest single society in Britain is the London Co¬
operative Society with 1-15 million members and a turnover of £90 million in
1970. Total sales of the retail co-operative societies in 1970 amounted to over
£1,100 million and accounted for 7-5 per cent of total retail trade compared
with 11 per cent in 1961.
Independent shops have been giving ground gradually in the face of increased
competition from the larger undertakings. The proprietors of many of the
smaller shops often have other means of livelihood. Average turnover per shop
has continued to increase, though by less than for the retail trade as a whole.
None the less, even allowing for a 15 per cent increase in prices, the average
independent shop sold more goods in 1966 than in 1961.
There were 760 department stores in Britain in 1966 with a turnover of
£653 million; 214 were owned by multiples and 308 by independents.
Department stores were defined for the purposes of the census as having 25 or

more persons engaged in selling a wide range of commodities notably clothing
and household goods. Co-operative societies owned a further 238 department
stores in 1966, with a turnover of ^118 million.
Out of a total of over 500,000 establishments recorded by the 1966 Census
of Distribution, and shown in Table 30, grocery and other food retailing
groups numbered over 227,000 establishments, and the clothing and foot¬
wear group over 83,000.
Though the total value of retail trade in Great Britain (inclusive of electricity
and gas showrooms and mail order business) rose by a quarter between 1961
and 1966, rates of growth (measured in turnover) varied appreciably between
different types of trade although, because of the mixed nature of some of the
businesses, this does not necessarily reflect the growth of the sales of com¬
modities in which these shops specialise. The slowest growth was in general
stores, in the food and clothing sectors, and department stores. The fastest
growth was in radio and television hire, mail order business, gas and electricity
showroom sales of durable goods, sports and leisure equipment, chemists
and photographic goods and sales of automatic vending machines.

However, the actual trends are blurred by the introduction into specialised
shops of other specialities, for example, clothing multiples opening food
sections, and vice versa. Though gas and electricity showroom business was
buoyant between 1961 and 1966, their combined turnover is relatively small,
amounting in 1966 to £186 million.
The real expansion in the volume of sales in Great Britain between 1961 and
1966, taking into account the exclusion of market traders (included in the 1961
Census) and a general increase in prices of 15 per cent, was about 9-6 per cent,
or an average of 1 -9 per cent a year. Sales by all kinds of retail business

increased in real terms by 4*2 per cent between 1966 and 1970, when they were
valued at some £14,000 million.
The Northern Ireland 1965 Census of Retail Distribution and Other
Services shows total spending of £385 million through 22,000 establishments.
The value increased by 20 per cent between 1965 and 1970.
The development of self-service trading has been a feature of the last two
decades. In 1969 there were some 23,000 stores operating wholly or partly
on self-service lines, compared with about 9,500 towards the end of 1961 and
less than 500 in 1950. This development has been accompanied by a trend to
larger shops in terms of both staff and floor space.
Supermarkets may be defined as self-service shops with a minimum selling
area of 2,000 square feet. There were about 870 supermarkets in 1961, accord¬
ing to the Census of Distribution, of which 524 were owned by multiples,
308 by co-operative societies and 38 by independents. It has been estimated
that by the end of 1969 over 3,300 had been opened and were handling some
25 per cent of Britain’s retail grocery trade.
New forms of automatic vending machines have come to the fore since 1955.
Over 400,000 machines are in use. Sales from automatic vending machines
totalled nearly £170 million in 1970; about £100 million was accounted for by
sales from cigarette machines. Machines now sell not only cigarettes, sweets
and stamps but also hot and cold beverages (about £35 million), prepared
foodstuffs, stockings, paper-back books and other commodities, including
various types of fuel. Another form is the self-service petrol pump. Organisa¬
tions selling automatic vending machines (not otherwise engaged in retail
trade) numbered 56 in 1966, with sales of nearly £11 million.
Some 11,700 mobile shops1 were reported in the Census of Distribution for
1961, with sales amounting to £93 million. Nearly a quarter of this turnover
was concentrated in Scotland (where the density of population is lower than
in England) compared with a tenth of all retail sales. Co-operative societies
accounted for 39 per cent of sales through mobile food shops, against 16 per
cent in ordinary food shops. For the most part, mobile shops were concerned
with food sales; about 42 per cent were travelling grocers, and over 28 per cent
and 21 per cent respectively were greengrocers and butchers. Only a very
small proportion (about 6 per cent) were non-food shops, and these specialised
mainly in paraffin supplies and hardware.
A number of large ‘out of town’ stores are being opened, providing a range
of goods under one roof, associated with extensive car parking facilities, away
from established central shopping areas.
‘Cash and Carry’ shops represent a combination of retail supermarkets and
wholesale warehouses covering practically every form of retail trade. By bulk
purchasing and little spending on attractive surroundings or credit facilities
they can offer large price discounts to retail customers. The numbers of this
type of store have grown rapidly from 400 in 1967 to an estimated 550 in May
1971, with a turnover of some £500 million a year.
All forms of consumer sales promotion have been expanding, including
reduced price offers, competitions, gift schemes, and stamp trading. The

stamps can be exchanged for goods but, by law, have to be marked with their
cash value and redeemed for cash on request.
A facility which is spreading in Britain is the ‘credit card’. Users are issued
with a card on production of which their signature is accepted on bills in
participating shops, hotels and restaurants. The issuers then meet the bills and
recover from the card-holder through a single account presented periodically.
Users of certain cards are also required to pay a regular subscription.
Mail order trading has been one of the most rapidly growing forms of selling
in Britain in recent years. The 1966 Census of Distribution showed that the
sales of retail mail order businesses had almost doubled in five years from
£227 million to £429 million. Turnover continued to rise steadily between
1966 and 1970. Between 1950 (when sales totalled £46 million) and 1970 their
share of total trade rose from 1 per cent to 4 per cent.
Sales by manufacturers direct to the public totalled ^144 million in 1961,
compared with £70 million in 1950. Mail order sales accounted for 24 per
cent of the former total, sales to employees for 11 per cent, and charges for
work done for 9 per cent. Other direct sales, including sales by door-to-door
salesmen, accounted for the balance. Included in these sales were items as
various as carpets, washing machines, brushes, books and soft drinks.
The Direct Sales and Service Association consists of 18 companies which
sell all their products directly to the consumers. Sales by members of the
association amounted to about £300 million in 1970.
Closely connected with the distributive trades are those which offer a service
directly to the public, notably catering and hotel trades, laundries and dry
cleaners, garage and motor repair trades, hairdressers and boot and shoe
repairers.
In 1964 there were 149,000 establishments primarily concerned with catering
(defined to cover public houses, canteens and fish and chip shops, as well as
licensed hotels and restaurants, etc.) with a total turnover in that year of nearly
£2,000 million. Hotels and holiday camps (excluding boarding houses and
unlicensed hotels) had receipts of about £286 million, of which £124 million
was from residential accommodation; in addition over £100 million was spent
on accommodation in unlicensed hotels and boarding houses. Nearly half the
total turnover of the catering trades was from the sale of alcoholic drinks.
Between 1964 and 1970 the catering trades’ turnover increased by 36 per cent,
rising by 8 per cent in 1970 alone. In addition coin-operated machines are
being widely installed in factories—some 60,000 beverage and snack machines
are estimated to have been provided in industrial sites—and in commercial
premises as well as in normal retail outlets.
There were about 5,600 commercial laundries, launderettes, linen and overalls
hire businesses and dry cleaning businesses with an annual turnover of £170
million in 1966. Between 1961 and 1966 turnover increased by 53 per cent
with particularly marked growth in launderettes and linen and overalls hire.
Between 1966 and 1970 turnover of this group, other than launderettes and
coin-operated dry cleaning establishments, rose by only 4 per cent.
There were nearly 43,000 businesses in the motor trades in Britain in 1967
with 51,000 establishments. Total turnover amounted to £4,198 million.
Traders classified as new vehicle dealers had nearly 14,000 establishments
and accounted for over two-thirds of total turnover. By 1970 there were some

23,000 motor repair and service traders, many of whom also supplied petrol,
oil and accessories. Between 1967 and 1970 the motor trades turnover has
increased by about 26 per cent. Sales during 1970 rose by 13-5 per cent to some
£5,300 million, of which sales of new vehicles accounted for some 34 per cent,
sales of second-hand vehicles for 16 per cent and other sales (including an
estimated £600 million for servicing and repair work) for the remainder.
Takings in hairdressing establishments increased very rapidly between 1950
(£38 million) and 1961 (£97 million), and between 1961 and 1966 to £136
million but between 1966 and 1970 they rose by only 5 per cent. In 1966 there
were about 48,000 hairdressing establishments.
There are some 8,700 establishments specialising in boot and shoe repairs
(excluding repairs handled through footwear shops); they had takings of £26
million in 1966.
Other establishments found in shopping areas and offering a service to the
public include those of radio and television rental companies (over 3,800
shops), about 15,500 licensed betting offices and over 3,500 funeral under¬
taking businesses.
British industry’s expenditure on packaging in 1970 has been estimated at
about £900 million, a rise of some 12 per cent over the 1969 level. The expan¬
sion of self-service shops, the spread of branded and standardised products,
and developments in partly prepared foods, for example, ready-washed vege¬
tables and ready-made cake mixes, have been major factors in the great changes
which have taken place in packaging methods. Paper packaging, including
cartons and boxes, remains the most extensively used (turnover of some £346
million a year), the fastest growing sector being paper sacks. Paper and board
account for about 38 per cent of packaging material sales, followed by tinplate
(20 per cent), plastics (13 per cent), glass (9 per cent), cellulose film (4 per cent)
and aluminium foil (3 per cent). New uses are being found for tinplate (output,
8,000 million cans in 1970), especially in sales of soft drinks and beer. Output
of aerosols rose by 20 per cent to 304 million units in 1970. Glass, aluminium
foil and plastics packaging account for about £83 million, £30 million and £120
million a year respectively. The use of plastics continues to develop; output of
plastics films is some 72,000 tons per year and that of polypropylene, and other
film, about 12,500 tons, while some 25,000 tons of low-density polythene
are used for bottles.
Hire-purchase The rapid growth of sales of household and durable consumer goods, such
Sales as cars, furniture, washing machines, television sets, refrigerators and cookers,
has been greatly helped by instalment purchase. Instalment credit debt
outstanding to the main providers amounted to £1,356 million1 at the end of
March 1971; nearly three-quarters was owed to finance companies and the
remainder to durable goods shops and department stores. A few finance
companies which operate on a national scale account for a high proportion of
the total business.
The DTI has powers to regulate the terms of hire-purchase, credit sales
and rental agreements in order to restrain the expansion of consumer credit.
In July 1971 all restrictions on terms were removed.

Hire-purchase in Northern Ireland directly financed by the major finance

About £525 million is estimated to have been spent on all forms of advertising
in 1970; as a proportion of the gross national product (1 *2 per cent) and of con¬
sumer expenditure (17 per cent), it has fallen slightly over the last ten years.
About £365 million was expended on press advertising and £125 million
(including tax) was spent on television advertising. The remainder was divided
between posters, films, and radio. Most of the advertising is carried out by
advertising agencies, which, in some cases, also provide marketing, consumer
research and other services; their representative organisation is the Institute of
Practitioners in Advertising. The trade association for the industry as a whole,
including agencies, advertisers and owners of advertising media, is the Advertis¬
ing Association. It was responsible for the setting up of the Advertising
Standards Authority, an independent body whose objective is the promotion
and enforcement of the highest standards of advertising, in particular through
the British Code of Advertising Practice.
Industry and commerce have in recent years paid increasing attention to
improving public understanding of their work and objectives. Public relations
consultancy firms and the public relations departments of advertising agencies
provide general services, apart from the increasing employment by industrial
organisations and trade associations of staff specialists in public relations.
Their professional body, founded in 1948, is the Institute of Public Relations;
not only commerce and industry, but the professions, national associations,
central and local government are represented within the Institute.
Various legislative measures exist in the United Kingdom to protect the
consumer against specific abuses. The most important are the Weights and
Measures Act 1963 and the Trade Descriptions Act 1968 (dealing with mis¬
description of goods and services) both of which are enforced by local weights
and measures authorities; the Food and Drugs Acts 1955 and 1956 which
control the purity, hygiene and description of food and are enforced by local
food and drugs authorities; and the Consumer Protection Act 1961 which
empowers the Government to make regulations to ensure the safety of any
class of goods.
The Hire-Purchase Act 1965 and the Hire-Purchase (Scotland) Act 1965
provide safeguards to the consumer who buys goods on hire-purchase or
credit sale terms. The protection extends to agreements up to £2,000 although
most of the safeguards do not apply to credit sale agreements for less than ^30.
Similar legislation operates in Northern Ireland. As a precaution against
fraud, virtually every hire-purchase agreement on a car is registered with
H.P. Information Ltd., a non-profit-making company whose members are car
dealers or finance companies concerned with car sales; dealers and finance
houses can check with it in confidence.
The British Standards Institution (see p. 211) has established a number of
standards for consumer goods, and the Council of Industrial Design (see
p. 211) helps to foster improvements in the design of consumer goods.
A number of private organisations exist to further the consumer’s interests.
The largest is the Consumers’ Association (CA) with a membership of over
600,000. CA pursues problems of general consumer interest and conducts an
388
Resale Price
Maintenance
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
extensive programme of comparative testing of goods bought on the open
market. The association’s views and test reports are published in its monthly
bulletin Which?, issued to members.
Work of this kind is also carried out by some 80 local consumer groups,
whose representative body is the National Federation of Consumer Groups.
Other private consumer organisations include the Housewife’s Trust and
the Research Institute for Consumer Affairs. A general advisory service
dealing with individual consumers’ problems is provided by the Citizens’
Advice Bureaux (see p. 124).
The practice of resale price maintenance and its enforcement by cutting off
supplies was made unlawful under the Resale Prices Act 1964; some limited
exemptions for certain classes of goods (notably pharmaceuticals) have been
granted by the Restrictive Practices Court (see p. 202).
17 LABOUR
Less than 200 years ago, government concern with all aspects of employment
was at a minimum. State intervention came first in the sphere of safety, health
and welfare. The first factory legislation was enacted in 1802. The first
effective Factory Act was that of 1833 which set up a national system of
inspection to enforce its provisions. Trade unions—forbidden in the eighteenth
and early nineteenth centuries as a threat to civil peace and individual liberty
-—ceased in 1824 to be ‘actionable conspiracies in restraint of trade’. During
the nineteenth century new unions of skilled and semi-skilled workers grew
up, more soundly organised than their forerunners and more acceptable to the
public because their ambitions were more restricted. A number of employers’
associations, mainly local, were formed; unions and employers learned to
bargain together; and procedures for conciliation and arbitration began to be
agreed. Legislation passed in the 1870s clarified and regularised the legal
status of trade unions. In 1910, the first employment exchanges were intro¬
duced to provide a national service for putting employers in touch with
workers and vice versa. In 1917 the exchanges were transferred to the newly
created Ministry of Labour, which also became responsible for arranging or
providing certain conciliation and arbitration services on request. The
factory inspectorate was added to its responsibilities in 1940. This department
became the principal instrument of the Government’s labour policies in
Great Britain; it was re-named Department of Employment and Productivity
in 1968 and the Department of Employment (DE) in 1970; it is principally
responsible for industrial relations, pay policy, employment, training and
related manpower questions (see p. 51). In Northern Ireland employment
matters are among the responsibilities of the Ministry of Health and Social
Services.
MANPOWER
The total working population of Great Britain at the middle of June 1970 was
about 25 million, about 46 per cent of the total population, and included
about 73 per cent of persons of normal working age (15 to 59 years for women,
15 to 64 years for men). About 91 per cent of the men of working age are
today in or seeking gainful work. The remaining 9 per cent consist mainly of
those continuing their education, of the severely disabled and of some persons
of private means. The proportion of women of working age in or seeking
gainful work is much lower, about 53 per cent, as many housewives either do
not wish or cannot manage to take employment outside the home. Nearly 62
per cent of the women at work are married. Besides those of normal working
age, there are over a million older men and women still at work. The great
majority of the working population work for a wage or salary, but about 1 *7
million are employers or self-employed.
Northern Ireland, which has 27 per cent of the total population of the
United Kingdom, has 2*3 per cent of its working population. The ratio of
working to total population in Northern Ireland is about 39 per cent, and
39°
