farmers and smallholders working their own holdings account for about
one-twelfth of the working population.
The working population increased slowly until 1966, and has since fallen
mainly because of the lower pressure of demand for labour and the increased
numbers in full-time education. Because of demographic factors and the
rising demands for higher education, the working population is unlikely to
increase much above the 1966 levels before the mid-1970s, even if the pressure
of demand for labour were as high as in 1966. The raising of the minimum
school-leaving age in 1972-73 is expected to result in a sharp fall in the working
population during the following year.
Though successful development policies in the less-prosperous regions may
raise the numbers above the levels forecast, it is clear that increasing demand
for labour must be met by better deployment of manpower and improved
productivity. Married women form the only substantial reserve and the
Government is studying the nature of the obstacles to employing those who
are willing to work and how they may be overcome.
The industrial distribution of employees in civil employment is shown in
Table 31. Of all employees about 41 per cent are employed in the mining and
manufacturing industries and only about 2 per cent in agriculture and
fisheries. Over 57 per cent of those in manufacturing are in the metal, en¬
gineering, vehicles and chemicals groups of industries.

Most industries employ women as well as men though not always for the
same types of work, for example, few women are managers and few personal
secretaries are men. It is illegal to employ women in certain jobs, such as
underground work in coal mines. The industrial groups in which women are
chiefly employed are: the metal-using industries; the manufacture of textiles
and clothing; the food, drink and tobacco industries; the distributive trades;
and professional and miscellaneous services.

The numbers given in Table 32 as working in any industry or service

industries in Great Britain 27-1 per cent were administrative, technical and

The DE has a Manpower Research Unit (MRU) set up to examine the problems
of forecasting manpower resources and requirements by occupation over a
period of 5 to 10 years ahead for both the whole economy and for some parti¬
cular industries and occupations.
The MRU also co-operates with industry training boards on technical
problems of forecasting. Its forecasts are designed to help with industrial and
manpower planning, recruitment, training and careers advice.

has been rising since 1966. It has been relatively low in the south-east and
Midlands of England, and consistently higher in those parts of the country
which have the greatest dependence on shipbuilding, coalmining, and certain
branches of the heavy engineering and metal manufacturing industries,
notably parts of Scotland and Wales, and north-east England and Merseyside.
These areas have been the subject of a series of measures of selective assistance
to stimulate industrial expansion; and counter-measures have been taken to
limit expansion in areas of manpower shortage (see p. 213)- The general un¬
employment rate in Great Britain in August 1971 was 3*7 Per cen^) areas
with the highest rates were northern England, Wales and Scotland.
The total working population of Northern Ireland—including employers and
self-employed but excluding certain unpaid helpers—was about 591,000 in
December 1970 (388,000 males and 203,000 females). The number of insured
employees was 516,000. The largest productive industries are agriculture,
engineering, textiles and clothing. Most of the agricultural work in Northern
Ireland is done without hired help.
The unemployment rate in Northern Ireland has remained higher than in
other parts of the United Kingdom. In June 1971 it was 7-3 per cent of insured
employees. The Ministry of Commerce of the Northern Ireland Government
has wide powers (similar to those in Great Britain) to assist the development
and diversification of industry. It is using these powers vigorously in an attempt
to improve the situation.
EMPLOYMENT, TRAINING AND PRODUCTIVITY SERVICES
The main government employment services are provided in Great Britain
through the country-wide network of 1,100 local offices including nearly 900
employment exchanges of the Department of Employment (DE). The services
in Northern Ireland are run on similar lines by the Ministry of Health and
Social Services but there are some variations related to the much smaller area
of administration.
The employment exchanges provide a free and confidential service for
employers needing staff and for workpeople, whether or not already in
employment, seeking jobs. Information and advice on any employment
problem is available to all. Use of the service is voluntary. Employers and em¬
ployees alike remain free to use general or specialised fee-charging private
employment agencies and direct recruitment by advertisement or personal
introduction. Exchanges, including the specialist placing services described
below, handle the full range of occupations and deal with full-time, part-time
and temporary vacancies. Details of unfilled vacancies (or of people seeking
jobs) can be circulated quickly in the ‘travel to work’ area, or more widely if
necessary. Local employment committees, on which employers, workers and
other local interests are represented, are attached to the employment exchanges
as advisory bodies to secure the full benefit of local knowledge and the close
co-operation of employers and workers. . .
The employment exchanges offer a wide range of specialised services. Over
40 of the larger exchanges hold a Professional and Executive Register con¬
cerned with senior posts in industry, commerce, and the professions both at
home and overseas. The Register is also able to give information about the
professions and allied occupations to young men and women considering a
career and to older people seeking a new one.
LABOUR
Occupational
Guidance
Service
Youth
Employment
Service
Disablement
Resettlement
Service
393
A special commercial employment service (office and shop work) is avail¬
able at all employment exchanges and also at a number of small commercial
employment offices. In the hotel and catering industry a specialist service is
based on the Hotel and Catering Trades Exchange in London.
The Regular Forces Resettlement Service, in which the DE collaborates
with the Ministry of Defence and the voluntary organisations concerned with
ex-regulars, helps members of the Forces to achieve a satisfactory transition
to civilian life. Nearly all those leaving the Services are successful in securing
satisfactory resettlement.
In areas where there are large groups of hospitals, there are officers specially
trained to deal with the employment problems of nurses, midwives and those
in related occupations or who wish to enter those professions. Elsewhere
nursing employment work is done as part of the general employment service.
The Occupational Guidance Service has over 40 units in the main centres of
population. The service is available free of charge to anybody over the age of
18 who has left school and who wishes to take expert advice before choosing
or changing his occupation. A person needing help in finding employment is
referred to the placing service.
The Youth Employment Service in Great Britain is available to all young
people up to the age of 18, or older if they are still at school. Its main functions
are: to work with careers teachers in schools in providing young people and
their parents with information on educational and employment opportunities;
to give vocational guidance to young people in their later years at school; to
help young people to find suitable employment and employers to find suitable
workers; and to follow up the progress of young people in employment and
give them any further help or advice they may need. The Secretary of State for
Employment has responsibility for the service and is advised by a National
Youth Employment Council. Central administration is the responsibility of
the Central Youth Employment Executive which consists of senior officers of
the DE and the education departments.
The service, set up under the Employment and Training Act 1958, gives
local education authorities the option of operating the service in their own
areas. Where an authority provides an approved scheme, 75 per cent of its
expenses is reimbursed from state funds. Some 143 local authorities covering
approximately 80 per cent of the school population operate the service based
on their own careers offices. In the remaining parts of the country the service
is provided from careers offices of the DE.
In Northern Ireland the functions of the Youth Employment Service are
similar to those in Great Britain but its organisation is different in that parlia¬
mentary responsibility rests with the Minister of Education and the service is
operated by a statutory board composed of representatives of local education
authorities and other educational and industrial interests.
The Disablement Resettlement Service is designed to help disabled persons
to get and keep suitable work. It is available to anyone over school-leaving age
who is substantially handicapped as a result of injury, disease or congenital
deformity in obtaining or keeping employment. The DE is responsible for the
administration of the Service and is assisted by the National Advisory Council
on the Employment of the Disabled.
The help given falls under five main headings:
394
Vocational
Guidance
BRITAIN 1972'. AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Vocational guidance is given at local offices by specialised disablement resettle¬
ment officers (DROs) in consultation, as necessary, with the local disablement
advisory committees, hospital resettlement clinics and medical interviewing
committees, and also in the industrial rehabilitation units.
Placing in Ordinary Having regard to a disabled person’s qualifications and aptitude and to medical
Employment guidance, the DRO endeavours to find the work most suited to him, and where
necessary arranges for a course of industrial rehabilitation or training or both.
A Register of Disabled Persons is maintained, and in mid-April 1971 the
number registered was about 621,000; registration is voluntary. All employers
of 20 or more persons are required to employ a quota (at present 3 per cent for
all industries, except shipping in respect of the manning of ships) of registered
disabled persons. The number of registered disabled persons unemployed in
mid-April 1971 was 80,172.
There are 30 specialised Blind Persons Resettlement Officers (BPROs)
attached to offices of the DE.
Industrial Industrial rehabilitation is provided at 25 units (including one combined
Rehabilitation medical/industrial rehabilitation unit) run by the DE. Their aim is to provide
the final link between sickness and employment by enabling men and women
to adjust themselves gradually to normal working conditions and to receive
vocational guidance based on skilled assessment of their aptitudes in a practical
workshop situation. Attendance at a unit is voluntary and maintenance
allowances are paid. They also provide special short assessment courses for
young people finding it difficult to enter suitable employment and at some there
are work preparation classes for handicapped school leavers (run in co-opera¬
tion with local education authorities). The staff includes a doctor, occupational
psychologist, social worker, DRO, industrially experienced workshop super¬
visors, and sometimes a remedial gymnast, all under the general leadership o a
rehabilitation officer.
The Department of Employment gives financial assistance to two centres
conducted by voluntary organisations which provide similar facilities for the
blind, to four schemes by other bodies for the rehabilitation of patients with
mental handicaps, and to two centres for spastics.
Vocational Training There are vocational training facilities for the disabled at Government Training
Centres (see p. 396), educational institutions and employers establishments.
For the more seriously disabled there are special residential training colleges
run by voluntary organisations with the financial assistance and technical help
of the DE. There are also arrangements for the training of special categories
such as the blind, and for providing grants to disabled persons qualified to
undertake study or training for professional or comparable employment.
Sheltered
Employment
Remploy Ltd., a non-profit-making company, provides sheltered employment
for registered severely disabled people who are unlikely to obtain work except
under special conditions. About 7,500 severely disabled men and women are
employed in 86 factories. Its board is appointed by the Secretary of State;
loans and grants for capital development and to meet operational costs are
provided from public funds. . .
The DE also gives financial assistance to local authorities and voluntary
organisations towards the cost of providing facilities for sheltered employment
for over 2,600 severely disabled sighted workers and for about 2,700 blind
workers.

395
The Manpower and Productivity Service of the DE, set up in 1968, offers
advice and guidance to firms seeking to improve their industrial relations. In
addition to conciliation in industrial disputes, it advises on the efficient use of
manpower, labour productivity, labour turnover and absenteeism, payment
systems and personnel practices. There are some 125 manpower advisers,
organised on a regional basis, with central consultancy and information
services.
As part of the policy of assisting geographical mobility of labour within
Britain to balance resources and demands, the Department of Employment
makes grants and allowances to help with costs of fares, temporary lodging
and acquisition of and removal to the new home, in specified instances. They
are available to unemployed workers moving to new employment, and there¬
fore settling, in another area; to key workers transferred by a firm into a develop¬
ment or intermediate area to inaugurate a new plant; and to local unemployed
workers recruited to new plants in areas of high unemployment and sent to the
parent works for preliminary training.
The Immigration Act 1971 placed Commonwealth citizens and foreign
nationals under a single system of immigration control. In general, people
coming to Britain for employment (including Commonwealth citizens who do
not have a right of abode, see p. 12) need a work permit issued by the DE.
This must be obtained by the prospective employer and issued for a specific
job for a fixed initial period, normally 12 months. People admitted may change
their jobs with the approval of the DE and normally their stay is extended if
they remain in approved employment. After four years’ residence conditions
of admission are cancelled and a worker’s stay is no longer subject to a time
limit and he is able to change employment without restriction. In addition,
Commonwealth citizens may be admitted for a limited period as trainees in
certain professions and types of employment, and foreign nationals may enter
Britain as student employees on a short-term basis to enable them to improve
their knowledge of English and widen their business or industrial experience.
Overseas doctors and dentists coming to take up professional appointments
may enter Britain without work permits for a limited period. The number of
work permits issued is controlled by the DE in the light of economic conditions
in Britain.
In Northern Ireland employment permits are required under the Safe¬
guarding of Employment Act (Northern Ireland) 1947 for non-Northern
Ireland workers. The Act defines Northern Ireland workers and subsequent
regulations make certain occupations exempt.
Under previous legislation nearly 4,000 Commonwealth citizens entered
Britain for employment in i97°* They consisted of people with special skills
and qualifications, such as doctors, dentists and science graduates, or people
with specific jobs to go to, for example, in the manufacturing, catering and
transport industries. About 19,000 foreign nationals entered Great Britain in
1970 to work in industry and commerce, 21,600 in the hotel and catering in¬
dustry, 9,700 for domestic work and 6,700 as student employees.
Britain, as a member of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and
Development, participates with 13 European countries in the arrangements
for assisting nationals of the countries concerned to obtain employment in
other member countries.
The framework of training in industry and commerce is mainly based on the
Industrial Training Act 1964. Under this Act industrial training boards are
q6 BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
appointed to be responsible for the quantity and quality of industrial training
in the industry concerned; up to June 1971, 28 boards had been set up covering
over 15 million employees or about 85 per cent of those in industry and com¬
merce to whom the Act applies. Each board covers as wide a sector of industry
as possible to reduce costs of administration and simplify problems of co¬
operation between boards. It can provide its own training courses or arrange
for other organisations to provide training. It raises a levy from employers and
makes grants to those whose training it approves. The Secretary of State meets
the initial administrative costs of each board and makes grants towards cer¬
tain other expenditure: for example, for capital expenditure on new semi¬
skilled training places in development and intermediate areas. To advise the
Secretary of State on the administration of the Act and on industrial training
questions generally, a Central Training Council (CTC) consisting of employer
and trade union members, representatives of nationalised industries, educa¬
tionists, selected chairmen of training boards and others with a special interest
in industrial training has been set up. It also advises on the running of the
Industrial Training Service (ITS), an independent non-profit-making body
sponsored by the DE and the CTC. The ITS provides companies, employers’
associations and industrial training boards in any industry with help in the
identification of training needs, the formulation of training policy, job analysis
for any occupational categories, training programme design and assessing the
effectiveness of training.
Government The Government Vocational Training Scheme, administered by the DE, is
Vocational intended to supplement what industry is doing to overcome shortages of
Training skilled workers in industries of national importance as well as helping persons
in special need, such as the disabled (see p. 394) an^ ex-Forces men and
women, to fit themselves for suitable employment. Training is provided for
suitable persons over 18 years of age who are unskilled or whose prospects of
work in their existing trade are poor. (Employed persons as well as the un¬
employed are accepted for training.) Most of it is done at Government Training
Centres (GTCs), which are within easy reach of the main industrial centres
of the country, and between them offer courses in some 50 different trades,
with emphasis on those in which there is a shortage of skilled labour. In June
1971 there were 52 GTCs (to be increased to 54 by the end of 1972). Schemes
of training for particular trades are agreed with representatives of the em¬
ployers and workers concerned.
For the disabled and for ex-Regular Service men and women and the un¬
employed training in trades and commercial work is also available under the
scheme at technical and commercial colleges and private training establish¬
ments or by means of individual courses at employers’ establishments. For
severely disabled persons training is provided at four residential training
colleges run by voluntary organisations with government financial assistance.
During training, trainees are paid good allowances to maintain themselves
and their dependants. During 1970 nearly 14,500 people were trained under
the scheme and over 90 per cent of them were subsequently employed in the
trade for which they had been trained.
The expansion of GTCs has made it possible to use their facilities with
increasing flexibility, including, for instance, the provision of free training for
sponsored employees. Under this scheme employers can nominate selected
employees for courses to upgrade or broaden their existing skills. The DE
also arranges special six-week business training courses for Regulars and ex-
Regulars (mainly ex-officers) at commercial and technical colleges; four-week
LABOUR
397
Special DE
Services
Legislation and
Conventions
courses in industrial supervision are provided at a centre in London for non¬
technical warrant officers and senior NCOs (or other Service equivalent ranks).
In addition to full courses for a civilian trade, refresher courses and conversion
courses required by ex-Service men and women can be arranged under the
Vocational Training Scheme.
The DE also provides assistance with training for firms moving into a
development or intermediate area or expanding an existing business there.
The assistance includes grants for training carried out by the employer and
direct training of employees on the firm’s premises by staff loaned by the
DE. Grants are also available to employers in development and intermediate
areas who take on and train men and women over the age of 45 who have been
unemployed for more than 8 weeks. Another scheme of government grants
administered by the industrial training boards has been introduced to promote
craft and technician training in development or intermediate areas. Grants are
available to employers in these areas who provide additional off-the-job
training facilities for apprentices and technicians, or otherwise increase the
numbers of such trainees.
A special service to industry is the Department of Employment’s Training
Within Industry for Supervisors (TWI) scheme. Its object is to develop the
skill of supervisors in instructing and communicating in human relations, in
improving methods and in preventing accidents (there are separate programmes
for each of these) in the shortest possible time. There are special versions of
TWI, usually in courses of a week’s duration, for supervisors employed in
offices, retail distribution and hospitals, and also an in-plant training develop¬
ment service to aid selection and further the training of operatives as instruc¬
tors. Training Officers of the DE either give these courses or train employers’
nominees to enable them to run TWI courses in their own concerns. A clerical
training course to aid selection and further the training of clerks as instructors
associates management and supervisory staff with the training of students.
The E)E also has an intensive course for training clerical staff in export offices
in basic export procedures.
In addition, two-week courses in industrial instructional techniques for the
training of instructors are available to outside firms (as well as GTC staff)
at the DE s two Instructor Training Colleges (one in England and one in
Scotland), and at six Instructor Training Units attached to GTCs. A one-
week advanced course is available for instructors likely to benefit.
Vocational training services at GTCs, TWI courses, and courses at In¬
structor Training Colleges are available to trainees from overseas under
approved schemes (for instance, those of the International Labour Organisation
or technical assistance provided jointly by the DE and the Overseas Develop¬
ment Administration of the Foreign and Commonwealth Office).
TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT AND WORKING CONDITIONS
Though Britain has been a pioneer in the introduction of protective legislation
for the safety, health and welfare of employees and in providing certain legal
immunities for trade unions (see p. 389)5 until recently there were relatively
few legal restrictions on the right of an employer to hire an employee on any
terms which he would accept and to dismiss him at will. The employee in
general looked to his trade union to protect him. The determination by
statute of minimum wages, holidays and holiday pay was in principle confined
to those trades and industries where the organisation of employers or workers.
398
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
or both, was inadequate to negotiate collective agreement and to ensure their
observance. However, both the 1971 Industrial Relations Act (see below) and
other recent legislation provide considerable safeguards for the employee in
his terms of employment as well as working conditions. The Terms and
Conditions of Employment Act 1959, as amended under the 1971 Industrial
Relations Act, provides machinery for enforcing on an employer the observ¬
ance of terms or conditions established by collective agreement in his industry.
The Contracts of Employment Act 1963, again as amended by the 1971
Industrial Relations Act, requires an employer to give an employee com¬
prehensive information on terms and conditions of employment, including
information about his right to choose whether to belong to a trade union and
the procedure available to him where he has a grievance about his employ¬
ment; it also lays down the right of both employers and employees to minimum
periods of notice when employment is to be terminated. Under the Redun¬
dancy Payments Acts 1965 and 1969 employees with a minimum period of
service of two years are entitled to lump sum payments if their jobs cease to
exist (for example, because of technological improvements or because of a
fall in demand) and their employers cannot offer suitable alternative work, the
cost being partly met from a fund subscribed to by industry as a whole. The
1971 Industrial Relations Act will give protection against unfair dismissal by
providing machinery under which an employee may bring an action against an
employer for unfair dismissal, and seek compensation. The 1971 Industrial
Relations Act will also give new legal support to the right to trade union organisa¬
tion by requiring an employer to recognise a trade union where that is the wish
of his workers, expressed in a ballot and after investigation by the Commission
on Industrial Relations and by making it an unfair industrial practice (see
p. 407) to refuse to employ a person because he is a trade union member. 1 he
Act also lays down that written collective agreements between trade unions or
other organisations of workers on the one hand, and employers or organisa¬
tions of employers on the other, are to be considered legally binding unless they
contain express provisions to the contrary. The Race Relations Act 1968 (see
p. 148) makes it illegal for an employer to discriminate on the grounds of race
colour or national origin in the engagement, dismissal or employment of
Other legislation prescribes minimum standards of safety, health and
welfare in most places of employment. 1 However, it is recognised that the causes
of many accidents are not amenable to statutory control. Therefore, volun ary
action taken by employer organisations, often in association with trade unions,
The further considerations which affect workers’ satisfaction with their
jobs and promote harmony between employers and employed, which can be
summed up as ‘good human relations’ between management and individual
employees, are hardly susceptible to codification; they have been recognised
for some time and are receiving increasing attention from managements an
from voluntary and official organisations.

On the basis of the latest survey in a series conducted regularly by the DE
into earnings and hours of work in manufacturing industries and some non¬

Minimum time rates for women manual workers tend to be lower than the
corresponding male rate, though the gap is gradually closing. Women’s
earnings are markedly lower than those of men, partly because on average they
work shorter hours, with less overtime paid at premium rates, but also because
a smaller proportion of women do skilled work. The Equal Pay Act 1970
provides that from 29th December 1975 a woman doing the same or broadly
equivalent work to a man qualifies for equal pay and conditions of employ¬
ment.

BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Between end-1957 and October 1970 average weekly wage rates increased by
89 per cent and average weekly earnings of manual workers by 125 per cent.
Part of the increase has been offset by a rise in prices of about 57 per cent.
The trends of manual workers’ earnings, wage rates, retail prices, wages and
salaries from 1958 to 1970 are shown in the diagram above.
Remuneration in commercial, technical and professional careers is normally
by annual salary, often on a scale carrying annual increases, and such careers
generally afford opportunities for promotion to posts with higher remunera¬
tion. Starting salaries may be in the range of ^800-^1,000 (lower for trainees
in their teens and higher for some graduates entering industry). The average
weekly earnings of male administrative, technical and clerical employees in
October 1970 were found by a Department of Employment survey to be £36 • 12.
The average weekly figure for females was ^19-59.
Most of the senior posts in business, the professions and the Civil Service
are in the range of £2,750 to ,£7,000 a year. The posts with salaries in the
range of £8,000 to ,£15,000 a year include those of Cabinet Ministers, top-
ranking judicial appointments, the highest positions in government depart¬
ments and the largest municipal authorities, editors of daily newspapers,
some persons outstanding in their professions and in the higher managerial
posts in industry, commerce and banking. A few persons in business draw
still higher salaries, while the earnings of star entertainers and certain other
very successful people exceed £20,000 a year.
Women have the same right of entry as men to nearly all public offices,
administrative posts and professions. They are paid the same salary for
doing the same work in journalism, broadcasting and architecture, and as
Ministers of the Crown, Members of Parliament, salaried magistrates and
solicitors. Women in independent professions are not expected to charge
lower fees than men. The principle of equal pay for men and women applies
generally for non-manual work in the public sector, but is still exceptional in
the private sector. The Equal Pay Act 197® will enforce the principle in all
occupations from the end of 1975.
The average earnings of all salaried employees increased by 151-6 per cent
between 1955 and 1970.
In October 1970 the number of hours actually worked by manual workers
averaged 45 -7 for full-time men and 37-9 for women on full-time work. Agreed
weekly hours are in the range 40 to 42 and are generally worked as either
a five-day or a five-and-a-half-day week according to the industry and the
rule of the particular establishment. Hours actually worked by men are
somewhat longer owing to overtime working.
National legislation limits and defines permissible hours of work for
women and younger persons in a number of industries or trades the maximum
permitted, with limited exceptions, being 48 hours a week and 10 hours a
day (9 hours a day for 6-day-week workers) in premises covered by the
Factories Act (see p. 401) for adult women over 18 and young people between
16 and 18; young people under 16 are limited to 44 hours a week. The
employment of women and young people at night is prohibited in industrial
undertakings, except that in certain continuous process industries young men
over 16 may, subject to certain conditions, be so employed. The DE can make
exemptions from these restrictions on grounds of public interest. In general
the hours of work of adult men are not restricted by statute.

With a few exceptions, manual workers (including shop assistants) in indus¬
tries covered by agreements or statutory orders are entitled to paid holidays
of at least 12 days or two weeks. Over half of the number of manual workers
are now entitled to paid annual holidays of three weeks. Moreover, payment is
made for public holidays, which are as follows: in addition to Good Friday
and Christmas Day there are public holidays in England and Wales on Easter
Monday, the last Monday in May or first in June, the last Monday in August
or first in September and the first weekday after Christmas (Boxing Day); and
in Scotland on New Year’s Day, the last Monday in May or first in June and
the last Monday in August or first in September.1 Northern Ireland observes
all the English holidays and, in addition, has a holiday on St. Patrick’s Day,
17th March, and on 12th July (commemorating the Battle of the Boyne, 1690);
the Tuesday after Easter is also a customary holiday for industry and trade.
Many agreements provide that payments should also be made for specially
proclaimed holidays.
In some industries agreements provide for extended holidays related to
length of service, work status, or both.
A variety of additional benefits in monetary form exist in varying degree. It
has been estimated that in 1970 15-7 million employees were covered by
occupational sick pay schemes, and about 11-5 million by occupational pension
schemes (additional or complementary to the State schemes, see p. 129). A
smaller number are covered by schemes for redundancy payments above the
statutory minimum (see p. 398). Such ‘fringe’ benefits are rather more usual
among clerical and professional employees receiving a standard salary than
among manual workers with a chance to earn overtime and other additions
to their pay. The former also tend to get longer holidays. Senior members
of firms may use a company car. Some firms provide for profit-sharing.
The Office of Manpower Economics was established in April 1971 as an
independent non-statutory body, with three functions, namely, acting as
secretariat for the three review bodies set up to advise on the remuneration of
certain groups in the public sector for which negotiating machinery is not
appropriate, such as, Members of Parliament, the Judiciary, the Armed
Forces, and doctors and dentists; servicing enquiries on particular pay
structures and related problems; and carrying out research on more general
matters affecting pay and manpower, either at the request or with the approval
of ministers.
Employers have a duty at common law to take reasonable care of their
employees and provide a safe system of working, while employees have a
duty of care towards each other. In addition, minimum required standards
of safety in certain kinds of workplaces or work are laid down under a number
of statutes; some of these also deal with health and welfare.
About 207,000 industrial premises (factories, warehouses, shipyards and
docks) come under the Factories Act 1961 (consolidating earlier legislation),
which is administered by the DE and enforced by Her Majesty’s Inspectorate
of Factories, which forms part of the DE. About 750,000 premises come under
the Offices, Shops and Railway Premises Act, which is also administered by
the DE; enforcement is shared by Her Majesty’s Inspectorate of Factories and
1 The appointed dates for the spring and autumn public holidays in 1972 are 29th
May and 28th August.
402
Other Work
Premises
Prevention
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
local authorities. Under these Acts, anyone intending to employ other people
in industrial or commercial premises to which the Acts apply has to notify the
enforcing authority of his intention before he begins to employ people^ and
every fatal accident and every accident causing more than three days’ in¬
capacity must be reported; under the Factories Act provision is also made for
compulsory notification and for investigation of certain dangerous occur-
rences.
The Acts are designed to secure the health, safety and welfare of employed
persons, and a wide range of provisions in the Acts and in regulations,
according to the nature of the premises, deal with such matters as the fencing
of machinery; precautions against fire and special risks; the safe condition of
the premises, cleanliness, lighting, temperature and ventilation. The Factories
Act also includes provisions for precautions against dangerous substances and
about the employment of women and young persons.
Comparable provision with appropriate variations covers mines and
quarries under the Mines and Quarries Act 1954; two statutes are concerned
with agriculture—the Agriculture (Poisonous Substances) Act 1952 and the
Agriculture (Safety, Health and Welfare Provisions) Act 1956; and specialised
statutes and delegated legislation are concerned with transport—the Railway
Employment (Prevention of Accidents) Act 1900, the Merchant Shipping
Acts, the Road Traffic Acts and the Air Navigation Order and Regulations.
As with the Factories Act these other provisions are, with some exceptions,
enforced through inspectorates—the Mines and Quarries Inspectorate (part
of the Department of Trade and Industry, which is responsible for safety in
mines and quarries), the Agricultural Inspectorate of the agricultural depart¬
ments, and, for railways, the Railway Employment Inspectorate of the
Department of the Environment. The Department of Trade and Industry is
responsible for administering the Merchant Shipping Acts and for safety in air
transport (most of the powers in respect of air worthiness are delegated to the
Air Registration Board, see p. 313), and the Department of the Environment is
responsible for road and rail transport safety matters.
Safety requirements in hotels, places of entertainment or educational establish¬
ments are covered by the 1971 Fire Precautions Act or (in respect of their
offices and shops) by the Offices, Shops and Railway Premises Act. The DE
has no statutory responsibility in regard to safety in workshops or laboratories
in educational establishments, though it keeps in touch with university authori¬
ties and the education departments. Employers, however, are bound by their
common law obligation to provide a safe system of work, and employers and
educational authorities may voluntarily seek the advice and help of the Factory
Inspectorate, which is given freely on request.
The voluntary accident prevention movement is strongly supported by the
Factory Inspectorate. Inspectors enquire into notified accidents and safety
aspects of machine design and specification, circulate expert advice by personal
exhortation, lectures and literature, and encourage the appointment of safety
officers and the formation of works safety committees. The Factory Inspector¬
ate maintains an industrial health and safety centre in London, at which
various types of machinery demonstrating the effectiveness of guards are
displayed, as well as a wide range of protective clothing and equipment. The
DE also actively encourages the development of voluntary central organisa¬
tion within each industry at national level for the consideration of safety
matters and the formulation of policy and accident prevention.
LABOUR
Advisory Bodies
Training for
Safety
Other Measures
4°3
Organisations in industry are now concerning themselves to an increasing
extent with the promotion of safety at work and the provision of information
and advisory services to their members. They participate also in joint standing
and advisory committees appointed by the Secretary of State. Representatives
of the Trades Union Congress, the Confederation of British Industry, the
nationalised industries and other interests meet on the Industrial Safety
Advisory Council under the chairmanship of the Secretary of State.
Training for safety is an important facet of the accident prevention effort and,
to help in this work, the DE provides a safety course in its TWI scheme (see
p. 397) and the Industrial Training Boards (see p. 395) include specific
provisions for safety training in their general training recommendations.
The Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents (RoSPA) and the British
Safety Council are the major national voluntary bodies concerned with
industrial accident prevention. RoSPA provides a variety of safety courses
for special needs mainly at its Industrial Safety Training Centre in Birmingham
and also helps the accident prevention movement by providing publicity and
organising conferences; its regional industrial safety officers work to promote
safety activity among top-level managers. The British Safety Council is
mainly concerned with industrial safety, provides publicity and offers safety
training courses. Other courses are organised by local accident prevention
groups and organisations such as the Federation of Civil Engineering Con¬
tractors. A number of the local accident prevention groups are affiliated to
either RoSPA or to the British Safety Council. These groups serve as forums
where questions of industrial safety can be examined and knowledge of
accident prevention exchanged.
A substantial amount of research is being done by industry, universities
and other academic bodies, and government research organisations into
problems of guarding machines, ergonomics, safe handling, electrical hazards,
protective personal equipment, construction methods, fires and explosions,
psychological factors and causes of accidents, both generally and in particular
sectors of industry. A register of research into industrial health and safety
matters has been compiled by the DE to give an indication of the scale and
nature of research being undertaken. Industrial research associations include
amongst their more purely economic research projects the improvement of
working conditions and the reduction of hazards.
The National Coal Board has its own safety organisation—a Standing
Committee on Safety, a chief safety engineer, and safety engineers at divisions,
areas and the largest collieries. It conducts courses of safety training for
workmen and officials and is constantly on the alert for new methods of
reducing risks. Its research programme includes a number of projects with a
direct bearing on safety.
The Department of Trade and Industry has a statutory responsibility for
research concerning the safety and health of coal miners. This responsibility
is largely exercised through its Safety in Mines Research Establishment.
To safeguard the many interests which might be adversely affected by the
use of chemicals in agriculture and food storage, a voluntary scheme is
operated by the Government with the help of an advisory committee and with
the full co-operation of the chemical industry.
Transport operators and ministries concerned with road and air travel give
high priority to safety measures affecting crews and passengers. Every
endeavour is made to counter the higher risks resulting from rising traffic
densities by improving the design of vehicles, transport plant and equipment,
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
by traffic regulation and control of standards of maintenance and by training
crews in competency and safety awareness.
HEALTH AND Local authorities have power, under the Public Health Acts, to regulate the
WELFARE provision of suitable sanitary accommodation in houses and at places of work
and to treat workplaces which are dirty or badly ventilated or overcrowded
as nuisances the abatement of which can be enforced. Factories, certain other
industrial premises, offices, shops and railway premises must comply with the
health and welfare requirements of the Factories Act or the Offices, Shops and
Railway Premises Act. These include: the cleanliness of workrooms, adequate
ventilation and suitable temperature and lighting, the avoidance of over¬
crowding and the provision of sanitary accommodation, and the protection
of workers against inhaling harmful dust or fumes; and the provision of
washing facilities, lockers or other accommodation for outdoor clothing,
drinking water, first aid and seats. Legislation concerning safety in other types
of work, for example, agriculture, also prescribes appropriate measures.
The laws restricting the employment of children, young persons and women
form an important part of protective legislation. National legislation, besides
forbidding employment of children under 13 years of age, forbids the employ¬
ment of children who have not reached the statutory minimum school¬
leaving age (see p. 154) in any industrial undertaking; of women and young
persons underground in mines and in certain other dangerous occupations
(for example, certain processes connected with lead manufacture); and of
women in factories and workshops within four weeks after childbirth. It also
limits and defines the permissible hours of employment for women and young
persons (see p. 400). Local authorities, moreover, have wide powers under the
Children and Young Persons Acts 1933-63 as well as the Education Acts
1944-48, to regulate hours and conditions of employment of children under
1 c years within their areas within the limits of national legislation. _
There are some 1,500 appointed factory doctors appointed for districts
whose duties include the initial and periodic medical examination of all young
people entering industry, and certain other medical examinations required
under the Factories Act for workers in particular hazardous trades. There are
also some 800 works medical officers appointed to the factories in which they
are employed. Legislation is under consideration to provide for the replace¬
ment of the appointed factory doctor service by a more expert medical advisory
service, with wider duties. . 1 ir
These are the main legislative provisions relating to health and welrare at
work, but it is essential to note that employers frequently achieve standards
considerably higher than those prescribed by law. They are helped to do this
by the inspectorates, by government departments and agencies, by employers
associations and trade unions and by expert voluntary bodies. _
In 1970 a Medical Services Division for the medical activities or the
Department of Employment was set up. Its responsibilities include the work
of the former medical inspectors of factories (renamed medical advisers), the
regional medical advisers and the doctors in government training centres and
industrial rehabilitation units. Close liaison with the work of the appointed
factory doctors is maintained. The Division maintains a medical laboratory
which provides routine service for the investigation of industrial hazards and
undertakes research and development work.
Industrial
Health Services
A number of employers voluntarily maintain medical services for their
employees over and above the statutory requirements. It is estimated that

The big employers, including the State and the boards of nationalised
industries, have naturally taken the lead but a number of smaller factories
also provide medical services and in a few cases have joined together in group
medical services. The Secretary of State is advised on measures to further
the development of industrial health services in workplaces covered by the
Factories Act by the Industrial Health Advisory Committee which includes
members nominated by the Confederation of British Industry, the Trades
Union Congress, the nationalised industries, the British Medical Association,
the Royal College of Nursing and other organisations closely concerned with
the promotion of industrial health.
Occupational hygiene services can give valuable assistance in securing
healthy working conditions in industry. Her Majesty’s Factory Inspectors
give advice on occupational hygiene problems as part of their normal duties
and an industrial hygiene unit, with laboratory facilities, has been set up
within the inspectorate. In addition there are some six centres in Great
Britain (including the TUC’s Institute of Occupational Health) which under¬
take studies of particular problems or health risks and also carry out routine
physical, chemical and biological tests for industry.
Research facilities are provided by government agencies such as the
Medical Research Council; by university faculties of industrial health and
social medicine; and by the research departments of various industries and
large industrial concerns. Field investigations are carried out by the Factory
Inspectorate, which has specialised technical branches; the Medical Service of
the DE arranges epidemiological surveys.
Other types of amenity vary considerably from one firm to another. The
requirements of a factory, office or shop where the work is light, and where
many employees are women or young persons, are different from those of an
iron foundry or steelworks, where much of the work is arduous and is under¬
taken by men. Progressive firms are careful to find out what their employees
want, and welfare policy is often decided in consultation with the workers,
through regular consultative machinery or by other means. An increasing
number of firms pay part or all of the cost of recreational facilities. Some have
their own rehabilitation centres or support convalescent homes. The provision
of low-priced meals at the place of employment has become usual in large
undertakings and quite common in smaller ones. Many offices and shops
which are unable to provide canteen facilities for their staff have adopted
luncheon voucher schemes.
The safety, health and welfare of employees in Northern Ireland have been
the subject of legislation which, with some exceptions, is similar to that in
Great Britain and is embodied in the Factories Act (Northern Ireland) 1965
and the Office and Shop Premises Act (Northern Ireland) 1966. Many firms
voluntarily employ safety officers, and an Industrial Safety Group for the area,
supported by representatives of industry, trade unions, insurance companies
and public authorities, makes a valuable contribution in the field of industrial
accident prevention on similar lines to what is done in Great Britain.
Practically all large industrial firms and many small ones now have a personnel
department staffed by one or more specialist officers. While the form of
406
INDUSTRIAL
RELATIONS
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
organisation of personnel departments varies, personnel officers are generally
responsible for advising all levels of management on every aspect of labour
relations. They also have particular duties with regard to recruitment,
selection, education and training, transfer of labour, the application of wage
agreements, the promotion of good communication and consultation and the
supervision of working conditions and employees’ amenities.
Recruitment and promotion policies are matters which each undertaking
decides for itself, although in some industries the decisions may be limited
by collective agreements or by trade practices. Great importance has recently
been attached to selection, and courses for training personnel officers in
modern interviewing techniques, including the use of test procedures, are
now well attended. ,
The Manpower and Productivity Service of the DE (see p. 395) is available
to give advice on personnel policies, personnel management techniques and
problems of human relations at the workplace. It also assists the creation and
support of machinery for negotiation and settlement of disputes.
Both official and voluntary organisations are concerned with promoting
better human relationships in industry. The Government has sought to
extend by research the available knowledge of the factors influencing human
relations in industry and human efficiency. Such research is sponsored or
conducted by the Social Science Research Council (see p. 332) and the Medica
Research Council (see p. 327)- Voluntary organisations include bodies which
deal with management problems and provide a service to subscribing Arms,
professional associations, linking individuals with a common interest in
particular functions of management; and bodies providing specialist services,
usually on a fee-paying basis.
The structure of labour relations in Britain has been established mainly on
a voluntary basis, and the extensive changes enacted in 1971 are designed
to retain the voluntary principle while modernising the conditions in which
it operates. The system will still rest on the organisation of employers and
workers into employers’ associations and trade unions. These organisations
discuss and negotiate terms and conditions of employment and other matters
affecting the workpeople at their work. In the past the emphasis has been
on detailed industry-wide agreements supplemented as necessary by m or-
mal agreements in firms or factories, but in a major reform of attitudes and
structure emphasis is now being placed on formal agreements at firm and
factory level. In some industries, firms and factories negotiations are con¬
ducted simply by ad hoc meetings of employers’ and employees’ representatives,
which are held when necessary; in others, voluntary joint councils or com¬
mittees have been established on a permanent basis. The scope of the various
joint bodies—from the National Joint Industrial Councils for whole in¬
dustries to the Works Councils and Committees in individual workplaces
varies widely. Some of them only negotiate. Others discuss a wide range
of topics. But the scope of the bodies is tending in genera to widen and the
distinction between discussion and negotiation to become blurred Normally
these arrangements for collective bargaining suffice to settle all questions
which are raised, but provision is sometimes made for matters not so settled
to be referred for settlement to independent arbitration; nowadays t is
provision is not often used. Standing arrangements exist for consultation at
national level between the Government, the Confederation of British Industry
(CBI) (see p. 408), the Trades Union Congress (TUC) (see p. 4°9) and the
nationalised industries through the National Joint Advisory Council, set up in
New Legal
Framework
Wages Councils
LABOUR 407
1939 to advise the Government on matters in which employers and workers
have a common interest. It meets under the chairmanship of the Secretary of
State.
The Report of the Royal Commission on Trade Unions and Employers’
Associations (Cmnd 3623) published in June 1968 analysed the industrial
relations system in Britain and made recommendations. In March 1969, the
Commission on Industrial Relations was established (see p. 412), on lines sug¬
gested by the Royal Commission, to form a focus for the improvement of collec¬
tive bargaining machinery. Another recommendation of the Royal Commission
was implemented when early in 1969 companies with 5,000 or more employees
were invited to register with the Manpower and Productivity Service of the
Department of Employment their procedure agreements, that is, all agreements
about the machinery for the determination of the terms and conditions of
employment, the settlement of grievances and disputes and other matters which
are generally the subject of consultation between management and unions.
In August 1971 a newT Industrial Relations Act became law. The Act provides
a new legal framework for industrial relations. The main provisions of the
Act include the right of an individual to join or not to join a trade union;
increased protection against unfair dismissal; the presumption that written
collective agreements are legally binding unless otherwise specified; the
granting of new and existing legal privileges, including the right to recognition
by employers, to those trade unions and employers’ associations whose rules
and conduct meet the standards laid down by legislation and supervised by the
Registrar of Trade Unions and Employers’ Associations; the setting-up of a
new system of expert and informal industrial relations courts to hear complaints
about and adjudicate on unfair industrial practices, and be empowered to
award compensation and to make restraining orders; the enlarging of the
functions of the Commission on Industrial Relations (see p. 412), particularly
in disputes over procedure agreements and bargaining agents; and the creation
of new emergency powers which enable the Government to impose a 60-day
cooling-off period or to order a secret ballot of workers in disputes where strike
action threatens the national economy. In addition, the Government is
required to draw up a Code of Industrial Relations Practice which will give
practical guidance on the conduct of industrial relations. The Code will not
be enforceable, but compliance or non-compliance with it may be taken into
account in any proceedings under the Act. A consultative document, which will
be the basis for the Code, has been issued on which comments have been invited
from trade unions, employers’ representatives and other interested parties.
The Code will be subject to the approval of Parliament.
In a small and decreasing number of industries and trades where the organisa¬
tion of employers or employees or both is not strong enough to provide a
basis for successful voluntary arrangements, there are statutory wage-regula¬
ting bodies, known as Wages Councils. These are composed of equal numbers
of representatives of employers and workers in the respective sectors of
industry, with, in addition, a small number of independent members. Wages
Councils may submit proposals for fixing minimum remuneration and
holidays with pay to the Secretary of State who must then make orders giving
statutory force to such proposals, subject only to his right to return them as a
whole for further consideration. The DE’s Wages Inspectorate helps em¬
ployers and workers to interpret the provisions of wage regulation orders and
sees that they are complied with.

Agricultural Wages Boards (there are separate Boards for England and
Wales and for Scotland) perform similar functions in relation to employment
in agriculture.
Many employers in Great Britain are members of employers’ organisations
wholly or partly concerned with labour questions. The primary aims of such
organisations are to help to establish suitable terms and conditions of em¬
ployment, including a sound wage structure and proper standards of safety,
health and welfare; to promote good relations with employees and the
efficient use of manpower; and to provide means of settling any disputes
which may arise. Different employers’ organisations vary in the emphasis
which they put upon these different aims and in the means by which they try
to achieve them. Although the negotiation of wages and working conditions
and the settlement of disputes remain their essential function, the majority
of the organisations provide help and advice on many aspects of industrial
relations, with the aim of developing positive employment policies and
PrTherenfsPd,ivereity'of structure as well as function. Generally, however,
employers’ organisations are organised on an industry basis rather than a
product basis. A few are purely local in character or deal with a section of
an industry; others are national in scope and are concerned with the whole
of a particular industry. In some of the chief industries there are loca or
regional organisations combined into national federations, while in others
within which different firms are engaged in making different principal
products, there is a complex structure with national and regional federations
for these different sections of the industry as well as for the industry as a
whole. Although there are some 1,400 employers’ organisations dealing with
labour matters, most of these are federated to national orgamsations. There
are about 85 of these, most of which are in membership of the CBI and these
are the ones that negotiate the important national collective agreements with
trade unions. . . , •
The final authority of a local or small national organisation may be a meeting
where all member firms are directly represented; but in larger organisations
some form of indirect representation is necessary, either through local
organisations or through regions or sections into which these ar<Lgr(™pe ‘
The representatives thus chosen, together with a number of office holders,
form a general council or central committee, which meets perhaps once a
quarter, mainly to make major policy decisions, to elect committees and to
ratify their work. A paid staff under a director or secretary carries out t e
organisation’s day-to-day work. There is usually a small working group
consisting of senior officials and committee chairmen, which meets to deal
with urgent questions and co-ordinate the work of committees.
The central body of employers is the CBI, which deals with all matters (not
only labour relations) affecting the interests of organised employers and
represents them nationally to the Government and the public and also
internationally, for instance, in the International Labour Organisation. The
majority of national employers’ organisations, nationalised industries and a
large number of individual companies are affiliated to the CBI. Its represen a-
tives sit on various government advisory committees, on other statutory
bodies and on voluntary bodies concerned with labour matters.
In nearly all industries and occupations some workers—and in some industries
Trade Union
Congress
LABOUR 409
nearly all workers—are organised into trade unions. These have grown up
gradually and independently over a great many years and, consequently, their
form and organisation vary considerably as do their traditions and attitudes,
for example, their degree of concern with political movements. Trade unions
started more than two hundred years ago among the skilled craftsmen and
spread later to the general labouring and unskilled classes. More recently trade
unionism has increased among clerical, supervisory, technical and adminis¬
trative workers. A number of associations of professional workers, formed
primarily for the preservation and improvement of professional standards,
have also come to exercise many of the functions of trade unions, including
negotiations on salary and fee scales, and are legally trade unions. The
qualification for membership of some unions is occupational (for instance,
they may recruit clerks or fitters wherever employed), while in others the
qualification is industrial (that is, they seek to recruit all persons in an industry,
whatever their occupation). In a number of unions recruitment is based on a
combination of these principles.
At the end of 1969 the total membership of British trade unions was about
10-3 million. There were 503 unions, but over 70 per cent of all trade unionists
were in the 24 largest unions, while more than half were in the nine unions
with a membership of over 250,000. The number of trade unionists has
increased during the last decade but the number of unions has gone down
owing to amalgamations.
The basic unit of organisation in most British trade unions is the local
branch. Every member of the union belongs to a branch. He may attend its
meetings, make suggestions about terms and conditions of employment,
discuss the work of the union, and take part in the election of the union’s
officers. The branch takes action on certain matters considered to be entirely,
or mainly, of local interest and forwards its views on wider issues for action by
the union’s national or regional bodies. The branch draws its members from
the locality and in only a few unions is it based on the place of work. Many
unions have shop stewards or other representatives at the place of work to
undertake organisation there. Where two or more unions have members in the
same workplace, shop stewards committees may be formed to discuss matters
of common concern.
In most large unions the central organisation is along the following lines:
elected officials, including a general secretary assisted by specialist and clerical
staff, are in charge of the work of the head office and are responsible to an
elected national executive council or committee which may be part-time or
full-time, and which is responsible to annual or biennial conferences of
delegates from the branches. Executive committees or councils play an
important part in the government of the unions; between conferences they
are the highest authorities and carry out policy decisions made by delegates.
Most unions also have some regional, district or area organisation.
In Britain the national centre of the trade union movement is the TUC, which
celebrated its centenary in June 1968. The TUC’s objects are to promote
the interests of its affiliated organisations and to improve the economic and
social conditions of the workers. Its membership comprises 145 organisations,
some of which are themselves federations of smaller organisations. Together
they represent about 9*5 million workpeople. The TUC deals with all general
questions which concern trade unions both nationally and internationally and
gives assistance on questions relating to particular trades or industries.
The Congress, which constitutes the TUC proper, meets for a week every
410
Scottish Trades
Union Congress
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
year to discuss matters of general interest to trade unionists and to employees
generally. It elects annually a General Council which represents it during the
remaining 51 weeks of the year. This is responsible for carrying out Congress
decisions, for watching economic and social developments, for providing
educational and advisory services to unions, and for presenting to the Govern¬
ment the trade union viewpoint on economic, social and industrial issues. It is
also empowered to mediate in inter-union disputes in certain circumstances
and its activities in this sphere were enlarged following a special Congress in
June 1969 and subsequent agreement with the Government. The General
Council undertook to use its authority to deal with unauthorised and un¬
constitutional stoppages of work, as well as the inter-union and official disputes
with which it had dealt previously.
The TUC is a non-political body but under the Trade Union Act 1913
individual trade unions can, by a ballot vote of members, decide to set up a
political fund, financed by a separate levy, which any member can refuse to
pay without loss of his normal union rights and benefits. About 100 separate
trade union organisations, including most of the largest trade unions, have
such a fund and, in most cases, it is used to support the Labour Party.
Both the TUC and many unions conduct extensive educational services for
members, mainly concerned with industrial subjects, trade unionism and
industrial relations principles and practice. In 1969, the first ever television
training series was organised by the BBC and TUC.
Branches of various trade unions in a locality generally affiliate to a local
trades council, which acts as a forum for the discussion of matters of common
interest and as a local agent of the TUC, by which it is registered each year
There are just over 495 trades councils in England and Wales alone, grouped
together in 22 federations.
Affiliation to the TUC is open to all trade unions anywhere in the United
Kingdom, but Scottish trade unionists have their own national centre, the
Scottish Trades Union Congress, similar within its objects to the TUC. The
Scottish TUC, to which trade unions may affiliate in respect of their member¬
ship in Scotland (a number of unions are affiliated to both bodies), also accepts
affiliation from trades councils and has an affiliated membership of about
840,000. It holds an annual congress and has consultations with the Govern¬
ment on issues affecting Scottish trade unionists.
State Provision
for Conciliation,
Arbitration and
Investigation
Matters which prove difficult to settle by negotiation are sometimes referred
by agreement to independent conciliators or arbitrators, and one way in which
the parties can find such persons is by invoking the help of the Secretary of
State. Under authority derived from the Conciliation Act 1896, and the
Industrial Courts Act 1919, the Secretary of State has certain powers to assist
industry to settle disputes which it is not found possible to resolve through an
industry’s own machinery and procedure. These powers are all intended to
supplement and not to supersede the industry’s own machinery. There is no
legal obligation on the parties to a dispute to notify the dispute to the Secretary
of State nor to place the question before a conciliator.
The DE assists with conciliation in industry through its Industrial Relations
Division and the field staff of the Manpower and Productivity Service (see p.
•mO who keep in touch with the course of relations between employers and
workers at national, district and, in some cases, factory level and assist them, if
requested, to settle their problems by joint discussion and negotiation. Con¬
ciliators have no legal powers.

Industrial
Disputes
Labour

Central and Local
Government
411
Disputes which cannot be settled in this way may, at the request of both
parties, be referred to voluntary arbitration, either by a single arbitrator, by
an ad hoc Board of Arbitration, or by the Industrial Court, a permanent
tribunal established under the Industrial Courts Act. The court normally
consists of three members—the president, one member experienced in
representing employers and one in representing workpeople.
Like collective agreements, arbitration awards are not in themselves en¬
forceable at law, but, under the Terms and Conditions of Employment Act
1959, reports that a particular employer is not observing the recognised terms
or conditions of employment in his trade or industry may be made to the
Secretary of State by organisations which are parties to the relevant agreement
or award. If the matter is not otherwise settled, the Secretary of State must
refer it to the Industrial Court which, after hearing the case, may issue an
award requiring the employer to observe the recognised terms or conditions.
Such an award becomes an implied term of the contract of employment of
individual employees.
The Secretary of State is also empowered to appoint a Court of Inquiry or
Committee of Investigation into a dispute, whether existing or apprehended.
These procedures are primarily means of informing public opinion of the
facts of a dispute (the report of a Court of Inquiry has to be laid before
Parliament). Although the recommendations contained in the reports of such
bodies are not binding on the parties, they often provide the basis for further
negotiations leading to a settlement.
Over the past 10 years the number of working days lost each year through
stoppages of work arising from industrial disputes has been on an average
about 4I million which, taking the working population as a whole, works out
at approximately i£ hours per worker a year. The time lost through industrial
stoppages is very much less than that lost on account of sickness, accidents and
absenteeism and Britain’s record over the past ten years compares well with
that of most other industrial countries.
Nevertheless Government, industry and trade unions have expressed
concern both at the number of strikes which take place without the backing of
trade union headquarters and without exhausting the agreed or customary
procedures in the industry or workplace, and at the concentration of a high
proportion of these strikes in a limited number of important industries and it is
partly with the intention of improving relations in industry generally and so of
reducing the incidence of strikes that the Government introduced the Industrial
Relations Act.
While labour relations in government service and in the nationalised indus¬
tries are, in general, organised on the same principle as in private industry,
there are some special features.
Non-industrial employees in central Government service, where salaries and
conditions of service are dealt with by the Civil Service Department (see p.
48), are permitted and encouraged to join the appropriate Civil Service staff
associations (trade unions) and there is a highly developed system of negotia¬
tion and joint consultation by means of the National and Departmental
Whitley Councils (see p. 65). If there is failure to reach agreement by negotia¬
tion a department or association may, subject to certain limitations, report the
dispute to the Secretary of State for reference to the Civil Service Arbitration
Tribunal, an independent body appointed by the Secretary of State by
412
BRITAIN 1972*. AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
powers under the Industrial Courts Act 1919. Government industrial
employees are similarly encouraged to belong to trade unions and machinery
exists for joint consultation. There are four Trades Joint Councils on which
representatives of the Government and the trade unions sit to consider pay and
conditions of employment affecting individual grades and certain other limited
matters. A Joint Co-ordinating Committee, on which the Government and
Trades Joint Councils are represented, deals with national pay negotiations,
conditions of service and other matters of general application. In the main
employing departments there are departmental Joint Councils for the discus¬
sion of domestic matters. Disputes on wages or conditions of employment that
cannot be resolved by the existing machinery can be referred to the Industrial
Court for arbitration. , T . ~ r
In local government service there are separate National Joint Councils for
the main grades of employees (such as manual, clerical and technical em¬
ployees) which deal with wages and conditions of service as well as other
matters. There are corresponding regional and district councils.
Nationalised
Industries
In the nationalised industries, the main corporations, though not subject to
detailed governmental control, have a statutory duty to establish satisfactory
arrangements for collective bargaining in their industries and for joint con¬
sultation with their employees; but in carrying out these duties they are free to
choose suitable arrangements. The main difference from private industry is
that the corporations are not usually members of employers associations
(although the majority are ‘public sector members of the CBI). In some
industries they are sole or main employers, but even where part of the industry
is in private hands, as for example in road transport, the corporations are
separately and directly represented on wage-negotiating bodies.
Wages and conditions of service in the nationalised industries are generally
settled by negotiation between representatives of managements and tra e
unions at the national level; in most cases there are also regional and local
bodies, similarly representative, to deal with local implications but not norm¬
ally to negotiate separate local agreements. Most of the industries use e
facilities for arbitration offered to industry generally by the DE, but coa -
mining and rail transport have their own special arrangements. Consultations
at all levels, including the workplace level, have been arranged in a e
nationalised industries according to the traditions and needs of each industry.
Some of the nationalised industries have felt that joint consultation was
best carried out by their negotiating bodies; others have established separate
and specially constituted joint committees at all levels.

Industrial
Relations

mission in March 1969 to examine such matters as might be referred to 1 y
the Secretary of State for Employment concerning the functioning and
devekfpment^of institutions and procedures for the conduct of mdustrral
relations; to promote improvements in such institutions, Pr°“dures and
relations; and to report. Under the 1971 Industrial Relations Act the CIR
will become a statutory body and its functions will be extended (see p. 407)-
