433
The
Periodical
Press
News Agencies
There are over 4,460 periodical publications in Britain, classified as ‘general’,
‘specialised’, ‘trade’, ‘technical’ and ‘professional’. There are also some 550
‘house magazines’ produced by industrial undertakings, business houses or
public services for the benefit of their employees and/or clients.
General and specialised periodicals include magazines of general interest;
women’s magazines; publications for children; religious periodicals for all
denominations; fiction magazines; magazines dealing with sport, gardening,
hobbies and humour; journals specialising in various subjects such as politics,
finance and economics, science, agriculture, medicine and the arts; and the
publications of learned societies, trade unions, regiments, universities and
other associations.
The weekly periodicals with the highest sales in Britain are: Woman
(2,050,855); Woman's (1,729,826); Woman's Own (1,703,331); Woman’s
Realm (1,022,784); and Weekend (1,274,418); together with the Radio Times
(3,501,096) and TV Times (3,129,381). The leading journals of opinion are
The Economist (circulation 99,747), a politically independent publication
covering topics from a wider angle than its title implies; the New Statesman
(circulation 76,035), which is a review of politics, literature and the arts with
an independent socialist political tendency; the Spectator, which covers much
the same subjects from an independent conservative standpoint; Tribune,
which has a strongly left-wing but anti-communist bias; New Society, which
covers the sociological aspects of current affairs; and New Scientist, which
reports on the progress of science and technology in terms which the non¬
specialist can understand. Punch (110,081), traditionally the leading humorous
periodical, has in recent years devoted increasing attention to public affairs.
Literary and political journals and those specialising in international and
Commonwealth affairs, published monthly or quarterly, appeal generally speak¬
ing to the more serious type of reader.
The publication of trade, technical, and professional journals (covering
some 500 subjects, many of them in considerable depth) has become one of the
more important aspects of the British publishing industry. In addition to
circulating in Britain, these journals have a considerable circulation outside
the United Kingdom and are an important media for selling British goods
overseas. Their publication ranges in frequency from weekly to quarterly.
Periodicals published in England circulate throughout the United Kingdom.
Weekly papers are also published in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland:
in Wales several monthly and quarterly journals in both Welsh and English;
in Scotland four monthly illustrated periodicals (Scottish Field, Scotland's
Magazine, Scots Magazine and Scotland), a weekly paper devoted to farming
interests (Scottish Farmer), a number of literary journals, of which the most
famous is probably Blackwood's, and numerous popular magazines; and in
Northern Ireland weekly, monthly and quarterly publications covering farm¬
ing, the linen industry, building, motoring, politics and social work.
There are three principal British news agencies:
Reuters Ltd. is a world news agency owned by the newspapers of the United
Kingdom, Australia and New Zealand through the Newspaper Publishers
Association, the Press Association, the Australian Associated Press and the
New Zealand Press Association, which are parties to a trust agreement to
safeguard the independence and integrity of the news service. Founded in
Aix-la-Chapelle in 1850 and transferred to London in 1851, Reuters now has
about 1,000 correspondents in 180 countries and territories, and links with 77
national or private news agencies, which give it access to coverage by many
434
Training for
Journalism
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
thousands of local reporters. Between 600,000 and 700,000 words of general
news, sports, and economic services reports are received in London every day
over a global network of leased cable and radio circuits. From these messages
regionalised news services, specially tailored to the needs of recipients in the
United Kingdom and eight main overseas regions, are transmitted to 120
countries for distribution to information media, either direct or through
national news agencies. Reuters Economic Services supply up-to-the-minute
information to business houses throughout the world. Its computerised sys¬
tems, including Stockmaster, Videoscan and Videomaster, offer virtually in¬
stant coverage of the important stock and commodity markets by computer
interrogation or video display. A computerised message-handling system,
known as the Automatic Data Exchange, is used to speed up the handling and
distribution of news.
The Press Association Ltd., the British national news agency founded in
1868, is co-operatively owned by the principal newspapers of the United
Kingdom outside London, and the Republic of Ireland. It provides news¬
papers, the broadcasting organisations, Reuters (of which it is a major joint
owner) and other international agencies with a complete service of home news,
including general and parliamentary news, legal reports, and all branches of
financial, commercial and sports news; and includes in its services to regional
papers the world news of Reuters and the Associated Press. Through its
Photographic Department the Press Association serves London and regional
newspapers with a daily picture service, including its own world photos and
those of the Associated Press. Its Special Reporting Service supplies reports
of local or special interest to daily and weekly papers and periodicals. All
profits are used to develop the service.
The Exchange Telegraph Company Ltd. (Extel), an independent news
agency founded in 1872, is a public company with over 1,000 shareholders,
which supplies financial and sporting news to newspapers and broadcasting
organisations. Racing services are also supplied by teleprinter and telephone
to subscribers in London and the provinces from offices in all important
cities and towns.
The British press and broadcasting organisations are also served by
Associated Press Ltd., which is the British operating company of the Associa¬
ted Press of America, and by United Press International, an international
news agency with a headquarters in London.
A number of other United Kingdom, Commonwealth and foreign agencies
and news services have offices in London, and there are agencies in other
cities, specialising in various aspects of newspaper and periodical require¬
ments. Syndication of features is not as common in the United Kingdom as
in some countries, but a few agencies specialise in this type of work.
The Printing and Publishing Industry Training Board (which has a chairman
and 23 members—nine employers, nine employees and five from educational
interests) is responsible for training in the printing, publishing and professional
photography industries. Its responsibilities include the formulation of training
schemes, the establishment of standards, ensuring that adequate facilities exist,
and the provision of a regional advisory service.
The National Council for the Training of Journalists (NCTJ), composed of
the major representative organisations in journalism and the press, works in
partnership with the Board. Its functions include superintending activities
concerning entry into journalism, setting and conducting examinations; and
organising short training courses and seminars for journalists.
THE PRESS
435
There are two normal methods of entry to newspaper journalism: (i) by
selection for a place on a full-time course lasting for one academic year and
(2) by direct recruitment to a regional or local newspaper. Students selected
for a pre-entry course must have gained two passes at the Advanced level of the
General Certificate of Education (GCE) and be under the age of 20 at the
beginning of a course. Some pre-entry students are sponsored by newspapers;
the others are assisted by the NCTJ to find employment on completion of the
course. The minimum educational requirement for direct entry is five GCE
passes at Ordinary level.
Entrants in both categories take part in a national training scheme which is
compulsory for all beginners under the age of 31. The scheme consists of
on-the-job training, and block-release courses for those who have not attended
a pre-entry course. A similar syllabus covering practical journalism, shorthand,
use of language, law, government and current affairs is used at both kinds of
course. Seven centres (five in England, one in Wales, and one in Scotland)
provide courses for reporters and there is one centre for newspaper photo¬
graphers.
All entrants to regional and local newspapers who are under the age of 24
serve an apprenticeship of three years (two years in the case of graduates)
following a period of probation which last six months for direct entrants and
three months for those who have attended pre-entry courses. At the end of
their apprenticeship trainees take a proficiency test which carries a salary
bonus. NCTJ approved training has been extended into the periodical field
on the basis of a special curriculum and courses are available for entrants in
London where the periodical publishing industry is mainly located.
Other training facilities include a university course in management (at
Warwick University) sponsored by the Newspaper Publishers Association and
the Newspaper Society, and a one-year postgraduate course in journalism
at the University College of South Wales in Cardiff. In addition a wide range
of training courses, covering circulation, advertising, industrial relations and
supervisory management've provided for the regional newspaper industry by
the Newspaper Socie*; training Service. Short general management courses
are also run, in conjunction with the University of Aston in Birmingham.
Under the Commonwealth Press Union Travelling Fellowship Scheme for
the training and education of young journalists throughout the Common¬
wealth, about eight journalists from overseas spend five months in the United
Kingdom each year, two months in the offices of newspapers or periodicals
and three months acquiring a general idea of life in Britain. A limited number
of travelling scholarships are also awarded to British journalists to enable
them to visit Commonwealth countries overseas.
The Thomson Foundation offers scholarships and organises training
courses for journalists from all parts of the world at its Centre in Cardiff,
and provides consultants and tutors for courses for journalists overseas.
The Commonwealth Secretariat is studying a plan for inter-Commonwealth
training arrangements in journalism and communications, based on a com¬
bination of indigenous schemes and training exchanges, and for the provision
of a special course in the United Kingdom on economics and finance for
Commonwealth journalists.
Press
Institutions
The most important organisations to which employers in the industry belong
are the Newspaper Publishers Association, whose members publish national
newspapers in London and Manchester; the Newspaper Society, which
represents the regional, local and London suburban press; the Scottish Daily
436 BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Newspaper Society, which represents the interests of daily and Sunday news¬
papers in Scotland; the Scottish Newspaper Proprietors Association, which
represents the owners of weekly newspapers in Scotland; Associated Northern
Ireland Newspapers, whose members are the proprietors of weekly newspapers
in Northern Ireland; and the Periodical Publishers Association, whose
membership embraces the independent publishers of trade and technical
publications and general magazines. On the journalists’ side there are the
Institute of Journalists (loj), founded in 1884 as the National Association
of Journalists, and the National Union of Journalists (NUJ), founded in 1907.
All practising journalists (including those engaged in radio, television, public
relations and freelance journalism) are eligible for membership of both these
organisations. In order to achieve joint working and prepare the ground for a
single organisation,1 an arrangement has been made for dual membership
without the payment of extra subscriptions. At the same time, to avoid over¬
lapping, different activities have been allocated to each organisation, the loj
being responsible for professional questions and the NUJ, primarily, for
industrial relations. Total membership is about 26,000 (NUJ about 24,000,
loj about 2,000).
The main aims of the Guild of British Newspaper Editors are to sustain
the dignity of editorship, to raise and safeguard the professional status of
editors, to protect the rights and freedom of the press, and to improve the
education and training of journalists: the Guild has about 400 members. The
British Association of Industrial Editors is the professional organisation to
which most editors of house journals belong.
The Printing and Kindred Trades Federation is the federation of the
printing trade unions which include the National Graphical Association,
the National Society of Operative Printers and Assistants (NATSOPA), the
Society of Graphical and Allied Trades (SOGAT), and the Scottish Typo¬
graphical Association.
The Press The Press Council, established in 1953 and reconstituted in 1963, has a lay
Council chairman and 25 members. Its aims are: to preserve the established freedom
of the British press; to maintain the character of the British press in ac¬
cordance with the highest professional and commercial standards; to keep
under review any developments likely to restrict the supply of information of
public interest and importance; to deal with complaints about the conduct
of the press or the conduct of persons and organisations towards the press; to
report on developments in the British press which may tend towards greater
concentration or monopoly; to make representation on appropriate occasions
to the Government, to organs of the United Nations and to press organisations
abroad; to publish its adjudications and periodical reports recording its work,
and to review from time to time developments in the British press and the
factors affecting them. In fulfilment of these aims, the council carries out the
main centralised research work into the press and the communications industry
generally, and publishes annual reports, which include statistics of the news¬
paper and periodical press and a series of articles examining the structure of
the leading press groups.
The Press and The press in Britain has the same freedom as the individual to do and say
the Law what it likes provided it does not transgress the law; in general, it is at liberty
1 Progress towards an amalgamation has reached the stage of the preparation of a draft
private Act of Parliament, which is considered to be necessary to constitute the new
combined body.
THE PRESS
437
to comment on matters of public interest. Apart from enactments relating
directly to such matters as the registration of newspapers for postal purposes,
there are no specific press laws but certain statutes include clauses which
apply, in particular or incidentally, to the press. These relate to such matters
as the extent of newspaper ownership in television companies; the transfer
of newspaper assets; restrictions on newspaper reporting of preliminary hear¬
ings of indictable offences (in England, Wales and Northern Ireland); the
right of press representatives to be admitted to meetings of local authorities;
restrictions on the publication of (a) divorce and domestic proceedings in
courts of law, (b) advertisement and investment circulars, which are governed
by Acts dealing with the publication of false or misleading descriptions of
goods and services and with fraud and (c) advertisements of remedies for
certain diseases, which are covered by public health legislation; agreements
between the Post Office and newspaper proprietors on telegraphic communica¬
tions, which must comply with telegraphs legislation; restrictions on certain
types of prize competition; and copyrights, which come under copyright laws.
Of particular relevance to the work of the press are the laws on libel and
defamation: contempt of court—a newspaper may not publish comments
on the conduct of judicial proceedings which are likely to prejudice their
reputation for fairness before or during the actual proceedings nor may it
publish before or during a trial anything which might tend to influence the
result; and seditious libel and incitement to disaffection. The obtaining and
publication of information from state and official sources of a confidential or
security nature is affected by the Official Secrets Acts.
Legal proceedings against the press are comparatively infrequent; the
majority of actions that do take place are libel actions1 brought by private
individuals. In such cases, the editor, proprietor, publisher, printer and
distributor of the newspaper, as well as the author of the article, may all be
held responsible.
1 In view of public anxiety about the severity of some penal damages in libel cases and
the application of official secrets legislation, the Government has set up two enquiries
into these aspects of the law as they affect the press. An enquiry is also in train about
the need for legislation to protect personal privacy in which the press and other media
are involved.
20 TELEVISION
AND RADIO
BROADCASTING
Broadcasting by television and radio in Britain is regulated by the Minister of
Posts and Telecommunications under the Wireless Telegraphy Acts 1949-
1967, which prohibit the sending or receiving of wireless communications,
except under licence.
Radio broadcasting services for Britain and abroad are provided by the
British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC), which was established by Royal
Charter in 1927.1 Television services are provided both by the BBC and by
the Independent Television Authority (ITA), which was established by the
Television Act 1954 as a supervisory body to control the operation of com¬
mercial television in Britain. The BBC operates two television and four radio
services on a national basis, and 20 local radio stations. The ITA provides one
television service.
Users of television sets must obtain an annual receiving licence, which can
be bought from most post offices. Licences for sets receiving black and white
pictures cost £7 a year, and for those receiving colour pictures £12 a year.
There were some 16-4 million receiving licences current in Britain in July 1971
of which nearly 15-6 million were for black and white, and over 800,000 for
colour television.
Hours of television and radio broadcasting are regulated by the Minister.
For television, BBC 1 and ITV are required to provide at least 55 hours of
broadcasting a week, but output must not exceed 3,300 hours in a year; for
BBC 2 the weekly requirement is 30 hours and the annual maximum i,95°
hours. Religious and educational programmes and broadcasts in the Welsh
language are excluded from these quotas. For BBC radio, the rules specify
daily limits to the broadcasting hours on each of the services.
Broadcasting Both the BBC and the ITA are constitutionally required to provide a ‘public
Authorities service’ with the purpose of disseminating information, education and
entertainment. The constitution and finances of the BBC are governed by
the Royal Charter of 1964 and by the Licence and Agreement of 1969, and
those of the ITA by the Television Act 1964 and its 1969 Licence.
The BBC and the ITA are independent authorities in the day-to-day
operations of broadcasting, including programmes and administration. The
Government, however, retains ultimate control, and the Minister of Posts and
Telecommunications, as the responsible minister, is answerable to Parliament
on broad questions of policy and may issue directions to the BBC and the
ITA on a number of technical and other subjects. Both organisations are
expected to show balance and due impartiality in their general presentation of
programmes, particularly where matters of public policy or controversial
1 Under Government proposals, commercial radio stations are to be allowed to broad¬
cast on a local basis (see p. 442)-
TELEVISION AND RADIO BROADCASTING
439
The British
Broadcasting
Corporation
The Independent
Television
Authority
subjects are concerned, and in this connection the Minister has powers to
prohibit the broadcasting of any particular item or class of item, or to revoke
the licences of the BBC or ITA at any time. These powers, however, are
treated as major reserve powers and, in fact, no formal veto has ever been
placed on the broadcasting of a particular item. Both the BBC and the ITA
are required to prepare annual reports and accounts which are presented to
Parliament.
The Corporation consists of 12 governors (including a chairman, a vice-
chairman and separate national governors for Scotland, Wales and Northern
Ireland), each appointed for a period of not more than five years by the
Queen on the advice of the Government. The governors are constitutionally
responsible for the conduct of the whole broadcasting operation, including
the production and presentation of the programmes on television and radio,
and the provision and working of the necessary installations and equipment.
A number of councils advise them on such matters as religious broadcasting,
music, agriculture, school broadcasting, further education, programmes for
immigrants, science and engineering and charitable appeals. The governors
appoint the chief executive officer of the BBC—the Director General—with
whom they discuss all major matters of policy and finance. He is chairman
of the Corporation’s board of management, which also includes the managing
directors for television, radio and external broadcasting, the directors of
programmes for television and radio, the directors of personnel, finance,
public affairs and engineering, and the editor, news and current affairs.
The National Broadcasting Councils for Scotland and Wales control the
policy and content of television and radio programmes intended primarily
for reception in their respective countries. Local radio councils, representa¬
tive of the local community, are appointed by the Minister of Posts and
Telecommunications (in consultation with the BBC) to help in the develop¬
ment and operation of local radio stations.
The services of the BBC are financed from: an annual grant voted by
Parliament for the domestic services, which is the income from the sale of
broadcast receiving licences less certain deductions for collection and other
expenses; an annual grant-in-aid voted by Parliament for the external
services; profits from BBC publications, mainly the Radio Times, which gives
details of BBC radio and television programmes and, with a weekly sale of
about 4 million copies, attracts a large advertising revenue; and income from
BBC Radio and Television Enterprises. The net revenue from the sale of
licences for the year ended March 1971 amounted to £91-5 million and the
net grant for the external services was £13 ’2 million. The cost of providing the
local radio services is met by the BBC out of licence revenue, although local
authorities are encouraged to contribute.
The Independent Television Authority consists of a chairman, a deputy
chairman and, at present, nine other members (three of whom have responsi¬
bility for Scotland, Wales and Monmouthshire, and Northern Ireland
severally) whose appointment is in the hands of the Minister of Posts and
Telecommunications. The ITA plays no part in producing programmes;
these are provided on a regional basis by commercial programme companies.
The authority’s four main functions are to appoint the programme companies,
to control the programme output, to control the advertising and to build, own
and operate the transmitting stations for the independent television network.
The ITA is advised by a General Advisory Council, by Scottish, Northern
Ireland and Welsh committees, and by committees on educational broad-
44°
The Programme
Companies
Control by
the IT A
Domestic
Television
and Radio
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
casting, religious broadcasting, charitable appeals and advertising. A specialist
panel advises on medical and allied advertisements.
The chief executive officer of the ITA is the Director General. There are
also two deputy directors general, and a headquarters and regional office staff
covering all technical and administrative services. Regional officers act as
representatives of the ITA to the programme companies.
The ITA receives no payments from licence revenue; the finance for its
operations is drawn from annual rental payments made to it by the programme
companies which amounted to about £7! million in the year ended March
1971. The programme companies also pay to the ITA for transfer to the
Exchequer a further sum (the levy) related to their advertising revenue; in the
year ended March 1971 this amounted to some £25 million.
Fifteen programme companies hold six-year contracts to provide television
programmes in the 14 independent television regions of Britain (two com¬
panies share the contract for London, one providing programmes during
the week and the other at the weekend). The companies operate on a commer¬
cial basis, deriving their revenue from advertisements which are inserted into
and between programmes. The financial resources, advertising revenue,
and programme production of the companies vary considerably, depending
largely on the size of population in their areas. (There are 4-3 million homes
receiving independent television in London as against only 32,000 in the
Channel Islands.)
With the guidance and approval of the ITA, each company plans the
content of the programmes to be broadcast in its area. These consist partly
of material produced by the company itself, partly of that produced by the
other programme companies, and partly of that produced elsewhere, for
example, by the major film companies. The five largest companies (Granada,
Thames, Yorkshire, London Weekend and ATV Network Ltd.) produce a
larger proportion of their own programmes and provide more programmes
for broadcast elsewhere in the national network than do the smaller ones.
A common news service is provided by Independent Television News
Limited, a non-profit-making-company in which all the programme com¬
panies are shareholders. The negotiations concerning the supply, exchange
and purchase of programmes and their co-ordinated transmission through
the independent television network take place largely on the Network
Planning Committee which consists of representatives of all the programme
companies and of the ITA.
When a company, on the basis of negotiations with the other companies, has
decided on a programme schedule for its area, it is required to submit this to
the ITA for approval. The authority has wide-ranging powers to control and
regulate the content and quality of programmes; for example, it ensures that a
‘proper balance’ of views is expressed and has drawn up a code on violence
stating that special precautions are to be taken when children are likely to be
viewing. There are also safeguards in the Television Act 19641° prevent news¬
paper shareholdings in a programme company leading to results contrary to
the public interest. However, the ITA believes that newspapers bring valu¬
able qualities to the development of television and is not opposed to investment
by them.
Television viewing has become by far the most popular recreational activity in
Britain and almost all families now have television sets. Average viewing time
per head of population in 1969—70 was over 14 hours a week. In the last decade
BBC Television
Independent
Television
TELEVISION AND RADIO BROADCASTING 441
there have been major advances in the technical quality and diversity of the
programmes. The introduction of a second BBC television channel in 1964
both increased the choice of programmes available and provided television
pictures of a clearer definition than had previously been possible. The trans¬
mission of colour programmes, which began in 1967 on this new channel and
has since been extended to the other two channels, further increased the scope
of television. A high proportion of programmes transmitted on the three
services during peak viewing hours are in colour.
Radio attracts its largest audiences during the day-time when television is
not on the air. In 1969-70 radio listening averaged some 8^ hours a week per
head of population. Among important innovations in recent years have been
the introduction of a separate BBC radio channel providing continuous ‘pop’
music, and the development of local radio.
In 1936 the BBC launched the world’s first regular public service of high
definition television. It now provides two services: BBC 1, which is trans¬
mitted on both 405 lines very high frequency (vhf) and on 625 lines ultra
high frequency (uhf); and BBC 2, which is transmitted only on 625 lines.
Practically all British families live within range of BBC 1 vhf transmitters.
Over 80 per cent of the population are within range of BBC 2 transmitters,
and some 9 million people are already equipped with sets and aerials capable
of receiving uhf transmissions.
The BBC started the first regular colour television service in Europe in
1967, on BBC 2. In November 1969 BBC 1 went into full colour. BBC colour
television productions cover the whole range of television output: drama,
documentary programmes, feature programmes, films, sport and other out¬
side broadcasts, comedy and other light entertainment, children’s programmes,
music, schools broadcasts, educational programmes for adults, and religious
programmes.
Through co-ordinated planning of programmes on its two television ser¬
vices, the BBC is able to cater simultaneously for people of differing interests.
BBC 1 presents a high proportion of family entertainment programmes and
other programmes with a wide appeal. This allows BBC 2 to be more experi¬
mental, to place greater emphasis on serious cultural and documentary pro¬
grammes, and to cater more for minority tastes.
All BBC 2 programmes and the majority of those on BBC 1 are broadcast
nationally. At certain times of day, programmes of regional news and interest
for different parts of the country are inserted into the BBC 1 service. An ex¬
tension and reorganisation of regional television production has been carried
out, based on proposals outlined in 1969 in the BBC plan Broadcasting in the
Seventies (see Bibliography p. 483). In the course of a year, the BBC television
service broadcasts on the national network for some 6,700 hours. Some 11,000
screen hours are exported annually to 80 countries, including those in Eastern
Europe.
The first regular independent television (ITV) service was inaugurated in
^55 b7 a programme transmission from the ITA London station at Croydon.
Black and white programmes, transmitted on 405 lines vhf, are within range
of almost all the population. In 1969 duplicate programmes in colour were
introduced on 625 lines uhf, and by mid-1971 over 80 per cent of the popu¬
lation were within range of ITV colour transmissions.
The main items broadcast in an average week by the independent television
companies are entertainment programmes, plays and serials, discussions and
documentaries, sport, films, and children’s, religious and educational pro-
442
BBC Radio
Commercial Radio
BBC External
Services
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
grammes. More than one-third of viewing time is filled with ‘serious’ pro¬
grammes. There are about three short advertising intervals an hour, in and
between programmes.
The first regular radio broadcasts by the BBC began in 1927. BBC Radio
provides listeners with four alternative national channels. Following changes
introduced in 1970, each channel has a distinct character of its own. Radio 1,
broadcasting some 12 hours a day, provides a programme of ‘pop’ music,
while Radio 2, broadcasting over 20 hours a day, provides light music as well
as being the principal channel for the coverage of sport. Radio 3, broad¬
casting over 15 hours a day, provides continuous, mainly classical music
(much of which is in stereo) and in the evening offers, in addition, works of
artistic and intellectual interest. Radio 4, broadcasting 17 hours a day, is the
main speech programme, providing the principal news and information service
of the BBC. In addition a wide range of drama, talks and entertainment pro¬
grammes is presented as well as broadcasts to schools.
Local radio was started by the BBC as an experiment in eight towns in
1967 and has since been extended to cover 20 towns. Broadcasting on vhf,
local radio stations provide at least 5-^ hours of locally produced programmes
each day, normally during the early morning, lunch-time and early evening
periods. During the rest of the day they transmit programmes from the BBC’s
national networks. Local broadcasts provide a comprehensive service of local
news and information, besides covering local arts and sports activities and
offering residents opportunities to air their views on subjects of local interest.
Government proposals to permit local broadcasting by a network of up to 60
commercial radio stations were published in March 1971 Alternative
Service of Radio Broadcasting, see Bibliography p. 483). The stations, which
would broadcast on both vhf and medium wavebands, would operate under
the control of the ITA, which would be renamed the Independent Broad¬
casting Authority. Financed by advertising revenue, they would be expected to
combine popular programming with ‘fostering a greater public awareness of
local affairs and involvement in the community’. No date has yet been fixed
for introducing the legislation necessary to implement these proposals.
The BBC broadcasts to most countries overseas. The main objectives of BBC
external broadcasts are to give unbiased news, to reflect British opinion and
to project British life and culture. The BBC broadcasts in 40 languages
(including English) for a total of over 720 hours a week. News bulletins (of
which there are more than 1,000 a week), current affairs programmes, political
commentaries and topical magazine programmes form the main part of the
output. A full service of sports commentaries and results, all kinds of music,
drama and a wide range of general entertainment programmes are also in¬
cluded.
The languages in which the external services broadcast and the length of
time each language is on the air are prescribed by the Government. Apart
from this the BBC has full responsibility for the broadcasting operations and is
completely independent in determining the content of news and other pro¬
grammes. .
The BBC World Service broadcasts for 24 hours a day in English and is
supplemented at peak listening times by additional series of programmes de¬
signed to be of special interest to Africa, Europe and the Caribbean.
The foreign language broadcast services are divided into areas, namely, the
African, Arabic, Eastern, Far Eastern, Latin American, French (to Europe and

Transmitting

BBC

Africa), Central European, South European, German and East European
Services. Broadcasts range from 70 hours a week in Arabic, 33 hours in Ger¬
man and 31 hours in Russian to half an hour in Nepali. The BBC’s English by
Radio and Television Service is the most extensive language teaching under¬
taking in the world. Some 230 radio programmes of English lessons are
broadcast weekly with explanations in 25 other languages, and recorded lessons
are supplied to some 280 stations in 69 countries. English by Television pro¬
grammes, also produced for teaching purposes, are shown in more than 60
countries.
BBC news bulletins and other programmes are rebroadcast by the domestic
radio services of many countries. Rebroadcasting takes the form of direct
relays from BBC transmissions and the use of programme material supplied
in recorded form through the BBC tape and disc transcription service. There
are about 160 rebroadcasts daily of World Service news bulletins in some 40
countries. The Transcription Service offers programmes to more than 80
countries.
Another part of the external services is the Monitoring Service which listens
to and reports on foreign broadcasts, supplying a daily flow of significant news
and comment from overseas to the BBC, the Press, and government depart¬
ments.
Programme links are generally rented by the BBC from the Post Office, al¬
though some are provided by the BBC with Post Office agreement. The opera¬
tion and maintenance of the 231 transmitting stations from which its various
programmes are sent out are, however, solely a BBC responsibility.
For its domestic radio programmes, the BBC uses 151 studios in London
and the regions, and for its external services 47 in London and 7 overseas.
In addition, there are 40 semi-automatic studios which can be operated by
programme officials without engineering staff. BBC television productions
come from main studios at the Television Centre in west London and other
studios in various parts of London, and from fully equipped regional studios
at Belfast, Birmingham, Bristol, Cardiff, Glasgow and Manchester. There are
also television studios at Aberdeen, Edinburgh, Hull, Leeds, Newcastle,
Norwich, Nottingham, Plymouth and Southampton. Outside broadcasting is
covered by a number of mobile units.
The ITA now transmits programmes from 47 vhf and 44 uhf stations through¬
out Britain, programme links being provided by the Post Office. Independent
television programmes are produced at studio centres in Aberdeen, Belfast,
Birmingham, Bristol, Cardiff, Carlisle, Dover, Glasgow, Leeds, London,
Manchester, Newcastle, Norwich, Plymouth, St. Helier, and Southampton.
The establishment of these studios is the direct result of the ITA’s policy of
encouraging the development of regional television, and the programmes are
designed for either local or national broadcasting. A number of new studios
have also been built for colour television.
The BBC does not give publicity to any individual firm or organised interest
except when it is necessary to provide effective and informative programmes.
Under the terms of its licence and agreement it must not broadcast sponsored
programmes or, without the consent of the Minister of Posts and Tele¬
communications, broadcast any matter for payment.
Advertisements are broadcast on independent television subject to the
relevant provisions in the Television Act, in particular that there should be
444
Political
Broadcasting
Technical
Developments

International

BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
no sponsoring of programmes by advertisers, that all advertisements should be
clearly distinguishable as such and recognisably separate from the pro¬
gramme, and the amount of time given to advertising should not be so great
as to detract from the value of the programmes as a medium of information,
education and entertainment. In any one hour of broadcasting the amount of
advertising time is normally limited to seven minutes. Averaged over the day’s
programmes it must not exceed six minutes per hour. The ITA has drawn
up a code governing standards and practice in advertising giving guidance
about the types and methods of advertisement that may not be used. Certain
types of advertising are prohibited, notably that of cigarettes (under a govern¬
ment ruling of 1965) and for betting. Advertisements may not be inserted in
certain types of programmes, for example, in broadcasts to schools. The cost
of inserting advertisements in the ITV service is borne by the advertisers,
who pay the programme companies for advertising time.
Broadcasts on political issues include a daily factual and impartial account of
proceedings in Parliament, transmitted on BBC’s Radio 4 when Parliament
is in session, and there is frequent coverage of political subjects in news
bulletins and current affairs programmes on both radio and television.
Ministerial and party political broadcasts are also transmitted periodically
under rules agreed between the major political parties, the BBC and the ITA.
The Minister of Posts and Telecommunications is advised on the technical
aspects of television and vhf sound broadcasting by the Television Advisory
Committee, which consists of an independent chairman, the Director General
of the BBC, the Director General of the ITA, representatives from the radio
industry, independent members, and representatives of interested government
departments.
Research into technical problems is carried out by the scientific and
engineering staffs of the BBC, the ITA, the Post Office, the Ministry of Posts
and Telecommunications, and the radio industry. Recent developments by the
BBC include the electronic conversion of monochrome and colour television
pictures between the European and the American systems j the reproduction
of television pictures in slow motion; and the development of a sound-and-
vision system, which enables the television sound and picture to be carried
over a single 625-line vision circuit, and thus eliminates the operational com¬
plexity and expense of a separate circuit for the sound. The ITA has carried
out research into unattended transmitter networks and has based its new uhf
network entirely on unmanned transmitters; it is investigating the use of com¬
puters for the control of transmitter networks.
Inter-continental television relays by means of communication satellites began
in 1962 when the first live programme exchanges between the United States
and Europe were made via Telstar, and have increased in range and scale as
synchronous satellites, which appear stationary relative to the earth and thus
permit 24-hour, high-grade transmissions, have been commissioned.
Direct links with other continents were achieved in 1964: between Europe
and Japan, and between Britain and Australia. In 1967 the first world-wide
television programme, containing live sequences from several countries in
Europe and Africa, the United States, Canada, Mexico, Australia and Japan,
was broadcast.
The BBC and the ITA (together with the Independent Television Companies
Association) are active members of the European Broadcasting Union (EBU),
TELEVISION AND RADIO BROADCASTING
445
which was established to advance international broadcasting projects. The
union now has 31 full members among the broadcasting organisations in
Western Europe and 55 associate members (mostly from outside Europe,
including the United States and many of the nations of the Commonwealth).
It manages Eurovision; is responsible for the technical and administrative
arrangements for co-ordinating the exchange of programmes over that net¬
work and for intercontinental satellite links; and maintains a technical
monitoring station, where frequency measurements and other observations
on broadcasting stations are carried out.
The BBC is a member of the Commonwealth Broadcasting Conference.
Each national organisation extends to the others facilities, for instance, in the
use of studios, recording channels, and programme contributions. The BBC,
in addition, provides a large amount of technical aid, particularly in training
the staff of other broadcasting organisations throughout the world, and mem¬
bers of the BBC’s staff are seconded for service overseas.
The BBC, Reuters, the Australian Broadcasting Commission, the Canadian
Broadcasting Corporation and the New Zealand Broadcasting Corporation
are joint partners in Visnews, which supplies a service of world news film to
some 150 television organisations in over 80 countries and is the most widely
used newsfilm agency in the world. The International Television Federation
(Intertel), whose members are broadcasting organisations from Canada,
Australia, the United States and the BBC, produces high-quality information
programmes which are exchanged overseas. United Press International, a
television newsfilm agency, and Independent Television News jointly provide
an international service to television organisations via the Eurovision network
and by satellite.
The Government has recently established the Centre for Educational De¬
velopment Overseas (CEDO, see p. 166), which includes in its activities train¬
ing in educational television and radio for members of broadcasting organisa¬
tions overseas. The centre receives an annual grant from the Government.
Training in television work is also provided for overseas trainees at the Thom¬
son Centre in Glasgow, run by the Thomson Foundation, a charitable trust.
The Overseas Development Administration of the Foreign and Commonwealth
Office spends a considerable amount each year on radio and television training
for overseas students in Britain.
The BBC and the ITA participate in the work of the International Tele¬
communication Union (ITU)—the United Nations specialised agency re¬
sponsible for the regulation and control of all international telecommunication
services (including radio and television), for the allocation and registration of
all radio frequencies and, through its international consultative committees,
for the promotion and co-ordination of the international study of technical
problems in broadcasting. The BBC is also represented on the United King¬
dom Committee of the International Special Committee on Radio Interference.

Sport
Interest in most sports in Britain, for both participants and spectators, is grow¬
ing, in some cases (notably swimming, golf, skating and sailing) at a very fast
rate; a recent trend has been the growth of ‘high risk’ sports such as mountain¬
eering and parachuting. Some of the sports most popular among participants
are: swimming, tenpin bowling, fishing, billiards and snooker, association and
rugby football, lawn tennis, squash rackets, golf, riding, cricket and skating.
For spectators (including audiences who watch sport on television) the follow¬
ing sports are among the most popular: association and rugby football, racing,
boxing and wrestling, motor car and motor cycle racing, athletics, cricket, show
jumping, lawn tennis, swimming and skating. Those who engage in sport may
be professionals (paid players) or amateurs.1 Professionals keep up the
technical standards of their sports and spectators make a vital contribution
by their enthusiasm and their financial support; but the sporting life of
Britain derives its character principally from the amateur element—people
who devote time and energy to organising sport and to teaching and training,
as well as the many thousands of all ages who engage in sport for pleasure alone.
The Government is not directly concerned with the organisation or promotion
of sport in Britain; however, it provides funds for the provision of recreational
facilities and for national governing bodies of sport towards administrative
costs, coaching schemes, participation in international events overseas, and the
holding in Britain of important international competitions. In 1971 the
Government announced that the Sports Council (which has advised the
Government on the allocation of funds) would be given executive powers,
including the responsibility for making grants. The Sports Council deals with
sports matters concerning England specifically and Great Britain as a whole;
Scotland and Wales have their own sports councils. All the councils advise the
Government on sport, co-operate with sports organisations and provide a
forum for the discussion of problems affecting sport. Nine regional councils in
England bring together local authorities, voluntary sports and other organisa¬
tions to consider regional sports matters, particularly the planning of facili¬
ties. In Northern Ireland, the Ministry of Education is advised about sport
and physical recreation by the Youth and Sports Council.
In 1970—71 direct government expenditure on sport in Great Britain totalled
some £2 million; in Northern Ireland £453,000 in grants was given to public
authorities and voluntary organisations for sports facilities, playgrounds,
overseas visits and coaching schemes. Voluntary bodies and private concerns
also make substantial provisions for sport in Britain, but the greatest provision
is made by local authorities; capital expenditure by local authorities on sports
and recreational facilities amounted to over £17 million in 1970-71.
The law requires all publicly maintained schools in Britain to provide for the
physical education (gymnastics, games, athletics, dancing and swimming) of
1 Some sports, for example, athletics, Rugby Union football, hockey and rowing, are
entirely amateur, but in other sports the distinction between professional and amateur
status is becoming less strictly defined and the Sports Council has recommended
the progressive elimination of the distinction.

their pupils. Schools in the national systems (except those solely for infants)
must have a playing field, or the use of one, and most secondary schools have a
gymnasium and other amenities such as swimming pools, sports halls and halls
designed for dance and movement: in an increasing number of areas, physical
education facilities in schools are being expanded to meet the recreational
needs of the whole community. Facilities for, and instruction in, many kinds of
sport are likewise provided at the independent preparatory and public schools
and at the universities (some of which have departments of physical education).
Local authorities also provide playing fields, gymnasia, tennis courts, golf
courses, boating lakes, swimming baths and sports centres on an increasing
scale, and some arrange further education classes in various physical education
subjects. Large industrial firms often provide sports facilities for their
employees and, in many cases, make them available for members of the public.
The national voluntary organisations most closely concerned with the general
development of sport are the Central Council of Physical Recreation, the
Scottish Council of Physical Recreation, and the National Playing Fields
Association. The British Olympic Association, whose main functions are
connected with the participation of British competitors in the Olympic
Games, is also interested in all matters likely to benefit sport or physical
recreation in Britain as a whole. In addition, each sport has its own governing
body with, in many cases, entirely separate autonomous governing bodies in
Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. The British Sports Association for the
Disabled organises sports and games for disabled people and receives a
government grant.
The Central Council of Physical Recreation (CCPR) in 1971 had a member¬
ship of about 300, over 200 representing national bodies in England, Wales and
Northern Ireland concerned with the development of post-school physical
recreation. Its functions included the promotion of physical recreation, the
organisation of courses for instructors, classes in personal performance,
lectures and publicity events. It has run some 2,000 courses for more than
40,000 people each year and provided advisory, technical and administrative
services, including the secretariat for the Sports Council and regional sports
councils. The CCPR’s role in the arrangements for the reorganisation of the
Sports Council (see p. 446) is being discussed.
The Scottish Council of Physical Recreation (SCPR), the counterpart in
Scotland of the CCPR, has 148 affiliated organisations, including the govern¬
ing bodies of all the Scottish sports, and receives a grant-in-aid from the
Scottish Education Department. In April 1972 the SCPR is to be merged
with the Sports Council for Scotland.
The National Playing Fields Association (NPFA) aims to stimulate the
provision of playing fields, playgrounds and sports centres by publicity and
technical and financial assistance. Since its inception in 1925 it has distributed
over ^1*9 million in the form of grants for playing field and playground
schemes and over £500,000 in the form of loans. It assists more than 400
schemes a year.
The NPFA council is composed of representatives of the governing bodies
of various sports organisations, of the British Olympic Association and the
CCPR, and of a number of educational bodies, voluntary youth organisations,
physical education associations and local authorities. The national head¬
quarters in London employs a small full-time staff, including a technical and
research department which gives advice on the provision and layout of indoor
448 BRITAIN I972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
and outdoor sports facilities, on matters relating to the recreational needs of
children from their earliest years, and on the establishment of playgrounds
and play leadership schemes. The NPFA derives its funds mainly from
voluntary contributions but it also receives a small government grant towards
administrative costs. It has branches in Scotland and Northern Ireland and in
nearly every English and Welsh county; administration is carried out volun¬
tarily—in many cases in association with a local authority or rural community
council.
National Nine national sports centres in Britain—four in England, two in Scotland, two
Sports in Wales and one in Northern Ireland—are administered by the CCPR and the
Centres SCPR with the help of government grants. The centres, some of which were
established with voluntary funds, provide a wide range of courses for instructors
and performers in many recreational activities. One centre has been developed
as a national sailing centre; two are primarily used as training centres for
mountain activities, including climbing and rescue techniques; and a fourth
provides training for outdoor activities such as walking, climbing, sailing and
field studies. Combined facilities for ranges of sports are provided at the other
centres which include the Crystal Palace National Recreation Centre in
London and the Welsh National Recreation Centre in Cardiff. The centre at
Crystal Palace has a main stadium seating 12,000 spectators, a sports hall seat¬
ing 2,000 spectators, a swimming hall with pools meeting Olympic require¬
ments, a teaching pool and a gallery for 2,000 spectators, an indoor cricket
school, practice rooms for all indoor activities, a hostel for 140 residents and
staff housing: these facilities are available for international competitions as
well as for training purposes, and are supported by a grant from the Greater
London Council, in addition to the government grant. The Cardiff centre is
supported by local authorities, as well as by government grants.
A newly built national rowing centre (financed by the Government and
Nottinghamshire County Council) is to be administered by the CCPR.
Meadowbank sports centre in Edinburgh, administered by Edinburgh
Corporation, includes facilities for athletics, water sports, cycling, squash
rackets, indoor climbing, target shooting and archery. There are several
national centres for individual sports or specialist courses, generally adminis¬
tered by the sponsoring organisations. These include: the national equestrian
centre in Warwickshire, run by the British Horse Society; and a national sports
stadium for the paralysed and disabled—the first of its kind in the world—run
by the British Sports Association for the Disabled.
POPULAR SPORTS Sports popular in Britain are described below in alphabetical order. Mention
is made of various organisations concerned with them, usually in Britain as a
whole; in many cases, associated or subsidiary organisations for particular
sports exist in one or more of the four component countries of Britain.
Aero Sports Aero sports—including private flying, gliding and parachuting—are becoming
increasingly popular in Britain. Private flying is promoted by the British Light
Aviation Centre, founded in 1966, to which are affiliated some 212 clubs.
There are over 18,000 pilots active in Britain (many of whom fly for business
purposes as well as for pleasure) and some 2,800 light aircraft are registered.
Air-racing, with about 250 pilots, is controlled by the Royal Aero Club. Gliding
attracts about 7,000 people to some 80 gliding clubs in Britain. The clubs
organise flying activities, including regional and national championships, and
are members of the British Gliding Association, founded in 1929. Parachuting
SPORT
449
Archery
Association
Football
is a popular sport, with 30 clubs affiliated to the British Parachute Association,
formed in 1962. The association, which has about 3,000 members, organises
national championships, prepares teams for international championships, and
regulates the safety aspects of the sport.
Target archery, which is to be reintroduced into the Olympic Games in
1972, has a following in Britain of some 9,000 members from over 600 clubs
and societies. The governing body is the Grand National Archery Society,
founded in 1844, to which are affiliated regional and county organisations.
Although football of a kind was played in the Middle Ages or even earlier,
as an organised game it dates from the nineteenth century; association football
was adopted at Cambridge in 1848. Nowadays, the game (often called ‘soccer’)
is controlled in England by the Football Association (FA), formed in 1863.
The FA promotes the interests of the game; prevents infringement of the
agreed rules; arranges for instruction of promising young players (some
£50,000 is spent annually on coaching); organises matches and competitions,
including the international matches played by England, the Amateur Cup
competition, the FA Sunday Cup competition, two national youth competitions,
and the competition for its own leading trophy, the FA Challenge Cup; and
chooses and manages English international teams. Over 360 clubs are registered
with the FA and some 32,000 clubs are affiliated to district or regional associa¬
tions. The FA derives its main income from subscriptions and admission
charges to international and cup matches, and ploughs back a large portion of
the money into the game. Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales have their
own controlling bodies: the Scottish Football Association, the Irish Football
Association and the Football Association of Wales.
The principal professional matches in England and Wales (played once or
twice weekly) are controlled by the Football League, comprising 92 professional
clubs. The League’s funds are derived largely from a levy of 4 per cent of the
net gate receipts from league matches, after allowable expenses have been
deducted; from annual payments from football pools promoters for the use of
league fixture lists; and from television rights. In Scotland the Scottish Foot¬
ball League comprises 37 clubs; Northern Ireland has its own League. Clubs
belonging to the English and Scottish Leagues are organised in divisions, the
members of which compete against one another for the respective league
championships. During the season attendances at Football League matches
total about 30 million and gate receipts amount to about £8 million. Several
million people stake small weekly sums on the results of league matches in a
form of pool betting operated by commercial companies.
The annual competitions for the FA Cup and the Scottish FA Cup are
organised on a knock-out basis and the finals—two of the most important
football matches of the year—are played at Wembley Stadium, London
(which can accommodate some 100,000 spectators) and at Hampden Park,
Glasgow (which can accommodate about 135,000 people). International
matches, especially those between England, Scotland, Wales and Northern
Ireland, also excite great interest.
Amateur footballers greatly outnumber the professionals (there are nearly
1 million amateurs, including schoolboys and members of the armed forces,
to 7,000 or 8,000 professionals), but their teams rarely compete on equal terms,
since professional teams are more systematically and intensively trained.
Amateur teams compete against each other for the FA Amateur Challenge Cup.

BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
In England and Wales, amateur athletics, which include running (track, road
and cross-country), relay racing, jumping, vaulting, hurdling, steeplechasing,
throwing and race-walking are governed (for men) by the Amateur Athletic
Association (AAA), founded in 1880 to encourage the sport, to establish
uniform regulations, and to promote annual championship meetings. The
AAA is now organised from club to national level by honorary officers and
managed by representative members appointed by the Northern, Midland,
Southern and Welsh areas and by affiliated clubs and associations (amateur
athletic clubs, schools and youth organisations), of which there are hundreds
throughout England and Wales. It administers a coaching scheme under which
eight full-time national coaches lecture and coach in schools, youth clubs,
evening institutes, training colleges and universities and at special courses
organised by the national associations, by regional associations or by the
Central Council of Physical Recreation. Some of the coaches’ work is directly
concerned with coaching young athletes but their main duties are to instruct
men who wish to qualify as AAA coaches, over 1,600 of whom give voluntary
service in the counties and districts of England and Wales. Women’s athletics
in England and Wales are promoted by the Women’s Amateur Athletic
Association, founded in 1922. Scotland and Northern Ireland have their own
amateur athletic associations, with similar functions; there are also separate
women’s AAAs for each country.
Track meetings are held throughout Britain from April to October. The
main events in England and Wales are: the national championships for men
and women and international matches usually held in London; area and county
championships; and the universities, Services, business houses and schools
championship meetings. Clubs usually compete in cross-country running from
October to March, and county, area and national cross-country champion¬
ships are held. Scottish events follow a similar pattern.
International athletics and the selection of British teams are dealt with by
the British Amateur Athletic Board, composed of representatives of the
national associations for men and women and affiliated to the International
Amateur Athletic Federation. Teams from Britain compete in the Olympic
Games, and separate teams representing England, Wales, Scotland, and
Northern Ireland compete in the Commonwealth Games, held at four-yearly
intervals between the Olympic Games.
The Highland Games, traditional gatherings of local people in the Highlands
of Scotland, at which sports (including tossing the caber, putting the weight,
and throwing the hammer) and dancing and piping competitions take place,
are unique spectacles which attract large numbers of spectators from all oyer
the world. Among better known Highland Games are the Braemar Gathering
on Deeside (traditionally attended by the Royal Family), the Argyllshire
Gathering at Oban, and the meeting at Aboyne.
The origins of badminton are not clear, but the Badminton Association of
England—which together with the Scottish and Welsh Badminton Unions
today organises the sport in Great Britain—was formed in 1893 and the first
tournament was promoted five years later. By I9t4 game had spread to
many other Commonwealth countries and it is now played throughout the
world (the national bodies in Great Britain were among the founder members
of the International Badminton Federation).
Basket ball is played in Britain both indoors and outdoors, primarily by men
and boys. There are about 1,000 senior clubs and the game is played in many
Billiards and
Snooker
Bowls
Boxing
Canoeing
SPORT 451
schools. The Amateur Basket Ball Association, organises championships and
is affiliated to the Federation Internationale de Basket Ball Amateur.
Although references to billiards in England survive from the sixteenth
century, the character of the present game was acquired at the end of the
seventeenth century .The Billiards and Snooker Control Council is the game’s
controlling body (for professionals and amateurs) and holds the copyright of
the rules. In the early 1930s snooker (a shorter game offering more diverse
incidents) began to acquire popularity, often at the expense of professional
billiards, and today, although both games are played widely at amateur levels,
snooker forms the essence of the professional game.
Bowls has been played in Britain since the thirteenth century. Nowadays the
game is regulated, as far as the English Bowling Association (EBA) is con¬
cerned, by the International Bowling Board (IBB), founded in 1905. The
Bowling Associations of Ireland, Scotland and Wales also play to the IBB’s
laws, but there are other bowling associations in England—the English Bowl¬
ing Federation, the Crown Green Association and the English Women’s
Bowling Association—which are not under the IBB’s control. During the
summer bowls is played on bowling greens in the open; in winter it is played
on indoor greens, which are increasing in number. At one time regarded as a
pastime for the elderly, the game is now played by people of all ages. Over
2,620 bowling clubs are affiliated to the EBA. International, inter-county
matches, and national championship competitions of singles, pairs, triples and
fours are played. The World Bowls Championships for 1972 are to be played
at Worthing, Sussex.
Boxing as an English sport probably originated in Saxon times. Its modern
form, which has been adopted in many overseas countries, dates from 1865
when the Marquess of Queensberry drew up a set of rules eliminating much of
the brutality that had characterised prize fighting, and making skill the basis
of the sport. Nowadays, many boys learn to box at school and in boys’ clubs,
and there are various amateur boxing competitions carried out according to
the rules of the Amateur Boxing Association, which controls all amateur
boxing, including schoolboy boxing, club and association boxing, and boxing
in the three Services.
Professional boxing is covered by the British Boxing Board of Control,
founded in 1929. The Board’s strict medical regulations provide for an
examination of boxers before and after each contest, an extensive annual
medical examination and the appointment of inspectors to ensure that the
regulations are observed and to guard against over-matching and exploitation.
Championships at fixed weights have been the rule in boxing contests since
the presentation of the Championship Challenge Belts by the late Lord
Lonsdale in 1909. Amateur championships are decided at 11 weights: light
flyweight, flyweight, bantamweight, featherweight, lightweight, light welter¬
weight, welterweight, light middleweight, middleweight, light heavyweight
and heavyweight. In professional boxing there are no light welterweight or
light middleweight categories.
Canoeing, the world’s oldest type of boating, dates as a modern sport from the
mid-nineteenth century; a canoe club was founded in 1866 and in 1867 a canoe
regatta was held on the Thames. The International Canoe Federation was
formed in 1946; in Great Britain, the British Canoe Union (a member of the
452
Cricket
Croquet
Cycling
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Federation and established in 1936) promotes canoeing in all its forms and
assists the interests of its members. There are about 400 canoe clubs in
Britain, with about 100,000 devotees.
Cricket, sometimes called the English national game, has uncertain origins,
but it is known to have been played at Guildford Grammar School by 1550,
and after the Restoration (of 1660) it became fashionable with the nobility,
who competed with each other to sponsor matches for very large sums of
money. Among the many clubs founded in the eighteenth century was the
famous Hambledon Club in Hampshire, whose members supported the most
brilliant players of the day. Towards the end of the century the Marylebone
Cricket Club (MCC) was founded in London and reframed the ‘Laws of
Cricket’. It has since had considerable influence on the development of the
game in Britain. Its headquarters, Lord’s (named after Thomas Lord, who
rented the first headquarters), are at a cricket ground in London which was
opened in 1814. Nowadays, cricket in Britain is governed by the Cricket
Council, made up of representatives of the MCC, the Test and County
Cricket Board (representing first-class cricket) and the National Cricket
Association (representing club and junior cricket). The MCC retains world¬
wide responsibility for the laws of cricket.
The game is played in schools and universities, and most towns and villages
(as well as industrial sports clubs) have teams which play at least one match a
week from late April to early September. In the London area a large number
of pitches are provided by local authorities to augment those leased or owned
by clubs. In the Midlands and the north of England there is a network of
League cricket, contested by teams of Saturday afternoon players reinforced
by professionals, often distinguished overseas players.
The focus of the season centres on a series of ‘Test matches’ played between
England and a touring team from overseas (or sometimes two teams). The
first of these matches was played in Melbourne between England and Australia
in 1877. Since then international tours have taken place regularly between
countries of Test status, which now number seven. The matches last 30 playing
hours spread over five days and arouse great popular interest.
In addition to the Test matches, a First Class County Championship,
decided on a points system, is contested by 17 counties, each playing 24
three-day matches. The counties not deemed first-class and second elevens of
the first-class counties play in a Minor Counties Championship. The univer¬
sity teams of Oxford and Cambridge rank as first-class and play an annual
match at Lord’s. The counties also compete in a knock-out competition with
one-day matches and in a Sunday League.
Cricket is also played by women and girls in Britain, the governing body
being the Women’s Cricket Association.
Croquet originated in Britain in the middle of the nineteenth century and has
developed into a game played by people of all ages on the lawns of local
croquet clubs and private gardens. Some 70 clubs are registered with the
Croquet Association—formed in 1896—which promotes the sport in Britain
and maintains links with croquet associations in other countries.
In Britain the internationally recognised body for cycle racing is the British
Cycling Federation which has 692 affiliated clubs and provides third party
insurance and a legal aid service for its members. It controls track and massed
start road racing in Britain, and is concerned with the cycling events in the
SPORT
Fencing
Field Sports
Hunting
Game Shooting
453
Olympic and Commonwealth Games and the annual world championship.
Time trials are organised by the Road Time Trials Council.
Touring by bicycle is catered for by both the British Cycling Federation
and the Cyclists’ Touring Club (CTC), the oldest touring club in the world,
with a membership of some 20,000. CTC representatives in all parts of Britain
offer help to touring cyclists; its 50 district associations arrange holiday and
week-end tours and competitions, rallies and rides of all kinds; and its travel
department provides touring itineraries for members both at home and over¬
seas, and maintains a full travel agency service. Other benefits include a tour¬
ing magazine, a member’s handbook, legal aid and third party insurance.
Fencing as a sport has made considerable progress throughout Britain during
the past 25 years. The Amateur Fencing Association (founded in 1902) has
over 700 clubs, and many classes are organised and financed by local authori¬
ties. Fencing is also practised in most universities and an increasing number of
schools. Under the auspices of the Association, national championships and
international tournaments are held every year.
The most popular field sports—hunting, game shooting and fishing—have a
long history, and still play a considerable part in the life of the countryside.
The British Field Sports Society looks after their interests.
In Britain hunting means primarily fox hunting on horseback with a pack of
hounds; but it also includes stag hunting (in Devon and Somerset), hunting
the hare, either on foot with beagles or with harriers when the followers are
mounted, and otter hunting along river banks. Hunting depends not on right
but on the goodwill of small landowners and farmers, most of whom support
their local hunt by allowing it to ride over their property.
Fox hunting orginated some 200 years ago. Originally a sport mainly for
the landed gentry and local farmers, it has gradually widened its appeal, in
spite of the fact that it is an expensive pastime for those who ride to hounds.
The sport is not without its critics, but an ever larger number of people,
including many townsmen, take a keen interest in it. Most hunts meet two
or three times a week and an estimated 25,000 to 30,000 people ride to hounds
weekly, many others following in cars, on bicycles or on foot. The fox hunting
season starts in early November and lasts until April; it is preceded by cub
hunting (the hunting of young foxes) when young hounds are trained. At the
end of the season most hunts organise steeplechases (point-to-points) which
attract large crowds. There are over 200 packs of hounds in England and
Wales, 17 in Northern Ireland, and 10 in Scotland. Hunts are financed mainly
by the subscriptions of their members (£15 or less to £50 or more), by ‘caps’
(contributions paid by non-subscribers), and by the proceeds of such annual
events as the point-to-points and the hunt ball. Sometimes the Master of
Fox-hounds, who is in charge of the hunt, bears a proportion of the cost.
Game shooting as an organised country sport may be said to date from the
early part of the nineteenth century; nowadays, game consists mainly of
grouse, partridge, pheasant, snipe and woodcock. There is virtually no free
shooting in Britain. A certificate (for which a fee is payable) must be obtained
from the local police by anyone who possesses, purchases or acquires a shot
gun1; and it is necessary to have a licence to kill game. Nearly all game birds
1 A shot gun is defined in the Criminal Justice Act 1967 as ‘a smooth bore gun having
a barrel not less than 24 inches in length, not being an air-gun’. Shot guns are subject to
control under the Firearms Acts 1937 and 1965.
BRITAIN 1972: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
are found on privately owned land, shot over either by the owner and his
friends or by syndicates which have leased the shooting rights. However, in
some parts of the more remote countryside, rough shooting may be enjoyed in
a less formal way. Much of the country’s wild-fowling is controlled by the
Wildfowling Association of Great Britain and Ireland, through its numerous
clubs. The Game Conservancy, formed by landowners, farmers and others
interested in game conservation and research, collects information on a
national scale and studies factors controlling game population.
Grouse, partridge, pheasant and certain other birds are protected by law
during a ‘close season’ and allowed to breed in security, often under the care of
privately employed gamekeepers on numerous estates. Grouse shooting takes
place mostly in Scotland, northern England and north Wales; partridge and
pheasant shooting in nearly all regions of Great Britain, the former mainly
over farm land, and the latter in or near woodland; and wildfowling on the
marshes and fenlands of the coastal areas.
Deer stalking is mainly a sport of the Highlands of Scotland. The deer are
preserved in privately owned ‘deer forests’, covering from 9,000 to over
30,000 acres (3,642 to 12,140 hectares), and are also protected during close
seasons.
Fishing is the most popular of the country sports, being within the reach
of everyone in some form or another (from the small boy with his hook and
line to the experienced fly-fisherman). There are some 3 million anglers
in Britain. The outstanding forms of the sport are salmon and trout fishing.
There are trout streams in most parts of the country, and in Scotland many
hundreds of lochs also provide good sport. Salmon fishing may be enjoyed in
many regions of Britain, but the best salmon rivers are in Scotland. In England
and Wales the most widely practised form of fishing is for coarse fish such as
pike, perch, carp, roach, dace, tench, chub and bream, and the National
Federation of Anglers (NFA) has some 450,000 members in over 3,000 clubs
comprising 160 associations. Match angling—competitive fishing for coarse
fish by weight—is a feature of the many angling clubs affiliated to the NFA,
particularly in the Midlands and north of England. A national angling cham¬
pionship, composed of teams of 12 anglers, is organised annually by the NFA,
and the NFA enters a team in the International Angling Competition. As a
rule, freshwater fishing has to be paid for and local enquiries made about any
permit or licence required. Most coarse fishing is let to angling clubs; trout
and salmon fishermen either rent a stretch of river, join a club, stay at an hotel
with its own fishing rights, or pay for the right to fish by the day, week or
month. The cost of salmon fishing is often high.
Coastal fishing and deep-sea fishing for shark and tunny are growing in
popularity and are free to all (except for salmon and sea trout fishing, which is
by licence only).
The National Anglers’ Council is a central consultative and co-ordinating
body, representative of the various national bodies concerned with angling.
Golf originated in Scotland, where for centuries it has borne the title of the
Royal and Ancient Game, but it did not become really well known in other
parts of Britain until towards the end of the nineteenth century. Since then,
however, it has gained steadily in popularity (particularly since the mid-
1950s); nowadays there are golf courses in the vicinity of many towns and
villages in all parts of Britain—some owned by local authorities, but the
majority owned by golf clubs—and the question of the game’s large land

Hockey
Judo
